If that ere true the murderer must have dropped some part of his dress, presumably his overcoat, in his flight, and must hav had the hardihood to return and to carry it away at the instant when the son was kneeling with his back turned not  dozen paces off. And now?" He raised his hand.

"Cerainly."

"You ddn't know this dead man, McCarthy. He was a devil incarnate. I tell you that. God keep you out of the clutches of suh a man as he. His grip has been upon me these twenty years, and he has blasted my life. I'll tell you first how I cme to be in his power.

"It was in the early '60's at the diggings. I was a young chap then, hot-blooded and recklss, ready to turn my hand at anything; I got among bad companions, took to drink, had no luck with my claim, took tothe bush, and in a word became what you would call over here a highway robber. There were six of us, and we had a wid, free life of it, sticking up a station from time to time, or stopping the wagons on the road to the diggings. Blak Jack of Ballarat was the name I went under, and our party is still remembered in the colony as the Ballarat Gang.
"One day a gold convoy came down from Ballarat to Melbourne, and we lay in wait for it and attacked it. There weresix troopers and six of us, so it was a close thing, but we emptied four of their saddles at the first volley. Threeof our boys were killed, however, before we got the swag. I put my pistol to the head of the wagon-driver, who was tis very man McCarthy. I wish to the Lord that I had shot him then, but I spared him, though I saw his wicked little yes fixed on my face, as though to remember every feature. We got away with the gold, became wealthy men, and made or way over to England without being suspected. There I parted from my old pals and determined to settle down to a quet and respectable life. I bought this estate, which chanced to be in the market, and I set myself to do a little god with my money, to make up for the way in which I had earned it. I married, too, and though my wife died young she eft me my dear little Alice. Even when she was just a baby her wee hand seemed to lead me down the right path as noting else had ever done. In a word, I turned over a new leaf and did my best to make up for the past. All was going wll when McCarthy laid his grip upon me.

"I had gone up to town about an investment, and I met him in Regent Stree with hardly a coat to his back or a boot to his foot.

" 'Here we are, Jack,' says he, touching me on the arm; 'w'll be as good as a family to you. There's two of us, me and my son, and you can have the keeping of us. If you don'--it's a fine, law-abiding country is England, and there's always a policeman within hail.'

"Well, down they cameto the west country, there was no shaking them off, and there they have lived rent free on my best land ever since. here was no rest for me, no peace, no forgetfulness; turn where I would, there was his cunning, grinning face at my lbow. It grew worse as Alice grew up, for he soon saw I was more afraid of her knowing my past than of the police. Watever he wanted he must have, and whatever it was I gave him without question, land, money, houses, until at last h asked a thing which I could not give. He asked for Alice.

"His son, you see, had grown up, and so had my girl, ad as I was known to be in weak health, it seemed a fine stroke to him that his lad should step into the whole propery. But there I was firm. I would not have his cursed stock mixed with mine; not that I had any dislike to the lad, bt his blood was in him, and that was enough. I stood firm. McCarthy threatened. I braved him to do his worst. We wer to meet at the pool midway between our houses to talk it over.

"When I went down there I found him talking with is son, so I smoked a cigar and waited behind a tree until he should be alone. But as I listened to his talk all tha was black and bitter in me seemed to come uppermost. He was urging his son to marry my daughter with as little regad for what she might think as if she were a slut from off the streets. It drove me mad to think that I and all that  held most dear should be in the power of such a man as this. Could I not snap the bond? I was already a dying and adesperate man. Though clear of mind and fairly strong of limb, I knew that my own fate was sealed. But my memory andmy girl! Both could be saved if I could but silence that foul tongue. I did it, Mr. Holmes. I would do it again. Deely as I have sinned, I have led a life of martyrdom to atone for it. But that my girl should be entangled in the sam meshes which held me was more than I could suffer. I struck him down with no more compunction than if he had been sme foul and venomous beast. His cry brought back his son; but I had gained the cover of the wood, though I was force to go back to fetch the cloak which I had dropped in my flight. That is the true story, gentlemen, of all that occured."

"Well, it is not for me to judge you," said Holmes as the old man signed the statement which had been drawnout. "I pray that we may never be exposed to such a temptation."

"I pray not, sir. And what do you intend to do?"

"In view of your health, nothing. You are yourself aware that you will soon have to answer for your deed at a higer court than the Assizes. I will keep your confession, and if McCarthy is condemned I shall be forced to use it. Ifnot, it shall never be seen by mortal eye; and your secret, whether you be alive or dead, shall be safe with us."
"Farewell, then," said the old man solemnly. "Your own deathbeds, when they come, will be the easier for the thoughtof the peace which you have given to mine." Tottering and shaking in all his giant frame, he stumbled slowly from th room.

"God help us!" said Holmes after a long silence. "Why does fate play such tricks with poor, helpless worms I never hear of such a case as this that I do not think of Baxter's words, and say, 'There, but for the grace of Go, goes Sherlock Holmes.' "

James McCarthy was acquitted at the Assizes on the strength of a number of objections hich had been drawn out by Holmes and submitted to the defending counsel. Old Turner lived for seven months after ou interview, but he is now dead; and there is every prospect that the son and daughter may come to live happily togeter in ignorance of the black cloud which rests upon their past.

ADVENTURE  V.  THE FIVE ORANGE PIPS


When I gance over my notes and records of the Sherlock Holmes cases between the years '82 and '90, I am faced by so many whih present strange and interesting features that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave. Som, however, have already gained publicity through the papers, and others have not offered a field for those peculiar ualities which my friend possessed in so high a degree, and which it is the object of these papers to illustrate. Soe, too, have baffled his analytical skill, and would be, as narratives, beginnings without an ending, while others hve been but partially cleared up, and have their explanations founded rather upon conjecture and surmise than on tha absolute logical proof which was so dear to him. There is, however, one of these last which was so remarkable in it details and so startling in its results that I am tempted to give some account of it in spite of the fact that ther are points in connection with it which never have been, and probably never will be, entirely cleared up.

The yea '87 furnished us with a long series of cases of greater or less interest, of which I retain the records. Among my hadings under this one twelve months I find an account of the adventure of the Paradol Chamber, of the Amateur Mendicnt Society, who held a luxurious club in the lower vault of a furniture warehouse, of the facts connected with the lss of the British barque Sophy Anderson, of the singular adventures of the Grice Patersons in the island of Uffa, an finally of the Camberwell poisoning case. In the latter, as may be remembered, Sherlock Holmes was able, by windingup the dead man's watch, to prove that it had been wound up two hours before, and that therefore the deceased had goe to bed within that time--a deduction which was of the greatest importance in clearing up the case. All these I maysketch out at some future date, but none of them present such singular features as the strange train of circumstance which I have now taken up my pen to describe.

It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales ad set in with exceptional violence. All day the wind had screamed and the rain had beaten against the windows, so tat even here in the heart of great, hand-made London we were forced to raise our minds for the instant from the routne of life and to recognise the presence of those great elemental forces which shriek at mankind through the bars ofhis civilisation, like untamed beasts in a cage. As evening drew in, the storm grew higher and louder, and the wind ried and sobbed like a child in the chimney. Sherlock Holmes sat moodily at one side of the fireplace cross-indexinghis records of crime, while I at the other was deep in one of Clark Russell's fine sea-stories until the howl of thegale from without seemed to blend with the text, and the splash of the rain to lengthen out into the long swash of te sea waves. My wife was on a visit to her mother's, and for a few days I was a dweller once more in my old quartersat Baker Street.

"Why," said I, glancing up at my companion, "that was surely the bell. Who could come to-night? ome friend of yours, perhaps?"

"Except yourself I have none," he answered. "I do not encourage visitors."

"A cient, then?"

"If so, it is a serious case. Nothing less would bring a man out on such a day and at such an hour. ut I take it that it is more likely to be some crony of the landlady's."

Sherlock Holmes was wrong in his conjectre, however, for there came a step in the passage and a tapping at the door. He stretched out his long arm to turn te lamp away from himself and towards the vacant chair upon which a newcomer must sit.

"Come in!" said he.

The an who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refineent and delicacy in his bearing. The streaming umbrella which he held in his hand, and his long shining waterproof tld of the fierce weather through which he had come. He looked about him anxiously in the glare of the lamp, and I cold see that his face was pale and his eyes heavy, like those of a man who is weighed down with some great anxiety.

"I owe you an apology," he said, raising his golden pince-nez to his eyes. "I trust that I am not intruding. I fearthat I have brought some traces of the storm and rain into your snug chamber."

"My uncle Elias emigrated to America when he was a young man and became a planter in Flrida, where he was reported to have done very well. At the time of the war he fought in Jackson's army, and afterwars under Hood, where he rose to be a colonel. When Lee laid down his arms my uncle returned to his plantation, where e remained for three or four years. About 1869 or 1870 he came back to Europe and took a small estate in Sussex, nea Horsham. He had made a very considerable fortune in the States, and his reason for leaving them was his aversion tothe negroes, and his dislike of the Republican policy in extending the franchise to them. He was a singular man, fiece and quick-tempered, very foul-mouthed when he was angry, and of a most retiring disposition. During all the yearsthat he lived at Horsham, I doubt if ever he set foot in the town. "He didn't mind me; in fact, he took a fancy to me, for at the time when he saw me first I was  youngster of twelve or so. This would be in the year 1878, after he had been eight or nine years in England. He beged my father to let me live with him and he was very kind to me in his way. When he was sober he used to be fond of laying backgammon and draughts with me, and he would make me his representative both with the servants and with the radespeople, so that by the time that I was sixteen I was quite master of the house. I kept all the keys and could g where I liked and do what I liked, so long as I did not disturb him in his privacy. With a boy's curiosity I have peeped through the keyhole, but I ws never able to see more than such a collection of old trunks and bundles as would be expected in such a room.

"Oe day--it was in March, 1883--a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel's plate. It ws not a common thing for him to receive letters, for his bills were all paid in ready money, and he had no friends o any sort. 'From India!' said he as he took it up, 'Pondicherry postmark! K.!' he shrieked, and hen, 'My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!'

Sherlock Holmes closed his eyes and placed his elbows upon the arms of his chair, with his finger-tips together. The ideal reasoner," he remarked, "would, when he had once been shown a single fact in all its bearings, deduce fromit not only all the chain of events which led up to it but also all the results which would follow from it. As Cuvie could correctly describe a whole animal by the contemplation of a single bone, so the observer who has thoroughly uderstood one link in a series of incidents should be able to accurately state all the other ones, both before and afer. We have not yet grasped the results which the reason alone can attain to. Problems may be solved in the study whch have baffled all those who have sought a solution by the aid of their senses. To carry the art, however, to its hghest pitch, it is necessary that the reasoner should be able to utilise all the facts which have come to his knowlege; and this in itself implies, as you will readily see, a possession of all knowledge, which, even in these days offree education and encyclopaedias, is a somewhat rare accomplishment. In the first place, we may start with a strong presumption that Colonel Openshaw had some very strong eason for leaving America. Men at his time of life do not change all their habits and exchange willingly the charmin climate of Florida for the lonely life of an English provincial town. His extreme love of solitude in England suggets the idea that he was in fear of someone or something, so we may assume as a working hypothesis that it was fear o someone or something which drove him from America. " 'Ku Klux Klan. A name derived from the fanciful resemblace to the sound produced by cocking a rifle. This terrible secret society was formed by some ex-Confederate soldiersin the Southern states after the Civil War, and it rapidly formed local branches in different parts of the country, otably in Tennessee, Louisiana, the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida. Its power was used for political purposes, prinipally for the terrorising of the negro voters and the murdering and driving from the country of those who were oppoed to its views. Its outrages were usually preceded by a warning sent to the marked man in some fantastic but generaly recognised shape--a sprig of oak-leaves in some parts, melon seeds or orange pips in others. On receiving this th victim might either openly abjure his former ways, or might fly from the country. If he braved the matter out, deat would unfailingly come upon him, and usually in some strange and unforeseen manner. So perfect was the organisationof the society, and so systematic its methods, that there is hardly a case upon record where any man succeeded in brving it with impunity, or in which any of its outrages were traced home to the perpetrators. For some years the orgaisation flourished in spite of the efforts of the United States government and of the better classes of the communit in the South. Eventually, in the year 1869, the movement rather suddenly collapsed, although there have been sporadc outbreaks of the same sort since that date.'

He walked up to the sideboard, and earing a piece from the loaf he devoured it voraciously, washing it down with a long draught of water.

"You are hngry," I remarked.

"Starving. It had escaped my memory. I have had nothing since breakfast."

"Nothing?"

"No a bite. I had no time to think of it."

"And how have you succeeded?"

"Well."

"You have a clue?"

"I havethem in the hollow of my hand. Young Openshaw shall not long remain unavenged. Why, Watson, let us put their own devlish trade-mark upon them. It is well thought of!"

"What do you mean?"

He took an orange from the cupboard, an tearing it to pieces he squeezed out the pips upon the table. Of these he took five and thrust them into an envelop. On the inside of the flap he wrote "S. H. for J. O." Then he sealed it and addressed it to "Captain James Calhoun,Barque Lone Star, Savannah, Georgia."

"That will await him when he enters port," said he, chuckling. "It may givehim a sleepless night. He will find it as sure a precursor of his fate as Openshaw did before him."

"And who is tis Captain Calhoun?"

"The leader of the gang. I shall have the others, but he first."

"How did you trace it, ten?"

He took a large sheet of paper from his pocket, all covered with dates and names.

"I have spent the wholeday," said he, "over Lloyd's registers and files of the old papers, following the future career of every vessel whic touched at Pondicherry in January and February in '83. There were thirty-six ships of fair tonnage which were repored there during those months. Of these, one, the Lone Star, instantly attracted my attention, since, although it wasreported as having cleared from London, the name is that which is given to one of the states of the Union."

"Texa, I think."

"I was not and am not sure which; but I knew that the ship must have an American origin."

"What thn?"

"I searched the Dundee records, and when I found that the barque Lone Star was there in January, '85, my suspcion became a certainty. I then inquired as to the vessels which lay at present in the port of London."

"Yes?"
"The Lone Star had arrived here last week. I went down to the Albert Dock and found that she had been taken down theriver by the early tide this morning, homeward bound to Savannah. I wired to Gravesend and learned that she had passd some time ago, and as the wind is easterly I have no doubt that she is now past the Goodwins and not very far fromthe Isle of Wight."

"What will you do, then?"

"Oh, I have my hand upon him. He and the two mates, are as I lean, the only native-born Americans in the ship. The others are Finns and Germans. I know, also, that they were all thee away from the ship last night. I had it from the stevedore who has been loading their cargo. By the time that ther sailing-ship reaches Savannah the mail-boat will have carried this letter, and the cable will have informed the poice of Savannah that these three gentlemen are badly wanted here upon a charge of murder."

There is ever a flaw, owever, in the best laid of human plans, and the murderers of John Openshaw were never to receive the orange pips whch would show them that another, as cunning and as resolute as themselves, was upon their track. Very long and very evere were the equinoctial gales that year. We waited long for news of the Lone Star of Savannah, but none ever reaced us. We did at last hear that somewhere far out in the Atlantic a shattered stern-post of a boat was seen swingingin the trough of a wave, with the letters "L. S." carved upon it, and that is all which we shall ever know of the fae of the Lone Star.

ADVENTURE  VI.  THE MAN WITH THE TWISTED LIP


Isa Whitney, brother of the late Elias Whitey, D.D., Principal of the Theological College of St. George's, was much addicted to opium. The habit grew upon him,as I understand, from some foolish freak when he was at college; for having read De Quincey's description of his drems and sensations, he had drenched his tobacco with laudanum in an attempt to produce the same effects. He found, asso many more have done, that the practice is easier to attain than to get rid of, and for many years he continued tobe a slave to the drug, an object of mingled horror and pity to his friends and relatives. I can see him now, with yllow, pasty face, drooping lids, and pin-point pupils, all huddled in a chair, the wreck and ruin of a noble man.
One night--it was in June, '89--there came a ring to my bell, about the hour when a man gives his first yawn and glaces at the clock. I sat up in my chair, and my wife laid her needle-work down in her lap and made a little face of dsappointment.

"A patient!" said she. "You'll have to go out."

I groaned, for I was newly come back from a wear day.

We heard the door open, a few hurried words, and then quick steps upon the linoleum. Our own door flew open and a lady, clad in some dark-coloured stuff, with a black veil, entered the room.

"You will excuse my calling s late," she began, and then, suddenly losing her self-control, she ran forward, threw her arms about my wife's neck,and sobbed upon her shoulder. "Oh, I'm in such trouble!" she cried; "I do so want a little help."

"Why," said my ife, pulling up her veil, "it is Kate Whitney. How you startled me, Kate! I had not an idea who you were when you cae in."

"I didn't know what to do, so I came straight to you." That was always the way. Folk who were in grief cam to my wife like birds to a light-house.

"It was very sweet of you to come. Now, you must have some wine and wate, and sit here comfortably and tell us all about it. Or should you rather that I sent James off to bed?"

"Oh, no,no! I want the doctor's advice and help, too. It's about Isa. He has not been home for two days. I am so frightened bout him!"

It was not the first time that she had spoken to us of her husband's trouble, to me as a doctor, to mywife as an old friend and school companion. We soothed and comforted her by such words as we could find. Did she kno where her husband was? Was it possible that we could bring him back to her?

It seems that it was. She had the suest information that of late he had, when the fit was on him, made use of an opium den in the farthest east of the Cty. Hitherto his orgies had always been confined to one day, and he had come back, twitching and shattered, in the eening. But now the spell had been upon him eight-and-forty hours, and he lay there, doubtless among the dregs of thedocks, breathing in the poison or sleeping off the effects. There he was to be found, she was sure of it, at the Barof Gold, in Upper Swandam Lane. But what was she to do? How could she, a young and timid woman, make her way into suh a place and pluck her husband out from among the ruffians who surrounded him?

There was the case, and of coursethere was but one way out of it. Might I not escort her to this place? And then, as a second thought, why should shecome at all? I was Isa Whitney's medical adviser, and as such I had influence over him. I could manage it better if  were alone. I promised her on my word that I would send him home in a cab within two hours if he were indeed at theaddress which she had given me. And so in ten minutes I had left my armchair and cheery sitting-room behind me, and as speeding eastward in a hansom on a strange errand, as it seemed to me at the time, though the future only could sow how strange it was to be.

But there was no great difficulty in the first stage of my adventure. Upper Swandam ane is a vile alley lurking behind the high wharves which line the north side of the river to the east of London Brige. Between a slop-shop and a gin-shop, approached by a steep flight of steps leading down to a black gap like the muth of a cave, I found the den of which I was in search. Ordering my cab to wait, I passed down the steps, worn hollw in the centre by the ceaseless tread of drunken feet; and by the light of a flickering oil-lamp above the door I fund the latch and made my way into a long, low room, thick and heavy with the brown opium smoke, and terraced with woden berths, like the forecastle of an emigrant ship.

Through the gloom one could dimly catch a glimpse of bodieslying in strange fantastic poses, bowed shoulders, bent knees, heads thrown back, and chins pointing upward, with hee and there a dark, lack-lustre eye turned upon the newcomer. Out of the black shadows there glimmered little red cicles of light, now bright, now faint, as the burning poison waxed or waned in the bowls of the metal pipes. The mostlay silent, but some muttered to themselves, and others talked together in a strange, low, monotonous voice, their cnversation coming in gushes, and then suddenly tailing off into silence, each mumbling out his own thoughts and payig little heed to the words of his neighbour. At the farther end was a small brazier of burning charcoal, beside whic on a three-legged wooden stool there sat a tall, thin old man, with his jaw resting upon his two fists, and his elbws upon his knees, staring into the fire.

As I entered, a sallow Malay attendant had hurried up with a pipe for m and a supply of the drug, beckoning me to an empty berth.

"Thank you. I have not come to stay," said I. "There i a friend of mine here, Mr. Isa Whitney, and I wish to speak with him."

There was a movement and an exclamation fom my right, and peering through the gloom, I saw Whitney, pale, haggard, and unkempt, staring out at me.

"My God It's Watson," said he. He was in a pitiable state of reaction, with every nerve in a twitter. "I say, Watson, what 'clock is it?"

"Nearly eleven."

"Yes, I have one waiting."

"Then I shall go in it. But I must owe something. Find wat I owe, Watson. I am all off colour. I can do nothing for myself."

"Ay, bodies, Watson. We should be rich men if we had $1000 for every poor devil who has been done to death in that dn. "The Cedars?"

Neville St. Clair went into town rather earlier than usual, remarking before he started that he had two importantcommissions to perform, and that he would bring his little boy home a box of bricks. "You are thefirst who have ever heard my story. My father was a schoolmaster in Chesterfield, where I received an excellent eduction. "I wrote my articlesand thought little more of the matter until, some time later, I backed a bill for a friend and had a writ served upo me for $25. I begged a fortnight's grac from the creditor, asked for a holiday from my employers, and spent the time in begging in the City under my disguie. In ten days I had the money and had paid the debt.

"Well, you can imagine how hard it was to settle down to aruous work at $2 a week when I knew that I could earn as much in a day by smearing my face with a little paint, layin my cap on the ground, and sitting still. It was a long fight between my pride and the money, but the dollars won atlast, and I threw up reporting and sat day after day in the corner which I had first chosen, inspiring pity by my ghstly face and filling my pockets with coppers. Only one man knew my secret. He was the keeper of a low den in which  used to lodge in Swandam Lane, where I could every morning emerge as a squalid beggar and in the evenings transformmyself into a well-dressed man about town. This fellow, a Lascar, was well paid by me for his rooms, so that I knew hat my secret was safe in his possession.

"Well, very soon I found that I was saving considerable sums of money.  do not mean that any beggar in the streets of London could earn $700 a year--which is less than my average takings-but I had exceptional advantages in my power of making up, and also in a facility of repartee, which improved by pratice and made me quite a recognised character in the City. All day a stream of pennies, varied by silver, poured in pon me, and it was a very bad day in which I failed to take $2.

"As I grew richer I grew more ambitious, took a huse in the country, and eventually married, without anyone having a suspicion as to my real occupation. My dear wifeknew that I had business in the City. She little knew what.

"Last Monday I had finished for the day and was dressng in my room above the opium den when I looked out of my window and saw, to my horror and astonishment, that my wif was standing in the street, with her eyes fixed full upon me. "That note only reached her yesterday," said Holmes.

"Good God! What a week she must have spent"

"Many times; but what was a fine to me?"

"I reached this one," said my friend, "b sitting upon five pillows and consuming an ounce of shag. I think, Watson, that if we drive to Baker Street we shal just be in time for breakfast."

VII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE BLUE CARBUNCLE


I had called upon my friend Sherlck Holmes upon the second morning after Christmas, with the intention of wishing him the compliments of the season. e was lounging upon the sofa in a purple dressing-gown, a pipe-rack within his reach upon the right, and a pile of cumpled morning papers, evidently newly studied, near at hand. Beside the couch was a wooden chair, and on the angle f the back hung a very seedy and disreputable hard-felt hat, much the worse for wear, and cracked in several places.A lens and a forceps lying upon the seat of the chair suggested that the hat had been suspended in this manner for te purpose of examination.

"You are engaged," said I; "perhaps I interrupt you."

"Not at all. I am glad to havea friend with whom I can discuss my results. The matter is a perfectly trivial one"--he jerked his thumb in the diretion of the old hat--"but there are points in connection with it which are not entirely devoid of interest and even f instruction."

I seated myself in his armchair and warmed my hands before his crackling fire, for a sharp frost ad set in, and the windows were thick with the ice crystals. "I suppose," I remarked, "that, homely as it looks, thi thing has some deadly story linked on to it--that it is the clue which will guide you in the solution of some mystey and the punishment of some crime."

"Only one of those whimscal little incidents which will happen when you have four million human beings all jostling each other within the spce of a few square miles. Amid the action and reaction of so dense a swarm of humanity, every possible combination o events may be expected to take place, and many a little problem will be presented which may be striking and bizarrewithout being criminal. We have already had experience of such."

"So much so," I remarked, "that of the last six ases which I have added to my notes, three have been entirely free of any legal crime."

"Yes."

"It is to him that this trophy belongs."

"It is his hat."
"No, no, he found it. Its owner is unknown. I beg that you will look upon it not as a battered billycock but as an itellectual problem. And, first, as to how it came here. It arrived upon Christmas morning, in company with a good fa goose, which is, I have no doubt, roasting at this moment in front of Peterson's fire. The facts are these: about fur o'clock on Christmas morning, Peterson, who, as you know, is a very honest fellow, was returning from some small ollification and was making his way homeward down Tottenham Court Road. In front of him he saw, in the gaslight, a tllish man, walking with a slight stagger, and carrying a white goose slung over his shoulder. As he reached the cornr of Goodge Street, a row broke out between this stranger and a little knot of roughs. Peterson had rushed forward to protect the stranger from his assailants; but the man, shocked at havingbroken the window, and seeing an official-looking person in uniform rushing towards him, dropped his goose, took to is heels, and vanished amid the labyrinth of small streets which lie at the back of Tottenham Court Road. The roughshad also fled at the appearance of Peterson, so that he was left in possession of the field of battle, and also of te spoils of victory in the shape of this battered hat and a most unimpeachable Christmas goose."

"My dear fellow, there lies the problem. It is true that 'For Mrs. Henry Baker' was prited upon a small card which was tied to the bird's left leg, and it is also true that the initials 'H. B.' are legibe upon the lining of this hat, but as there are some thousands of Bakers, and some hundreds of Henry Bakers in this ity of ours, it is not easy to restore lost property to any one of them."

"What, then, did Peterson do?"

"He bought round both hat and goose to me on Christmas morning, knowing that even the smallest problems are of interest t me. The goose we retained until this morning, when there were signs that, in spite of the slight frost, it would bewell that it should be eaten without unnecessary delay. Its finder has carried it off, therefore, to fulfil the ultiate destiny of a goose, while I continue to retain the hat of the unknown gentleman who lost his Christmas dinner."
"Did he not advertise?"

"No."

"Then, what clue could you have as to his identity?"

"Only as much as we ca deduce."

"From his hat?"

"Precisely."

"But you are joking. What can you gather from this old battered felt"

"Here is my lens. You know my methods. What can you gather yourself as to the individuality of the man who has orn this article?"

I took the tattered object in my hands and turned it over rather ruefully. It was a very ordinry black hat of the usual round shape, hard and much the worse for wear. The lining had been of red silk, but was a ood deal discoloured. There was no maker's name; but, as Holmes had remarked, the initials "H. B." were scrawled upo one side. It was pierced in the brim for a hat-securer, but the elastic was missing. For the rest, it was cracked, xceedingly dusty, and spotted in several places, although there seemed to have been some attempt to hide the discolored patches by smearing them with ink.

He picked it up and gazed at t in the peculiar introspective fashion which was characteristic of him. This may account also or the obvious fact that his wife has ceased to love him."

"My dear Holmes!"

"This hat is three yers old. These flat brims curled at the edge came in then. It is a hat of the very best quality. Look at the band of ibbed silk and the excellent lining. "Well, that is clear enough, certainly. But how abou the foresight and the moral retrogression?"

Sherlock Holmes laughed. "Here is the foresight," said he putting hi finger upon the little disc and loop of the hat-securer. "They are never sold upon hats. If this man ordered one, i is a sign of a certain amount of foresight, since he went out of his way to take this precaution against the wind. ut since we see that he has broken the elastic and has not troubled to replace it, it is obvious that he has less foesight now than formerly, which is a distinct proof of a weakening nature. On the other hand, he has endeavoured to onceal some of these stains upon the felt by daubing them with ink, which is a sign that he has not entirely lost hi self-respect."

"The further points, that he is middle-aged, that hishair is grizzled, that it has been recently cut, and that he uses lime-cream, are all to be gathered from a close exmination of the lower part of the lining. This dust, you will obsere, is not the gritty, grey dust of the street but the fluffy brown dust of the house, showing that it has been hung p indoors most of the time, while the marks of moisture upon the inside are proof positive that the wearer perspiredvery freely, and could therefore, hardly be in the best of training."

"This hat has not been brushed for weeks. When I see you, my dear Watson, with a week's accumulatio of dust upon your hat, and when your wife allows you to go out in such a state, I shall fear that you also have bee unfortunate enough to lose your wife's affection."

"What, sir! Oh, Heaven bless you!"

"No more words. Get out!

And no more words were needed. There was a rush, a clatter upon the stairs, the bang of a door, and the crisp ratle of running footfalls from the street.

"After all, Watson," said Holmes, reaching up his hand for his clay pip, "I am not retained by the police to supply their deficiencies. Chance has put inour way a most singular and whimsical problem, and its solution is its own reward. If you will have the goodness to ouch the bell, Doctor, we will begin another investigation, in which, also a bird will be the chief feature."

VII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE SPECKLED BAND


On glancing over my notes of the seventy odd cases in which I have duringthe last eight years studied the methods of my friend Sherlock Holmes, I find many tragic, some comic, a large numbe merely strange, but none commonplace; for, working as he did rather for the love of his art than for the acquiremen of wealth, he refused to associate himself with any investigation which did not tend towards the unusual, and even he fantastic. Of all these varied cases, however, I cannot recall any which presented more singular features than tht which was associated with the well-known Surrey family of the Roylotts of Stoke Moran. The events in question occured in the early days of my association with Holmes, when we were sharing rooms as bachelors in Baker Street. It is ossible that I might have placed them upon record before, but a promise of secrecy was made at the time, from which  have only been freed during the last month by the untimely death of the lady to whom the pledge was given. It is pehaps as well that the facts should now come to light, for I have reasons to know that there are widespread rumours a to the death of Dr. Grimesby Roylott which tend to make the matter even more terrible than the truth.

It was eary in April in the year '83 that I woke one morning to find Sherlock Holmes standing, fully dressed, by the side of m bed. He was a late riser, as a rule, and as the clock on the mantelpiece showed me that it was only a quarter-past even, I blinked up at him in some surprise, and perhaps just a little resentment, for I was myself regular in my habts.

Should it prove to be a interesting case, you would, I am sure, wish to follow it from the outset. I thought, at any rate, that I should cal you and give you the chance."

"My dear fellow, I would not miss it for anything."

I had no keener pleasure tan in following Holmes in his professional investigations, and in admiring the rapid deductions, as swift as intuitins, and yet always founded on a logical basis with which he unravelled the problems which were submitted to him. The lady gave a violent start and stared in bewildermnt at my companion.

There is no vehicle save a dog-cart which hrows up mud in that way, and then only when you sit on the left-hand side of the driver."

"Your sister is dead, then?"

"She died just two years ago, and it is of her death that I wish to speak to yo. You can understand that, living the life which I have described, we were little likely to see anyone of our own ag and position. My stepfather learned of the engagement whenmy sister returned and offered no objection to the marriage; but within a fortnight of the day which had been fixed or the wedding, the terrible event occurred which has deprived me of my only companion."

Sherlock Holmes had beenleaning back in his chair with his eyes closed and his head sunk in a cushion, but he half opened his lids now and ganced across at his visitor.

"The windows of the three rooms open out upon the lawn. That fatal night Dr. Roylott had gone to his rom early, though we knew that he had not retired to rest, for my sister was troubled by the smell of the strong Indin cigars which it was his custom to smoke. IX.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE ENGINEER'S THUMB


Of all the problems which have been submitted to my friend, Mr. Shrlock Holmes, for solution during the years of our intimacy, there were only two which I was the means of introducin to his notice--that of Mr. Hatherley's thumb, and that of Colonel Warburton's madness. Of these the latter may haveafforded a finer field for an acute and original observer, but the other was so strange in its inception and so dramtic in its details that it may be the more worthy of being placed upon record, even if it gave my friend fewer openigs for those deductive methods of reasoning by which he achieved such remarkable results. The story has, I believe, een told more than once in the newspapers, but, like all such narratives, its effect is much less striking when set orth en bloc in a single half-column of print than when the facts slowly evolve before your own eyes, and the myster clears gradually away as each new discovery furnishes a step which leads on to the complete truth. At the time the ircumstances made a deep impression upon me, and the lapse of two years has hardly served to weaken the effect.

I was in the summer of '89, not long after my marriage, that the events occurred which I am now about to summarise. Ihad returned to civil practice and had finally abandoned Holmes in his Baker Street rooms, although I continually viited him and occasionally even persuaded him to forgo his Bohemian habits so far as to come and visit us. My practic had steadily increased, and as I happened to live at no very great distance from Paddington Station, I got a few paients from among the officials. One of these, whom I had cured of a painful and lingering disease, was never weary o advertising my virtues and of endeavouring to send me on every sufferer over whom he might have any influence.

Oe morning, at a little before seven o'clock, I was awakened by the maid tapping at the door to announce that two menhad come from Paddington and were waiting in the consulting-room. I dressed hurriedly, for I knew by experience thatrailway cases were seldom trivial, and hastened downstairs. As I descended, my old ally, the guard, came out of the oom and closed the door tightly behind him.

"I've got him here," he whispered, jerking his thumb over his shoulde; "he's all right."

"What is it, then?" I asked, for his manner suggested that it was some strange creature whichhe had caged up in my room.

"It's a new patient," he whispered. "I thought I'd bring him round myself; then he coldn't slip away. There he is, all safe and sound. I must go now, Doctor; I have my dooties, just the same as you." Ad off he went, this trusty tout, without even giving me time to thank him.

I entered my consulting-room and founda gentleman seated by the table. He was quietly dressed in a suit of heather tweed with a soft cloth cap which he ha laid down upon my books. Round one of his hands he had a handkerchief wrapped, which was mottled all over with bloostains. He was young, not more than five-and-twenty, I should say, with a strong, masculine face; but he was exceedigly pale and gave me the impression of a man who was suffering from some strong agitation, which it took all his strngth of mind to control.

"I am sorry to knock you up so early, Doctor," said he, "but I have had a very serious acident during the night. I came in by train this morning, and on inquiring at Paddington as to where I might find a octor, a worthy fellow very kindly escorted me here. I gave the maid a card, but I see that she has left it upon theside-table."

I took it up and glanced at it. "Mr. Victor Hatherley, hydraulic engineer, 16A, Victoria Street (3rdfloor)." That was the name, style, and abode of my morning visitor. "I regret that I have kept you waiting," said I,sitting down in my library-chair. "You are fresh from a night journey, I understand, which is in itself a monotonousoccupation."

"Oh, my night could not be called monotonous," said he, and laughed. He laughed very heartily, with  high, ringing note, leaning back in his chair and shaking his sides. All my medical instincts rose up against that augh.

"Stop it!" I cried; "pull yourself together!" and I poured out some water from a caraffe.

It was useless however. He was off in one of those hysterical outbursts which come upon a strong nature when some great crisis is ver and gone. Presently he came to himself once more, very weary and pale-looking.

"I have been making a fool of yself," he gasped.

"Not at all. Drink this." I dashed some brandy into the water, and the colour began to come bak to his bloodless cheeks.

"That's better!" said he. "And now, Doctor, perhaps you would kindly attend to my thum, or rather to the place where my thumb used to be."

He unwound the handkerchief and held out his hand. It gave een my hardened nerves a shudder to look at it. There were four protruding fingers and a horrid red, spongy surface were the thumb should have been. It had been hacked or torn right out from the roots.

"Good heavens!" I cried, "ths is a terrible injury. It must have bled considerably."

"Yes, it did. I fainted when it was done, and I think tht I must have been senseless for a long time. When I came to I found that it was still bleeding, so I tied one end o my handkerchief very tightly round the wrist and braced it up with a twig."

"Excellent! You should have been a srgeon."

"It is a question of hydraulics, you see, and came within my own province."

"This has been done," saidI, examining the wound, "by a very heavy and sharp instrument."

"A thing like a cleaver," said he.

"An acciden, I presume?"

"By no means."

"What! a murderous attack?"

"Very murderous indeed."

"You horrify me."

Isponged the wound, cleaned it, dressed it, and finally covered it over with cotton wadding and carbolised bandages. e lay back without wincing, though he bit his lip from time to time.

"How is that?" I asked when I had finished.
"Capital! Between your brandy and your bandage, I feel a new man. I was very weak, but I have had a good deal to g through."

"Perhaps you had better not speak of the matter. It is evidently trying to your nerves."

I shall have to tell my tale to the police; but, between ourselves, if it were not for the convincing evidenc of this wound of mine, I should be surprised if they believed my statement, for it is a very extraordinary one, andI have not much in the way of proof with which to back it up; and, even if they believe me, the clues which I can gie them are so vague that it is a question whether justice will be done."

"Ha!" cried I, "if it is anything in thenature of a problem which you desire to see solved, I should strongly recommend you to come to my friend, Mr. Sherlok Holmes, before you go to the official police."

"Oh, I have heard of that fellow," answered my visitor, "and I sould be very glad if he would take the matter up, though of course I must use the official police as well. Would yougive me an introduction to him?"

"I'll do better. I'll take you round to him myself."

"I should be immensely oliged to you."

Sherlock Holmes was, as I expected,lounging about his sitting-room in his dressing-gown, reading the agony column of The Times and smoking his before-beakfast pipe, which was composed of all the plugs and dottles left from his smokes of the day before, all carefully ried and collected on the corner of the mantelpiece. Holmes sat in his big armchair with the weary, heavy-lidded expression which veiled his keenand eager nature, while I sat opposite to him, and we listened in silence to the strange story which our visitor detiled to us.

"You must know," said he, "that I am an orphan and a bachelor, residing alone in lodgings in London. y profession I am a hydraulic engineer, and I have had considerable experience of my work during the seven years tha I was apprenticed to Venner & Matheson, the well-known firm, of Greenwich. Two years ago, having served my time, an having also come into a fair sum of money through my poor father's death, I determined to start in business for myslf and took professional chambers in Victoria Street.

"I suppose that everyone finds his first independent start n business a dreary experience. To me it has been exceptionally so. During two years I have had three consultations nd one small job, and that is absolutely all that my profession has brought me. My gross takings amount to $27 10s. very day, from nine in the morning until four in the afternoon, I waited in my little den, until at last my heart bean to sink, and I came to believe that I should never have any practice at all.

"Yesterday, however, just as I wa thinking of leaving the office, my clerk entered to say there was a gentleman waiting who wished to see me upon busness. There can be no question that it was your oil-lamp which, whn it was crushed in the press, set fire to the wooden walls, though no doubt they were too excited in the chase afte you to observe it at the time. Now keep your eyes open in this crowd for your friends of last night, though I very uch fear that they are a good hundred miles off by now."

And Holmes' fears came to be realised, for from that dayto this no word has ever been heard either of the beautiful woman, the sinister German, or the morose Englishman. Ealy that morning a peasant had met a cart containing several people and some very bulky boxes driving rapidly in the irection of Reading, but there all traces of the fugitives disappeared, and even Holmes' ingenuity failed ever to dicover the least clue as to their whereabouts.

The firemen had been much perturbed at the strange arrangements whih they had found within, and still more so by discovering a newly severed human thumb upon a window-sill of the secod floor. About sunset, however, their efforts were at last successful, and they subdued the flames, but not before te roof had fallen in, and the whole place been reduced to such absolute ruin that, save some twisted cylinders and ion piping, not a trace remained of the machinery which had cost our unfortunate acquaintance so dearly. Large massesof nickel and of tin were discovered stored in an out-house, but no coins were to be found, which may have explainedthe presence of those bulky boxes which have been already referred to.

How our hydraulic engineer had been conveyd from the garden to the spot where he recovered his senses might have remained forever a mystery were it not for th soft mould, which told us a very plain tale. He had evidently been carried down by two persons, one of whom had remrkably small feet and the other unusually large ones. On the whole, it was most probable that the silent Englishman,being less bold or less murderous than his companion, had assisted the woman to bear the unconscious man out of the ay of danger.

"Well," said our engineer ruefully as we took our seats to return once more to London, "it has beena pretty business for me! I have lost my thumb and I have lost a fifty-guinea fee, and what have I gained?"

"Expeience," said Holmes, laughing. "Indirectly it may be of value, you know; you have only to put it into words to gain he reputation of being excellent company for the remainder of your existence."

X.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE NOBLE BACELOR


The Lord St. Simon marriage, and its curious termination, have long ceased to be a subject of interest in hose exalted circles in which the unfortunate bridegroom moves. Fresh scandals have eclipsed it, and their more piqunt details have drawn the gossips away from this four-year-old drama. As I have reason to believe, however, that thefull facts have never been revealed to the general public, and as my friend Sherlock Holmes had a considerable sharein clearing the matter up, I feel that no memoir of him would be complete without some little sketch of this remarkale episode.

It was a few weeks before my own marriage, during the days when I was still sharing rooms with Holmesin Baker Street, that he came home from an afternoon stroll to find a letter on the table waiting for him. I had remined indoors all day, for the weather had taken a sudden turn to rain, with high autumnal winds, and the Jezail bullt which I had brought back in one of my limbs as a relic of my Afghan campaign throbbed with dull persistence. "Here is a veryfashionable epistle," I remarked as he entered. "Your morning letters, if I remember right, were from a fish-monger nd a tide-waiter."

"Yes, my correspondence has certainly the charm of variety," he answered, smiling, "and the hubler are usually the more interesting. This looks like one of those unwelcome social summonses which call upon a maneither to be bored or to lie."

He broke the seal and glanced over the contents.

"Oh, come, it may prove to be omething of interest, after all."

"No, distinctly professional."

"One of the highest in England."

XI.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

I went and saw him. At first, of course, he denied everything. But when I gave him every particular that ha occurred, he tried to bluster and took down a life-preserver from the wall. I knew my man, however, and I clapped apistol to his head before he could strike. Then he became a little more reasonable. "A day which has saved England from a grea public scandal," said the banker, rising. "Sir, I cannot find words to thank you, but you shall not find me ungrateul for what you have done. "I think that we may safely say," returned Holmes, "tat she is wherever Sir George Burnwell is. It is equally certain, too, that whatever her sins are, they will soon reeive a more than sufficient punishment."

XII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES


"To the man who loves artfor its own sake," remarked Sherlock Holmes, tossing aside the advertisement sheet of the Daily Telegraph, "it is frquently in its least important and lowliest manifestations that the keenest pleasure is to be derived. The road is an important highway, and there are usually peole there. This man, however, was leaning against the railings which bordered our field and was looking earnestly up.I lowered my handkerchief and glanced at Mrs. Rucastle to find her eyes fixed upon me with a most searching gaze. Sh said nothing, but I am convinced that she had divined that I had a mirror in my hand and had seen what was behind m. She rose at once.

" 'Jephro,' said she, 'there is an impertinent fellow upon the road there who stares up at Mis Hunter.'

" 'No friend of yours, Miss Hunter?' he asked.

" 'No, I know no one in these parts.'

" 'Dear me!How very impertinent! Kindly turn round and motion to him to go away.'

" 'Surely it would be better to take no noice.'

" 'No, no, we should have him loitering here always. Kindly turn round and wave him away like that.'

"I id as I was told, and at the same instant Mrs. Rucastle drew down the blind. That was a week ago, and from that timeI have not sat again in the window, nor have I worn the blue dress, nor seen the man in the road."

"Pray continue" said Holmes. "Your narrative promises to be a most interesting one."

"You will find it rather disconnected, I far, and there may prove to be little relation between the different incidents of which I speak. On the very first da that I was at the Copper Beeches, Mr. Rucastle took me to a small outhouse which stands near the kitchen door. As w approached it I heard the sharp rattling of a chain, and the sound as of a large animal moving about.

" 'Look inhere!' said Mr. Rucastle, showing me a slit between two planks. 'Is he not a beauty?'

"I looked through and was cnscious of two glowing eyes, and of a vague figure huddled up in the darkness.

" 'Don't be frightened,' said my eployer, laughing at the start which I had given. 'It's only Carlo, my mastiff. I call him mine, but really old Tolle, my groom, is the only man who can do anything with him. We feed him once a day, and not too much then, so that he s always as keen as mustard. Toller lets him loose every night, and God help the trespasser whom he lays his fangs uon. For goodness' sake don't you ever on any pretext set your foot over the threshold at night, for it's as much as our life is worth.'

"The warning was no idle one, for two nights later I happened to look out of my bedroom windo about two o'clock in the morning. It was a beautiful moonlight night, and the lawn in front of the house was silverd over and almost as bright as day. I was standing, rapt in the peaceful beauty of the scene, when I was aware that omething was moving under the shadow of the copper beeches. As it emerged into the moonshine I saw what it was. It ws a giant dog, as large as a calf, tawny tinted, with hanging jowl, black muzzle, and huge projecting bones. It walkd slowly across the lawn and vanished into the shadow upon the other side. That dreadful sentinel sent a chill to myheart which I do not think that any burglar could have done.

"And now I have a very strange experience to tell yo. I had, as you know, cut off my hair in London, and I had placed it in a great coil at the bottom of my trunk. One vening, after the child was in bed, I began to amuse myself by examining the furniture of my room and by rearrangingmy own little things. There was an old chest of drawers in the room, the two upper ones empty and open, the lower on locked. I had filled the first two with my linen, and as I had still much to pack away I was naturally annoyed at nt having the use of the third drawer. It struck me that it might have been fastened by a mere oversight, so I took ot my bunch of keys and tried to open it. The very first key fitted to perfection, and I drew the drawer open. There as only one thing in it, but I am sure that you would never guess what it was. It was my coil of hair.

"I took itup and examined it. It was of the same peculiar tint, and the same thickness. But then the impossibility of the thin obtruded itself upon me. How could my hair have been locked in the drawer? With trembling hands I undid my trunk, trned out the contents, and drew from the bottom my own hair. I laid the two tresses together, and I assure you that hey were identical. Was it not extraordinary? Puzzle as I would, I could make nothing at all of what it meant. I retrned the strange hair to the drawer, and I said nothing of the matter to the Rucastles as I felt that I had put mysef in the wrong by opening a drawer which they had locked.

"I am naturally observant, as you may have remarked, Mr Holmes, and I soon had a pretty good plan of the whole house in my head. There was one wing, however, which appeare not to be inhabited at all. A door which faced that which led into the quarters of the Tollers opened into this suie, but it was invariably locked. One day, however, as I ascended the stair, I met Mr. Rucastle coming out through ths door, his keys in his hand, and a look on his face which made him a very different person to the round, jovial manto whom I was accustomed. His cheeks were red, his brow was all crinkled with anger, and the veins stood out at his emples with passion. He locked the door and hurried past me without a word or a look.

"This aroused my curiosity,so when I went out for a walk in the grounds with my charge, I strolled round to the side from which I could see thewindows of this part of the house. There were four of them in a row, three of which were simply dirty, while the fouth was shuttered up. They were evidently all deserted. As I strolled up and down, glancing at them occasionally, Mr.Rucastle came out to me, looking as merry and jovial as ever.

" 'Ah!' said he, 'you must not think me rude if I pssed you without a word, my dear young lady. I was preoccupied with business matters.'

"I assured him that I was ot offended. 'By the way,' said I, 'you seem to have quite a suite of spare rooms up there, and one of them has the hutters up.'

"He looked surprised and, as it seemed to me, a little startled at my remark.

" 'Photography is oe of my hobbies,' said he. 'I have made my dark room up there. But, dear me! what an observant young lady we have coe upon. Who would have believed it? Who would have ever believed it?' He spoke in a jesting tone, but there was no jst in his eyes as he looked at me. I read suspicion there and annoyance, but no jest.

"Well, Mr. Holmes, from themoment that I understood that there was something about that suite of rooms which I was not to know, I was all on fie to go over them. It was not mere curiosity, though I have my share of that. It was more a feeling of duty--a feelig that some good might come from my penetrating to this place. They talk of woman's instinct; perhaps it was woman'sinstinct which gave me that feeling. At any rate, it was there, and I was keenly on the lookout for any chance to pas the forbidden door.

"It was only yesterday that the chance came. I may tell you that, besides Mr. Rucastle, bot Toller and his wife find something to do in these deserted rooms, and I once saw him carrying a large black linen bg with him through the door. Recently he has been drinking hard, and yesterday evening he was very drunk; and when Icame upstairs there was the key in the door. I have no doubt at all that he had left it there. Mr. and Mrs. Rucastlewere both downstairs, and the child was with them, so that I had an admirable opportunity. I turned the key gently i the lock, opened the door, and slipped through.

"There was a little passage in front of me, unpapered and uncarpted, which turned at a right angle at the farther end. Round this corner were three doors in a line, the first and tird of which were open. They each led into an empty room, dusty and cheerless, with two windows in the one and one i the other, so thick with dirt that the evening light glimmered dimly through them. The centre door was closed, and cross the outside of it had been fastened one of the broad bars of an iron bed, padlocked at one end to a ring in th wall, and fastened at the other with stout cord. The door itself was locked as well, and the key was not there. Thi barricaded door corresponded clearly with the shuttered window outside, and yet I could see by the glimmer from benath it that the room was not in darkness. Evidently there was a skylight which let in light from above. As I stood i the passage gazing at the sinister door and wondering what secret it might veil, I suddenly heard the sound of step within the room and saw a shadow pass backward and forward against the little slit of dim light which shone out fro under the door. A mad, unreasoning terror rose up in me at the sight, Mr. Holmes. My overstrung nerves failed me sudenly, and I turned and ran--ran as though some dreadful hand were behind me clutching at the skirt of my dress. I rshed down the passage, through the door, and straight into the arms of Mr. Rucastle, who was waiting outside.

" 'o,' said he, smiling, 'it was you, then. I thought that it must be when I saw the door open.'

" 'Oh, I am so frigtened!' I panted.

" 'My dear young lady! my dear young lady!'--you cannot think how caressing and soothing his maner was--'and what has frightened you, my dear young lady?'

"But his voice was just a little too coaxing. He overid it. I was keenly on my guard against him.

" 'I was foolish enough to go into the empty wing,' I answered. 'Butit is so lonely and eerie in this dim light that I was frightened and ran out again. Oh, it is so dreadfully still i there!'

" 'Only that?' said he, looking at me keenly.

" 'Why, what did you think?' I asked.

" 'Why do you hink that I lock this door?'

" 'I am sure that I do not know.'

" 'It is to keep people out who have no busines there. Do you see?' He was still smiling in the most amiable manner.

" 'I am sure if I had known--'

" 'Well, hen, you know now. And if you ever put your foot over that threshold again'--here in an instant the smile hardened ito a grin of rage, and he glared down at me with the face of a demon--'I'll throw you to the mastiff.'

"I was so errified that I do not know what I did. I suppose that I must have rushed past him into my room. I remember nothing ntil I found myself lying on my bed trembling all over. Then I thought of you, Mr. Holmes. I could not live there loger without some advice. I was frightened of the house, of the man, of the woman, of the servants, even of the child They were all horrible to me. If I could only bring you down all would be well. Of course I might have fled from th house, but my curiosity was almost as strong as my fears. My mind was soon made up. I would send you a wire. I put n my hat and cloak, went down to the office, which is about half a mile from the house, and then returned, feeling vry much easier. A horrible doubt came into my mind as I approached the door lest the dog might be loose, but I rememered that Toller had drunk himself into a state of insensibility that evening, and I knew that he was the only one i the household who had any influence with the savage creature, or who would venture to set him free. I slipped in insafety and lay awake half the night in my joy at the thought of seeing you. I had no difficulty in getting leave to ome into Winchester this morning, but I must be back before three o'clock, for Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle are going on a isit, and will be away all the evening, so that I must look after the child. Now I have told you all my adventures, r. Holmes, and I should be very glad if you could tell me what it all means, and, above all, what I should do."

Hlmes and I had listened spellbound to this extraordinary story. My friend rose now and paced up and down the room, hs hands in his pockets, and an expression of the most profound gravity upon his face.

"Is Toller still drunk?" heasked.

"Yes. I heard his wife tell Mrs. Rucastle that she could do nothing with him."

"That is well. And the Rcastles go out to-night?"

"Yes."

"Is there a cellar with a good strong lock?"

"Yes, the wine-cellar."

"Yu seem to me to have acted all through this matter like a very brave and sensible girl, Miss Hunter. Do you think tht you could perform one more feat? I should not ask it of you if I did not think you a quite exceptional woman."

I will try. What is it?"

"We shall be at the Copper Beeches by seven o'clock, my friend and I. The Rucastles willbe gone by that time, and Toller will, we hope, be incapable. There only remains Mrs. Toller, who might give the alam. If you could send her into the cellar on some errand, and then turn the key upon her, you would facilitate matter immensely."

"I will do it."

"Excellent! We shall then look thoroughly into the affair. Of course there is onl one feasible explanation. You have been brought there to personate someone, and the real person is imprisoned in ths chamber. That is obvious. As to who this prisoner is, I have no doubt that it is the daughter, Miss Alice Rucastle if I remember right, who was said to have gone to America. You were chosen, doubtless, as resembling her in height,figure, and the colour of your hair. Hers had been cut off, very possibly in some illness through which she has passd, and so, of course, yours had to be sacrificed also. By a curious chance you came upon her tresses. The man in theroad was undoubtedly some friend of hers--possibly her fiance--and no doubt, as you wore the girl's dress and were s like her, he was convinced from your laughter, whenever he saw you, and afterwards from your gesture, that Miss Rucstle was perfectly happy, and that she no longer desired his attentions. The dog is let loose at night to prevent hi from endeavouring to communicate with her. So much is fairly clear. The most serious point in the case is the dispoition of the child."

"What on earth has that to do with it?" I ejaculated.

"My dear Watson, you as a medical mn are continually gaining light as to the tendencies of a child by the study of the parents. Don't you see that the onverse is equally valid. I have frequently gained my first real insight into the character of parents by studying teir children. This child's disposition is abnormally cruel, merely for cruelty's sake, and whether he derives this fom his smiling father, as I should suspect, or from his mother, it bodes evil for the poor girl who is in their powe."

"I am sure that you are right, Mr. Holmes," cried our client. "A thousand things come back to me which make mecertain that you have hit it. Oh, let us lose not an instant in bringing help to this poor creature."

"We must becircumspect, for we are dealing with a very cunning man. We can do nothing until seven o'clock. At that hour we shal be with you, and it will not be long before we solve the mystery."

We were as good as our word, for it was just even when we reached the Copper Beeches, having put up our trap at a wayside public-house. The group of trees, with heir dark leaves shining like burnished metal in the light of the setting sun, were sufficient to mark the house eve had Miss Hunter not been standing smiling on the door-step.

"Have you managed it?" asked Holmes.

A loud thuddng noise came from somewhere downstairs. "That is Mrs. Toller in the cellar," said she. "Her husband lies snoring onthe kitchen rug. Here are his keys, which are the duplicates of Mr. Rucastle's."

"You have done well indeed!" crid Holmes with enthusiasm. "Now lead the way, and we shall soon see the end of this black business."

We passed up he stair, unlocked the door, followed on down a passage, and found ourselves in front of the barricade which Miss Huter had described. Holmes cut the cord and removed the transverse bar. Then he tried the various keys in the lock, bt without success. No sound came from within, and at the silence Holmes' face clouded over.

"I trust that we are ot too late," said he. "I think, Miss Hunter, that we had better go in without you. Now, Watson, put your shoulder t it, and we shall see whether we cannot make our way in."

It was an old rickety door and gave at once before our nited strength. Together we rushed into the room. It was empty. There was no furniture save a little pallet bed, a sall table, and a basketful of linen. The skylight above was open, and the prisoner gone.

"There has been some vilainy here," said Holmes; "this beauty has guessed Miss Hunter's intentions and has carried his victim off."

"But ow?"

"Through the skylight. We shall soon see how he managed it." He swung himself up onto the roof. "Ah, yes," h cried, "here's the end of a long light ladder against the eaves. That is how he did it."

"But it is impossible,"said Miss Hunter; "the ladder was not there when the Rucastles went away."

"He has come back and done it. I tell ou that he is a clever and dangerous man. I should not be very much surprised if this were he whose step I hear now pon the stair. I think, Watson, that it would be as well for you to have your pistol ready."

The words were hardl out of his mouth before a man appeared at the door of the room, a very fat and burly man, with a heavy stick in hishand. Miss Hunter screamed and shrunk against the wall at the sight of him, but Sherlock Holmes sprang forward and cnfronted him.

"You villain!" said he, "where's your daughter?"

The fat man cast his eyes round, and then up atthe open skylight.

"It is for me to ask you that," he shrieked, "you thieves! Spies and thieves! I have caught yo, have I? You are in my power. I'll serve you!" He turned and clattered down the stairs as hard as he could go.

"e's gone for the dog!" cried Miss Hunter.

"I have my revolver," said I.

"Better close the front door," cried Hlmes, and we all rushed down the stairs together. We had hardly reached the hall when we heard the baying of a hound and then a scream of agony, with a horrible worrying sound which it was dreadful to listen to. An elderly man with  red face and shaking limbs came staggering out at a side door.

"My God!" he cried. "Someone has loosed the dog. t's not been fed for two days. Quick, quick, or it'll be too late!"

Holmes and I rushed out and round the angle o the house, with Toller hurrying behind us. There was the huge famished brute, its black muzzle buried in Rucastle'sthroat, while he writhed and screamed upon the ground. Running up, I blew its brains out, and it fell over with its een white teeth still meeting in the great creases of his neck. With much labour we separated them and carried him, iving but horribly mangled, into the house. We laid him upon the drawing-room sofa, and having dispatched the sobere Toller to bear the news to his wife, I did what I could to relieve his pain. We were all assembled round him when te door opened, and a tall, gaunt woman entered the room.

"Mrs. Toller!" cried Miss Hunter.

"Yes, miss. Mr. Rucstle let me out when he came back before he went up to you. Ah, miss, it is a pity you didn't let me know what you wre planning, for I would have told you that your pains were wasted."

"Ha!" said Holmes, looking keenly at her. "I is clear that Mrs. Toller knows more about this matter than anyone else."

"Yes, sir, I do, and I am ready enoughto tell what I know."

"Then, pray, sit down, and let us hear it for there are several points on which I must confss that I am still in the dark."

"I will soon make it clear to you," said she; "and I'd have done so before now i I could ha' got out from the cellar. If there's police-court business over this, you'll remember that I was the onethat stood your friend, and that I was Miss Alice's friend too.

"She was never happy at home, Miss Alice wasn't, rom the time that her father married again. She was slighted like and had no say in anything, but it never really beame bad for her until after she met Mr. Fowler at a friend's house. As well as I could learn, Miss Alice had rights f her own by will, but she was so quiet and patient, she was, that she never said a word about them but just left evrything in Mr. Rucastle's hands. He knew he was safe with her; but when there was a chance of a husband coming forwad, who would ask for all that the law would give him, then her father thought it time to put a stop on it. He wantedher to sign a paper, so that whether she married or not, he could use her money. When she wouldn't do it, he kept onworrying her until she got brain-fever, and for six weeks was at death's door. Then she got better at last, all wornto a shadow, and with her beautiful hair cut off; but that didn't make no change in her young man, and he stuck to hr as true as man could be."

"Ah," said Holmes, "I think that what you have been good enough to tell us makes the atter fairly clear, and that I can deduce all that remains. Mr. Rucastle then, I presume, took to this system of impisonment?"

"Yes, sir."

"And brought Miss Hunter down from London in order to get rid of the disagreeable persitence of Mr. Fowler."

"That was it, sir."

"But Mr. Fowler being a persevering man, as a good seaman should be,blockaded the house, and having met you succeeded by certain arguments, metallic or otherwise, in convincing you tha your interests were the same as his."

"Mr. Fowler was a very kind-spoken, free-handed gentleman," said Mrs. Tollr serenely.

"And in this way he managed that your good man should have no want of drink, and that a ladder shouldbe ready at the moment when your master had gone out."

"You have it, sir, just as it happened."

"I am sure we we you an apology, Mrs. Toller," said Holmes, "for you have certainly cleared up everything which puzzled us. And hee comes the country surgeon and Mrs. Rucastle, so I think, Watson, that we had best escort Miss Hunter back to Winchster, as it seems to me that our locus standi now is rather a questionable one."

And thus was solved the mystery f the sinister house with the copper beeches in front of the door. Mr. Rucastle survived, but was always a broken ma, kept alive solely through the care of his devoted wife. They still live with their old servants, who probably knowso much of Rucastle's past life that he finds it difficult to part from them. Mr. Fowler and Miss Rucastle were marred, by special license, in Southampton the day after their flight, and he is now the holder of a government appointmnt in the island of Mauritius. As to Miss Violet Hunter, my friend Holmes, rather to my disappointment, manifested n further interest in her when once she had ceased to be the centre of one of his problems, and she is now the head o a private school at Walsall, where I believe that she has met with considerable success.
