Outside of New England the idea o compulsory education was not regarded
with the same favor; but the whole land was nevertheless dotted with
littleschools kept by "dames, itinerant teachers, or local parsons."
Whether we turn to the life of Franklin in the Northor Washington in
the South, we read of tiny schoolhouses, where boys, and sometimes
girls, were taught to read andwrite. Where there were no schools,
fathers and mothers of the better kind gave their children the rudiments
of lerning. Though illiteracy was widespread, there is evidence to show
that the diffusion of knowledge among the masseswas making steady
progress all through the eighteenth century.

=Religion and Higher Learning.=--Religious motive entered into the
establishment of colleges as well as local schools. Harvard, founded in
1636, and Yale, opened i 1718, were intended primarily to train
"learned and godly ministers" for the Puritan churches of New England.
To he far North, Dartmouth, chartered in 1769, was designed first as a
mission to the Indians and then as a college fo the sons of New England
farmers preparing to preach, teach, or practice law. The College of New
Jersey, organizedin 1746 and removed to Princeton eleven years later,
was sustained by the Presbyterians. Two colleges looked to the
Established Church as their source of inspiration and support: William
and Mary, founded in Virginia in 1693, and ing's College, now Columbia
University, chartered by King George II in 1754, on an appeal from the
New York Anglicns, alarmed at the growth of religious dissent and the
"republican tendencies" of the age. Two colleges revealed a rift away
from sectarianism. Brown, established in Rhode Island in 1764, and the
Philadelphia Academy, forerunner f the University of Pennsylvania,
organized by Benjamin Franklin, reflected the spirit of toleration by
giving repesentation on the board of trustees to several religious
sects. It was Franklin's idea that his college should prepre young men
to serve in public office as leaders of the people and ornaments to
their country.

=Self-educationin America.=--Important as were these institutions of
learning, higher education was by no means confined within thir walls.
Many well-to-do families sent their sons to Oxford or Cambridge in
England. Private tutoring in the homewas common. In still more families
there were intelligent children who grew up in the great colonial school
of advrsity and who trained themselves until, in every contest of mind
and wit, they could vie with the sons of Harvard o William and Mary or
any other college. Such, for example, was Benjamin Franklin, whose
charming autobiography, inaddition to being an American classic, is a
fine record of self-education. His formal training in the classroom was
limited to a few years at a local school in Boston; but his
self-education continued throughout his life. He earlymanifested a zeal
for reading, and devoured, he tells us, his father's dry library on
theology, Bunyan's works, Deoe's writings, Plutarch's _Lives_, Locke's
_On the Human Understanding_, and innumerable volumes dealing with
secuar subjects. His literary style, perhaps the best of his time,
Franklin acquired by the diligent and repeated analyis of the
_Spectator_. In a life crowded with labors, he found time to read widely
in natural science and to win sngle-handed recognition at the hands of
European savants for his discoveries in electricity. By his own efforts
he"attained an acquaintance" with Latin, Italian, French, and Spanish,
thus unconsciously preparing himself for the dy when he was to speak
for all America at the court of the king of France.

Lesser lights than Franklin, educatedby the same process, were found
all over colonial America. From this fruitful source of native ability,
self-educaed, the American cause drew great strength in the trials of
the Revolution.


THE COLONIAL PRESS

=The Rise ofthe Newspaper.=--The evolution of American democracy into a
government by public opinion, enlightened by the open dscussion of
political questions, was in no small measure aided by a free press. That
too, like education, was a mater of slow growth. A printing press was
brought to Massachusetts in 1639, but it was put in charge of an
officialcensor and limited to the publication of religious works. Forty
years elapsed before the first newspaper appeared, earing the curious
title, _Public Occurrences Both Foreign and Domestic_, and it had not
been running very long beore the government of Massachusetts suppressed
it for discussing a political question.

Publishing, indeed, seeme to be a precarious business; but in 1704
there came a second venture in journalism, _The Boston News-Letter_,
whih proved to be a more lasting enterprise because it refrained from
criticizing the authorities. Still the public inerest languished. When
Franklin's brother, James, began to issue his _New England Courant_
about 1720, his friendssought to dissuade him, saying that one
newspaper was enough for America. Nevertheless he continued it; and his
cofidence in the future was rewarded. In nearly every colony a gazette
or chronicle appeared within the next thirty yars or more. Benjamin
Franklin was able to record in 1771 that America had twenty-five
newspapers. Boston led withfive. Philadelphia had three: two in English
and one in German.

=Censorship and Restraints on the Press.=--The iea of printing,
unlicensed by the government and uncontrolled by the church, was,
however, slow in taking form. Th founders of the American colonies had
never known what it was to have the free and open publication of books,
pamhlets, broadsides, and newspapers. When the art of printing was
first discovered, the control of publishing was vesed in clerical
authorities. After the establishment of the State Church in England in
the reign of Elizabeth, censrship of the press became a part of royal
prerogative. Printing was restricted to Oxford, Cambridge, and London;
ad no one could publish anything without previous approval of the
official censor. When the Puritans were in power, he popular party,
with a zeal which rivaled that of the crown, sought, in turn, to silence
royalist and clerical witers by a vigorous censorship. After the
restoration of the monarchy, control of the press was once more placed
i royal hands, where it remained until 1695, when Parliament, by
failing to renew the licensing act, did away entirey with the official

censorship. By that time political parties were so powerful and so
active and printing presss were so numerous that official review of all
published matter became a sheer impossibility.

In America, likewie, some troublesome questions arose in connection
with freedom of the press. The Puritans of Massachusetts were no ess
anxious than King Charles or the Archbishop of London to shut out from
the prying eyes of the people all literture "not mete for them to
read"; and so they established a system of official licensing for
presses, which lasteduntil 1755. In the other colonies where there was
more diversity of opinion and publishers could set up in businesswith
impunity, they were nevertheless constantly liable to arrest for
printing anything displeasing to the colonia governments. In 1721 the
editor of the _Mercury_ in Philadelphia was called before the
proprietary council and orered to apologize for a political article,
and for a later offense of a similar character he was thrown into jail.A still more famous case was that of Peter Zenger, a New York publisher,
who was arrested in 1735 for criticising te administration. Lawyers who
ventured to defend the unlucky editor were deprived of their licenses to
practice, ad it became necessary to bring an attorney all the way from
Philadelphia. By this time the tension of feeling was hgh, and the
approbation of the public was forthcoming when the lawyer for the
defense exclaimed to the jury that te very cause of liberty itself, not
that of the poor printer, was on trial! The verdict for Zenger, when it
finall came, was the signal for an outburst of popular rejoicing.
Already the people of King George's province knew how pecious a thing
is the freedom of the press.

Thanks to the schools, few and scattered as they were, and to the
vgilance of parents, a very large portion, perhaps nearly one-half, of
the colonists could read. Through the newspaprs, pamphlets, and
almanacs that streamed from the types, the people could follow the
course of public events and rasp the significance of political
arguments. An American opinion was in the process of making--an
independent opiion nourished by the press and enriched by discussions
around the fireside and at the taverns. When the day of resitance to
British rule came, government by opinion was at hand. For every person
who could hear the voice of Patric Henry and Samuel Adams, there were a
thousand who could see their appeals on the printed page. Men who had
spelle out their letters while poring over Franklin's _Poor Richard's
Almanac_ lived to read Thomas Paine's thrilling cal to arms.


THE EVOLUTION IN POLITICAL INSTITUTIONS

Two very distinct lines of development appeared in colonia politics.
The one, exalting royal rights and aristocratic privileges, was the
drift toward provincial government hrough royal officers appointed in
England. The other, leading toward democracy and self-government, was
the growt in the power of the popular legislative assembly. Each
movement gave impetus to the other, with increasing force dring the
passing years, until at last the final collision between the two ideals
of government came in the war of ndependence.

=The Royal Provinces.=--Of the thirteen English colonies eight were
royal provinces in 1776, with gvernors appointed by the king. Virginia
passed under the direct rule of the crown in 1624, when the charter of
theLondon Company was annulled. The Massachusetts Bay corporation lost
its charter in 1684, and the new instrument grated seven years later
stripped the colonists of the right to choose their chief executive. In
the early decades ofthe eighteenth century both the Carolinas were
given the provincial instead of the proprietary form. New Hampshire,
severed from Massachusetts in 1679, and Georgia, surrendered by the
trustees in 1752, went into the hands of the cown. New York,
transferred to the Duke of York on its capture from the Dutch in 1664,
became a province when he tok the title of James II in 1685. New
Jersey, after remaining for nearly forty years under proprietors, was
broughtdirectly under the king in 1702. Maryland, Pennsylvania, and
Delaware, although they retained their proprietary chaacter until the
Revolution, were in some respects like the royal colonies, for their
governors were as independentof popular choice as were the appointees
of King George. Only two colonies, Rhode Island and Connecticut,
retainedfull self-government on the eve of the Revolution. They alone
had governors and legislatures entirely of their own hoosing.

The chief officer of the royal province was the governor, who enjoyed
high and important powers which h naturally sought to augment at every
turn. He enforced the laws and, usually with the consent of a council,
appoited the civil and military officers. He granted pardons and
reprieves; he was head of the highest court; he was comander-in-chief
of the militia; he levied troops for defense and enforced martial law in
time of invasion, war, andrebellion. In all the provinces, except
Massachusetts, he named the councilors who composed the upper house of
thelegislature and was likely to choose those who favored his claims.
He summoned, adjourned, and dissolved the popula assembly, or the lower
house; he laid before it the projects of law desired by the crown; and
he vetoed measures hich he thought objectionable. Here were in America
all the elements of royal prerogative against which Hampden had
protested and Cromwell had battled in England.

[Illustration: THE ROYAL GOVERNOR'S PALACE AT NEW BERNE]

The clonial governors were generally surrounded by a body of
office-seekers and hunters for land grants. Some of them wee noblemen
of broken estates who had come to America to improve their fortunes. The
pretensions of this circle graed on colonial nerves, and privileges
granted to them, often at the expense of colonists, did much to deepen
populr antipathy to the British government. Favors extended to
adherents of the Established Church displeased Dissenters The
reappearance of this formidable union of church and state, from which
they had fled, stirred anew the ancientwrath against that combination.

=The Colonial Assembly.=--Coincident with the drift toward
administration throug royal governors was the second and opposite
tendency, namely, a steady growth in the practice of self-government.The voters of England had long been accustomed to share in taxation and
law-making through representatives in Parliment, and the idea was early
introduced in America. Virginia was only twelve years old (1619) when
its first repreentative assembly appeared. As the towns of
Massachusetts multiplied and it became impossible for all the members o
the corporation to meet at one place, the representative idea was
adopted, in 1633. The river towns of Connecticu formed a representative
system under their "Fundamental Orders" of 1639, and the entire colony
was given a royal harter in 1662. Generosity, as well as practical
considerations, induced such proprietors as Lord Baltimore and Wiliam
Penn to invite their colonists to share in the government as soon as any
considerable settlements were made. Tus by one process or another every
one of the colonies secured a popular assembly.

It is true that in the provison for popular elections, the suffrage was
finally restricted to property owners or taxpayers, with a leaning
towad the freehold qualification. In Virginia, the rural voter had to
be a freeholder owning at least fifty acres of lad, if there was no
house on it, or twenty-five acres with a house twenty-five feet square.
In Massachusetts, the vter for member of the assembly under the charter
of 1691 had to be a freeholder of an estate worth forty shillings  year
at least or of other property to the value of forty pounds sterling. In
Pennsylvania, the suffrage was grantd to freeholders owning fifty acres
or more of land well seated, twelve acres cleared, and to other persons
worth t least fifty pounds in lawful money.

Restrictions like these undoubtedly excluded from the suffrage a very
consderable number of men, particularly the mechanics and artisans of
the towns, who were by no means content with thei position.
Nevertheless, it was relatively easy for any man to acquire a small
freehold, so cheap and abundant wasland; and in fact a large proportion
of the colonists were land owners. Thus the assemblies, in spite of the
limitd suffrage, acquired a democratic tone.

The popular character of the assemblies increased as they became engagedin battles with the royal and proprietary governors. When called upon by
the executive to make provision for the suport of the administration,
the legislature took advantage of the opportunity to make terms in the
interest of thetaxpayers. It made annual, not permanent, grants of
money to pay official salaries and then insisted upon electing 
treasurer to dole it out. Thus the colonists learned some of the
mysteries of public finance, as well as the manaement of rapacious
officials. The legislature also used its power over money grants to
force the governor to sign ills which he would otherwise have vetoed.

=Contests between Legislatures and Governors.=--As may be imagined, may
and bitter were the contests between the royal and proprietary governors
and the colonial assemblies. Franklin rlates an amusing story of how
the Pennsylvania assembly held in one hand a bill for the executive to
sign and, in he other hand, the money to pay his salary. Then, with sly
humor, Franklin adds: "Do not, my courteous reader, takepet at our
proprietary constitution for these our bargain and sale proceedings in
legislation. It is a happy county where justice and what was your own
before can be had for ready money. It is another addition to the value
of moey and of course another spur to industry. Every land is not so
blessed."

It must not be thought, however, that very governor got off as easily
as Franklin's tale implies. On the contrary, the legislatures, like
Caesar, fed upn meat that made them great and steadily encroached upon
executive prerogatives as they tried out and found their srength. If
we may believe contemporary laments, the power of the crown in America
was diminishing when it was struk down altogether. In New York, the
friends of the governor complained in 1747 that "the inhabitants of
plantation are generally educated in republican principles; upon
republican principles all is conducted. Little more than a sadow of
royal authority remains in the Northern colonies." "Here," echoed the
governor of South Carolina, the follwing year, "levelling principles
prevail; the frame of the civil government is unhinged; a governor, if
he would b idolized, must betray his trust; the people have got their
whole administration in their hands; the election of th members of the
assembly is by ballot; not civil posts only, but all ecclesiastical
preferments, are in the disposl or election of the people."

Though baffled by the "levelling principles" of the colonial assemblies,
the goverors did not give up the case as hopeless. Instead they evolved
a system of policy and action which they thought coud bring the
obstinate provincials to terms. That system, traceable in their letters
to the government in London, cnsisted of three parts: (1) the royal
officers in the colonies were to be made independent of the legislatures
by axes imposed by acts of Parliament; (2) a British standing army was
to be maintained in America; (3) the remaining olonial charters were to
be revoked and government by direct royal authority was to be enlarged.

Such a system semed plausible enough to King George III and to many
ministers of the crown in London. With governors, courts, and n army
independent of the colonists, they imagined it would be easy to carry
out both royal orders and acts of Pariament. This reasoning seemed both
practical and logical. Nor was it founded on theory, for it came fresh
from thegovernors themselves. It was wanting in one respect only. It
failed to take account of the fact that the American pople were growing
strong in the practice of self-government and could dispense with the
tutelage of the British miistry, no matter how excellent it might be or
how benevolent its intentions.

CHAPTER IV

THE DEVELPMENT OF COLONIAL NATIONALISM


It is one of the well-known facts of history that a people loosely
united by domstic ties of a political and economic nature, even a
people torn by domestic strife, may be welded into a solid andcompact
body by an attack from a foreign power. The imperative call to common
defense, the habit of sharing commonburdens, the fusing force of common
service--these things, induced by the necessity of resisting outside
interferece, act as an amalgam drawing together all elements, except,
perhaps, the most discordant. The presence of the enem allays the most
virulent of quarrels, temporarily at least. "Politics," runs an old
saying, "stops at the water'sedge."

This ancient political principle, so well understood in diplomatic
circles, applied nearly as well to theoriginal thirteen American
colonies as to the countries of Europe. The necessity for common
defense, if not equall great, was certainly always pressing. Though it
has long been the practice to speak of the early settlements as fonded
in "a wilderness," this was not actually the case. From the earliest
days of Jamestown on through the years, he American people were
confronted by dangers from without. All about their tiny settlements
were Indians, growingmore and more hostile as the frontier advanced and
as sharp conflicts over land aroused angry passions. To the sout and
west was the power of Spain, humiliated, it is true, by the disaster to
the Armada, but still presenting an iposing front to the British
empire. To the north and west were the French, ambitious, energetic,
imperial in tempe, and prepared to contest on land and water the
advance of British dominion in America.


RELATIONS WITH THE INDANS AND THE FRENCH

=Indian Affairs.=--It is difficult to make general statements about the
relations of the coloists to the Indians. The problem was presented in
different shape in different sections of America. It was not handed
according to any coherent or uniform plan by the British government,
which alone could speak for all the provines at the same time. Neither
did the proprietors and the governors who succeeded one another, in an
irregular trai, have the consistent policy or the matured experience
necessary for dealing wisely with Indian matters. As the dificulties
arose mainly on the frontiers, where the restless and pushing pioneers
were making their way with gun andax, nearly everything that happened
was the result of chance rather than of calculation. A personal quarrel
betwee traders and an Indian, a jug of whisky, a keg of gunpowder, the
exchange of guns for furs, personal treachery, or  flash of bad temper
often set in motion destructive forces of the most terrible character.

On one side of the ldger may be set innumerable generous records--of
Squanto and Samoset teaching the Pilgrims the ways of the wilds; o
Roger Williams buying his lands from the friendly natives; or of William
Penn treating with them on his arrival i America. On the other side of
the ledger must be recorded many a cruel and bloody conflict as the
frontier rolledwestward with deadly precision. The Pequots on the
Connecticut border, sensing their doom, fell upon the tiny settlments
with awful fury in 1637 only to meet with equally terrible punishment. A
generation later, King Philip, son f Massasoit, the friend of the
Pilgrims, called his tribesmen to a war of extermination which brought
the strengthof all New England to the field and ended in his own
destruction. In New York, the relations with the Indians, espeially
with the Algonquins and the Mohawks, were marked by periodic and
desperate wars. Virginia and her Southern nighbors suffered as did New
England. In 1622 Opecacano, a brother of Powhatan, the friend of the
Jamestown settler, launched a general massacre; and in 1644 he
attempted a war of extermination. In 1675 the whole frontier was ablae.
Nathaniel Bacon vainly attempted to stir the colonial governor to put up
an adequate defense and, failing in tht plea, himself headed a revolt
and a successful expedition against the Indians. As the Virginia
outposts advancedinto the Kentucky country, the strife with the natives
was transferred to that "dark and bloody ground"; while to te
southeast, a desperate struggle with the Tuscaroras called forth the
combined forces of the two Carolinas and Viginia.

[Illustration: _From an old print._

VIRGINIANS DEFENDING THEMSELVES AGAINST THE INDIANS]

From such hrrors New Jersey and Delaware were saved on account of their
geographical location. Pennsylvania, consistently follwing a policy of
conciliation, was likewise spared until her western vanguard came into
full conflict with the alled French and Indians. Georgia, by clever
negotiations and treaties of alliance, managed to keep on fair terms
wit her belligerent Cherokees and Creeks. But neither diplomacy nor
generosity could stay the inevitable conflict as te frontier advanced,
especially after the French soldiers enlisted the Indians in their
imperial enterprises. It ws then that desultory fighting became general
warfare.

[Illustration: ENGLISH, FRENCH, AND SPANISH POSSESSIONS I AMERICA,
1750]

=Early Relations with the French.=--During the first decades of French
exploration and settlemet in the St. Lawrence country, the English
colonies, engrossed with their own problems, gave little or no thought
o their distant neighbors. Quebec, founded in 1608, and Montreal, in
1642, were too far away, too small in populatin, and too slight in
strength to be much of a menace to Boston, Hartford, or New York. It was
the statesmen in Frace and England, rather than the colonists in
America, who first grasped the significance of the slowly converging
mpires in North America. It was the ambition of Louis XIV of France,
rather than the labors of Jesuit missionaries nd French rangers, that
sounded the first note of colonial alarm.

Evidence of this lies in the fact that three cnflicts between the
English and the French occurred before their advancing frontiers met on
the Pennsylvania borde. King William's War (1689-1697), Queen Anne's
War (1701-1713), and King George's War (1744-1748) owed their origin
and their endings mainly to the intrigues and rivalries of European
powers, although they all involved the Americn colonies in struggles
with the French and their savage allies.

=The Clash in the Ohio Valley.=--The second of hese wars had hardly
closed, however, before the English colonists themselves began to be
seriously alarmed about he rapidly expanding French dominion in the
West. Marquette and Joliet, who opened the Lake region, and La Salle,
ho in 1682 had gone down the Mississippi to the Gulf, had been followed
by the builders of forts. In 1718, the Frenh founded New Orleans, thus
taking possession of the gateway to the Mississippi as well as the St.
Lawrence. A fewyears later they built Fort Niagara; in 1731 they
occupied Crown Point; in 1749 they formally announced their dominon
over all the territory drained by the Ohio River. Having asserted this
lofty claim, they set out to make it goo by constructing in the years
1752-1754 Fort Le Boeuf near Lake Erie, Fort Venango on the upper
waters of the Alleheny, and Fort Duquesne at the junction of the
streams forming the Ohio. Though they were warned by George Washingtn,
in the name of the governor of Virginia, to keep out of territory "so
notoriously known to be property of the cown of Great Britain," the
French showed no signs of relinquishing their pretensions.

[Illustration: _From an ol print_

BRADDOCK'S RETREAT]

=The Final Phase--the French and Indian War.=--Thus it happened that the
shot whih opened the Seven Years' War, known in America as the French
and Indian War, was fired in the wilds of Pennsylvani. There began the
conflict that spread to Europe and even Asia and finally involved
England and Prussia, on the on side, and France, Austria, Spain, and
minor powers on the other. On American soil, the defeat of Braddock in
1755and Wolfe's exploit in capturing Quebec four years later were the
dramatic features. On the continent of Europe, Enland subsidized
Prussian arms to hold France at bay. In India, on the banks of the
Ganges, as on the banks of the t. Lawrence, British arms were
triumphant. Well could the historian write: "Conquests equaling in
rapidity and farsurpassing in magnitude those of Cortes and Pizarro had
been achieved in the East." Well could the merchants of Lonon declare
that under the administration of William Pitt, the imperial genius of
this world-wide conflict, commerc had been "united with and made to
flourish by war."

From the point of view of the British empire, the results o the war
were momentous. By the peace of 1763, Canada and the territory east of
the Mississippi, except New Orlean, passed under the British flag. The
remainder of the Louisiana territory was transferred to Spain and French
impeial ambitions on the American continent were laid to rest. In
exchange for Havana, which the British had seized durng the war, Spain
ceded to King George the colony of Florida. Not without warrant did
Macaulay write in after year that Pitt "was the first Englishman of his
time; and he had made England the first country in the world."


THEEFFECTS OF WARFARE ON THE COLONIES

The various wars with the French and the Indians, trivial in detail as
they sem to-day, had a profound influence on colonial life and on the
destiny of America. Circumstances beyond the contro of popular
assemblies, jealous of their individual powers, compelled cooperation
among them, grudging and stingy o doubt, but still cooperation. The
American people, more eager to be busy in their fields or at their
trades, wer simply forced to raise and support armies, to learn the
arts of warfare, and to practice, if in a small theater, te science of
statecraft. These forces, all cumulative, drove the colonists, so
tenaciously provincial in their habts, in the direction of nationalism.

=The New England Confederation.=--It was in their efforts to deal with
the roblems presented by the Indian and French menace that the
Americans took the first steps toward union. Though ther were many
common ties among the settlers of New England, it required a deadly
fear of the Indians to produce in 143 the New England Confederation,
composed of Massachusetts, Plymouth, Connecticut, and New Haven. The
colonies sounited were bound together in "a firm and perpetual league
of friendship and amity for offense and defense, mutual ervice and
succor, upon all just occasions." They made provision for distributing
the burdens of wars among the mebers and provided for a congress of
commissioners from each colony to determine upon common policies. For
some twety years the Confederation was active and it continued to hold
meetings until after the extinction of the Indian peil on the immediate
border.

Virginia, no less than Massachusetts, was aware of the importance of
intercolonial ooperation. In the middle of the seventeenth century, the
Old Dominion began treaties of commerce and amity with Ne York and the
colonies of New England. In 1684 delegates from Virginia met at Albany
with the agents of New York ad Massachusetts to discuss problems of
mutual defense. A few years later the Old Dominion cooperated loyally
with he Carolinas in defending their borders against Indian forays.

=The Albany Plan of Union.=--An attempt at a generl colonial union was
made in 1754. On the suggestion of the Lords of Trade in England, a
conference was held at Alany to consider Indian relations, to devise
measures of defense against the French, and to enter into "articles ofunion and confederation for the general defense of his Majesty's
subjects and interests in North America as well intime of peace as of
war." New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, New York,
Pennsylvania, and Marland were represented. After a long discussion, a
plan of union, drafted mainly, it seems, by Benjamin Franklin, wa
adopted and sent to the colonies and the crown for approval. The
colonies, jealous of their individual rights, reused to accept the
scheme and the king disapproved it for the reason, Franklin said, that
it had "too much weight n the democratic part of the constitution."
Though the Albany union failed, the document is still worthy of study
ecause it forecast many of the perplexing problems that were not solved
until thirty-three years afterward, when anther convention of which
also Franklin was a member drafted the Constitution of the United
States.

[Illustratio: BENJAMIN FRANKLIN]

=The Military Education of the Colonists.=--The same wars that showed
the provincials the maning of union likewise instructed them in the art
of defending their institutions. Particularly was this true of te last
French and Indian conflict, which stretched all the way from Maine to
the Carolinas and made heavy calls upn them all for troops. The answer,
it is admitted, was far from satisfactory to the British government and
the conuct of the militiamen was far from professional; but thousands
of Americans got a taste, a strong taste, of actual ighting in the
field. Men like George Washington and Daniel Morgan learned lessons that
were not forgotten in afte years. They saw what American militiamen
could do under favorable circumstances and they watched British regularsoperating on American soil. "This whole transaction," shrewdly remarked
Franklin of Braddock's campaign, "gave us Aericans the first suspicion
that our exalted ideas of the prowess of British regular troops had not
been well founed." It was no mere accident that the Virginia colonel
who drew his sword under the elm at Cambridge and took commad of the
army of the Revolution was the brave officer who had "spurned the
whistle of bullets" at the memorable batle in western Pennsylvania.

=Financial Burdens and Commercial Disorder.=--While the provincials were
learning lssons in warfare they were also paying the bills. All the
conflicts were costly in treasure as in blood. King Phili's war left
New England weak and almost bankrupt. The French and Indian struggle was
especially expensive. The twety-five thousand men put in the field by
the colonies were sustained only by huge outlays of money. Paper
currencystreamed from the press and debts were accumulated. Commerce
was driven from its usual channels and prices were enhnced. When the
end came, both England and America were staggering under heavy
liabilities, and to make matters wore there was a fall of prices
accompanied by a commercial depression which extended over a period of
ten years. It as in the midst of this crisis that measures of taxation
had to be devised to pay the cost of the war, precipitatin the quarrel
which led to American independence.

=The Expulsion of French Power from North America.=--The effect of the
defeat administered to France, as time proved, were difficult to
estimate. Some British statesmen regardedit as a happy circumstance
that the colonists, already restive under their administration, had no
foreign power athand to aid them in case they struck for independence.
American leaders, on the other hand, now that the soldiers o King Louis
were driven from the continent, thought that they had no other country
to fear if they cast off Britis sovereignty. At all events, France,
though defeated, was not out of the sphere of American influence; for,
as evets proved, it was the fortunate French alliance negotiated by
Franklin that assured the triumph of American arms inthe War of the
Revolution.


COLONIAL RELATIONS WITH THE BRITISH GOVERNMENT

It was neither the Indian wars no the French wars that finally brought
forth American nationality. That was the product of the long strife
with themother country which culminated in union for the war of
independence. The forces that created this nation did not oerate in the
colonies alone. The character of the English sovereigns, the course of
events in English domestic poltics, and English measures of control
over the colonies--executive, legislative, and judicial--must all be
taken ito account.

=The Last of the Stuarts.=--The struggles between Charles I (1625-49)
and the parliamentary party an the turmoil of the Puritan regime
(1649-60) so engrossed the attention of Englishmen at home that they had
littletime to think of colonial policies or to interfere with colonial
affairs. The restoration of the monarchy in 1660, ccompanied by
internal peace and the increasing power of the mercantile classes in the
House of Commons, changed al that. In the reign of Charles II
(1660-85), himself an easy-going person, the policy of regulating trade
by act f Parliament was developed into a closely knit system and
powerful agencies to supervise the colonies were created.At the same
time a system of stricter control over the dominions was ushered in by
the annulment of the old charte of Massachusetts which conferred so
much self-government on the Puritans.

Charles' successor, James II, a man o sterner stuff and jealous of his
authority in the colonies as well as at home, continued the policy thus
inauguraed and enlarged upon it. If he could have kept his throne, he
would have bent the Americans under a harsh rule or bought on in his
dominions a revolution like that which he precipitated at home in 1688.
He determined to unite theNorthern colonies and introduce a more
efficient administration based on the pattern of the royal provinces. He
mae a martinet, Sir Edmund Andros, governor of all New England, New
York, and New Jersey. The charter of Massachusett, annulled in the last
days of his brother's reign, he continued to ignore, and that of
Connecticut would have bee seized if it had not been spirited away and
hidden, according to tradition, in a hollow oak.

For several months Andros gave the Northern colonies a taste of
ill-tempered despotism. He wrung quit rents from land owners not
accstomed to feudal dues; he abrogated titles to land where, in his
opinion, they were unlawful; he forced the Episcopl service upon the
Old South Church in Boston; and he denied the writ of _habeas corpus_ to
a preacher who denouncd taxation without representation. In the middle
of his arbitrary course, however, his hand was stayed. The news cae
that King James had been dethroned by his angry subjects, and the people
of Boston, kindling a fire on Beacon Hil, summoned the countryside to
dispose of Andros. The response was prompt and hearty. The hated
governor was arresed, imprisoned, and sent back across the sea under
guard.

The overthrow of James, followed by the accession of Wlliam and Mary
and by assured parliamentary supremacy, had an immediate effect in the
colonies. The new order was reeted with thanksgiving. Massachusetts was
given another charter which, though not so liberal as the first,
restoed the spirit if not the entire letter of self-government. In the
other colonies where Andros had been operating, te old course of
affairs was resumed.

=The Indifference of the First Two Georges.=--On the death in 1714 of
Quee Anne, the successor of King William, the throne passed to a
Hanoverian prince who, though grateful for English honrs and revenues,
was more interested in Hanover than in England. George I and George II,
whose combined reigns extnded from 1714 to 1760, never even learned to
speak the English language, at least without an accent. The necessityof
taking thought about colonial affairs bored both of them so that the
stoutest defender of popular privileges inBoston or Charleston had no
ground to complain of the exercise of personal prerogatives by the king.
Moreover, durng a large part of this period, the direction of affairs
was in the hands of an astute leader, Sir Robert Walpole, ho betrayed
his somewhat cynical view of politics by adopting as his motto: "Let
sleeping dogs lie." He revealed hs appreciation of popular sentiment
by exclaiming: "I will not be the minister to enforce taxes at the
expense of lood." Such kings and such ministers were not likely to
arouse the slumbering resistance of the thirteen colonies aross the
sea.

=Control of the Crown over the Colonies.=--While no English ruler from
James II to George III venured to interfere with colonial matters
personally, constant control over the colonies was exercised by royal
offiers acting under the authority of the crown. Systematic supervision
began in 1660, when there was created by royal rder a committee of the
king's council to meet on Mondays and Thursdays of each week to consider
petitions, memorils, and addresses respecting the plantations. In 1696
a regular board was established, known as the "Lords of Tradeand
Plantations," which continued, until the American Revolution, to
scrutinize closely colonial business. The chif duties of the board were
to examine acts of colonial legislatures, to recommend measures to those
assemblies foradoption, and to hear memorials and petitions from the
colonies relative to their affairs.

The methods employed y this board were varied. All laws passed by
American legislatures came before it for review as a matter of routine
If it found an act unsatisfactory, it recommended to the king the
exercise of his veto power, known as the royal isallowance. Any person
who believed his personal or property rights injured by a colonial law
could be heard by te board in person or by attorney; in such cases it
was the practice to hear at the same time the agent of the colon so
involved. The royal veto power over colonial legislation was not,
therefore, a formal affair, but was constanty employed on the
suggestion of a highly efficient agency of the crown. All this was in
addition to the powers execised by the governors in the royal
provinces.

=Judicial Control.=--Supplementing this administrative control ovr the
colonies was a constant supervision by the English courts of law. The
king, by virtue of his inherent authorty, claimed and exercised high
appellate powers over all judicial tribunals in the empire. The right
of appeal fro local courts, expressly set forth in some charters, was,
on the eve of the Revolution, maintained in every colony.Any subject in
England or America, who, in the regular legal course, was aggrieved by
any act of a colonial legislture or any decision of a colonial court,
had the right, subject to certain regulations, to carry his case to the
ing in council, forcing his opponent to follow him across the sea. In
the exercise of appellate power, the king in ouncil acting as a court
could, and frequently did, declare acts of colonial legislatures duly
enacted and approve, null and void, on the ground that they were
contrary to English law.

=Imperial Control in Operation.=--Day aftr day, week after week, year
after year, the machinery for political and judicial control over
colonial affairs wa in operation. At one time the British governors in
the colonies were ordered not to approve any colonial law imposng a
duty on European goods imported in English vessels. Again, when North
Carolina laid a tax on peddlers, the concil objected to it as
"restrictive upon the trade and dispersion of English manufactures
throughout the continent" At other times, Indian trade was regulated in
the interests of the whole empire or grants of lands by a coloniallegislature were set aside. Virginia was forbidden to close her ports to
North Carolina lest there should be retalition.

In short, foreign and intercolonial trade were subjected to a control
higher than that of the colony, forehadowing a day when the
Constitution of the United States was to commit to Congress the power to
regulate interstae and foreign commerce and commerce with the Indians.
A superior judicial power, towering above that of the colonie, as the
Supreme Court at Washington now towers above the states, kept the
colonial legislatures within the metes nd bounds of established law. In
the thousands of appeals, memorials, petitions, and complaints, and the
rulings ad decisions upon them, were written the real history of
British imperial control over the American colonies.

So reat was the business before the Lords of Trade that the colonies
had to keep skilled agents in London to protect teir interests. As
common grievances against the operation of this machinery of control
arose, there appeared in eah colony a considerable body of men, with
the merchants in the lead, who chafed at the restraints imposed on theirenterprise. Only a powerful blow was needed to weld these bodies into a
common mass nourishing the spirit of colonil nationalism. When to the
repeated minor irritations were added general and sweeping measures of
Parliament applyng to every colony, the rebound came in the Revolution.

=Parliamentary Control over Colonial Affairs.=--As soon a Parliament
gained in power at the expense of the king, it reached out to bring the
American colonies under its swy as well. Between the execution of
Charles I and the accession of George III, there was enacted an immense
body o legislation regulating the shipping, trade, and manufactures of
America. All of it, based on the "mercantile" theoy then prevalent in
all countries of Europe, was designed to control the overseas
plantations in such a way as to oster the commercial and business
interests of the mother country, where merchants and men of finance had
got the pper hand. According to this theory, the colonies of the
British empire should be confined to agriculture and the poduction of
raw materials, and forced to buy their manufactured goods of England.

_The Navigation Acts._--In thefirst rank among these measures of
British colonial policy must be placed the navigation laws framed for
the purpoe of building up the British merchant marine and navy--arms so
essential in defending the colonies against the Spansh, Dutch, and
French. The beginning of this type of legislation was made in 1651 and
it was worked out into a sysem early in the reign of Charles II
(1660-85).

The Navigation Acts, in effect, gave a monopoly of colonial commece to
British ships. No trade could be carried on between Great Britain and
her dominions save in vessels built an manned by British subjects. No
European goods could be brought to America save in the ships of the
country that poduced them or in English ships. These laws, which were
almost fatal to Dutch shipping in America, fell with severiy upon the
colonists, compelling them to pay higher freight rates. The adverse
effect, however, was short-lived, fr the measures stimulated
shipbuilding in the colonies, where the abundance of raw materials gave
the master buildrs of America an advantage over those of the mother
country. Thus the colonists in the end profited from the restritive
policy written into the Navigation Acts.

_The Acts against Manufactures._--The second group of laws was
deiberately aimed to prevent colonial industries from competing too
sharply with those of England. Among the earliestof these measures may
be counted the Woolen Act of 1699, forbidding the exportation of woolen
goods from the colones and even the woolen trade between towns and
colonies. When Parliament learned, as the result of an inquiry, thatNew
England and New York were making thousands of hats a year and sending
large numbers annually to the Southern clonies and to Ireland, Spain,
and Portugal, it enacted in 1732 a law declaring that "no hats or felts,
dyed or unded, finished or unfinished" should be "put upon any vessel
or laden upon any horse or cart with intent to export toany place
whatever." The effect of this measure upon the hat industry was almost
ruinous. A few years later a simiar blow was given to the iron
industry. By an act of 1750, pig and bar iron from the colonies were
given free entr to England to encourage the production of the raw
material; but at the same time the law provided that "no mill orother
engine for slitting or rolling of iron, no plating forge to work with a
tilt hammer, and no furnace for makig steel" should be built in the
colonies. As for those already built, they were declared public
nuisances and ordeed closed. Thus three important economic interests of
the colonists, the woolen, hat, and iron industries, were lai under the
ban.

_The Trade Laws._--The third group of restrictive measures passed by the
British Parliament relted to the sale of colonial produce. An act of
1663 required the colonies to export certain articles to Great Britan
or to her dominions alone; while sugar, tobacco, and ginger consigned to
the continent of Europe had to pass thrugh a British port paying custom
duties and through a British merchant's hands paying the usual
commission. At firt tobacco was the only one of the "enumerated
articles" which seriously concerned the American colonies, the rest
oming mainly from the British West Indies. In the course of time,
however, other commodities were added to the listof enumerated
articles, until by 1764 it embraced rice, naval stores, copper, furs,
hides, iron, lumber, and pearlashes. This was not all. The colonies
were compelled to bring their European purchases back through English
ports,paying duties to the government and commissions to merchants
again.

_The Molasses Act._--Not content with laws eacted in the interest of
English merchants and manufacturers, Parliament sought to protect the
British West Indiesagainst competition from their French and Dutch
neighbors. New England merchants had long carried on a lucrative trde
with the French islands in the West Indies and Dutch Guiana, where sugar
and molasses could be obtained in larg quantities at low prices. Acting
on the protests of English planters in the Barbadoes and Jamaica,
Parliament, in1733, passed the famous Molasses Act imposing duties on
sugar and molasses imported into the colonies from foreigncountries--rates which would have destroyed the American trade with the
French and Dutch if the law had been enforcd. The duties, however, were
not collected. The molasses and sugar trade with the foreigners went on
merrily, smugling taking the place of lawful traffic.

=Effect of the Laws in America.=--As compared with the strict monopoly
f her colonial trade which Spain consistently sought to maintain, the
policy of England was both moderate and liberl. Furthermore, the
restrictive laws were supplemented by many measures intended to be
favorable to colonial prosprity. The Navigation Acts, for example,
redounded to the advantage of American shipbuilders and the producers
of hmp, tar, lumber, and ship stores in general. Favors in British
ports were granted to colonial producers as against oreign competitors
and in some instances bounties were paid by England to encourage
colonial enterprise. Taken allin all, there is much justification in
the argument advanced by some modern scholars to the effect that the
colonits gained more than they lost by British trade and industrial
legislation. Certainly after the establishment of indpendence, when
free from these old restrictions, the Americans found themselves
handicapped by being treated as foeigners rather than favored traders
and the recipients of bounties in English markets.

Be that as it may, it appars that the colonists felt little irritation
against the mother country on account of the trade and navigation law
enacted previous to the close of the French and Indian war. Relatively
few were engaged in the hat and iron indusries as compared with those
in farming and planting, so that England's policy of restricting America
to agricultur did not conflict with the interests of the majority of
the inhabitants. The woolen industry was largely in the hans of women
and carried on in connection with their domestic duties, so that it was
not the sole support of any coniderable number of people.

As a matter of fact, moreover, the restrictive laws, especially those
relating to trae, were not rigidly enforced. Cargoes of tobacco were
boldly sent to continental ports without even so much as a bo to the
English government, to which duties should have been paid. Sugar and
molasses from the French and Dutch coonies were shipped into New
England in spite of the law. Royal officers sometimes protested against
smuggling and ometimes connived at it; but at no time did they succeed
in stopping it. Taken all in all, very little was heard of"the galling
restraints of trade" until after the French war, when the British
government suddenly entered upon a ew course.


SUMMARY OF THE COLONIAL PERIOD

In the period between the landing of the English at Jamestown, Virinia,
in 1607, and the close of the French and Indian war in 1763--a period of
a century and a half--a new nation as being prepared on this continent
to take its place among the powers of the earth. It was an epoch of
migration.Western Europe contributed emigrants of many races and
nationalities. The English led the way. Next to them in numeical
importance were the Scotch-Irish and the Germans. Into the melting pot
were also cast Dutch, Swedes, French, ews, Welsh, and Irish. Thousands
of negroes were brought from Africa to till Southern fields or labor as
domestic ervants in the North.

Why did they come? The reasons are various. Some of them, the Pilgrims
and Puritans of NewEngland, the French Huguenots, Scotch-Irish and
Irish, and the Catholics of Maryland, fled from intolerant governmets
that denied them the right to worship God according to the dictates of
their consciences. Thousands came to escpe the bondage of poverty in
the Old World and to find free homes in America. Thousands, like the
negroes from Afrca, were dragged here against their will. The lure of
adventure appealed to the restless and the lure of profits tothe
enterprising merchants.

How did they come? In some cases religious brotherhoods banded together
and borrowe or furnished the funds necessary to pay the way. In other
cases great trading companies were organized to found coonies. Again it
was the wealthy proprietor, like Lord Baltimore or William Penn, who
undertook to plant settlement. Many immigrants were able to pay their
own way across the sea. Others bound themselves out for a term of years
i exchange for the cost of the passage. Negroes were brought on account
of the profits derived from their sale as slves.

Whatever the motive for their coming, however, they managed to get
across the sea. The immigrants set to wok with a will. They cut down
forests, built houses, and laid out fields. They founded churches,
schools, and collees. They set up forges and workshops. They spun and
wove. They fashioned ships and sailed the seas. They bartered ad
traded. Here and there on favorable harbors they established centers of
commerce--Boston, Providence, New York, hiladelphia, Baltimore, and
Charleston. As soon as a firm foothold was secured on the shore line
they pressed westard until, by the close of the colonial period, they
were already on the crest of the Alleghanies.

Though they wre widely scattered along a thousand miles of seacoast,
the colonists were united in spirit by many common ties. Th major
portion of them were Protestants. The language, the law, and the
literature of England furnished the basis f national unity. Most of the
colonists were engaged in the same hard task; that of conquering a
wilderness. To tis of kinship and language were added ties created by
necessity. They had to unite in defense; first, against the Inians and
later against the French. They were all subjects of the same
sovereign--the king of England. The English arliament made laws for
them and the English government supervised their local affairs, their
trade, and their manfactures. Common forces assailed them. Common
grievances vexed them. Common hopes inspired them.

Many of the thigs which tended to unite them likewise tended to throw
them into opposition to the British Crown and Parliament. Mot of them
were freeholders; that is, farmers who owned their own land and tilled
it with their own hands. A free sil nourished the spirit of freedom.
The majority of them were Dissenters, critics, not friends, of the
Church of Egland, that stanch defender of the British monarchy. Each
colony in time developed its own legislature elected by te voters; it
grew accustomed to making laws and laying taxes for itself. Here was a
people learning self-reliance nd self-government. The attempts to
strengthen the Church of England in America and the transformation of
coloniesinto royal provinces only fanned the spirit of independence
which they were designed to quench.

Nevertheless, th Americans owed much of their prosperity to the
assistance of the government that irritated them. It was the protecion
of the British navy that prevented Holland, Spain, and France from
wiping out their settlements. Though their anufacture and trade were
controlled in the interests of the mother country, they also enjoyed
great advantages inher markets. Free trade existed nowhere upon the
earth; but the broad empire of Britain was open to American ships nd
merchandise. It could be said, with good reason, that the disadvantages
which the colonists suffered through Brtish regulation of their
industry and trade were more than offset by the privileges they enjoyed.
Still that is soewhat beside the point, for mere economic advantage is
not necessarily the determining factor in the fate of people. A
thousand circumstances had helped to develop on this continent a nation,
to inspire it with a passion for indeendence, and to prepare it for a
destiny greater than that of a prosperous dominion of the British
empire. The ecoomists, who tried to prove by logic unassailable that
America would be richer under the British flag, could not chage the
spirit of Patrick Henry, Samuel Adams, Benjamin Franklin, or George
Washington.
