Only one man knew my secret. H was the keeper of a low den in which I used to lodge in Swandam Lane, where I could every morning emerge as a squald beggar and in the evenings transform myself into a well-dressed man about town. This fellow, a Lascar, was well pad by me for his rooms, so that I knew that my secret was safe in his possession.

"Well, very soon I found that I as saving considerable sums of money. I do not mean that any beggar in the streets of London could earn $700 a year-which is less than my average takings--but I had exceptional advantages in my power of making up, and also in a faciity of repartee, which improved by practice and made me quite a recognised character in the City. All day a stream o pennies, varied by silver, poured in upon me, and it was a very bad day in which I failed to take $2.

"As I grewricher I grew more ambitious, took a house in the country, and eventually married, without anyone having a suspicionas to my real occupation. My dear wife knew that I had business in the City. She little knew what.

"Last Monday Ihad finished for the day and was dressing in my room above the opium den when I looked out of my window and saw, to y horror and astonishment, that my wife was standing in the street, with her eyes fixed full upon me. I gave a cry o surprise, threw up my arms to cover my face, and, rushing to my confidant, the Lascar, entreated him to prevent anyne from coming up to me. I heard her voice downstairs, but I knew that she could not ascend. Swiftly I threw off my lothes, pulled on those of a beggar, and put on my pigments and wig. Even a wife's eyes could not pierce so completea disguise. But then it occurred to me that there might be a search in the room, and that the clothes might betray m. "That note only reached her yesterday," said Holmes.

"God God! What a week she must have spent!"

"Many times; but what was a fine to me?"

" reached this one," said my friend, "by sitting upon five pillows and consuming an ounce of shag. I think, Watson, tat if we drive to Baker Street we shall just be in time for breakfast."

VII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE BLUE CARBUNCLE


I had called upon my friend Sherlock Holmes upon the second morning after Christmas, with the intention of wishng him the compliments of the season. He was lounging upon the sofa in a purple dressing-gown, a pipe-rack within hi reach upon the right, and a pile of crumpled morning papers, evidently newly studied, near at hand. Beside the couc was a wooden chair, and on the angle of the back hung a very seedy and disreputable hard-felt hat, much the worse fr wear, and cracked in several places. A lens and a forceps lying upon the seat of the chair suggested that the hat ad been suspended in this manner for the purpose of examination.

"You are engaged," said I; "perhaps I interrupt ou."

"Not at all. I am glad to have a friend with whom I can discuss my results. The matter is a perfectly trivia one"--he jerked his thumb in the direction of the old hat--"but there are points in connection with it which are no entirely devoid of interest and even of instruction."

I seated myself in his armchair and warmed my hands beforehis crackling fire, for a sharp frost had set in, and the windows were thick with the ice crystals. "I suppose," I rmarked, "that, homely as it looks, this thing has some deadly story linked on to it--that it is the clue which will uide you in the solution of some mystery and the punishment of some crime."

"Only one of those whimsical little incidents which will happen when you have four million human being all jostling each other within the space of a few square miles. Amid the action and reaction of so dense a swarm ofhumanity, every possible combination of events may be expected to take place, and many a little problem will be presnted which may be striking and bizarre without being criminal. We have already had experience of such."

"So much o," I remarked, "that of the last six cases which I have added to my notes, three have been entirely free of any legl crime."

Well, I have no doubt that this small matter wil fall into the same innocent category. You know Peterson, the commissionaire?"

"Yes."

"It is to him that this rophy belongs."

It arrived upon Chrismas morning, in company with a good fat goose, which is, I have no doubt, roasting at this moment in front of Petersn's fire. The facts are these: about four o'clock on Christmas morning, Peterson, who, as you know, is a very honestfellow, was returning from some small jollification and was making his way homeward down Tottenham Court Road. In frnt of him he saw, in the gaslight, a tallish man, walking with a slight stagger, and carrying a white goose slung ovr his shoulder. Peterson had rushed forward to protect the stranger from his assilants; but the man, shocked at having broken the window, and seeing an official-looking person in uniform rushing twards him, dropped his goose, took to his heels, and vanished amid the labyrinth of small streets which lie at the bck of Tottenham Court Road. The roughs had also fled at the appearance of Peterson, so that he was left in possessio of the field of battle, and also of the spoils of victory in the shape of this battered hat and a most unimpeachabl Christmas goose."

B.' are legible upon the lining of this hat, but as there are some thousands of Bakers, andsome hundreds of Henry Bakers in this city of ours, it is not easy to restore lost property to any one of them."

What, then, did Peterson do?"

"He brought round both hat and goose to me on Christmas morning, knowing that even he smallest problems are of interest to me. The goose we retained until this morning, when there were signs that, inspite of the slight frost, it would be well that it should be eaten without unnecessary delay. Its finder has carrie it off, therefore, to fulfil the ultimate destiny of a goose, while I continue to retain the hat of the unknown genleman who lost his Christmas dinner."

"Did he not advertise?"

"No."

"Then, what clue could you have as to hs identity?"

"Only as much as we can deduce."

"From his hat?"

"Precisely."

"But you are joking. What canyou gather from this old battered felt?"

I took the tattered object in my hands and turned it ovr rather ruefully. It was a very ordinary black hat of the usual round shape, hard and much the worse for wear. "My dear Holmes"

Anyhow, he never got tallow-stains from a gas-je. Are you satisfied?"

"Well, it is very ingenious," said I, laughing; "but since, as you said just now, there hasbeen no crime committed, and no harm done save the loss of a goose, all this seems to be rather a waste of energy."
Sherlock Holmes had opened his mouth to reply, when the door flew open, and Peterson, the commissionaire, rushed ito the apartment with flushed cheeks and the face of a man who is dazed with astonishment.

"Hotel Cosmopolitan Jewel Robbery. John Horner, 26, plumber, was brought up upon the charge of hving upon the 22nd inst., abstracted from the jewel-case of the Countess of Morcar the valuable gem known as the blu carbuncle. Honer, who had shown signs of intense emotion during the proceedings, fainted away at the conclusion and was carried ot of court."

"When Horner had been arrested, it seemed to me that it would e best for me to get away with the stone at once, for I did not know at what moment the police might not take it int their heads to search me and my room. VIII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE SPECKLED BAND


On glancing over my notes of the sventy odd cases in which I have during the last eight years studied the methods of my friend Sherlock Holmes, I findmany tragic, some comic, a large number merely strange, but none commonplace; for, working as he did rather for the ove of his art than for the acquirement of wealth, he refused to associate himself with any investigation which did ot tend towards the unusual, and even the fantastic. Of all these varied cases, however, I cannot recall any which pesented more singular features than that which was associated with the well-known Surrey family of the Roylotts of Soke Moran. The events in question occurred in the early days of my association with Holmes, when we were sharing roos as bachelors in Baker Street. It is possible that I might have placed them upon record before, but a promise of serecy was made at the time, from which I have only been freed during the last month by the untimely death of the ladyto whom the pledge was given. It is perhaps as well that the facts should now come to light, for I have reasons to kow that there are widespread rumours as to the death of Dr. Grimesby Roylott which tend to make the matter even moreterrible than the truth.

It was early in April in the year '83 that I woke one morning to find Sherlock Holmes stnding, fully dressed, by the side of my bed. He was a late riser, as a rule, and as the clock on the mantelpiece shoed me that it was only a quarter-past seven, I blinked up at him in some surprise, and perhaps just a little resentmnt, for I was myself regular in my habits.

"Very sorry to knock you up, Watson," said he, "but it's the common lo this morning. Mrs. Hudson has been knocked up, she retorted upon me, and I on you."

"What is it, then--a fire?"
"No; a client. It seems that a young lady has arrived in a considerable state of excitement, who insists upon seeig me. She is waiting now in the sitting-room. Now, when young ladies wander about the metropolis at this hour of themorning, and knock sleepy people up out of their beds, I presume that it is something very pressing which they have o communicate. Should it prove to be an interesting case, you would, I am sure, wish to follow it from the outset. Ithought, at any rate, that I should call you and give you the chance."

"My dear fellow, I would not miss it for aything."

I had no keener pleasure than in following Holmes in his professional investigations, and in admiring th rapid deductions, as swift as intuitions, and yet always founded on a logical basis with which he unravelled the prblems which were submitted to him. I rapidly threw on my clothes and was ready in a few minutes to accompany my fried down to the sitting-room. A lady dressed in black and heavily veiled, who had been sitting in the window, rose as e entered.

"Good-morning, madam," said Holmes cheerily. "My name is Sherlock Holmes. This is my intimate friend ad associate, Dr. Watson, before whom you can speak as freely as before myself. Ha! I am glad to see that Mrs. Hudsonhas had the good sense to light the fire. Pray draw up to it, and I shall order you a cup of hot coffee, for I obsere that you are shivering."

"It is not cold which makes me shiver," said the woman in a low voice, changing her set as requested.

IX.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE ENGINEER'S THUMB


Of all the problems which hve been submitted to my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, for solution during the years of our intimacy, there were only wo which I was the means of introducing to his notice--that of Mr. Hatherley's thumb, and that of Colonel Warburton' madness. Of these the latter may have afforded a finer field for an acute and original observer, but the other was o strange in its inception and so dramatic in its details that it may be the more worthy of being placed upon record even if it gave my friend fewer openings for those deductive methods of reasoning by which he achieved such remarkale results. The story has, I believe, been told more than once in the newspapers, but, like all such narratives, itseffect is much less striking when set forth en bloc in a single half-column of print than when the facts slowly evole before your own eyes, and the mystery clears gradually away as each new discovery furnishes a step which leads on o the complete truth. At the time the circumstances made a deep impression upon me, and the lapse of two years has hrdly served to weaken the effect.

It was in the summer of '89, not long after my marriage, that the events occurrd which I am now about to summarise. I had returned to civil practice and had finally abandoned Holmes in his Baker treet rooms, although I continually visited him and occasionally even persuaded him to forgo his Bohemian habits so ar as to come and visit us. One of these, whom I had cured of a painful ad lingering disease, was never weary of advertising my virtues and of endeavouring to send me on every sufferer overwhom he might have any influence.

One morning, at a little before seven o'clock, I was awakened by the maid tappig at the door to announce that two men had come from Paddington and were waiting in the consulting-room. I dressed hrriedly, for I knew by experience that railway cases were seldom trivial, and hastened downstairs. As I descended, m old ally, the guard, came out of the room and closed the door tightly behind him.

"I've got him here," he whispeed, jerking his thumb over his shoulder; "he's all right."

I entered my consulting-room and found a gentleman seated by the table. He was quietly dressed in a suit of heather weed with a soft cloth cap which he had laid down upon my books. Round one of his hands he had a handkerchief wrappe, which was mottled all over with bloodstains. I came in by train this morning, and on inquiring atPaddington as to where I might find a doctor, a worthy fellow very kindly escorted me here. I gave the maid a card, ut I see that she has left it upon the side-table."

I took it up and glanced at it. "Mr. Victor Hatherley, hydrauic engineer, 16A, Victoria Street (3rd floor)." That was the name, style, and abode of my morning visitor. It was useless, however. He was off in one of those hysterical outbursts which come upon a srong nature when some great crisis is over and gone. Presently he came to himself once more, very weary and pale-looing.

He unwound the handkechief and held out his hand. It gave even my hardened nerves a shudder to look at it. There were four protruding finers and a horrid red, spongy surface where the thumb should have been. It had been hacked or torn right out from theroots.

"Excellent! You should have been a surgeon."

"It is a question of hydraulics, you see, and came within my own povince."

"A thing lke a cleaver," said he.

"You horrify me."

" 'To Eyford, in Berkshire. It is a little place near the borders of Oxfordshire, and within seven miles of Reading.There is a train from Paddington which would bring you there at about 11:15.'

X.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE NOBLE BACHELOR


The Lord St. Simon marriage, and its curious termination, have longceased to be a subject of interest in those exalted circles in which the unfortunate bridegroom moves. Fresh scandal have eclipsed it, and their more piquant details have drawn the gossips away from this four-year-old drama. As I hae reason to believe, however, that the full facts have never been revealed to the general public, and as my friend Serlock Holmes had a considerable share in clearing the matter up, I feel that no memoir of him would be complete witout some little sketch of this remarkable episode.

It was a few weeks before my own marriage, during the days whe I was still sharing rooms with Holmes in Baker Street, that he came home from an afternoon stroll to find a letter n the table waiting for him. I had remained indoors all day, for the weather had taken a sudden turn to rain, with hgh autumnal winds, and the Jezail bullet which I had brought back in one of my limbs as a relic of my Afghan campaig throbbed with dull persistence. With my body in one easy-chair and my legs upon another, I had surrounded myself wih a cloud of newspapers until at last, saturated with the news of the day, I tossed them all aside and lay listless,watching the huge crest and monogram upon the envelope upon the table and wondering lazily who my friend's noble corespondent could be.

"Here is a very fashionable epistle," I remarked as he entered. "Your morning letters, if I rmember right, were from a fish-monger and a tide-waiter."

"Yes, my correspondence has certainly the charm of varity," he answered, smiling, "and the humbler are usually the more interesting. This looks like one of those unwelcomesocial summonses which call upon a man either to be bored or to lie."

He broke the seal and glanced over the contnts.

"Oh, come, it may prove to be something of interest, after all."

"Not social, then?"

"No, distinctly pofessional."

"And from a noble client?"

"One of the highest in England."

"My dear fellow, I congratulate yo."

Then Lord St. Simon came to 'Friso, and we came to London, and a marriage was arranged, and Pa was very pleased, but I felt all the time that no man n this earth would ever take the place in my heart that had been given to my poor Frank.

"I saw it in a paper," explained the American. "It gve the name and the church but not where the lady lived."

Lord St. Simon had by no means relaxed his rigid attitude, but had listend with a frowning brow and a compressed lip to this long narrative.

"Oh, certainly, if it would give you any pleasure." He put out his hand and coldly grasped tht which she extended to him.

"It is always a joy to meet an American,Mr. Moulton, for I am one of those who believe that the folly of a monarch and the blundering of a minister in far-gne years will not prevent our children from being some day citizens of the same world-wide country under a flag whic shall be a quartering of the Union Jack with the Stars and Stripes."

"And how in the world did you find them?"

"It might have been difficult, but friend Lestrade held information in his hands the value of which he did not hiself know. Draw your chair up and hand me my violin, or the only problem we have still to solve is how to while away these bleak autumnal evenings."

XI.  THE ADVENTUR OF THE BERYL CORONET


"Holmes," said I as I stood one morning in our bow-window looking down the street, "here s a madman coming along. It seems rather sad that his relatives should allow him to come out alone."

My friend roe lazily from his armchair and stood with his hands in the pockets of his dressing-gown, looking over my shoulder. XII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPERBEECHES


"To the man who loves art for its own sake," remarked Sherlock Holmes, tossing aside the advertisement heet of the Daily Telegraph, "it is frequently in its least important and lowliest manifestations that the keenest peasure is to be derived. It is pleasant to me to observe, Watson, that you have so far grasped this truth that in thse little records of our cases which you have been good enough to draw up, and, I am bound to say, occasionally to ebellish, you have given prominence not so much to the many causes celebres and sensational trials in which I have fiured but rather to those incidents which may have been trivial in themselves, but which have given room for those faulties of deduction and of logical synthesis which I have made my special province."

"And yet," said I, smiling, I cannot quite hold myself absolved from the charge of sensationalism which has been urged against my records."

"ou have erred, perhaps," he observed, taking up a glowing cinder with the tongs and lighting with it the long cherrywood pipe which was wont to replace his clay when he was in a disputatious rather than a meditative mood--"you have rred perhaps in attempting to put colour and life into each of your statements instead of confining yourself to the ask of placing upon record that severe reasoning from cause to effect which is really the only notable feature aboutthe thing."

"It seems to me that I have done you full justice in the matter," I remarked with some coldness, for  was repelled by the egotism which I had more than once observed to be a strong factor in my friend's singular charater.

"No, it is not selfishness or conceit," said he, answering, as was his wont, my thoughts rather than my word. "If I claim full justice for my art, it is because it is an impersonal thing--a thing beyond myself. Crime is commn. Logic is rare. Therefore it is upon the logic rather than upon the crime that you should dwell. You have degradedwhat should have been a course of lectures into a series of tales."

It was a cold morning of the early spring, an we sat after breakfast on either side of a cheery fire in the old room at Baker Street. A thick fog rolled down beteen the lines of dun-coloured houses, and the opposing windows loomed like dark, shapeless blurs through the heavy yllow wreaths. Our gas was lit and shone on the white cloth and glimmer of china and metal, for the table had not bee cleared yet. Sherlock Holmes had been silent all the morning, dipping continuously into the advertisement columns o a succession of papers until at last, having apparently given up his search, he had emerged in no very sweet temperto lecture me upon my literary shortcomings.

"At the same time," he remarked after a pause, during which he had st puffing at his long pipe and gazing down into the fire, "you can hardly be open to a charge of sensationalism, forout of these cases which you have been so kind as to interest yourself in, a fair proportion do not treat of crime, n its legal sense, at all. The small matter in which I endeavoured to help the King of Bohemia, the singular experiece of Miss Mary Sutherland, the problem connected with the man with the twisted lip, and the incident of the noble bchelor, were all matters which are outside the pale of the law. His cheeks were red, his brow was all crinkled withanger, and the veins stood out at his temples with passion. He locked the door and hurried past me without a word ora look.

"This aroused my curiosity, so when I went out for a walk in the grounds with my charge, I strolled roundto the side from which I could see the windows of this part of the house. There were four of them in a row, three ofwhich were simply dirty, while the fourth was shuttered up. They were evidently all deserted. As I strolled up and dwn, glancing at them occasionally, Mr. Rucastle came out to me, looking as merry and jovial as ever.

" 'Ah!' saidhe, 'you must not think me rude if I passed you without a word, my dear young lady. I was preoccupied with business atters.'

"I assured him that I was not offended. 'By the way,' said I, 'you seem to have quite a suite of spare roms up there, and one of them has the shutters up.'

"He looked surprised and, as it seemed to me, a little startld at my remark.

" 'Photography is one of my hobbies,' said he. 'I have made my dark room up there. But, dear me! hat an observant young lady we have come upon. Who would have believed it? Who would have ever believed it?' He spok in a jesting tone, but there was no jest in his eyes as he looked at me. I read suspicion there and annoyance, but o jest.

"Well, Mr. Holmes, from the moment that I understood that there was something about that suite of rooms wich I was not to know, I was all on fire to go over them. It was not mere curiosity, though I have my share of that.It was more a feeling of duty--a feeling that some good might come from my penetrating to this place. They talk of wman's instinct; perhaps it was woman's instinct which gave me that feeling. At any rate, it was there, and I was keely on the lookout for any chance to pass the forbidden door.

"It was only yesterday that the chance came. I may tll you that, besides Mr. Rucastle, both Toller and his wife find something to do in these deserted rooms, and I oncesaw him carrying a large black linen bag with him through the door. Recently he has been drinking hard, and yesterda evening he was very drunk; and when I came upstairs there was the key in the door. I have no doubt at all that he hd left it there. Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle were both downstairs, and the child was with them, so that I had an admirableopportunity. I turned the key gently in the lock, opened the door, and slipped through.

"There was a little passae in front of me, unpapered and uncarpeted, which turned at a right angle at the farther end. Round this corner werethree doors in a line, the first and third of which were open. They each led into an empty room, dusty and cheerless with two windows in the one and one in the other, so thick with dirt that the evening light glimmered dimly throughthem. The centre door was closed, and across the outside of it had been fastened one of the broad bars of an iron be, padlocked at one end to a ring in the wall, and fastened at the other with stout cord. The door itself was locked s well, and the key was not there. This barricaded door corresponded clearly with the shuttered window outside, and et I could see by the glimmer from beneath it that the room was not in darkness. Evidently there was a skylight whic let in light from above. As I stood in the passage gazing at the sinister door and wondering what secret it might vil, I suddenly heard the sound of steps within the room and saw a shadow pass backward and forward against the littl slit of dim light which shone out from under the door. A mad, unreasoning terror rose up in me at the sight, Mr. Homes. My overstrung nerves failed me suddenly, and I turned and ran--ran as though some dreadful hand were behind me lutching at the skirt of my dress. I rushed down the passage, through the door, and straight into the arms of Mr. Ruastle, who was waiting outside.

" 'So,' said he, smiling, 'it was you, then. I thought that it must be when I sawthe door open.'

" 'Oh, I am so frightened!' I panted.

" 'My dear young lady! my dear young lady!'--you cannot hink how caressing and soothing his manner was--'and what has frightened you, my dear young lady?'

"But his voicewas just a little too coaxing. He overdid it. I was keenly on my guard against him.

" 'I was foolish enough to gointo the empty wing,' I answered. 'But it is so lonely and eerie in this dim light that I was frightened and ran outagain. Oh, it is so dreadfully still in there!'

" 'Only that?' said he, looking at me keenly.

" 'Why, what didyou think?' I asked.

" 'Why do you think that I lock this door?'

" 'I am sure that I do not know.'

" 'It isto keep people out who have no business there. Do you see?' He was still smiling in the most amiable manner.

" 'Iam sure if I had known--'

" 'Well, then, you know now. And if you ever put your foot over that threshold again'--ere in an instant the smile hardened into a grin of rage, and he glared down at me with the face of a demon--'I'll trow you to the mastiff.'

"I was so terrified that I do not know what I did. I suppose that I must have rushed pas him into my room. I remember nothing until I found myself lying on my bed trembling all over. Then I thought of you Mr. Holmes. I could not live there longer without some advice. I was frightened of the house, of the man, of the woan, of the servants, even of the child. They were all horrible to me. If I could only bring you down all would be wel. Of course I might have fled from the house, but my curiosity was almost as strong as my fears. My mind was soon mde up. I would send you a wire. I put on my hat and cloak, went down to the office, which is about half a mile from he house, and then returned, feeling very much easier. A horrible doubt came into my mind as I approached the door lst the dog might be loose, but I remembered that Toller had drunk himself into a state of insensibility that evening and I knew that he was the only one in the household who had any influence with the savage creature, or who would vnture to set him free. I slipped in in safety and lay awake half the night in my joy at the thought of seeing you. Ihad no difficulty in getting leave to come into Winchester this morning, but I must be back before three o'clock, fo Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle are going on a visit, and will be away all the evening, so that I must look after the child. ow I have told you all my adventures, Mr. Holmes, and I should be very glad if you could tell me what it all means, nd, above all, what I should do."

Holmes and I had listened spellbound to this extraordinary story. My friend ros now and paced up and down the room, his hands in his pockets, and an expression of the most profound gravity upon hs face.

"Is Toller still drunk?" he asked.

"Yes. I heard his wife tell Mrs. Rucastle that she could do nothingwith him."

"That is well. And the Rucastles go out to-night?"

"Yes."

"Is there a cellar with a good strong ock?"

"Yes, the wine-cellar."

"You seem to me to have acted all through this matter like a very brave and sensble girl, Miss Hunter. Do you think that you could perform one more feat? I should not ask it of you if I did not thnk you a quite exceptional woman."

"I will try. What is it?"

"We shall be at the Copper Beeches by seven o'clok, my friend and I. The Rucastles will be gone by that time, and Toller will, we hope, be incapable. There only remans Mrs. Toller, who might give the alarm. If you could send her into the cellar on some errand, and then turn the ke upon her, you would facilitate matters immensely."

"I will do it."

"Excellent! We shall then look thoroughly nto the affair. Of course there is only one feasible explanation. You have been brought there to personate someone, nd the real person is imprisoned in this chamber. That is obvious. As to who this prisoner is, I have no doubt that t is the daughter, Miss Alice Rucastle, if I remember right, who was said to have gone to America. You were chosen, oubtless, as resembling her in height, figure, and the colour of your hair. Hers had been cut off, very possibly in ome illness through which she has passed, and so, of course, yours had to be sacrificed also. By a curious chance yo came upon her tresses. The man in the road was undoubtedly some friend of hers--possibly her fiance--and no doubt, s you wore the girl's dress and were so like her, he was convinced from your laughter, whenever he saw you, and aftewards from your gesture, that Miss Rucastle was perfectly happy, and that she no longer desired his attentions. The og is let loose at night to prevent him from endeavouring to communicate with her. So much is fairly clear. The mostserious point in the case is the disposition of the child."

"What on earth has that to do with it?" I ejaculated.

"My dear Watson, you as a medical man are continually gaining light as to the tendencies of a child by the study f the parents. Don't you see that the converse is equally valid. I have frequently gained my first real insight intothe character of parents by studying their children. This child's disposition is abnormally cruel, merely for cruelt's sake, and whether he derives this from his smiling father, as I should suspect, or from his mother, it bodes evilfor the poor girl who is in their power."

"I am sure that you are right, Mr. Holmes," cried our client. "A thousad things come back to me which make me certain that you have hit it. Oh, let us lose not an instant in bringing helpto this poor creature."

"We must be circumspect, for we are dealing with a very cunning man. We can do nothing unil seven o'clock. At that hour we shall be with you, and it will not be long before we solve the mystery."

We wer as good as our word, for it was just seven when we reached the Copper Beeches, having put up our trap at a wayside ublic-house. The group of trees, with their dark leaves shining like burnished metal in the light of the setting sun were sufficient to mark the house even had Miss Hunter not been standing smiling on the door-step.

"Have you manged it?" asked Holmes.

A loud thudding noise came from somewhere downstairs. "That is Mrs. Toller in the cellar,"said she. "Her husband lies snoring on the kitchen rug. Here are his keys, which are the duplicates of Mr. Rucastle'."

"You have done well indeed!" cried Holmes with enthusiasm. "Now lead the way, and we shall soon see the end ofthis black business."

We passed up the stair, unlocked the door, followed on down a passage, and found ourselves n front of the barricade which Miss Hunter had described. Holmes cut the cord and removed the transverse bar. Then h tried the various keys in the lock, but without success. No sound came from within, and at the silence Holmes' faceclouded over.

"I trust that we are not too late," said he. "I think, Miss Hunter, that we had better go in withou you. Now, Watson, put your shoulder to it, and we shall see whether we cannot make our way in."

It was an old rikety door and gave at once before our united strength. Together we rushed into the room. It was empty. There was no urniture save a little pallet bed, a small table, and a basketful of linen. The skylight above was open, and the prioner gone.

"There has been some villainy here," said Holmes; "this beauty has guessed Miss Hunter's intentions an has carried his victim off."

"But how?"

"Through the skylight. We shall soon see how he managed it." He swunghimself up onto the roof. "Ah, yes," he cried, "here's the end of a long light ladder against the eaves. That is howhe did it."

"But it is impossible," said Miss Hunter; "the ladder was not there when the Rucastles went away."
"He has come back and done it. I tell you that he is a clever and dangerous man. I should not be very much surprisedif this were he whose step I hear now upon the stair. I think, Watson, that it would be as well for you to have yourpistol ready."

The words were hardly out of his mouth before a man appeared at the door of the room, a very fat ad burly man, with a heavy stick in his hand. Miss Hunter screamed and shrunk against the wall at the sight of him, bt Sherlock Holmes sprang forward and confronted him.

"You villain!" said he, "where's your daughter?"

The fat an cast his eyes round, and then up at the open skylight.

"It is for me to ask you that," he shrieked, "you thievs! Spies and thieves! I have caught you, have I? You are in my power. I'll serve you!" He turned and clattered down he stairs as hard as he could go.

"He's gone for the dog!" cried Miss Hunter.

"I have my revolver," said I.
"Better close the front door," cried Holmes, and we all rushed down the stairs together. We had hardly reached the hll when we heard the baying of a hound, and then a scream of agony, with a horrible worrying sound which it was dreaful to listen to. An elderly man with a red face and shaking limbs came staggering out at a side door.

"My God!" e cried. "Someone has loosed the dog. It's not been fed for two days. Quick, quick, or it'll be too late!"

Holmesand I rushed out and round the angle of the house, with Toller hurrying behind us. There was the huge famished brute its black muzzle buried in Rucastle's throat, while he writhed and screamed upon the ground. Running up, I blew itsbrains out, and it fell over with its keen white teeth still meeting in the great creases of his neck. With much labur we separated them and carried him, living but horribly mangled, into the house. We laid him upon the drawing-roomsofa, and having dispatched the sobered Toller to bear the news to his wife, I did what I could to relieve his pain.We were all assembled round him when the door opened, and a tall, gaunt woman entered the room.

"Mrs. Toller!" cred Miss Hunter.

"Yes, miss. Mr. Rucastle let me out when he came back before he went up to you. Ah, miss, it is apity you didn't let me know what you were planning, for I would have told you that your pains were wasted."

"Ha!"said Holmes, looking keenly at her. "It is clear that Mrs. Toller knows more about this matter than anyone else."
"Yes, sir, I do, and I am ready enough to tell what I know."

"Then, pray, sit down, and let us hear it for there re several points on which I must confess that I am still in the dark."

"I will soon make it clear to you," said he; "and I'd have done so before now if I could ha' got out from the cellar. If there's police-court business over tis, you'll remember that I was the one that stood your friend, and that I was Miss Alice's friend too.

"She was nver happy at home, Miss Alice wasn't, from the time that her father married again. She was slighted like and had no ay in anything, but it never really became bad for her until after she met Mr. Fowler at a friend's house. As well a I could learn, Miss Alice had rights of her own by will, but she was so quiet and patient, she was, that she never aid a word about them but just left everything in Mr. Rucastle's hands. He knew he was safe with her; but when therewas a chance of a husband coming forward, who would ask for all that the law would give him, then her father thoughtit time to put a stop on it. He wanted her to sign a paper, so that whether she married or not, he could use her mony. When she wouldn't do it, he kept on worrying her until she got brain-fever, and for six weeks was at death's door Then she got better at last, all worn to a shadow, and with her beautiful hair cut off; but that didn't make no chage in her young man, and he stuck to her as true as man could be."

"Ah," said Holmes, "I think that what you havebeen good enough to tell us makes the matter fairly clear, and that I can deduce all that remains. Mr. Rucastle then I presume, took to this system of imprisonment?"

"Yes, sir."

"And brought Miss Hunter down from London in ordr to get rid of the disagreeable persistence of Mr. Fowler."

"That was it, sir."

"But Mr. Fowler being a perseering man, as a good seaman should be, blockaded the house, and having met you succeeded by certain arguments, metalic or otherwise, in convincing you that your interests were the same as his."

"Mr. Fowler was a very kind-spoken,free-handed gentleman," said Mrs. Toller serenely.

"And in this way he managed that your good man should have no ant of drink, and that a ladder should be ready at the moment when your master had gone out."

"You have it, sir, ust as it happened."

"I am sure we owe you an apology, Mrs. Toller," said Holmes, "for you have certainly clearedup everything which puzzled us. And here comes the country surgeon and Mrs. Rucastle, so I think, Watson, that we ha best escort Miss Hunter back to Winchester, as it seems to me that our locus standi now is rather a questionable on."

And thus was solved the mystery of the sinister house with the copper beeches in front of the door. Mr. Rucaste survived, but was always a broken man, kept alive solely through the care of his devoted wife. They still live wit their old servants, who probably know so much of Rucastle's past life that he finds it difficult to part from them.Mr. Fowler and Miss Rucastle were married, by special license, in Southampton the day after their flight, and he is ow the holder of a government appointment in the island of Mauritius. As to Miss Violet Hunter, my friend Holmes, raher to my disappointment, manifested no further interest in her when once she had ceased to be the centre of one of is problems, and she is now the head of a private school at Walsall, where I believe that she has met with considerale success.

PREFACE


As things now stand, the course f instruction in American history in
our public schools embraces three distinct treatments of the subject.
Three sparate books are used. First, there is the primary book, which
is usually a very condensed narrative with emphasis n biographies and
anecdotes. Second, there is the advanced text for the seventh or eighth
grade, generally speakin, an expansion of the elementary book by the
addition of forty or fifty thousand words. Finally, there is the highschool manual. This, too, ordinarily follows the beaten path, giving
fuller accounts of the same events and charactrs. To put it bluntly, we
do not assume that our children obtain permanent possessions from their
study of historyin the lower grades. If mathematicians followed the
same method, high school texts on algebra and geometry would inlude the
multiplication table and fractions.

There is, of course, a ready answer to the criticism advanced above It
is that teachers have learned from bitter experience how little history
their pupils retain as they pass alongthe regular route. No teacher of
history will deny this. Still it is a standing challenge to existing
methods of hstorical instruction. If the study of history cannot be
made truly progressive like the study of mathematics, sciene, and
languages, then the historians assume a grave responsibility in adding
their subject to the already overloaed curriculum. If the successive
historical texts are only enlarged editions of the first text--more
facts, more dtes, more words--then history deserves most of the sharp
criticism which it is receiving from teachers of science, ivics, and
economics.

In this condition of affairs we find our justification for offering a
new high school tex in American history. Our first contribution is one
of omission. The time-honored stories of exploration and the
bographies of heroes are left out. We frankly hold that, if pupils know
little or nothing about Columbus, Cortes, Maellan, or Captain John
Smith by the time they reach the high school, it is useless to tell the
same stories for pehaps the fourth time. It is worse than useless. It
is an offense against the teachers of those subjects that are
dmonstrated to be progressive in character.

In the next place we have omitted all descriptions of battles. Our
resons for this are simple. The strategy of a campaign or of a single
battle is a highly technical, and usually a higly controversial, matter
about which experts differ widely. In the field of military and naval
operations most wriers and teachers of history are mere novices. To
dispose of Gettysburg or the Wilderness in ten lines or ten pages s
equally absurd to the serious student of military affairs. Any one who
compares the ordinary textbook account ofa single Civil War campaign
with the account given by Ropes, for instance, will ask for no further
comment. No youh called upon to serve our country in arms would think
of turning to a high school manual for information about theart of
warfare. The dramatic scene or episode, so useful in arousing the
interest of the immature pupil, seems outof place in a book that
deliberately appeals to boys and girls on the very threshold of life's
serious responsibilties.

It is not upon negative features, however, that we rest our case. It is
rather upon constructive features.

_First._ We have written a topical, not a narrative, history. We have
tried to set forth the important aspects, roblems, and movements of
each period, bringing in the narrative rather by way of illustration.

_Second._ We hav emphasized those historical topics which help to
explain how our nation has come to be what it is to-day.

_Thir._ We have dwelt fully upon the social and economic aspects of our
history, especially in relation to the politics f each period.

_Fourth._ We have treated the causes and results of wars, the problems
of financing and sustainin armed forces, rather than military strategy.
These are the subjects which belong to a history for civilians. These
are matters which civilians can understand--matters which they must
understand, if they are to play well their par in war and peace.

_Fifth._ By omitting the period of exploration, we have been able to
enlarge the treatment ofour own time. We have given special attention
to the history of those current questions which must form the subject
matter of sound instruction in citizenship.

_Sixth._ We have borne in mind that America, with all her unique
chracteristics, is a part of a general civilization. Accordingly we
have given diplomacy, foreign affairs, world relaions, and the
reciprocal influences of nations their appropriate place.

_Seventh._ We have deliberately aimed atstandards of maturity. The
study of a mere narrative calls mainly for the use of the memory. We
have aimed to stimlate habits of analysis, comparison, association,
reflection, and generalization--habits calculated to enlarge as wll as
inform the mind. We have been at great pains to make our text clear,
simple, and direct; but we have earnesty sought to stretch the
intellects of our readers--to put them upon their mettle. Most of them
will receive the lat of their formal instruction in the high school.
The world will soon expect maturity from them. Their achievementswill
depend upon the possession of other powers than memory alone. The
effectiveness of their citizenship in our rpublic will be measured by
the excellence of their judgment as well as the fullness of their
information.

     .A.B.
     M.R.B.

     NEW YORK CITY,
     February 8, 1921.

HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES




PART I. THE COLONIAL PERIOD




CHAPTER I

THE GREAT MIGRATION TO AMERICA


The tide of migration that set in toward the shores of Norh America
during the early years of the seventeenth century was but one phase in
the restless and eternal movementof mankind upon the surface of the
earth. The ancient Greeks flung out their colonies in every direction,
westwardas far as Gaul, across the Mediterranean, and eastward into
Asia Minor, perhaps to the very confines of India. The omans, supported
by their armies and their government, spread their dominion beyond the
narrow lands of Italy unti it stretched from the heather of Scotland to
the sands of Arabia. The Teutonic tribes, from their home beyond theDanube and the Rhine, poured into the empire of the Caesars and made the
beginnings of modern Europe. Of this greatsweep of races and empires
the settlement of America was merely a part. And it was, moreover, only
one aspect of te expansion which finally carried the peoples, the
institutions, and the trade of Europe to the very ends of the eath.

In one vital point, it must be noted, American colonization differed
from that of the ancients. The Greeks uually carried with them
affection for the government they left behind and sacred fire from the
altar of the parentcity; but thousands of the immigrants who came to
America disliked the state and disowned the church of the mothercountry. They established compacts of government for themselves and set
up altars of their own. They sought not onl new soil to till but also
political and religious liberty for themselves and their children.


THE AGENCIES OF MERICAN COLONIZATION

It was no light matter for the English to cross three thousand miles of
water and found homs in the American wilderness at the opening of the
seventeenth century. Ships, tools, and supplies called for huge utlays
of money. Stores had to be furnished in quantities sufficient to sustain
the life of the settlers until the could gather harvests of their own.
Artisans and laborers of skill and industry had to be induced to risk
the hazrds of the new world. Soldiers were required for defense and
mariners for the exploration of inland waters. Leadersof good judgment,
adept in managing men, had to be discovered. Altogether such an
enterprise demanded capital largr than the ordinary merchant or
gentleman could amass and involved risks more imminent than he dared to
assume. Thugh in later days, after initial tests had been made, wealthy
proprietors were able to establish colonies on their wn account, it was
the corporation that furnished the capital and leadership in the
beginning.

=The Trading Comany.=--English pioneers in exploration found an
instrument for colonization in companies of merchant adventurers, wich
had long been employed in carrying on commerce with foreign countries.
Such a corporation was composed of manypersons of different ranks of
society--noblemen, merchants, and gentlemen--who banded together for a
particular unertaking, each contributing a sum of money and sharing in
the profits of the venture. It was organized under royal uthority; it
received its charter, its grant of land, and its trading privileges from
the king and carried on its perations under his supervision and
control. The charter named all the persons originally included in the
corporaton and gave them certain powers in the management of its
affairs, including the right to admit new members. The comany was in
fact a little government set up by the king. When the members of the
corporation remained in England, a in the case of the Virginia Company,
they operated through agents sent to the colony. When they came over the
sea themselves and settled in America, as in the case of Massachusetts,
they became the direct government of the county they possessed. The
stockholders in that instance became the voters and the governor, the
chief magistrate.

[llustration: JOHN WINTHROP, GOVERNOR OF THE MASSACHUSETTS BAY
COMPANY]

Four of the thirteen colonies in America wed their origins to the
trading corporation. It was the London Company, created by King James I,
in 1606, that lad during the following year the foundations of Virginia
at Jamestown. It was under the auspices of their West IndiaCompany,
chartered in 1621, that the Dutch planted the settlements of the New
Netherland in the valley of the Hudsn. The founders of Massachusetts
were Puritan leaders and men of affairs whom King Charles I incorporated
in 1629 nder the title: "The governor and company of the Massachusetts
Bay in New England." In this case the law did but inorporate a group
drawn together by religious ties. "We must be knit together as one man,"
wrote John Winthrop, thefirst Puritan governor in America. Far to the
south, on the banks of the Delaware River, a Swedish commercial compay
in 1638 made the beginnings of a settlement, christened New Sweden; it
was destined to pass under the rule of th Dutch, and finally under the
rule of William Penn as the proprietary colony of Delaware.

In a certain sense, Gergia may be included among the "company
colonies." It was, however, originally conceived by the moving spirit,
Jams Oglethorpe, as an asylum for poor men, especially those imprisoned
for debt. To realize this humane purpose, he scured from King George
II, in 1732, a royal charter uniting several gentlemen, including
himself, into "one body plitic and corporate," known as the "Trustees
for establishing the colony of Georgia in America." In the structure o
their organization and their methods of government, the trustees did not
differ materially from the regular compaies created for trade and
colonization. Though their purposes were benevolent, their transactions
had to be under he forms of law and according to the rules of business.

=The Religious Congregation.=--A second agency which figued largely in
the settlement of America was the religious brotherhood, or
congregation, of men and women brought tgether in the bonds of a common
religious faith. By one of the strange fortunes of history, this
institution, founed in the early days of Christianity, proved to be a
potent force in the origin and growth of self-government in a and far
away from Galilee. "And the multitude of them that believed were of one
heart and of one soul," we are tol in the Acts describing the Church at
Jerusalem. "We are knit together as a body in a most sacred covenant of
the ord ... by virtue of which we hold ourselves strictly tied to all
care of each other's good and of the whole," wrot John Robinson, a
leader among the Pilgrims who founded their tiny colony of Plymouth in
1620. The Mayflower Compat, so famous in American history, was but a
written and signed agreement, incorporating the spirit of obedience tothe common good, which served as a guide to self-government until
Plymouth was annexed to Massachusetts in 1691.
[Illustration: THE ORIGINAL GRANTS]

Three other colonies, all of which retained their identity until the eve
of he American Revolution, likewise sprang directly from the
congregations of the faithful: Rhode Island, Connecticut,and New
Hampshire, mainly offshoots from Massachusetts. They were founded by
small bodies of men and women, "unite in solemn covenants with the
Lord," who planted their settlements in the wilderness. Not until many a
year after oger Williams and Anne Hutchinson conducted their followers
to the Narragansett country was Rhode Island granted a harter of
incorporation (1663) by the crown. Not until long after the congregation
of Thomas Hooker from Newtown bazed the way into the Connecticut River
Valley did the king of England give Connecticut a charter of its own
(1662 and a place among the colonies. Half a century elapsed before the
towns laid out beyond the Merrimac River by emigants from Massachusetts
were formed into the royal province of New Hampshire in 1679.

Even when Connecticut was hartered, the parchment and sealing wax of
the royal lawyers did but confirm rights and habits of self-government
nd obedience to law previously established by the congregations. The
towns of Hartford, Windsor, and Wethersfield hd long lived happily
under their "Fundamental Orders" drawn up by themselves in 1639; so had
the settlers dwelt pecefully at New Haven under their "Fundamental
Articles" drafted in the same year. The pioneers on the Connecticut
hore had no difficulty in agreeing that "the Scriptures do hold forth a
perfect rule for the direction and governmet of all men."

=The Proprietor.=--A third and very important colonial agency was the
proprietor, or proprietary.As the name, associated with the word
"property," implies, the proprietor was a person to whom the king
granted prperty in lands in North America to have, hold, use, and enjoy
for his own benefit and profit, with the right to han the estate down
to his heirs in perpetual succession. The proprietor was a rich and
powerful person, prepared to urnish or secure the capital, collect the
ships, supply the stores, and assemble the settlers necessary to found
ad sustain a plantation beyond the seas. Sometimes the proprietor
worked alone. Sometimes two or more were associate like partners in the
common undertaking.

Five colonies, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and the Carolinas,owe their formal origins, though not always their first settlements, nor
in most cases their prosperity, to the prorietary system. Maryland,
established in 1634 under a Catholic nobleman, Lord Baltimore, and
blessed with religiou toleration by the act of 1649, flourished under
the mild rule of proprietors until it became a state in the Americn
union. New Jersey, beginning its career under two proprietors, Berkeley
and Carteret, in 1664, passed under the irect government of the crown
in 1702. Pennsylvania was, in a very large measure, the product of the
generous spirt and tireless labors of its first proprietor, the leader
of the Friends, William Penn, to whom it was granted in 181 and in
whose family it remained until 1776. The two Carolinas were first
organized as one colony in 1663 under he government and patronage of
eight proprietors, including Lord Clarendon; but after more than half a
century bot became royal provinces governed by the king.

[Illustration: WILLIAM PENN, PROPRIETOR OF PENNSYLVANIA]


THE CLONIAL PEOPLES

=The English.=--In leadership and origin the thirteen colonies, except
New York and Delaware, wer English. During the early days of all, save
these two, the main, if not the sole, current of immigration was fromEngland. The colonists came from every walk of life. They were men,
women, and children of "all sorts and condition." The major portion
were yeomen, or small land owners, farm laborers, and artisans. With
them were merchants and entlemen who brought their stocks of goods or
their fortunes to the New World. Scholars came from Oxford and
Cambrdge to preach the gospel or to teach. Now and then the son of an
English nobleman left his baronial hall behind andcast his lot with
America. The people represented every religious faith--members of the
Established Church of Englnd; Puritans who had labored to reform that
church; Separatists, Baptists, and Friends, who had left it altogether;
and Catholics, who clung to the religion of their fathers.

New England was almost purely English. During the yeas between 1629 and
1640, the period of arbitrary Stuart government, about twenty thousand
Puritans emigrated to Amrica, settling in the colonies of the far
North. Although minor additions were made from time to time, the greaterportion of the New England people sprang from this original stock.
Virginia, too, for a long time drew nearly all hr immigrants from
England alone. Not until the eve of the Revolution did other
nationalities, mainly the Scotch-Irsh and Germans, rival the English in
numbers.

The populations of later English colonies--the Carolinas, New York
Pennsylvania, and Georgia--while receiving a steady stream of
immigration from England, were constantly augmentedby wanderers from
the older settlements. New York was invaded by Puritans from New England
in such numbers as to cuse the Anglican clergymen there to lament that
"free thinking spreads almost as fast as the Church." North Carolin was
first settled toward the northern border by immigrants from Virginia.
Some of the North Carolinians, particulrly the Quakers, came all the
way from New England, tarrying in Virginia only long enough to learn how
little theywere wanted in that Anglican colony.

=The Scotch-Irish.=--Next to the English in numbers and influence were
the cotch-Irish, Presbyterians in belief, English in tongue. Both
religious and economic reasons sent them across the sa. Their Scotch
ancestors, in the days of Cromwell, had settled in the north of Ireland
whence the native Irish ha been driven by the conqueror's sword. There
the Scotch nourished for many years enjoying in peace their own form o
religion and growing prosperous in the manufacture of fine linen and
woolen cloth. Then the blow fell. Toward theend of the seventeenth
century their religious worship was put under the ban and the export of
their cloth was foridden by the English Parliament. Within two decades
twenty thousand Scotch-Irish left Ulster alone, for America; an all
during the eighteenth century the migration continued to be heavy.
Although no exact record was kept, it is rckoned that the Scotch-Irish
and the Scotch who came directly from Scotland, composed one-sixth of
the entire Amercan population on the eve of the Revolution.

[Illustration: SETTLEMENTS OF GERMAN AND SCOTCH-IRISH
IMMIGRANTS]

These newcomers in America made their homes chiefly in New Jersey,
Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, and the Carolnas. Coming late upon
the scene, they found much of the land immediately upon the seaboard
already taken up. For tis reason most of them became frontier people
settling the interior and upland regions. There they cleared the land
laid out their small farms, and worked as "sturdy yeomen on the soil,"
hardy, industrious, and independent in spiit, sharing neither the
luxuries of the rich planters nor the easy life of the leisurely
merchants. To their agriclture they added woolen and linen
manufactures, which, flourishing in the supple fingers of their tireless
women, ade heavy inroads upon the trade of the English merchants in
the colonies. Of their labors a poet has sung:

       "O, willing hands to toil;
    Strong natures tuned to the harvest-song and bound to the kindly soil;
    Bold ioneers for the wilderness, defenders in the field."

=The Germans.=--Third among the colonists in order of numerial
importance were the Germans. From the very beginning, they appeared in
colonial records. A number of the artisas and carpenters in the first
Jamestown colony were of German descent. Peter Minuit, the famous
governor of New Moherland, was a German from Wesel on the Rhine, and
Jacob Leisler, leader of a popular uprising against the provincil
administration of New York, was a German from Frankfort-on-Main. The
wholesale migration of Germans began with te founding of Pennsylvania.
Penn was diligent in searching for thrifty farmers to cultivate his
lands and he made  special effort to attract peasants from the Rhine
country. A great association, known as the Frankfort Company, boght
more than twenty thousand acres from him and in 1684 established a
center at Germantown for the distribution o German immigrants. In old
New York, Rhinebeck-on-the-Hudson became a similar center for
distribution. All the wayfrom Maine to Georgia inducements were offered
to the German farmers and in nearly every colony were to be found, i
time, German settlements. In fact the migration became so large that
German princes were frightened at the loss o so many subjects and
England was alarmed by the influx of foreigners into her overseas
dominions. Yet nothing coud stop the movement. By the end of the
colonial period, the number of Germans had risen to more than two
hundred tousand.

The majority of them were Protestants from the Rhine region, and South
Germany. Wars, religious controvesies, oppression, and poverty drove
them forth to America. Though most of them were farmers, there were also
amongthem skilled artisans who contributed to the rapid growth of
industries in Pennsylvania. Their iron, glass, paper, nd woolen mills,
dotted here and there among the thickly settled regions, added to the
wealth and independence of he province.

[Illustration: _From an old print_

A GLIMPSE OF OLD GERMANTOWN]

Unlike the Scotch-Irish, the Grmans did not speak the language of the
original colonists or mingle freely with them. They kept to themselves,
bult their own schools, founded their own newspapers, and published
their own books. Their clannish habits often irriated their neighbors
and led to occasional agitations against "foreigners." However, no
serious collisions seem tohave occurred; and in the days of the
Revolution, German soldiers from Pennsylvania fought in the patriot
armies sde by side with soldiers from the English and Scotch-Irish
sections.

=Other Nationalities.=--Though the English,the Scotch-Irish, and the
Germans made up the bulk of the colonial population, there were other
racial strains as ell, varying in numerical importance but contributing
their share to colonial life.

From France came the Huguenos fleeing from the decree of the king which
inflicted terrible penalties upon Protestants.

From "Old Ireland" cae thousands of native Irish, Celtic in race and
Catholic in religion. Like their Scotch-Irish neighbors to the nort,
they revered neither the government nor the church of England imposed
upon them by the sword. How many came we d not know, but shipping
records of the colonial period show that boatload after boatload left
the southern and easern shores of Ireland for the New World.
Undoubtedly thousands of their passengers were Irish of the native
stock.This surmise is well sustained by the constant appearance of
Celtic names in the records of various colonies.

[Ilustration:_From an old print_

OLD DUTCH FORT AND ENGLISH CHURCH NEAR ALBANY]

The Jews, then as ever engaged i their age-long battle for religious
and economic toleration, found in the American colonies, not complete
liberty but certainly more freedom than they enjoyed in England,
France, Spain, or Portugal. The English law did not actualy recognize
their right to live in any of the dominions, but owing to the easy-going
habits of the Americans theywere allowed to filter into the seaboard
towns. The treatment they received there varied. On one occasion the
mayo and council of New York forbade them to sell by retail and on
another prohibited the exercise of their religious wrship. Newport,
Philadelphia, and Charleston were more hospitable, and there large
Jewish colonies, consisting pricipally of merchants and their families,
flourished in spite of nominal prohibitions of the law.

Though the smal Swedish colony in Delaware was quickly submerged
beneath the tide of English migration, the Dutch in New York contnued
to hold their own for more than a hundred years after the English
conquest in 1664. At the end of the colonia period over one-half of the
170,000 inhabitants of the province were descendants of the original
Dutch--still disinct enough to give a decided cast to the life and
manners of New York. Many of them clung as tenaciously to their other
tongue as they did to their capacious farmhouses or their Dutch ovens;
but they were slowly losing their idetity as the English pressed in
beside them to farm and trade.

The melting pot had begun its historic mission.

THE PROCESS OF COLONIZATION

Considered from one side, colonization, whatever the motives of the
emigrants, wasan economic matter. It involved the use of capital to pay
for their passage, to sustain them on the voyage, and to tart them on
the way of production. Under this stern economic necessity, Puritans,
Scotch-Irish, Germans, and all ere alike laid.

=Immigrants Who Paid Their Own Way.=--Many of the immigrants to America
in colonial days were caitalists themselves, in a small or a large way,
and paid their own passage. What proportion of the colonists were ale
to finance their voyage across the sea is a matter of pure conjecture.
Undoubtedly a very considerable number culd do so, for we can trace the
family fortunes of many early settlers. Henry Cabot Lodge is authority
for the staement that "the settlers of New England were drawn from the
country gentlemen, small farmers, and yeomanry of the mther
country.... Many of the emigrants were men of wealth, as the old lists
show, and all of them, with few exceptons, were men of property and
good standing. They did not belong to the classes from which emigration
is usually spplied, for they all had a stake in the country they left
behind." Though it would be interesting to know how accurte this
statement is or how applicable to the other colonies, no study has as
yet been made to gratify that interet. For the present it is an
unsolved problem just how many of the colonists were able to bear the
cost of their ow transfer to the New World.

=Indentured Servants.=--That at least tens of thousands of immigrants
were unable topay for their passage is established beyond the shadow of
a doubt by the shipping records that have come down to us The great
barrier in the way of the poor who wanted to go to America was the cost
of the sea voyage. To overcome his difficulty a plan was worked out
whereby shipowners and other persons of means furnished the passage
money to mmigrants in return for their promise, or bond, to work for a
term of years to repay the sum advanced. This system as called
indentured servitude.

It is probable that the number of bond servants exceeded the original
twenty thusand Puritans, the yeomen, the Virginia gentlemen, and the
Huguenots combined. All the way down the coast from Masachusetts to
Georgia were to be found in the fields, kitchens, and workshops, men,
women, and children serving outterms of bondage generally ranging from
five to seven years. In the proprietary colonies the proportion of bond
sevants was very high. The Baltimores, Penns, Carterets, and other
promoters anxiously sought for workers of every naionality to till
their fields, for land without labor was worth no more than land in the
moon. Hence the gates of he proprietary colonies were flung wide open.
Every inducement was offered to immigrants in the form of cheap land,
and special efforts were made to increase the population by importing
servants. In Pennsylvania, it was not uncommn to find a master with
fifty bond servants on his estate. It has been estimated that two-thirds
of all the immigrnts into Pennsylvania between the opening of the
eighteenth century and the outbreak of the Revolution were in bondge.
In the other Middle colonies the number was doubtless not so large; but
it formed a considerable part of the ppulation.

The story of this traffic in white servants is one of the most striking
things in the history of labor Bondmen differed from the serfs of the
feudal age in that they were not bound to the soil but to the master.
Theylikewise differed from the negro slaves in that their servitude had
a time limit. Still they were subject to many secial disabilities. It
was, for instance, a common practice to impose on them penalties far
heavier than were impoed upon freemen for the same offense. A free
citizen of Pennsylvania who indulged in horse racing and gambling waslet off with a fine; a white servant guilty of the same unlawful conduct
was whipped at the post and fined as well.

The ordinary life of the white servant was also severely restricted. A
bondman could not marry without his maste's consent; nor engage in
trade; nor refuse work assigned to him. For an attempt to escape or
indeed for any infration of the law, the term of service was extended.
The condition of white bondmen in Virginia, according to Lodge, was
little better than that of slaves. Loose indentures and harsh laws put
them at the mercy of their masters." Itwould not be unfair to add that
such was their lot in all other colonies. Their fate depended upon the
temper of teir masters.

Cruel as was the system in many ways, it gave thousands of people in the
Old World a chance to reac the New--an opportunity to wrestle with fate
for freedom and a home of their own. When their weary years of servitde
were over, if they survived, they might obtain land of their own or
settle as free mechanics in the towns. For any a bondman the gamble
proved to be a losing venture because he found himself unable to rise
out of the state ofpoverty and dependence into which his servitude
carried him. For thousands, on the contrary, bondage proved to be areal
avenue to freedom and prosperity. Some of the best citizens of America
have the blood of indentured servants n their veins.

=The Transported--Involuntary Servitude.=--In their anxiety to secure
settlers, the companies andproprietors having colonies in America
either resorted to or connived at the practice of kidnapping men, women,
an children from the streets of English cities. In 1680 it was
officially estimated that "ten thousand persons were sirited away" to
America. Many of the victims of the practice were young children, for
the traffic in them was highy profitable. Orphans and dependents were
sometimes disposed of in America by relatives unwilling to support them.In a single year, 1627, about fifteen hundred children were shipped to
Virginia.

In this gruesome business therelurked many tragedies, and very few
romances. Parents were separated from their children and husbands from
their wves. Hundreds of skilled artisans--carpenters, smiths, and
weavers--utterly disappeared as if swallowed up by death A few thus
dragged off to the New World to be sold into servitude for a term of
five or seven years later became rosperous and returned home with
fortunes. In one case a young man who was forcibly carried over the sea
lived to ake his way back to England and establish his claim to a
peerage.

Akin to the kidnapped, at least in economic poition, were convicts
deported to the colonies for life in lieu of fines and imprisonment. The
Americans protested igorously but ineffectually against this practice.
Indeed, they exaggerated its evils, for many of the "criminals" ere
only mild offenders against unduly harsh and cruel laws. A peasant
caught shooting a rabbit on a lord's estateor a luckless servant girl
who purloined a pocket handkerchief was branded as a criminal along with
sturdy thievesand incorrigible rascals. Other transported offenders
were "political criminals"; that is, persons who criticized o opposed
the government. This class included now Irish who revolted against
British rule in Ireland; now Cavalierswho championed the king against
the Puritan revolutionists; Puritans, in turn, dispatched after the
monarchy was rstored; and Scotch and English subjects in general who
joined in political uprisings against the king.

=The Afrian Slaves.=--Rivaling in numbers, in the course of time, the
indentured servants and whites carried to America agaist their will
were the African negroes brought to America and sold into slavery. When
this form of bondage was firt introduced into Virginia in 1619, it was
looked upon as a temporary necessity to be discarded with the increase
f the white population. Moreover it does not appear that those planters
who first bought negroes at the auction blok intended to establish a
system of permanent bondage. Only by a slow process did chattel slavery
take firm root ad become recognized as the leading source of the labor
supply. In 1650, thirty years after the introduction of slavry, there
were only three hundred Africans in Virginia.

The great increase in later years was due in no small mesure to the
inordinate zeal for profits that seized slave traders both in Old and in
New England. Finding it relatvely easy to secure negroes in Africa,
they crowded the Southern ports with their vessels. The English Royal
Africn Company sent to America annually between 1713 and 1743 from five
to ten thousand slaves. The ship owners of New Egland were not far
behind their English brethren in pushing this extraordinary traffic.

As the proportion of thenegroes to the free white population steadily
rose, and as whole sections were overrun with slaves and slave trader,
the Southern colonies grew alarmed. In 1710, Virginia sought to curtail
the importation by placing a duty of $5 n each slave. This effort was
futile, for the royal governor promptly vetoed it. From time to time
similar bills wre passed, only to meet with royal disapproval. South
Carolina, in 1760, absolutely prohibited importation; but themeasure
was killed by the British crown. As late as 1772, Virginia, not daunted
by a century of rebuffs, sent to Gorge III a petition in this vein:
"The importation of slaves into the colonies from the coast of Africa
hath long een considered as a trade of great inhumanity and under its
present encouragement, we have too much reason to fear,will endanger
the very existence of Your Majesty's American dominions.... Deeply
impressed with these sentiments, e most humbly beseech Your Majesty to
remove all those restraints on Your Majesty's governors of this colony
whichinhibit their assenting to such laws as might check so very
pernicious a commerce."

All such protests were withot avail. The negro population grew by leaps
and bounds, until on the eve of the Revolution it amounted to more than
half a million. In five states--Maryland, Virginia, the two Carolinas,
and Georgia--the slaves nearly equalled or ctually exceeded the whites
in number. In South Carolina they formed almost two-thirds of the
population. Even in he Middle colonies of Delaware and Pennsylvania
about one-fifth of the inhabitants were from Africa. To the North, he
proportion of slaves steadily diminished although chattel servitude was
on the same legal footing as in the Souh. In New York approximately one
in six and in New England one in fifty were negroes, including a few
freedmen.
The climate, the soil, the commerce, and the industry of the North were
all unfavorable to the growth of a servile opulation. Still, slavery,
though sectional, was a part of the national system of economy. Northern
ships carried laves to the Southern colonies and the produce of the
plantations to Europe. "If the Northern states will consult teir
interest, they will not oppose the increase in slaves which will
increase the commodities of which they will bcome the carriers," said
John Rutledge, of South Carolina, in the convention which framed the
Constitution of the nited States. "What enriches a part enriches the
whole and the states are the best judges of their particular interst,"
responded Oliver Ellsworth, the distinguished spokesman of Connecticut.
