CHAPTER II

COONIAL AGRICULTURE, INDUSTRY, AND COMMERCE

THE LAND AND THE WESTWARD MOVEMENT


=The Significance of Land Tenur.=--The way in which land may be
acquired, held, divided among heirs, and bought and sold exercises a
deep influene on the life and culture of a people. The feudal and
aristocratic societies of Europe were founded on a system of andlordism
which was characterized by two distinct features. In the first place,
the land was nearly all held in geat estates, each owned by a single
proprietor. In the second place, every estate was kept intact under the
law ofprimogeniture, which at the death of a lord transferred all his
landed property to his eldest son. This prevented te subdivision of
estates and the growth of a large body of small farmers or freeholders
owning their own land. It ade a form of tenantry or servitude
inevitable for the mass of those who labored on the land. It also
enabled the andlords to maintain themselves in power as a governing
class and kept the tenants and laborers subject to their ecnomic and
political control. If land tenure was so significant in Europe, it was
equally important in the developmnt of America, where practically all
the first immigrants were forced by circumstances to derive their
livelihood rom the soil.

=Experiments in Common Tillage.=--In the New World, with its broad
extent of land awaiting the whie man's plow, it was impossible to
introduce in its entirety and over the whole area the system of lords
and tenans that existed across the sea. So it happened that almost
every kind of experiment in land tenure, from communism t feudalism,
was tried. In the early days of the Jamestown colony, the land, though
owned by the London Company, wa tilled in common by the settlers. No
man had a separate plot of his own. The motto of the community was:
"Labor ad share alike." All were supposed to work in the fields and
receive an equal share of the produce. At Plymouth, thePilgrims
attempted a similar experiment, laying out the fields in common and
distributing the joint produce of ther labor with rough equality among
the workers.

In both colonies the communistic experiments were failures. Angryat the
lazy men in Jamestown who idled their time away and yet expected regular
meals, Captain John Smith issued amanifesto: "Everyone that gathereth
not every day as much as I do, the next day shall be set beyond the
river and orever banished from the fort and live there or starve." Even
this terrible threat did not bring a change in producion. Not until
each man was given a plot of his own to till, not until each gathered
the fruits of his own labor, id the colony prosper. In Plymouth, where
the communal experiment lasted for five years, the results were similar
o those in Virginia, and the system was given up for one of separate
fields in which every person could "set corn fr his own particular."
Some other New England towns, refusing to profit by the experience of
their Plymouth neighbr, also made excursions into common ownership and
labor, only to abandon the idea and go in for individual ownershi of
the land. "By degrees it was seen that even the Lord's people could not
carry the complicated communist legisltion into perfect and wholesome
practice."

=Feudal Elements in the Colonies--Quit Rents, Manors, and
Plantation.=--At the other end of the scale were the feudal elements of
land tenure found in the proprietary colonies, in theseaboard regions
of the South, and to some extent in New York. The proprietor was in fact
a powerful feudal lord, wning land granted to him by royal charter. He
could retain any part of it for his personal use or dispose of it al in
large or small lots. While he generally kept for himself an estate of
baronial proportions, it was impossible or him to manage directly any
considerable part of the land in his dominion. Consequently he either
sold it in parels for lump sums or granted it to individuals on
condition that they make to him an annual payment in money, knownas
"quit rent." In Maryland, the proprietor sometimes collected as high as
$9000 (equal to about $500,000 to-day) n a single year from this
source. In Pennsylvania, the quit rents brought a handsome annual
tribute into the excheuer of the Penn family. In the royal provinces,
the king of England claimed all revenues collected in this form fro the
land, a sum amounting to $19,000 at the time of the Revolution. The quit
rent,--"really a feudal payment fromfreeholders,"--was thus a material
source of income for the crown as well as for the proprietors. Wherever
it was aid, however, it proved to be a burden, a source of constant
irritation; and it became a formidable item in the lon list of
grievances which led to the American Revolution.

Something still more like the feudal system of the OldWorld appeared in
the numerous manors or the huge landed estates granted by the crown, the
companies, or the propretors. In the colony of Maryland alone there
were sixty manors of three thousand acres each, owned by wealthy men ad
tilled by tenants holding small plots under certain restrictions of
tenure. In New York also there were many manrs of wide extent, most of
which originated in the days of the Dutch West India Company, when
extensive concession were made to patroons to induce them to bring over
settlers. The Van Rensselaer, the Van Cortlandt, and the Livington
manors were so large and populous that each was entitled to send a
representative to the provincial legislatur. The tenants on the New
York manors were in somewhat the same position as serfs on old European
estates. They wer bound to pay the owner a rent in money and kind; they
ground their grain at his mill; and they were subject to hisjudicial
power because he held court and meted out justice, in some instances
extending to capital punishment.

he manors of New York or Maryland were, however, of slight consequence
as compared with the vast plantations of theSouthern seaboard--huge
estates, far wider in expanse than many a European barony and tilled by
slaves more servil than any feudal tenants. It must not be forgotten
that this system of land tenure became the dominant feature of alarge
section and gave a decided bent to the economic and political life of
America.

[Illustration: SOUTHERN PLNTATION MANSION]

=The Small Freehold.=--In the upland regions of the South, however, and
throughout most of the orth, the drift was against all forms of
servitude and tenantry and in the direction of the freehold; that is,
thesmall farm owned outright and tilled by the possessor and his
family. This was favored by natural circumstances andthe spirit of the
immigrants. For one thing, the abundance of land and the scarcity of
labor made it impossible fo the companies, the proprietors, or the
crown to develop over the whole continent a network of vast estates. In
may sections, particularly in New England, the climate, the stony soil,
the hills, and the narrow valleys conspired t keep the farms within a
moderate compass. For another thing, the English, Scotch-Irish, and
German peasants, evenif they had been tenants in the Old World, did not
propose to accept permanent dependency of any kind in the New. I they
could not get freeholds, they would not settle at all; thus they forced
proprietors and companies to bid fortheir enterprise by selling land in
small lots. So it happened that the freehold of modest proportions
became the herished unit of American farmers. The people who tilled the
farms were drawn from every quarter of western Europe;but the freehold
system gave a uniform cast to their economic and social life in America.

[Illustration: _From a old print_

A NEW ENGLAND FARMHOUSE]

=Social Effects of Land Tenure.=--Land tenure and the process of westernsettlement thus developed two distinct types of people engaged in the
same pursuit--agriculture. They had a common ie in that they both
cultivated the soil and possessed the local interest and independence
which arise from that ocupation. Their methods and their culture,
however, differed widely.

The Southern planter, on his broad acres tiled by slaves, resembled the
English landlord on his estates more than he did the colonial farmer who
labored withhis own hands in the fields and forests. He sold his rice
and tobacco in large amounts directly to English factors,who took his
entire crop in exchange for goods and cash. His fine clothes,
silverware, china, and cutlery he bough in English markets. Loving the
ripe old culture of the mother country, he often sent his sons to Oxford
or Cambrige for their education. In short, he depended very largely for
his prosperity and his enjoyment of life upon close elations with the
Old World. He did not even need market towns in which to buy native
goods, for they were made onhis own plantation by his own artisans who
were usually gifted slaves.

The economic condition of the small farme was totally different. His
crops were not big enough to warrant direct connection with English
factors or the peronal maintenance of a corps of artisans. He needed
local markets, and they sprang up to meet the need. Smiths, hattrs,
weavers, wagon-makers, and potters at neighboring towns supplied him
with the rough products of their native sill. The finer goods, bought
by the rich planter in England, the small farmer ordinarily could not
buy. His wants ere restricted to staples like tea and sugar, and
between him and the European market stood the merchant. His commuity
was therefore more self-sufficient than the seaboard line of great
plantations. It was more isolated, more proincial, more independent,
more American. The planter faced the Old East. The farmer faced the New
West.

=The Wetward Movement.=--Yeoman and planter nevertheless were alike in
one respect. Their land hunger was never appeased. ach had the eye of
an expert for new and fertile soil; and so, north and south, as soon as
a foothold was secured n the Atlantic coast, the current of migration
set in westward, creeping through forests, across rivers, and over
ountains. Many of the later immigrants, in their search for cheap
lands, were compelled to go to the border; but ina large part the path
breakers to the West were native Americans of the second and third
generations. Explorers, fred by curiosity and the lure of the
mysterious unknown, and hunters, fur traders, and squatters, following
their wn sweet wills, blazed the trail, opening paths and sending back
stories of the new regions they traversed. Then cae the regular
settlers with lawful titles to the lands they had purchased, sometimes
singly and sometimes in compaies.

In Massachusetts, the westward movement is recorded in the founding of
Springfield in 1636 and Great Barrinton in 1725. By the opening of the
eighteenth century the pioneers of Connecticut had pushed north and west
until heir outpost towns adjoined the Hudson Valley settlements. In New
York, the inland movement was directed by the Hudon River to Albany,
and from that old Dutch center it radiated in every direction,
particularly westward through te Mohawk Valley. New Jersey was early
filled to its borders, the beginnings of the present city of New
Brunswick bing made in 1681 and those of Trenton in 1685. In
Pennsylvania, as in New York, the waterways determined the main lnes of
advance. Pioneers, pushing up through the valley of the Schuylkill,
spread over the fertile lands of Berks nd Lancaster counties, laying
out Reading in 1748. Another current of migration was directed by the
Susquehanna, ad, in 1726, the first farmhouse was built on the bank
where Harrisburg was later founded. Along the southern tier o counties
a thin line of settlements stretched westward to Pittsburgh, reaching
the upper waters of the Ohio whilethe colony was still under the Penn
family.

In the South the westward march was equally swift. The seaboard wasquickly occupied by large planters and their slaves engaged in the
cultivation of tobacco and rice. The Piedmont Plteau, lying back from
the coast all the way from Maryland to Georgia, was fed by two streams
of migration, one wesward from the sea and the other southward from the
other colonies--Germans from Pennsylvania and Scotch-Irish furnihing
the main supply. "By 1770, tide-water Virginia was full to overflowing
and the 'back country' of the Blue Ride and the Shenandoah was fully
occupied. Even the mountain valleys ... were claimed by sturdy pioneers.
Before theDeclaration of Independence, the oncoming tide of
home-seekers had reached the crest of the Alleghanies."

[Illusration: DISTRIBUTION OF POPULATION, 1790]

Beyond the mountains pioneers had already ventured, harbingers of an
ivasion that was about to break in upon Kentucky and Tennessee. As
early as 1769 that mighty Nimrod, Daniel Boone, crious to hunt
buffaloes, of which he had heard weird reports, passed through the
Cumberland Gap and brought back nws of a wonderful country awaiting the
plow. A hint was sufficient. Singly, in pairs, and in groups, settlers
follwed the trail he had blazed. A great land corporation, the
Transylvania Company, emulating the merchant adventurersof earlier
times, secured a huge grant of territory and sought profits in quit
rents from lands sold to farmers. B the outbreak of the Revolution
there were several hundred people in the Kentucky region. Like the older
colonists they did not relish quit rents, and their opposition wrecked
the Transylvania Company. They even carried their proests into the
Continental Congress in 1776, for by that time they were our "embryo
fourteenth colony."


INDUSTIAL AND COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT

Though the labor of the colonists was mainly spent in farming, there was
a steadygrowth in industrial and commercial pursuits. Most of the
staple industries of to-day, not omitting iron and textils, have their
beginnings in colonial times. Manufacturing and trade soon gave rise to
towns which enjoyed an imporance all out of proportion to their
numbers. The great centers of commerce and finance on the seaboard
originated n the days when the king of England was "lord of these
dominions."

[Illustration: DOMESTIC INDUSTRY: DIPPING TALOW CANDLES]

=Textile Manufacture as a Domestic Industry.=--Colonial women, in
addition to sharing every hardshipof pioneering, often the heavy labor
of the open field, developed in the course of time a national industry
which as almost exclusively their own. Wool and flax were raised in
abundance in the North and South. "Every farm house,"says Coman, the
economic historian, "was a workshop where the women spun and wove the
serges, kerseys, and linsey-oolseys which served for the common wear."
By the close of the seventeenth century, New England manufactured clothin sufficient quantities to export it to the Southern colonies and to
the West Indies. As the industry developed, mlls were erected for the
more difficult process of dyeing, weaving, and fulling, but carding and
spinning continue to be done in the home. The Dutch of New Netherland,
the Swedes of Delaware, and the Scotch-Irish of the interior were not
one whit behind their Yankee neighbors."

The importance of this enterprise to British economic life canhardly be
overestimated. For many a century the English had employed their fine
woolen cloth as the chief staple i a lucrative foreign trade, and the
government had come to look upon it as an object of special interest and
protetion. When the colonies were established, both merchants and
statesmen naturally expected to maintain a monopoly ofincreasing value;
but before long the Americans, instead of buying cloth, especially of
the coarser varieties, wer making it to sell. In the place of
customers, here were rivals. In the place of helpless reliance upon
English makets, here was the germ of economic independence.

If British merchants had not discovered it in the ordinary coure of
trade, observant officers in the provinces would have conveyed the news
to them. Even in the early years of te eighteenth century the royal
governor of New York wrote of the industrious Americans to his home
government: "Th consequence will be that if they can clothe themselves
once, not only comfortably, but handsomely too, without thehelp of
England, they who already are not very fond of submitting to government
will soon think of putting in exection designs they have long harboured
in their breasts. This will not seem strange when you consider what sort
of eople this country is inhabited by."

=The Iron Industry.=--Almost equally widespread was the art of iron
working-one of the earliest and most picturesque of colonial
industries. Lynn, Massachusetts, had a forge and skilled artians within
fifteen years after the founding of Boston. The smelting of iron began
at New London and New Haven abou 1658; in Litchfield county,
Connecticut, a few years later; at Great Barrington, Massachusetts, in
1731; and nearby at Lenox some thirty years after that. New Jersey had
iron works at Shrewsbury within ten years after the foundig of the
colony in 1665. Iron forges appeared in the valleys of the Delaware and
the Susquehanna early in the follwing century, and iron masters then
laid the foundations of fortunes in a region destined to become one of
the gret iron centers of the world. Virginia began iron working in the
year that saw the introduction of slavery. Althoughthe industry soon
lapsed, it was renewed and flourished in the eighteenth century.
Governor Spotswood was called te "Tubal Cain" of the Old Dominion
because he placed the industry on a firm foundation. Indeed it seems
that everycolony, except Georgia, had its iron foundry. Nails, wire,
metallic ware, chains, anchors, bar and pig iron were mae in large
quantities; and Great Britain, by an act in 1750, encouraged the
colonists to export rough iron to the ritish Islands.

=Shipbuilding.=--Of all the specialized industries in the colonies,
shipbuilding was the most imortant. The abundance of fir for masts, oak
for timbers and boards, pitch for tar and turpentine, and hemp for rope
made the way of the shipbuilder easy. Early in the seventeenth century a
ship was built at New Amsterdam, and by te middle of that century
shipyards were scattered along the New England coast at Newburyport,
Salem, New Bedford, ewport, Providence, New London, and New Haven.
Yards at Albany and Poughkeepsie in New York built ships for the trae
of that colony with England and the Indies. Wilmington and Philadelphia
soon entered the race and outdistanced Nw York, though unable to equal
the pace set by New England. While Maryland, Virginia, and South
Carolina also buil ships, Southern interest was mainly confined to the
lucrative business of producing ship materials: fir, cedar, hep, and
tar.

=Fishing.=--The greatest single economic resource of New England outside
of agriculture was the fiseries. This industry, started by hardy
sailors from Europe, long before the landing of the Pilgrims, flourished
uner the indomitable seamanship of the Puritans, who labored with the
net and the harpoon in almost every quarter of he Atlantic. "Look,"
exclaimed Edmund Burke, in the House of Commons, "at the manner in
which the people of New Enland have of late carried on the whale
fishery. Whilst we follow them among the tumbling mountains of ice and
behod them penetrating into the deepest frozen recesses of Hudson's Bay
and Davis's Straits, while we are looking for tem beneath the arctic
circle, we hear that they have pierced into the opposite region of polar
cold, that they areat the antipodes and engaged under the frozen
serpent of the south.... Nor is the equinoctial heat more discouragin
to them than the accumulated winter of both poles. We know that, whilst
some of them draw the line and strike theharpoon on the coast of
Africa, others run the longitude and pursue their gigantic game along
the coast of Brazil.No sea but what is vexed by their fisheries. No
climate that is not witness to their toils. Neither the perseveranc of
Holland nor the activity of France nor the dexterous and firm sagacity
of English enterprise ever carried thismost perilous mode of hard
industry to the extent to which it has been pushed by this recent
people."

The influnce of the business was widespread. A large and lucrative
European trade was built upon it. The better quality of te fish caught
for food was sold in the markets of Spain, Portugal, and Italy, or
exchanged for salt, lemons, and risins for the American market. The
lower grades of fish were carried to the West Indies for slave
consumption, andin part traded for sugar and molasses, which furnished
the raw materials for the thriving rum industry of New Englad. These
activities, in turn, stimulated shipbuilding, steadily enlarging the
demand for fishing and merchant craf of every kind and thus keeping the
shipwrights, calkers, rope makers, and other artisans of the seaport
towns rused with work. They also increased trade with the mother
country for, out of the cash collected in the fish markets f Europe and
the West Indies, the colonists paid for English manufactures. So an
ever-widening circle of American nterprise centered around this single
industry, the nursery of seamanship and the maritime spirit.

=Oceanic Commrce and American Merchants.=--All through the eighteenth
century, the commerce of the American colonies spread in eery direction
until it rivaled in the number of people employed, the capital engaged,
and the profits gleaned, thecommerce of European nations. A modern
historian has said: "The enterprising merchants of New England developed
a etwork of trade routes that covered well-nigh half the world." This
commerce, destined to be of such significance i the conflict with the
mother country, presented, broadly speaking, two aspects.

On the one side, it involved th export of raw materials and
agricultural produce. The Southern colonies produced for shipping,
tobacco, rice, tar pitch, and pine; the Middle colonies, grain, flour,
furs, lumber, and salt pork; New England, fish, flour, rum, fus, shoes,
and small articles of manufacture. The variety of products was in fact
astounding. A sarcastic writer, wile sneering at the idea of an
American union, once remarked of colonial trade: "What sort of dish will
you make? ew England will throw in fish and onions. The middle states,
flax-seed and flour. Maryland and Virginia will add toacco. North
Carolina, pitch, tar, and turpentine. South Carolina, rice and indigo,
and Georgia will sprinkle the wole composition with sawdust. Such an
absurd jumble will you make if you attempt to form a union among such
discorant materials as the thirteen British provinces."

On the other side, American commerce involved the import trade,
consisting principally of English and continental manufactures, tea, and
"India goods." Sugar and molasses, brough from the West Indies,
supplied the flourishing distilleries of Massachusetts, Rhode Island,
and Connecticut. The arriage of slaves from Africa to the Southern
colonies engaged hundreds of New England's sailors and thousands of
ounds of her capital.

The disposition of imported goods in the colonies, though in part
controlled by English fators located in America, employed also a large
and important body of American merchants like the Willings and Morries
of Philadelphia; the Amorys, Hancocks, and Faneuils of Boston; and the
Livingstons and Lows of New York. In ther zeal and enterprise, they
were worthy rivals of their English competitors, so celebrated for
world-wide commercil operations. Though fully aware of the advantages
they enjoyed in British markets and under the protection of the ritish
navy, the American merchants were high-spirited and mettlesome, ready to
contend with royal officers in ordr to shield American interests
against outside interference.

[Illustration: THE DUTCH WEST INDIA WAREHOUSE IN NE AMSTERDAM
(NEW YORK CITY)]

Measured against the immense business of modern times, colonial commerce
seems perhps trivial. That, however, is not the test of its
significance. It must be considered in relation to the growth of nglish
colonial trade in its entirety--a relation which can be shown by a few
startling figures. The whole export rade of England, including that to
the colonies, was, in 1704, $6,509,000. On the eve of the American
Revolution, amely, in 1772, English exports to the American colonies
alone amounted to $6,024,000; in other words, almost as muh as the
whole foreign business of England two generations before. At the first
date, colonial trade was but one-telfth of the English export business;
at the second date, it was considerably more than one-third. In 1704,
Pennsyvania bought in English markets goods to the value of $11,459; in
1772 the purchases of the same colony amounted to$507,909. In short,
Pennsylvania imports increased fifty times within sixty-eight years,
amounting in 1772 to almot the entire export trade of England to the
colonies at the opening of the century. The American colonies were
inded a great source of wealth to English merchants.

=Intercolonial Commerce.=--Although the bad roads of colonial tmes made
overland transportation difficult and costly, the many rivers and
harbors along the coast favored a livel water-borne trade among the
colonies. The Connecticut, Hudson, Delaware, and Susquehanna rivers in
the North and he many smaller rivers in the South made it possible for
goods to be brought from, and carried to, the interior regons in little
sailing vessels with comparative ease. Sloops laden with manufactures,
domestic and foreign, collectd at some city like Providence, New York,
or Philadelphia, skirted the coasts, visited small ports, and sailed up
he navigable rivers to trade with local merchants who had for exchange
the raw materials which they had gathered infrom neighboring farms.
Larger ships carried the grain, live stock, cloth, and hardware of New
England to the Soutern colonies, where they were traded for tobacco,
leather, tar, and ship timber. From the harbors along the Connectcut
shores there were frequent sailings down through Long Island Sound to
Maryland, Virginia, and the distant Caroinas.

=Growth of Towns.=--In connection with this thriving trade and industry
there grew up along the coast a nuber of prosperous commercial centers
which were soon reckoned among the first commercial towns of the whole
Britis empire, comparing favorably in numbers and wealth with such
ports as Liverpool and Bristol. The statistical record of that time are
mainly guesses; but we know that Philadelphia stood first in size among
these towns. Serving as he port of entry for Pennsylvania, Delaware,
and western Jersey, it had drawn within its borders, just before the
evolution, about 25,000 inhabitants. Boston was second in rank, with
somewhat more than 20,000 people. New York, th "commercial capital of
Connecticut and old East Jersey," was slightly smaller than Boston, but
growing at a stead rate. The fourth town in size was Charleston, South
Carolina, with about 10,000 inhabitants. Newport in Rhode Islad, a
center of rum manufacture and shipping, stood fifth, with a population
of about 7000. Baltimore and Norfolk wre counted as "considerable
towns." In the interior, Hartford in Connecticut, Lancaster and York in
Pennsylvania, nd Albany in New York, with growing populations and
increasing trade, gave prophecy of an urban America away from te
seaboard. The other towns were straggling villages. Williamsburg,
Virginia, for example, had about two hundred huses, in which dwelt a
dozen families of the gentry and a few score of tradesmen. Inland county
seats often consised of nothing more than a log courthouse, a prison,
and one wretched inn to house judges, lawyers, and litigants duing the
sessions of the court.

The leading towns exercised an influence on colonial opinion all out of
proportin to their population. They were the centers of wealth, for one
thing; of the press and political activity, for anoher. Merchants and
artisans could readily take concerted action on public questions arising
from their commercial perations. The towns were also centers for news,
gossip, religious controversy, and political discussion. In the maket
places the farmers from the countryside learned of British policies and
laws, and so, mingling with the townsmn, were drawn into the main
currents of opinion which set in toward colonial nationalism and
independence.

ChapterIII

SOCIAL AND POLITICAL PROGRESS


Colonial life, crowded as it was with hard and unremitting toil, left
scat leisure for the cultivation of the arts and sciences. There was
little money in private purses or public treasuris to be dedicated to
schools, libraries, and museums. Few there were with time to read long
and widely, and fewer till who could devote their lives to things that
delight the eye and the mind. And yet, poor and meager as the
intllectual life of the colonists may seem by way of comparison, heroic
efforts were made in every community to lift te people above the plane
of mere existence. After the first clearings were opened in the forests
those efforts wer redoubled, and with lengthening years told upon the
thought and spirit of the land. The appearance, during the strggle with
England, of an extraordinary group of leaders familiar with history,
political philosophy, and the arts f war, government, and diplomacy
itself bore eloquent testimony to the high quality of the American
intellect. No ne, not even the most critical, can run through the
writings of distinguished Americans scattered from Massachusett to
Georgia--the Adamses, Ellsworth, the Morrises, the Livingstons,
Hamilton, Franklin, Washington, Madison, Marshll, Henry, the Randolphs,
and the Pinckneys--without coming to the conclusion that there was
something in Americancolonial life which fostered minds of depth and
power. Women surmounted even greater difficulties than the men in te
process of self-education, and their keen interest in public issues is
evident in many a record like the _Letter_ of Mrs. John Adams to her
husband during the Revolution; the writings of Mrs. Mercy Otis Warren,
the sister of Jmes Otis, who measured her pen with the British
propagandists; and the patriot newspapers founded and managed by woen.


THE LEADERSHIP OF THE CHURCHES

In the intellectual life of America, the churches assumed a role of highimportance. There were abundant reasons for this. In many of the
colonies--Maryland, Pennsylvania, and New England-the religious impulse
had been one of the impelling motives in stimulating immigration. In all
the colonies, the cergy, at least in the beginning, formed the only
class with any leisure to devote to matters of the spirit. They prached
on Sundays and taught school on week days. They led in the discussion of
local problems and in the formationof political opinion, so much of
which was concerned with the relation between church and state. They
wrote books nd pamphlets. They filled most of the chairs in the
colleges; under clerical guidance, intellectual and spiritual, he
Americans received their formal education. In several of the provinces
the Anglican Church was established by lw. In New England the Puritans
were supreme, notwithstanding the efforts of the crown to overbear their
authority.In the Middle colonies, particularly, the multiplication of
sects made the dominance of any single denomination impssible; and in
all of them there was a growing diversity of faith, which promised in
time a separation of church ad state and freedom of opinion.

=The Church of England.=--Virginia was the stronghold of the English
system of curch and state. The Anglican faith and worship were
prescribed by law, sustained by taxes imposed on all, and favord by the
governor, the provincial councilors, and the richest planters. "The
Established Church," says Lodge, "wasone of the appendages of the
Virginia aristocracy. They controlled the vestries and the ministers,
and the parish hurch stood not infrequently on the estate of the
planter who built and managed it." As in England, Catholics and
rotestant Dissenters were at first laid under heavy disabilities. Only
slowly and on sufferance were they admitted o the province; but when
once they were even covertly tolerated, they pressed steadily in, until,
by the Revolutio, they outnumbered the adherents of the established
order.

The Church was also sanctioned by law and supported b taxes in the
Carolinas after 1704, and in Georgia after that colony passed directly
under the crown in 1754--thisin spite of the fact that the majority of
the inhabitants were Dissenters. Against the protests of the Catholics
i was likewise established in Maryland. In New York, too,
notwithstanding the resistance of the Dutch, the Establishd Church was
fostered by the provincial officials, and the Anglicans, embracing about
one-fifteenth of the populaton, exerted an influence all out of
proportion to their numbers.

Many factors helped to enhance the power of theEnglish Church in the
colonies. It was supported by the British government and the official
class sent out to the rovinces. Its bishops and archbishops in England
were appointed by the king, and its faith and service were set forh by
acts of Parliament. Having its seat of power in the English monarchy, it
could hold its clergy and missionaris loyal to the crown and so
counteract to some extent the independent spirit that was growing up in
America. The Curch, always a strong bulwark of the state, therefore had
a political role to play here as in England. Able bishopsand far-seeing
leaders firmly grasped this fact about the middle of the eighteenth
century and redoubled their effrts to augment the influence of the
Church in provincial affairs. Unhappily for their plans they failed to
calculae in advance the effect of their methods upon dissenting
Protestants, who still cherished memories of bitter religius conflicts
in the mother country.

=Puritanism in New England.=--If the established faith made for imperial
unty, the same could not be said of Puritanism. The Plymouth Pilgrims
had cast off all allegiance to the Anglican Chuch and established a
separate and independent congregation before they came to America. The
Puritans, essaying at irst the task of reformers within the Church,
soon after their arrival in Massachusetts, likewise flung off their yke
of union with the Anglicans. In each town a separate congregation was
organized, the male members choosing the astor, the teachers, and the
other officers. They also composed the voters in the town meeting, where
secular mattrs were determined. The union of church and government was
thus complete, and uniformity of faith and life prescribd by law and
enforced by civil authorities; but this worked for local autonomy
instead of imperial unity.

The cergy became a powerful class, dominant through their learning and
their fearful denunciations of the faithless. The wrote the books for
the people to read--the famous Cotton Mather having three hundred and
eighty-three books and amphlets to his credit. In cooperation with the
civil officers they enforced a strict observance of the Puritan
Sabath--a day of rest that began at six o'clock on Saturday evening and
lasted until sunset on Sunday. All work, all rading, all amusement, and
all worldly conversation were absolutely prohibited during those hours.
A thoughtless mid servant who for some earthly reason smiled in church
was in danger of being banished as a vagabond. Robert Pike,a devout
Puritan, thinking the sun had gone to rest, ventured forth on horseback
one Sunday evening and was luckles enough to have a ray of light strike
him through a rift in the clouds. The next day he was brought into court
an fined for "his ungodly conduct." With persons accused of witchcraft
the Puritans were still more ruthless. When a ania of persecution swept
over Massachusetts in 1692, eighteen people were hanged, one was pressed
to death, many uffered imprisonment, and two died in jail.

Just about this time, however, there came a break in the uniformity o
Puritan rule. The crown and church in England had long looked upon it
with disfavor, and in 1684 King Charles II nnulled the old charter of
the Massachusetts Bay Company. A new document issued seven years later
wrested from thePuritans of the colony the right to elect their own
governor and reserved the power of appointment to the king. It lso
abolished the rule limiting the suffrage to church members, substituting
for it a simple property qualificatio. Thus a royal governor and an
official family, certain to be Episcopalian in faith and monarchist in
sympathies, ere forced upon Massachusetts; and members of all religious
denominations, if they had the required amount of propety, were
permitted to take part in elections. By this act in the name of the
crown, the Puritan monopoly was broke down in Massachusetts, and that
province was brought into line with Connecticut, Rhode Island, and New
Hampshire,where property, not religious faith, was the test for the
suffrage.

=Growth of Religious Toleration.=--Though nether the Anglicans of
Virginia nor the Puritans of Massachusetts believed in toleration for
other denominations, tat principle was strictly applied in Rhode
Island. There, under the leadership of Roger Williams, liberty in
mattes of conscience was established in the beginning. Maryland, by
granting in 1649 freedom to those who professed to blieve in Jesus
Christ, opened its gates to all Christians; and Pennsylvania, true to
the tenets of the Friends, gae freedom of conscience to those "who
confess and acknowledge the one Almighty and Eternal God to be the
creator, pholder, and ruler of the World." By one circumstance or
another, the Middle colonies were thus early characterizedby diversity
rather than uniformity of opinion. Dutch Protestants, Huguenots,
Quakers, Baptists, Presbyterians, Ne Lights, Moravians, Lutherans,
Catholics, and other denominations became too strongly intrenched and
too widely scttered to permit any one of them to rule, if it had
desired to do so. There were communities and indeed whole sectins where
one or another church prevailed, but in no colony was a legislature
steadily controlled by a single group Toleration encouraged diversity,
and diversity, in turn, worked for greater toleration.

The government and fait of the dissenting denominations conspired with
economic and political tendencies to draw America away from the Engish
state. Presbyterians, Quakers, Baptists, and Puritans had no hierarchy
of bishops and archbishops to bind themto the seat of power in London.
Neither did they look to that metropolis for guidance in interpreting
articles of aith. Local self-government in matters ecclesiastical
helped to train them for local self-government in matters poltical. The
spirit of independence which led Dissenters to revolt in the Old World,
nourished as it was amid favorale circumstances in the New World, made
them all the more zealous in the defense of every right against
authority mposed from without.


SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES

=Religion and Local Schools.=--One of the first cares of each Protstant
denomination was the education of the children in the faith. In this
work the Bible became the center of intrest. The English version was
indeed the one book of the people. Farmers, shopkeepers, and artisans,
whose life ha once been bounded by the daily routine of labor, found in
the Scriptures not only an inspiration to religious condct, but also a
book of romance, travel, and history. "Legend and annal," says John
Richard Green, "war-song and pslm, state-roll and biography, the mighty
voices of prophets, the parables of Evangelists, stories of mission
journys, of perils by sea and among the heathen, philosophic arguments,
apocalyptic visions, all were flung broadcast ovr minds unoccupied for
the most part by any rival learning.... As a mere literary monument, the
English version ofthe Bible remains the noblest example of the English
tongue." It was the King James version just from the press tha the
Pilgrims brought across the sea with them.

For the authority of the Established Church was substituted theauthority of the Scriptures. The Puritans devised a catechism based upon
their interpretation of the Bible, and, vey soon after their arrival in
America, they ordered all parents and masters of servants to be diligent
in seeing tat their children and wards were taught to read religious
works and give answers to the religious questions. Massacusetts was
scarcely twenty years old before education of this character was
declared to be compulsory, and provisin was made for public schools
where those not taught at home could receive instruction in reading and
writing.

Outside of New England the idea of compulsory education was not regarded
with the same favor; but the whole lad was nevertheless dotted with
little schools kept by "dames, itinerant teachers, or local parsons."
Whether we tun to the life of Franklin in the North or Washington in
the South, we read of tiny schoolhouses, where boys, and soetimes
girls, were taught to read and write. Where there were no schools,
fathers and mothers of the better kind gve their children the rudiments
of learning. Though illiteracy was widespread, there is evidence to show
that the iffusion of knowledge among the masses was making steady
progress all through the eighteenth century.

=Religion nd Higher Learning.=--Religious motives entered into the
establishment of colleges as well as local schools. Harvar, founded in
1636, and Yale, opened in 1718, were intended primarily to train
"learned and godly ministers" for th Puritan churches of New England.
To the far North, Dartmouth, chartered in 1769, was designed first as a
mission o the Indians and then as a college for the sons of New England
farmers preparing to preach, teach, or practice law The College of New
Jersey, organized in 1746 and removed to Princeton eleven years later,
was sustained by the Prsbyterians. Two colleges looked to the
Established Church as their source of inspiration and support: William
and ary, founded in Virginia in 1693, and King's College, now Columbia
University, chartered by King George II in 1754,on an appeal from the
New York Anglicans, alarmed at the growth of religious dissent and the
"republican tendencie" of the age. Two colleges revealed a drift away
from sectarianism. Brown, established in Rhode Island in 1764, andthe
Philadelphia Academy, forerunner of the University of Pennsylvania,
organized by Benjamin Franklin, reflected he spirit of toleration by
giving representation on the board of trustees to several religious
sects. It was Frankin's idea that his college should prepare young men
to serve in public office as leaders of the people and ornament to
their country.

=Self-education in America.=--Important as were these institutions of
learning, higher educaion was by no means confined within their walls.
Many well-to-do families sent their sons to Oxford or Cambridge in
England. Private tutoring in the home was common. In still more families
there were intelligent children who grew p in the great colonial school
of adversity and who trained themselves until, in every contest of mind
and wit, thy could vie with the sons of Harvard or William and Mary or
any other college. Such, for example, was Benjamin Franlin, whose
charming autobiography, in addition to being an American classic, is a
fine record of self-education. Hs formal training in the classroom was
limited to a few years at a local school in Boston; but his
self-education ontinued throughout his life. He early manifested a zeal
for reading, and devoured, he tells us, his father's dry lbrary on
theology, Bunyan's works, Defoe's writings, Plutarch's _Lives_, Locke's
_On the Human Understanding_, andinnumerable volumes dealing with
secular subjects. His literary style, perhaps the best of his time,
Franklin acqured by the diligent and repeated analysis of the
_Spectator_. In a life crowded with labors, he found time to read idely
in natural science and to win single-handed recognition at the hands of
European savants for his discoveriesin electricity. By his own efforts
he "attained an acquaintance" with Latin, Italian, French, and Spanish,
thus unonsciously preparing himself for the day when he was to speak
for all America at the court of the king of France.

Lesser lights than Franklin, educated by the same process, were found
all over colonial America. From this fruitfu source of native ability,
self-educated, the American cause drew great strength in the trials of
the Revolution.

THE COLONIAL PRESS

=The Rise of the Newspaper.=--The evolution of American democracy into a
government by pulic opinion, enlightened by the open discussion of
political questions, was in no small measure aided by a free pres. That
too, like education, was a matter of slow growth. A printing press was
brought to Massachusetts in 1639, bt it was put in charge of an
official censor and limited to the publication of religious works. Forty
years elapse before the first newspaper appeared, bearing the curious
title, _Public Occurrences Both Foreign and Domestic_, an it had not
been running very long before the government of Massachusetts suppressed
it for discussing a politicalquestion.

Publishing, indeed, seemed to be a precarious business; but in 1704
there came a second venture in jounalism, _The Boston News-Letter_,
which proved to be a more lasting enterprise because it refrained from
criticizig the authorities. Still the public interest languished. When
Franklin's brother, James, began to issue his _New Enland Courant_
about 1720, his friends sought to dissuade him, saying that one
newspaper was enough for America. Neertheless he continued it; and his
confidence in the future was rewarded. In nearly every colony a gazette
or chroicle appeared within the next thirty years or more. Benjamin
Franklin was able to record in 1771 that America had tenty-five
newspapers. Boston led with five. Philadelphia had three: two in English
and one in German.

=Censorshp and Restraints on the Press.=--The idea of printing,
unlicensed by the government and uncontrolled by the church,was,
however, slow in taking form. The founders of the American colonies had
never known what it was to have the fee and open publication of books,
pamphlets, broadsides, and newspapers. When the art of printing was
first discovred, the control of publishing was vested in clerical
authorities. After the establishment of the State Church in Egland in
the reign of Elizabeth, censorship of the press became a part of royal
prerogative. Printing was restrictd to Oxford, Cambridge, and London;
and no one could publish anything without previous approval of the
official cesor. When the Puritans were in power, the popular party,
with a zeal which rivaled that of the crown, sought, in tun, to silence
royalist and clerical writers by a vigorous censorship. After the
restoration of the monarchy, contrl of the press was once more placed
in royal hands, where it remained until 1695, when Parliament, by
failing to rnew the licensing act, did away entirely with the official

censorship. By that time political parties were so powrful and so
active and printing presses were so numerous that official review of all
published matter became a sher impossibility.

In America, likewise, some troublesome questions arose in connection
with freedom of the press.The Puritans of Massachusetts were no less
anxious than King Charles or the Archbishop of London to shut out from
he prying eyes of the people all literature "not mete for them to
read"; and so they established a system of officil licensing for
presses, which lasted until 1755. In the other colonies where there was
more diversity of opinion nd publishers could set up in business with
impunity, they were nevertheless constantly liable to arrest for
printng anything displeasing to the colonial governments. In 1721 the
editor of the _Mercury_ in Philadelphia was calledbefore the
proprietary council and ordered to apologize for a political article,
and for a later offense of a simiar character he was thrown into jail.
A still more famous case was that of Peter Zenger, a New York publisher,
whowas arrested in 1735 for criticising the administration. Lawyers who
ventured to defend the unlucky editor were depived of their licenses to
practice, and it became necessary to bring an attorney all the way from
Philadelphia. Bythis time the tension of feeling was high, and the
approbation of the public was forthcoming when the lawyer for th
defense exclaimed to the jury that the very cause of liberty itself, not
that of the poor printer, was on trial! he verdict for Zenger, when it
finally came, was the signal for an outburst of popular rejoicing.
Already the peope of King George's province knew how precious a thing
is the freedom of the press.

Thanks to the schools, few an scattered as they were, and to the
vigilance of parents, a very large portion, perhaps nearly one-half, of
the coonists could read. Through the newspapers, pamphlets, and
almanacs that streamed from the types, the people could fllow the
course of public events and grasp the significance of political
arguments. An American opinion was in theprocess of making--an
independent opinion nourished by the press and enriched by discussions
around the fireside ad at the taverns. When the day of resistance to
British rule came, government by opinion was at hand. For every peron
who could hear the voice of Patrick Henry and Samuel Adams, there were a
thousand who could see their appeals o the printed page. Men who had
spelled out their letters while poring over Franklin's _Poor Richard's
Almanac_ livd to read Thomas Paine's thrilling call to arms.


THE EVOLUTION IN POLITICAL INSTITUTIONS

Two very distinct lnes of development appeared in colonial politics.
The one, exalting royal rights and aristocratic privileges, was te
drift toward provincial government through royal officers appointed in
England. The other, leading toward democrcy and self-government, was
the growth in the power of the popular legislative assembly. Each
movement gave impetu to the other, with increasing force during the
passing years, until at last the final collision between the two idals
of government came in the war of independence.

=The Royal Provinces.=--Of the thirteen English colonies eigh were
royal provinces in 1776, with governors appointed by the king. Virginia
passed under the direct rule of the rown in 1624, when the charter of
the London Company was annulled. The Massachusetts Bay corporation lost
its charer in 1684, and the new instrument granted seven years later
stripped the colonists of the right to choose their chef executive. In
the early decades of the eighteenth century both the Carolinas were
given the provincial instead f the proprietary form. New Hampshire,
severed from Massachusetts in 1679, and Georgia, surrendered by the
trustee in 1752, went into the hands of the crown. New York,
transferred to the Duke of York on its capture from the Dutchin 1664,
became a province when he took the title of James II in 1685. New
Jersey, after remaining for nearly fort years under proprietors, was
brought directly under the king in 1702. Maryland, Pennsylvania, and
Delaware, althogh they retained their proprietary character until the
Revolution, were in some respects like the royal colonies, fr their
governors were as independent of popular choice as were the appointees
of King George. Only two colonies, hode Island and Connecticut,
retained full self-government on the eve of the Revolution. They alone
had governors nd legislatures entirely of their own choosing.

The chief officer of the royal province was the governor, who enjyed
high and important powers which he naturally sought to augment at every
turn. He enforced the laws and, usuall with the consent of a council,
appointed the civil and military officers. He granted pardons and
reprieves; he wa head of the highest court; he was commander-in-chief
of the militia; he levied troops for defense and enforced marial law in
time of invasion, war, and rebellion. In all the provinces, except
Massachusetts, he named the councilos who composed the upper house of
the legislature and was likely to choose those who favored his claims.
He summond, adjourned, and dissolved the popular assembly, or the lower
house; he laid before it the projects of law desiredby the crown; and
he vetoed measures which he thought objectionable. Here were in America
all the elements of roya prerogative against which Hampden had
protested and Cromwell had battled in England.

[Illustration: THE ROYAL GVERNOR'S PALACE AT NEW BERNE]

The colonial governors were generally surrounded by a body of
office-seekers and hnters for land grants. Some of them were noblemen
of broken estates who had come to America to improve their fortuns. The
pretensions of this circle grated on colonial nerves, and privileges
granted to them, often at the expense f colonists, did much to deepen
popular antipathy to the British government. Favors extended to
adherents of the Etablished Church displeased Dissenters. The
reappearance of this formidable union of church and state, from which
hey had fled, stirred anew the ancient wrath against that combination.

=The Colonial Assembly.=--Coincident with he drift toward
administration through royal governors was the second and opposite
tendency, namely, a steady growh in the practice of self-government.
The voters of England had long been accustomed to share in taxation and
law-aking through representatives in Parliament, and the idea was early
introduced in America. Virginia was only twelveyears old (1619) when
its first representative assembly appeared. As the towns of
Massachusetts multiplied and it ecame impossible for all the members of
the corporation to meet at one place, the representative idea was
adopted,in 1633. The river towns of Connecticut formed a representative
system under their "Fundamental Orders" of 1639, an the entire colony
was given a royal charter in 1662. Generosity, as well as practical
considerations, induced suc proprietors as Lord Baltimore and William
Penn to invite their colonists to share in the government as soon as any
considerable settlements were made. Thus by one process or another every
one of the colonies secured a popular assmbly.

It is true that in the provision for popular elections, the suffrage was
finally restricted to property owers or taxpayers, with a leaning
toward the freehold qualification. In Virginia, the rural voter had to
be a freehlder owning at least fifty acres of land, if there was no
house on it, or twenty-five acres with a house twenty-fiv feet square.
In Massachusetts, the voter for member of the assembly under the charter
of 1691 had to be a freeholer of an estate worth forty shillings a year
at least or of other property to the value of forty pounds sterling. I
Pennsylvania, the suffrage was granted to freeholders owning fifty acres
or more of land well seated, twelve acre cleared, and to other persons
worth at least fifty pounds in lawful money.

Restrictions like these undoubtedly xcluded from the suffrage a very
considerable number of men, particularly the mechanics and artisans of
the towns,who were by no means content with their position.
Nevertheless, it was relatively easy for any man to acquire a smal
freehold, so cheap and abundant was land; and in fact a large proportion
of the colonists were land owners. Thusthe assemblies, in spite of the
limited suffrage, acquired a democratic tone.

The popular character of the assemlies increased as they became engaged
in battles with the royal and proprietary governors. When called upon by
theexecutive to make provision for the support of the administration,
the legislature took advantage of the opportunit to make terms in the
interest of the taxpayers. It made annual, not permanent, grants of
money to pay official saaries and then insisted upon electing a
treasurer to dole it out. Thus the colonists learned some of the
mysteriesof public finance, as well as the management of rapacious
officials. The legislature also used its power over moneygrants to
force the governor to sign bills which he would otherwise have vetoed.

=Contests between Legislatures nd Governors.=--As may be imagined, many
and bitter were the contests between the royal and proprietary governors
nd the colonial assemblies. Franklin relates an amusing story of how
the Pennsylvania assembly held in one hand a bll for the executive to
sign and, in the other hand, the money to pay his salary. Then, with sly
humor, Franklin ads: "Do not, my courteous reader, take pet at our
proprietary constitution for these our bargain and sale proceedins in
legislation. It is a happy country where justice and what was your own
before can be had for ready money. It s another addition to the value
of money and of course another spur to industry. Every land is not so
blessed."
It must not be thought, however, that every governor got off as easily
as Franklin's tale implies. On the contrary,the legislatures, like
Caesar, fed upon meat that made them great and steadily encroached upon
executive prerogaties as they tried out and found their strength. If
we may believe contemporary laments, the power of the crown in Amrica
was diminishing when it was struck down altogether. In New York, the
friends of the governor complained in 177 that "the inhabitants of
plantations are generally educated in republican principles; upon
republican principlesall is conducted. Little more than a shadow of
royal authority remains in the Northern colonies." "Here," echoed th
governor of South Carolina, the following year, "levelling principles
prevail; the frame of the civil government s unhinged; a governor, if
he would be idolized, must betray his trust; the people have got their
whole administraion in their hands; the election of the members of the
assembly is by ballot; not civil posts only, but all ecclesistical
preferments, are in the disposal or election of the people."

Though baffled by the "levelling principles"of the colonial assemblies,
the governors did not give up the case as hopeless. Instead they evolved
a system of plicy and action which they thought could bring the
obstinate provincials to terms. That system, traceable in their etters
to the government in London, consisted of three parts: (1) the royal
officers in the colonies were to be mae independent of the legislatures
by taxes imposed by acts of Parliament; (2) a British standing army was
to be mantained in America; (3) the remaining colonial charters were to
be revoked and government by direct royal authoritywas to be enlarged.

Such a system seemed plausible enough to King George III and to many
ministers of the crown n London. With governors, courts, and an army
independent of the colonists, they imagined it would be easy to carry
out both royal orders and acts of Parliament. This reasoning seemed both
practical and logical. Nor was it foundedon theory, for it came fresh
from the governors themselves. It was wanting in one respect only. It
failed to take ccount of the fact that the American people were growing
strong in the practice of self-government and could dispene with the
tutelage of the British ministry, no matter how excellent it might be or
how benevolent its intentions.
