CHAPTER VI

THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION


RESISTANCE AND RETALIATION

=The Continental Congress.=--When the news of the "intolrable acts"
reached America, every one knew what strong medicine Parliament was
prepared to administer to all thos who resisted its authority. The
cause of Massachusetts became the cause of all the colonies. Opposition
to Britis policy, hitherto local and spasmodic, now took on a national
character. To local committees and provincial conventons was added a
Continental Congress, appropriately called by Massachusetts on June 17,
1774, at the instigation o Samuel Adams. The response to the summons
was electric. By hurried and irregular methods delegates were elected
dring the summer, and on September 5 the Congress duly assembled in
Carpenter's Hall in Philadelphia. Many of the gratest men in America
were there--George Washington and Patrick Henry from Virginia and John
and Samuel Adams from assachusetts. Every shade of opinion was
represented. Some were impatient with mild devices; the majority favored
oderation.

The Congress drew up a declaration of American rights and stated in
clear and dignified language the rievances of the colonists. It
approved the resistance to British measures offered by Massachusetts and
promised te united support of all sections. It prepared an address to
King George and another to the people of England, disavwing the idea of
independence but firmly attacking the policies pursued by the British
government.

=The Non-Imprtation Agreement.=--The Congress was not content, however,
with professions of faith and with petitions. It took oe revolutionary
step. It agreed to stop the importation of British goods into America,
and the enforcement of thisagreement it placed in the hands of local
"committees of safety and inspection," to be elected by the qualified
voers. The significance of this action is obvious. Congress threw
itself athwart British law. It made a rule to bind merican citizens and
to be carried into effect by American officers. It set up a state within
the British state an laid down a test of allegiance to the new order.
The colonists, who up to this moment had been wavering, had to chose
one authority or the other. They were for the enforcement of the
non-importation agreement or they were agains it. They either bought
English goods or they did not. In the spirit of the toast--"May Britain
be wise and Americ be free"--the first Continental Congress adjourned
in October, having appointed the tenth of May following for themeeting
of a second Congress, should necessity require.

=Lord North's "Olive Branch."=--When the news of the acton of the
American Congress reached England, Pitt and Burke warmly urged a repeal
of the obnoxious laws, but in van. All they could wring from the prime
minister, Lord North, was a set of "conciliatory resolutions" proposing
to elieve from taxation any colony that would assume its share of
imperial defense and make provision for supporting te local officers of
the crown. This "olive branch" was accompanied by a resolution assuring
the king of support atall hazards in suppressing the rebellion and by
the restraining act of March 30, 1775, which in effect destroyed th
commerce of New England.

=Bloodshed at Lexington and Concord (April 19, 1775).=--Meanwhile the
British authoriies in Massachusetts relaxed none of their efforts in
upholding British sovereignty. General Gage, hearing that miltary
stores had been collected at Concord, dispatched a small force to seize
them. By this act he precipitated theconflict he had sought to avoid.
At Lexington, on the road to Concord, occurred "the little thing" that
produced "he great event." An unexpected collision beyond the thought
or purpose of any man had transferred the contest from he forum to the
battle field.

=The Second Continental Congress.=--Though blood had been shed and war
was actualy at hand, the second Continental Congress, which met at
Philadelphia in May, 1775, was not yet convinced that concliation was
beyond human power. It petitioned the king to interpose on behalf of the
colonists in order that the epire might avoid the calamities of civil
war. On the last day of July, it made a temperate but firm answer to
LordNorth's offer of conciliation, stating that the proposal was
unsatisfactory because it did not renounce the right t tax or repeal
the offensive acts of Parliament.

=Force, the British Answer.=--Just as the representatives of Amrica
were about to present the last petition of Congress to the king on
August 23, 1775, George III issued a proclmation of rebellion. This
announcement declared that the colonists, "misled by dangerous and
ill-designing men," wre in a state of insurrection; it called on the
civil and military powers to bring "the traitors to justice"; and i
threatened with "condign punishment the authors, perpetrators, and
abettors of such traitorous designs." It close with the usual prayer:
"God, save the king." Later in the year, Parliament passed a sweeping
act destroying all tade and intercourse with America. Congress was
silent at last. Force was also America's answer.


AMERICAN INDEPNDENCE

=Drifting into War.=--Although the Congress had not given up all hope of
reconciliation in the spring andsummer of 1775, it had firmly resolved
to defend American rights by arms if necessary. It transformed the
militiamn who had assembled near Boston, after the battle of Lexington,
into a Continental army and selected Washington as ommander-in-chief.
It assumed the powers of a government and prepared to raise money, wage
war, and carry on diploatic relations with foreign countries.

[Illustration: _From an old print_

SPIRIT OF 1776]

Events followed tick and fast. On June 17, the American militia, by
the stubborn defense of Bunker Hill, showed that it could make Bitish
regulars pay dearly for all they got. On July 3, Washington took command
of the army at Cambridge. In Januar, 1776, after bitter disappointments
in drumming up recruits for its army in England, Scotland, and Ireland,
the Bitish government concluded a treaty with the Landgrave of
Hesse-Cassel in Germany contracting, at a handsome figure for thousands
of soldiers and many pieces of cannon. This was the crowning insult to
America. Such was the view o all friends of the colonies on both sides
of the water. Such was, long afterward, the judgment of the conservative
historian Lecky: "The conduct of England in hiring German mercenaries to
subdue the essentially English populationbeyond the Atlantic made
reconciliation hopeless and independence inevitable." The news of this
wretched transactin in German soldiers had hardly reached America
before there ran all down the coast the thrilling story that Washinton
had taken Boston, on March 17, 1776, compelling Lord Howe to sail with
his entire army for Halifax.

=The Grwth of Public Sentiment in Favor of Independence.=--Events were
bearing the Americans away from their old position nder the British
constitution toward a final separation. Slowly and against their
desires, prudent and honorable mn, who cherished the ties that united
them to the old order and dreaded with genuine horror all thought of
revoluton, were drawn into the path that led to the great decision. In
all parts of the country and among all classes, thequestion of the hour
was being debated. "American independence," as the historian Bancroft
says, "was not an act o sudden passion nor the work of one man or one
assembly. It had been discussed in every part of the country by farmrs
and merchants, by mechanics and planters, by the fishermen along the
coast and the backwoodsmen of the West; intown meetings and from the
pulpit; at social gatherings and around the camp fires; in county
conventions and confeences or committees; in colonial congresses and
assemblies."

[Illustration: _From an old print_

THOMAS PAINE]

=Paine's "Commonsense."=--In the midst of this ferment of American
opinion, a bold and eloquent pamphleteer brok in upon the hesitating
public with a program for absolute independence, without fears and
without apologies. In te early days of 1776, Thomas Paine issued the
first of his famous tracts, "Commonsense," a passionate attack upon te
British monarchy and an equally passionate plea for American liberty.
Casting aside the language of petition wit which Americans had hitherto
addressed George III, Paine went to the other extreme and assailed him
with many a volent epithet. He condemned monarchy itself as a system
which had laid the world "in blood and ashes." Instead of paising the
British constitution under which colonists had been claiming their
rights, he brushed it aside as ridiclous, protesting that it was "owing
to the constitution of the people, not to the constitution of the
government, hat the Crown is not as oppressive in England as in
Turkey."

Having thus summarily swept away the grounds of allgiance to the old
order, Paine proceeded relentlessly to an argument for immediate
separation from Great Britain. here was nothing in the sphere of
practical interest, he insisted, which should bind the colonies to the
mother contry. Allegiance to her had been responsible for the many wars
in which they had been involved. Reasons of trade wee not less weighty
in behalf of independence. "Our corn will fetch its price in any market
in Europe and our impored goods must be paid for, buy them where we
will." As to matters of government, "it is not in the power of Britain
to do this continent justice; the business of it will soon be too
weighty and intricate to be managed with any tolrable degree of
convenience by a power so distant from us and so very ignorant of us."

There is accordingly no aternative to independence for America.
"Everything that is right or natural pleads for separation. The blood of
th slain, the weeping voice of nature cries ''tis time to part.' ...
Arms, the last resort, must decide the contest; he appeal was the
choice of the king and the continent hath accepted the challenge.... The
sun never shone on a case of greater worth. 'Tis not the affair of a
city, a county, a province or a kingdom, but of a continent.... 'Tis ot
the concern of a day, a year or an age; posterity is involved in the
contest and will be more or less affected o the end of time by the
proceedings now. Now is the seed-time of Continental union, faith, and
honor.... O! ye tht love mankind! Ye that dare oppose not only the
tyranny, but the tyrant, stand forth.... Let names of Whig and Tor be
extinct. Let none other be heard among us than those of a good citizen,
an open and resolute friend, and a viruous supporter of the rights of
mankind and of the free and independent states of America." As more than
100,000 cpies were scattered broadcast over the country, patriots
exclaimed with Washington: "Sound doctrine and unanswerabl reason!"

=The Drift of Events toward Independence.=--Official support for the
idea of independence began to com from many quarters. On the tenth of
February, 1776, Gadsden, in the provincial convention of South Carolina,
advoated a new constitution for the colony and absolute independence
for all America. The convention balked at the lattr but went half way
by abolishing the system of royal administration and establishing a
complete plan of self-govenment. A month later, on April 12, the
neighboring state of North Carolina uttered the daring phrase from which
oters shrank. It empowered its representatives in the Congress to
concur with the delegates of the other colonies in eclaring
independence. Rhode Island, Massachusetts, and Virginia quickly
responded to the challenge. The conventio of the Old Dominion, on May
15, instructed its delegates at Philadelphia to propose the independence
of the Unite Colonies and to give the assent of Virginia to the act of
separation. When the resolution was carried the British lag on the
state house was lowered for all time.

Meanwhile the Continental Congress was alive to the course of eents
outside. The subject of independence was constantly being raised. "Are
we rebels?" exclaimed Wyeth of Virgini during a debate in February.
"No: we must declare ourselves a free people." Others hesitated and
spoke of waitingfor the arrival of commissioners of conciliation. "Is
not America already independent?" asked Samuel Adams a few weks later.
"Why not then declare it?" Still there was uncertainty and delegates
avoided the direct word. A few moreweeks elapsed. At last, on May 10,
Congress declared that the authority of the British crown in America
must be supressed and advised the colonies to set up governments of
their own.

[Illustration: _From an old print_

THOMA JEFFERSON READING HIS DRAFT OF THE DECLARATION OF
INDEPENDENCE TO THE COMMITTEE OF CONGRESS]

=Independence Declred.=--The way was fully prepared, therefore, when,
on June 7, the Virginia delegation in the Congress moved that "hese
united colonies are and of right ought to be free and independent
states." A committee was immediately appoined to draft a formal
document setting forth the reasons for the act, and on July 2 all the
states save New York wet on record in favor of severing their political
connection with Great Britain. Two days later, July 4, Jefferson'sdraft
of the Declaration of Independence, changed in some slight particulars,
was adopted. The old bell in Indepenence Hall, as it is now known, rang
out the glad tidings; couriers swiftly carried the news to the uttermost
hamle and farm. A new nation announced its will to have a place among
the powers of the world.

To some documents is gven immortality. The Declaration of Independence
is one of them. American patriotism is forever associated with it;but
patriotism alone does not make it immortal. Neither does the vigor of
its language or the severity of its inditment give it a secure place in
the records of time. The secret of its greatness lies in the simple fact
that it i one of the memorable landmarks in the history of a political
ideal which for three centuries has been taking form nd spreading
throughout the earth, challenging kings and potentates, shaking down
thrones and aristocracies, breakng the armies of irresponsible power on
battle fields as far apart as Marston Moor and Chateau-Thierry. That
ideal now so familiar, then so novel, is summed up in the simple
sentence: "Governments derive their just powers from th consent of the
governed."

Written in a "decent respect for the opinions of mankind," to set forth
the causes wich impelled the American colonists to separate from
Britain, the Declaration contained a long list of "abuses andusurpations" which had induced them to throw off the government of King
George. That section of the Declaration haspassed into "ancient"
history and is seldom read. It is the part laying down a new basis for
government and givinga new dignity to the common man that has become a
household phrase in the Old World as in the New.

In the more eduring passages there are four fundamental ideas which,
from the standpoint of the old system of government, were te essence of
revolution: (1) all men are created equal and are endowed by their
Creator with certain unalienable rghts including life, liberty, and the
pursuit of happiness; (2) the purpose of government is to secure these
right; (3) governments derive their just powers from the consent of the
governed; (4) whenever any form of government beomes destructive of
these ends it is the right of the people to alter or abolish it and
institute new government, aying its foundations on such principles and
organizing its powers in such form as to them shall seem most likely t
effect their safety and happiness. Here was the prelude to the historic
drama of democracy--a challenge to every orm of government and every
privilege not founded on popular assent.


THE ESTABLISHMENT OF GOVERNMENT AND THE NW ALLEGIANCE

=The Committees of Correspondence.=--As soon as debate had passed into
armed resistance, the patrios found it necessary to consolidate their
forces by organizing civil government. This was readily effected, for
th means were at hand in town meetings, provincial legislatures, and
committees of correspondence. The working tools f the Revolution were
in fact the committees of correspondence--small, local, unofficial
groups of patriots formedto exchange views and create public sentiment.
As early as November, 1772, such a committee had been created in Boson
under the leadership of Samuel Adams. It held regular meetings, sent
emissaries to neighboring towns, and carrid on a campaign of education
in the doctrines of liberty.

[Illustration: THE COLONIES OF NORTH AMERICA AT THE TIE OF THE
DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE]

Upon local organizations similar in character to the Boston committee
wer built county committees and then the larger colonial committees,
congresses, and conventions, all unofficial and rpresenting the
revolutionary elements. Ordinarily the provincial convention was merely
the old legislative assembl freed from all royalist sympathizers and
controlled by patriots. Finally, upon these colonial assemblies was
buil the Continental Congress, the precursor of union under the
Articles of Confederation and ultimately under the Consitution of the
United States. This was the revolutionary government set up within the
British empire in America.

=State Constitutions Framed.=--With the rise of these new assemblies of
the people, the old colonial governments boke down. From the royal
provinces the governor, the judges, and the high officers fled in haste,
and it became neessary to substitute patriot authorities. The appeal to
the colonies advising them to adopt a new form of governmen for
themselves, issued by the Congress in May, 1776, was quickly acted upon.
Before the expiration of a year, Virinia, New Jersey, Pennsylvania,
Delaware, Maryland, Georgia, and New York had drafted new constitutions
as states,not as colonies uncertain of their destinies. Connecticut and
Rhode Island, holding that their ancient charters wer equal to their
needs, merely renounced their allegiance to the king and went on as
before so far as the form of gvernment was concerned. South Carolina,
which had drafted a temporary plan early in 1776, drew up a new and more
cmplete constitution in 1778. Two years later Massachusetts with much
deliberation put into force its fundamental la, which in most of its
essential features remains unchanged to-day.

The new state constitutions in their broad otlines followed colonial
models. For the royal governor was substituted a governor or president
chosen usually by he legislature; but in two instances, New York and
Massachusetts, by popular vote. For the provincial council therewas
substituted, except in Georgia, a senate; while the lower house, or
assembly, was continued virtually without hange. The old property
restriction on the suffrage, though lowered slightly in some states, was
continued in fullforce to the great discontent of the mechanics thus
deprived of the ballot. The special qualifications, laid down i several
constitutions, for governors, senators, and representatives, indicated
that the revolutionary leaders wer not prepared for any radical
experiments in democracy. The protests of a few women, like Mrs. John
Adams of Massahusetts and Mrs. Henry Corbin of Virginia, against a
government which excluded them from political rights were treaed as
mild curiosities of no significance, although in New Jersey women were
allowed to vote for many years on thesame terms as men.

By the new state constitutions the signs and symbols of royal power, of
authority derived fro any source save "the people," were swept aside
and republican governments on an imposing scale presented for the frst
time to the modern world. Copies of these remarkable documents prepared
by plain citizens were translated intoFrench and widely circulated in
Europe. There they were destined to serve as a guide and inspiration to
a generatin of constitution-makers whose mission it was to begin the
democratic revolution in the Old World.

=The Articlesof Confederation.=--The formation of state constitutions
was an easy task for the revolutionary leaders. They had oly to build
on foundations already laid. The establishment of a national system of
government was another matter. here had always been, it must be
remembered, a system of central control over the colonies, but Americans
had had ittle experience in its operation. When the supervision of the
crown of Great Britain was suddenly broken, the patrot leaders,
accustomed merely to provincial statesmanship, were poorly trained for
action on a national stage.

any forces worked against those who, like Franklin, had a vision of
national destiny. There were differences in ecoomic interest--commerce
and industry in the North and the planting system of the South. There
were contests over te apportionment of taxes and the quotas of troops
for common defense. To these practical difficulties were added loal
pride, the vested rights of state and village politicians in their
provincial dignity, and the scarcity of men ith a large outlook upon
the common enterprise.

Nevertheless, necessity compelled them to consider some sort offederation. The second Continental Congress had hardly opened its work
before the most sagacious leaders began to uge the desirability of a
permanent connection. As early as July, 1775, Congress resolved to go
into a committee ofthe whole on the state of the union, and Franklin,
undaunted by the fate of his Albany plan of twenty years before,again
presented a draft of a constitution. Long and desultory debates followed
and it was not until late in 1777 tat Congress presented to the states
the Articles of Confederation. Provincial jealousies delayed
ratification, andit was the spring of 1781, a few months before the
surrender of Cornwallis at Yorktown, when Maryland, the last of he
states, approved the Articles. This plan of union, though it was all
that could be wrung from the reluctant staes, provided for neither a
chief executive nor a system of federal courts. It created simply a
Congress of delegats in which each state had an equal voice and gave it
the right to call upon the state legislatures for the sinews o
government--money and soldiers.

=The Application of Tests of Allegiance.=--As the successive steps were
taken n the direction of independent government, the patriots devised
and applied tests designed to discover who were forand who were against
the new nation in the process of making. When the first Continental
Congress agreed not to alow the importation of British goods, it
provided for the creation of local committees to enforce the rules. Such
aencies were duly formed by the choice of men favoring the scheme, all
opponents being excluded from the elections. efore these bodies those
who persisted in buying British goods were summoned and warned or
punished according to crcumstances. As soon as the new state
constitutions were put into effect, local committees set to work in the
sameway to ferret out all who were not outspoken in their support of
the new order of things.

[Illustration: MOBBINGTHE TORIES]

These patriot agencies, bearing different names in different sections,
were sometimes ruthless in thir methods. They called upon all men to
sign the test of loyalty, frequently known as the "association test."
Thos who refused were promptly branded as outlaws, while some of the
more dangerous were thrown into jail. The prison cmp in Connecticut at
one time held the former governor of New Jersey and the mayor of New
York. Thousands were blak-listed and subjected to espionage. The
black-list of Pennsylvania contained the names of nearly five hundred
perons of prominence who were under suspicion. Loyalists or Tories who
were bold enough to speak and write against theRevolution were
suppressed and their pamphlets burned. In many places, particularly in
the North, the property of he loyalists was confiscated and the
proceeds applied to the cause of the Revolution.

The work of the official aencies for suppression of opposition was
sometimes supplemented by mob violence. A few Tories were hanged without
rial, and others were tarred and feathered. One was placed upon a cake
of ice and held there "until his loyalty to ing George might cool."
Whole families were driven out of their homes to find their way as best
they could within he British lines or into Canada, where the British
government gave them lands. Such excesses were deplored by Washigton,
but they were defended on the ground that in effect a civil war, as well
as a war for independence, was bein waged.

=The Patriots and Tories.=--Thus, by one process or another, those who
were to be citizens of the new reublic were separated from those who
preferred to be subjects of King George. Just what proportion of the
Americansfavored independence and what share remained loyal to the
British monarchy there is no way of knowing. The questionof revolution
was not submitted to popular vote, and on the point of numbers we have
conflicting evidence. On the atriot side, there is the testimony of a
careful and informed observer, John Adams, who asserted that two-thirds
o the people were for the American cause and not more than one-third
opposed the Revolution at all stages.

On behlf of the loyalists, or Tories as they were popularly known,
extravagant claims were made. Joseph Galloway, who hadbeen a member of
the first Continental Congress and had fled to England when he saw its
temper, testified before acommittee of Parliament in 1779 that not
one-fifth of the American people supported the insurrection and that
"man more than four-fifths of the people prefer a union with Great
Britain upon constitutional principles to independene." At the same
time General Robertson, who had lived in America twenty-four years,
declared that "more than two-tirds of the people would prefer the
king's government to the Congress' tyranny." In an address to the king
in thatyear a committee of American loyalists asserted that "the number
of Americans in his Majesty's army exceeded the nuber of troops
enlisted by Congress to oppose them."

=The Character of the Loyalists.=--When General Howe evacuatd Boston,
more than a thousand people fled with him. This great company, according
to a careful historian, "formedthe aristocracy of the province by
virtue of their official rank; of their dignified callings and
professions; of heir hereditary wealth and of their culture." The act
of banishment passed by Massachusetts in 1778, listing over 30 Tories,
"reads like the social register of the oldest and noblest families of
New England," more than one out offive being graduates of Harvard
College. The same was true of New York and Philadelphia; namely, that
the leading oyalists were prominent officials of the old order,
clergymen and wealthy merchants. With passion the loyalists fouht
against the inevitable or with anguish of heart they left as refugees
for a life of uncertainty in Canada or th mother country.

=Tories Assail the Patriots.=--The Tories who remained in America joined
the British army by th thousands or in other ways aided the royal
cause. Those who were skillful with the pen assailed the patriots in
eitorials, rhymes, satires, and political catechisms. They declared
that the members of Congress were "obscure, pettfogging attorneys,
bankrupt shopkeepers, outlawed smugglers, etc." The people and their
leaders they characterizedas "wretched banditti ... the refuse and
dregs of mankind." The generals in the army they sneered at as "men of
rak and honor nearly on a par with those of the Congress."

=Patriot Writers Arouse the National Spirit.=--Stung by ory taunts,
patriot writers devoted themselves to creating and sustaining a public
opinion favorable to the Americn cause. Moreover, they had to combat
the depression that grew out of the misfortunes in the early days of the
war A terrible disaster befell Generals Arnold and Montgomery in the
winter of 1775 as they attempted to bring Canada nto the revolution--a
disaster that cost 5000 men; repeated calamities harassed Washington in
1776 as he was defeaed on Long Island, driven out of New York City, and
beaten at Harlem Heights and White Plains. These reverses were lmost
too great for the stoutest patriots.

Pamphleteers, preachers, and publicists rose, however, to meet the neds
of the hour. John Witherspoon, provost of the College of New Jersey,
forsook the classroom for the field of poltical controversy. The poet,
Philip Freneau, flung taunts of cowardice at the Tories and celebrated
the spirit of iberty in many a stirring poem. Songs, ballads, plays,
and satires flowed from the press in an unending stream. Fas days,
battle anniversaries, celebrations of important steps taken by Congress
afforded to patriotic clergymen abudant opportunities for sermons.
"Does Mr. Wiberd preach against oppression?" anxiously inquired John
Adams in a leter to his wife. The answer was decisive. "The clergy of
every denomination, not excepting the Episcopalian, thunde and lighten
every Sabbath. They pray for Boston and Massachusetts. They thank God
most explicitly and fervently fr our remarkable successes. They pray
for the American army."

Thomas Paine never let his pen rest. He had been wth the forces of
Washington when they retreated from Fort Lee and were harried from New
Jersey into Pennsylvania. e knew the effect of such reverses on the
army as well as on the public. In December, 1776, he made a second greatappeal to his countrymen in his pamphlet, "The Crisis," the first part
of which he had written while defeat and glom were all about him. This
tract was a cry for continued support of the Revolution. "These are the
times that try en's souls," he opened. "The summer soldier and the
sunshine patriot will, in this crisis, shrink from the service f his
country; but he that stands it now deserves the love and thanks of men
and women." Paine laid his lash fiercly on the Tories, branding every
one as a coward grounded in "servile, slavish, self-interested fear." He
deploredthe inadequacy of the militia and called for a real army. He
refuted the charge that the retreat through New Jerseywas a disaster
and he promised victory soon. "By perseverance and fortitude," he
concluded, "we have the prospect f a glorious issue; by cowardice and
submission the sad choice of a variety of evils--a ravaged country, a
depopulted city, habitations without safety and slavery without
hope.... Look on this picture and weep over it." His ringig call to
arms was followed by another and another until the long contest was
over.


MILITARY AFFAIRS

=The wo Phases of the War.=--The war which opened with the battle of
Lexington, on April 19, 1775, and closed with the srrender of
Cornwallis at Yorktown on October 19, 1781, passed through two distinct
phases--the first lasting untilthe treaty of alliance with France, in
1778, and the second until the end of the struggle. During the first
phase,the war was confined mainly to the North. The outstanding
features of the contest were the evacuation of Boston by he British,
the expulsion of American forces from New York and their retreat through
New Jersey, the battle of Treton, the seizure of Philadelphia by the
British (September, 1777), the invasion of New York by Burgoyne and his
cature at Saratoga in October, 1777, and the encampment of American
forces at Valley Forge for the terrible winter of1777-78.

The final phase of the war, opening with the treaty of alliance with
France on February 6, 1778, was cofined mainly to the Middle states,
the West, and the South. In the first sphere of action the chief events
were th withdrawal of the British from Philadelphia, the battle of
Monmouth, and the inclosure of the British in New York y deploying
American forces from Morristown, New Jersey, up to West Point. In the
West, George Rogers Clark, by hi famous march into the Illinois
country, secured Kaskaskia and Vincennes and laid a firm grip on the
country betwen the Ohio and the Great Lakes. In the South, the second
period opened with successes for the British. They capture Savannah,
conquered Georgia, and restored the royal governor. In 1780 they seized
Charleston, administered a crusing defeat to the American forces under
Gates at Camden, and overran South Carolina, though meeting reverses at
Copens and King's Mountain. Then came the closing scenes. Cornwallis
began the last of his operations. He pursued Genral Greene far into
North Carolina, clashed with him at Guilford Court House, retired to the
coast, took charge ofBritish forces engaged in plundering Virginia, and
fortified Yorktown, where he was penned up by the French fleet fom the
sea and the combined French and American forces on land.

=The Geographical Aspects of the War.=--For the ritish the theater of
the war offered many problems. From first to last it extended from
Massachusetts to Georgia,a distance of almost a thousand miles. It was
nearly three thousand miles from the main base of supplies and, thoug
the British navy kept the channel open, transports were constantly
falling prey to daring privateers and fleet Amrican war vessels. The
sea, on the other hand, offered an easy means of transportation between
points along the cost and gave ready access to the American centers of
wealth and population. Of this the British made good use. Thoug early
forced to give up Boston, they seized New York and kept it until the end
of the war; they took Philadelphiaand retained it until threatened by
the approach of the French fleet; and they captured and held both
Savannah andCharleston. Wars, however, are seldom won by the conquest
of cities.

Particularly was this true in the case of te Revolution. Only a small
portion of the American people lived in towns. Countrymen back from the
coast were in n way dependent upon them for a livelihood. They lived on
the produce of the soil, not upon the profits of trade. Ths very fact
gave strength to them in the contest. Whenever the British ventured far
from the ports of entry, they ncountered reverses. Burgoyne was forced
to surrender at Saratoga because he was surrounded and cut off from his
bse of supplies. As soon as the British got away from Charleston, they
were harassed and worried by the guerrilla wariors of Marion, Sumter,
and Pickens. Cornwallis could technically defeat Greene at Guilford far
in the interior; ut he could not hold the inland region he had invaded.
Sustained by their own labor, possessing the interior to whih their
armies could readily retreat, supplied mainly from native resources, the
Americans could not be hemmed in,penned up, and destroyed at one fell
blow.

=The Sea Power.=--The British made good use of their fleet in cutting
off American trade, but control of the sea did not seriously affect the
United States. As an agricultural country,the ruin of its commerce was
not such a vital matter. All the materials for a comfortable though
somewhat rude lif were right at hand. It made little difference to a
nation fighting for existence, if silks, fine linens, and chinaare were
cut off. This was an evil to which submission was necessary.

Nor did the brilliant exploits of John Pau Jones and Captain John Barry
materially change the situation. They demonstrated the skill of American
seamen and heir courage as fighting men. They raised the rates of
British marine insurance, but they did not dethrone the mistess of the
seas. Less spectacular, and more distinctive, were the deeds of the
hundreds of privateers and minor catains who overhauled British supply
ships and kept British merchantmen in constant anxiety. Not until the
French feet was thrown into the scale, were the British compelled to
reckon seriously with the enemy on the sea and make plns based upon the
possibilities of a maritime disaster.

=Commanding Officers.=--On the score of military leadersip it is
difficult to compare the contending forces in the revolutionary contest.
There is no doubt that all the Bitish commanders were men of experience
in the art of warfare. Sir William Howe had served in America during the
Fench War and was accounted an excellent officer, a strict
disciplinarian, and a gallant gentleman. Nevertheless he oved ease,
society, and good living, and his expulsion from Boston, his failure to
overwhelm Washington by salliesfrom his comfortable bases at New York
and Philadelphia, destroyed every shred of his military reputation. John
Bugoyne, to whom was given the task of penetrating New York from
Canada, had likewise seen service in the French War oth in America and
Europe. He had, however, a touch of the theatrical in his nature and
after the collapse of his lans and the surrender of his army in 1777,
he devoted his time mainly to light literature. Sir Henry Clinton, whodirected the movement which ended in the capture of Charleston in 1780,
had "learned his trade on the continent," ad was regarded as a man of
discretion and understanding in military matters. Lord Cornwallis, whose
achievements a Camden and Guilford were blotted out by his surrender at
Yorktown, had seen service in the Seven Years' War and ha undoubted
talents which he afterward displayed with great credit to himself in
India. Though none of them, perhap, were men of first-rate ability,
they all had training and experience to guide them.

[Illustration: GEORGE WASHNGTON]

The Americans had a host in Washington himself. He had long been
interested in military strategy and had ested his coolness under fire
during the first clashes with the French nearly twenty years before. He
had no doubt about the justice of his cause, such as plagued some of
the British generals. He was a stern but reasonable discipinarian. He
was reserved and patient, little given to exaltation at success or
depression at reverses. In the darkhour of the Revolution, "what held
the patriot forces together?" asks Beveridge in his _Life of John
Marshall_. Thn he answers: "George Washington and he alone. Had he
died or been seriously disabled, the Revolution would have ened....
Washington was the soul of the American cause. Washington was the
government. Washington was the Revolution" The weakness of Congress in
furnishing men and supplies, the indolence of civilians, who lived at
ease while thearmy starved, the intrigues of army officers against him
such as the "Conway cabal," the cowardice of Lee at Monmouh, even the
treason of Benedict Arnold, while they stirred deep emotions in his
breast and aroused him to make pasionate pleas to his countrymen, did
not shake his iron will or his firm determination to see the war through
to th bitter end. The weight of Washington's moral force was
immeasurable.

Of the generals who served under him, nonecan really be said to have
been experienced military men when the war opened. Benedict Arnold, the
unhappy traitorbut brave and daring soldier, was a druggist, book
seller, and ship owner at New Haven when the news of Lexington clled
him to battle. Horatio Gates was looked upon as a "seasoned soldier"
because he had entered the British army s a youth, had been wounded at
Braddock's memorable defeat, and had served with credit during the Seven
Years' War but he was the most conspicuous failure of the Revolution.
The triumph over Burgoyne was the work of other men; an his crushing
defeat at Camden put an end to his military pretensions. Nathanael
Greene was a Rhode Island farmer nd smith without military experience
who, when convinced that war was coming, read Caesar's _Commentaries_ and
too up the sword. Francis Marion was a shy and modest planter of South
Carolina whose sole passage at arms had been a rief but desperate brush
with the Indians ten or twelve years earlier. Daniel Morgan, one of the
heroes of Cowpens had been a teamster with Braddock's army and had seen
some fighting during the French and Indian War, but his miliary
knowledge, from the point of view of a trained British officer, was
negligible. John Sullivan was a successfullawyer at Durham, New
Hampshire, and a major in the local militia when duty summoned him to
lay down his briefs an take up the sword. Anthony Wayne was a
Pennsylvania farmer and land surveyor who, on hearing the clash of arms,
rad a few books on war, raised a regiment, and offered himself for
service. Such is the story of the chief American ilitary leaders, and
it is typical of them all. Some had seen fighting with the French and
Indians, but none of thm had seen warfare on a large scale with regular
troops commanded according to the strategy evolved in European
exerience. Courage, native ability, quickness of mind, and knowledge of
the country they had in abundance, and in batles such as were fought
during the Revolution all those qualities counted heavily in the
balance.

=Foreign Offiers in American Service.=--To native genius was added
military talent from beyond the seas. Baron Steuben, well scholed in
the iron regime of Frederick the Great, came over from Prussia, joined
Washington at Valley Forge, and dayafter day drilled and manoeuvered the
men, laughing and cursing as he turned raw countrymen into regular
soldiers.From France came young Lafayette and the stern De Kalb, from
Poland came Pulaski and Kosciusko;--all acquainted wit the arts of war
as waged in Europe and fitted for leadership as well as teaching.
Lafayette came early, in 1776, n a ship of his own, accompanied by
several officers of wide experience, and remained loyally throughout the
war saring the hardships of American army life. Pulaski fell at the
siege of Savannah and De Kalb at Camden. Kosciusko srvived the American
war to defend in vain the independence of his native land. To these
distinguished foreigners, ho freely threw in their lot with American
revolutionary fortunes, was due much of that spirit and discipline which
fitted raw recruits and temperamental militiamen to cope with a military
power of the first rank.

=The Soldiers=--As far as the British soldiers were concerned their
annals are short and simple. The regulars from the standing rmy who
were sent over at the opening of the contest, the recruits drummed up
by special efforts at home, and the housands of Hessians bought
outright by King George presented few problems of management to the
British officers. hese common soldiers were far away from home and
enlisted for the war. Nearly all of them were well disciplined andmany
of them experienced in actual campaigns. The armies of King George
fought bravely, as the records of Bunker Hll, Brandywine, and Monmouth
demonstrate. Many a man and subordinate officer and, for that matter,
some of the hig officers expressed a reluctance at fighting against
their own kin; but they obeyed orders.

The Americans, on th other hand, while they fought with grim
determination, as men fighting for their homes, were lacking in
disciplin and in the experience of regular troops. When the war broke
in upon them, there were no common preparations for it There was no
continental army; there were only local bands of militiamen, many of
them experienced in fighting bu few of them "regulars" in the military
sense. Moreover they were volunteers serving for a short time,
unaccustome to severe discipline, and impatient at the restraints
imposed on them by long and arduous campaigns. They were coninually
leaving the service just at the most critical moments. "The militia,"
lamented Washington, "come in, you cnnot tell how; go, you cannot tell
where; consume your provisions; exhaust your stores; and leave you at
last at acritical moment."

Again and again Washington begged Congress to provide for an army of
regulars enlisted for thewar, thoroughly trained and paid according to
some definite plan. At last he was able to overcome, in part at least
the chronic fear of civilians in Congress and to wring from that
reluctant body an agreement to grant half pay toall officers and a
bonus to all privates who served until the end of the war. Even this
scheme, which Washington rgarded as far short of justice to the
soldiers, did not produce quick results. It was near the close of the
conflit before he had an army of well-disciplined veterans capable of
meeting British regulars on equal terms.

Though here were times when militiamen and frontiersmen did valiant and
effective work, it is due to historical accuracy t deny the
time-honored tradition that a few minutemen overwhelmed more numerous
forces of regulars in a seven year' war for independence. They did
nothing of the sort. For the victories of Bennington, Trenton, Saratoga,
and Yorkown there were the defeats of Bunker Hill, Long Island, White
Plains, Germantown, and Camden. Not once did an army f militiamen
overcome an equal number of British regulars in an open trial by battle.
"To bring men to be well acqainted with the duties of a soldier," wrote
Washington, "requires time.... To expect the same service from raw andundisciplined recruits as from veteran soldiers is to expect what never
did and perhaps never will happen."

=Howthe War Was Won.=--Then how did the American army win the war? For
one thing there were delays and blunders on the art of the British
generals who, in 1775 and 1776, dallied in Boston and New York with
large bodies of regular trops when they might have been dealing
paralyzing blows at the scattered bands that constituted the American
army. "othing but the supineness or folly of the enemy could have saved
us," solemnly averred Washington in 1780. Still itis fair to say that
this apparent supineness was not all due to the British generals. The
ministers behind them beieved that a large part of the colonists were
loyal and that compromise would be promoted by inaction rather than b a
war vigorously prosecuted. Victory by masterly inactivity was obviously
better than conquest, and the slighter he wounds the quicker the
healing. Later in the conflict when the seasoned forces of France were
thrown into the sale, the Americans themselves had learned many things
about the practical conduct of campaigns. All along, the Britsh were
embarrassed by the problem of supplies. Their troops could not forage
with the skill of militiamen, as the were in unfamiliar territory. The
long oversea voyages were uncertain at best and doubly so when the
warships of rance joined the American privateers in preying on supply
boats.

The British were in fact battered and worn downby a guerrilla war and
outdone on two important occasions by superior forces--at Saratoga and
Yorktown. Stern fact convinced them finally that an immense army, which
could be raised only by a supreme effort, would be necessary tosubdue
the colonies if that hazardous enterprise could be accomplished at all.
They learned also that America woul then be alienated, fretful, and the
scene of endless uprisings calling for an army of occupation. That was a
pric which staggered even Lord North and George III. Moreover, there
were forces of opposition at home with which they ad to reckon.

=Women and the War.=--At no time were the women of America indifferent
to the struggle for indepenence. When it was confined to the realm of
opinion they did their part in creating public sentiment. Mrs. Elizabeth
Timothee, for example, founded in Charleston, in 1773, a newspaper to
espouse the cause of the province. Far to th north the sister of James
Otis, Mrs. Mercy Warren, early begged her countrymen to rest their case
upon their natual rights, and in influential circles she urged the
leaders to stand fast by their principles. While John Adams wastossing
about with uncertainty at the Continental Congress, his wife was writing
letters to him declaring her fait in "independency."

When the war came down upon the country, women helped in every field. In
sustaining public sntiment they were active. Mrs. Warren with a
tireless pen combatted loyalist propaganda in many a drama and satire.
Almost every revolutionary leader had a wife or daughter who rendered
service in the "second line of defense." Mrs Washington managed the
plantation while the General was at the front and went north to face the
rigors of the awfl winter at Valley Forge--an inspiration to her
husband and his men. The daughter of Benjamin Franklin, Mrs. SarahBache, while her father was pleading the American cause in France, set
the women of Pennsylvania to work sewing andcollecting supplies. Even
near the firing line women were to be found, aiding the wounded, hauling
powder to the font, and carrying dispatches at the peril of their
lives.

In the economic sphere, the work of women was invaluabe. They harvested
crops without enjoying the picturesque title of "farmerettes" and they
canned and preserved for he wounded and the prisoners of war. Of their
labor in spinning and weaving it is recorded: "Immediately on being ct
off from the use of English manufactures, the women engaged within their
own families in manufacturing various knds of cloth for domestic use.
They thus kept their households decently clad and the surplus of their
labors they old to such as chose to buy rather than make for
themselves. In this way the female part of families by their indusry
and strict economy frequently supported the whole domestic circle,
evincing the strength of their attachment an the value of their
service."

For their war work, women were commended by high authorities on more
than one occsion. They were given medals and public testimonials even
as in our own day. Washington thanked them for their labos and paid
tribute to them for the inspiration and material aid which they had
given to the cause of independence.


THE FINANCES OF THE REVOLUTION

When the Revolution opened, there were thirteen little treasuries in
Americabut no common treasury, and from first to last the Congress was
in the position of a beggar rather than a sovereign Having no authority
to lay and collect taxes directly and knowing the hatred of the
provincials for taxation, it esorted mainly to loans and paper money to
finance the war. "Do you think," boldly inquired one of the delegates,
that I will consent to load my constituents with taxes when we can send
to the printer and get a wagon load of mone, one quire of which will
pay for the whole?"

=Paper Money and Loans.=--Acting on this curious but appealing poltical
economy, Congress issued in June, 1776, two million dollars in bills of
credit to be redeemed by the states n the basis of their respective
populations. Other issues followed in quick succession. In all about
$241,000,000 f continental paper was printed, to which the several
states added nearly $210,000,000 of their own notes. Then cam
interest-bearing bonds in ever increasing quantities. Several millions
were also borrowed from France and small sms from Holland and Spain. In
desperation a national lottery was held, producing meager results. The
property of Tries was confiscated and sold, bringing in about
$16,000,000. Begging letters were sent to the states asking them t
raise revenues for the continental treasury, but the states, burdened
with their own affairs, gave little heed.

=Inflation and Depreciation.=--As paper money flowed from the press, it
rapidly declined in purchasing power untilin 1779 a dollar was worth
only two or three cents in gold or silver. Attempts were made by
Congress and the state to compel people to accept the notes at face
value; but these were like attempts to make water flow uphill.
Specuators collected at once to fatten on the calamities of the
republic. Fortunes were made and lost gambling on the prces of public
securities while the patriot army, half clothed, was freezing at Valley
Forge. "Speculation, peculaton, engrossing, forestalling," exclaimed
Washington, "afford too many melancholy proofs of the decay of public
virue. Nothing, I am convinced, but the depreciation of our currency
... aided by stock jobbing and party dissensions as fed the hopes of
the enemy."

=The Patriot Financiers.=--To the efforts of Congress in financing the
war wereadded the labors of private citizens. Hayn Solomon, a merchant
of Philadelphia, supplied members of Congress, incluing Madison,
Jefferson, and Monroe, and army officers, like Lee and Steuben, with
money for their daily needs. Alltogether he contributed the huge sum of
half a million dollars to the American cause and died broken in purse,
if ot in spirit, a British prisoner of war. Another Philadelphia
merchant, Robert Morris, won for himself the name of he "patriot
financier" because he labored night and day to find the money to meet
the bills which poured in upon te bankrupt government. When his own
funds were exhausted, he borrowed from his friends. Experienced in the
handlin of merchandise, he created agencies at important points to
distribute supplies to the troops, thus displaying admiistrative as
well as financial talents.

[Illustration: ROBERT MORRIS]

Women organized "drives" for money, conributed their plate and their
jewels, and collected from door to door. Farmers took worthless paper in
return for heir produce, and soldiers saw many a pay day pass without
yielding them a penny. Thus by the labors and sacrificesof citizens,
the issuance of paper money, lotteries, the floating of loans,
borrowings in Europe, and the impressmnt of supplies, the Congress
staggered through the Revolution like a pauper who knows not how his
next meal is to e secured but is continuously relieved at a crisis by a
kindly fate.


THE DIPLOMACY OF THE REVOLUTION

When te full measure of honor is given to the soldiers and sailors and
their commanding officers, the civilians who managd finances and
supplies, the writers who sustained the American spirit, and the women
who did well their part, thee yet remains the duty of recognizing the
achievements of diplomacy. The importance of this field of activity was
eenly appreciated by the leaders in the Continental Congress. They were
fairly well versed in European history. The knew of the balance of
power and the sympathies, interests, and prejudices of nations and their
rulers. All this nformation they turned to good account, in opening
relations with continental countries and seeking money, supplies and
even military assistance. For the transaction of this delicate business,
they created a secret committee on freign correspondence as early as
1775 and prepared to send agents abroad.

=American Agents Sent Abroad.=--Havingheard that France was inclining a
friendly ear to the American cause, the Congress, in March, 1776, sent a
commissoner to Paris, Silas Deane of Connecticut, often styled the
"first American diplomat." Later in the year a form of reaty to be
presented to foreign powers was drawn up, and Franklin, Arthur Lee, and
Deane were selected as America representatives at the court of "His
Most Christian Majesty the King of France." John Jay of New York was
chosen inister to Spain in 1779; John Adams was sent to Holland the
same year; and other agents were dispatched to Florenc, Vienna, and
Berlin. The representative selected for St. Petersburg spent two
fruitless years there, "ignored by he court, living in obscurity and
experiencing nothing but humiliation and failure." Frederick the Great,
king of russia, expressed a desire to find in America a market for
Silesian linens and woolens, but, fearing England's commnd of the sea,
he refused to give direct aid to the Revolutionary cause.

=Early French Interest.=--The great dipomatic triumph of the Revolution
was won at Paris, and Benjamin Franklin was the hero of the occasion,
although may circumstances prepared the way for his success. Louis
XVI's foreign minister, Count de Vergennes, before the arrial of any
American representative, had brought to the attention of the king the
opportunity offered by the outbrea of the war between England and her
colonies. He showed him how France could redress her grievances and
"reduce th power and greatness of England"--the empire that in 1763 had
forced upon her a humiliating peace "at the price of ur possessions,
of our commerce, and our credit in the Indies, at the price of Canada,
Louisiana, Isle Royale, Acaia, and Senegal." Equally successful in
gaining the king's interest was a curious French adventurer,
Beaumarchais,a man of wealth, a lover of music, and the author of two
popular plays, "Figaro" and "The Barber of Seville." Thesetwo men had
already urged upon the king secret aid for America before Deane appeared
on the scene. Shortly after hs arrival they made confidential
arrangements to furnish money, clothing, powder, and other supplies to
the strugging colonies, although official requests for them were
officially refused by the French government.

=Franklin atParis.=--When Franklin reached Paris, he was received only
in private by the king's minister, Vergennes. The Frenchpeople,
however, made manifest their affection for the "plain republican" in
"his full dress suit of spotted Manchster velvet." He was known among
men of letters as an author, a scientist, and a philosopher of
extraordinary abilty. His "Poor Richard" had thrice been translated
into French and was scattered in numerous editions throughout the
kingdom. People of all ranks--ministers, ladies at court, philosophers,
peasants, and stable boys--knew of Frankli and wished him success in
his mission. The queen, Marie Antoinette, fated to lose her head in a
revolution soon t follow, played with fire by encouraging "our dear
republican."

For the king of France, however, this was more srious business. England
resented the presence of this "traitor" in Paris, and Louis had to be
cautious about plungng into another war that might also end
disastrously. Moreover, the early period of Franklin's sojourn in Paris
wa a dark hour for the American Revolution. Washington's brilliant
exploit at Trenton on Christmas night, 1776, and te battle with
Cornwallis at Princeton had been followed by the disaster at Brandywine,
the loss of Philadelphia, te defeat at Germantown, and the retirement
to Valley Forge for the winter of 1777-78. New York City and
Philadelpha--two strategic ports--were in British hands; the Hudson
and Delaware rivers were blocked; and General Burgoyne wih his British
troops was on his way down through the heart of northern New York,
cutting New England off from the est of the colonies. No wonder the
king was cautious. Then the unexpected happened. Burgoyne, hemmed in
from all sdes by the American forces, his flanks harried, his foraging
parties beaten back, his supplies cut off, surrenderedon October 17,
1777, to General Gates, who had superseded General Schuyler in time to
receive the honor.

=Treates of Alliance and Commerce (1778).=--News of this victory,
placed by historians among the fifteen decisive battlesof the world,
reached Franklin one night early in December while he and some friends
sat gloomily at dinner. Beaumrchais, who was with him, grasped at once
the meaning of the situation and set off to the court at Versailles withsuch haste that he upset his coach and dislocated his arm. The king and
his ministers were at last convinced that te hour had come to aid the
Revolution. Treaties of commerce and alliance were drawn up and signed
in February, 177. The independence of the United States was recognized
by France and an alliance was formed to guarantee that indepndence.
Combined military action was agreed upon and Louis then formally
declared war on England. Men who had, a fw short years before, fought
one another in the wilderness of Pennsylvania or on the Plains of
Abraham, were now rnged side by side in a war on the Empire that Pitt
had erected and that George III was pulling down.

=Spain and olland Involved.=--Within a few months, Spain, remembering
the steady decline of her sea power since the days of th Armada and
hoping to drive the British out of Gibraltar, once more joined the
concert of nations against England.Holland, a member of a league of
armed neutrals formed in protest against British searches on the high
seas, sent er fleet to unite with the forces of Spain, France, and
America to prey upon British commerce. To all this trouble or England
was added the danger of a possible revolt in Ireland, where the spirit
of independence was flaming up.
=The British Offer Terms to America.=--Seeing the colonists about to be
joined by France in a common war on the Eglish empire, Lord North
proposed, in February, 1778, a renewal of negotiations. By solemn
enactment, Parliament dclared its intention not to exercise the right
of imposing taxes within the colonies; at the same time it authorize
the opening of negotiations through commissioners to be sent to America.
A truce was to be established, pardons ganted, objectionable laws
suspended, and the old imperial constitution, as it stood before the
opening of hostilites, restored to full vigor. It was too late. Events
had taken the affairs of America out of the hands of British
cmmissioners and diplomats.

=Effects of French Aid.=--The French alliance brought ships of war,
large sums of gol and silver, loads of supplies, and a considerable
body of trained soldiers to the aid of the Americans. Timely as as this
help, it meant no sudden change in the fortunes of war. The British
evacuated Philadelphia in the summer fllowing the alliance, and
Washington's troops were encouraged to come out of Valley Forge. They
inflicted a heavy low on the British at Monmouth, but the treasonable
conduct of General Charles Lee prevented a triumph. The recover of
Philadelphia was offset by the treason of Benedict Arnold, the loss of
Savannah and Charleston (1780), and thedefeat of Gates at Camden.

The full effect of the French alliance was not felt until 1781, when
Cornwallis went nto Virginia and settled at Yorktown. Accompanied by
French troops Washington swept rapidly southward and penned th British
to the shore while a powerful French fleet shut off their escape by sea.
It was this movement, which certinly could not have been executed
without French aid, that put an end to all chance of restoring British
dominion n America. It was the surrender of Cornwallis at Yorktown that
caused Lord North to pace the floor and cry out: "Itis all over! It is
all over!" What might have been done without the French alliance lies
hidden from mankind. Whatwas accomplished with the help of French
soldiers, sailors, officers, money, and supplies, is known to all the
earh. "All the world agree," exultantly wrote Franklin from Paris to
General Washington, "that no expedition was ever etter planned or
better executed. It brightens the glory that must accompany your name to
the latest posterity." Dplomacy as well as martial valor had its
reward.


PEACE AT LAST

=British Opposition to the War.=--In measurig the forces that led to
the final discomfiture of King George and Lord North, it is necessary to
remember that frm the beginning to the end the British ministry at home
faced a powerful, informed, and relentless opposition. Ther were
vigorous protests, first against the obnoxious acts which precipitated
the unhappy quarrel, then against theway in which the war was waged,
and finally against the futile struggle to retain a hold upon the
American dominios. Among the members of Parliament who thundered
against the government were the first statesmen and orators of theland.
William Pitt, Earl of Chatham, though he deplored the idea of American
independence, denounced the governmen as the aggressor and rejoiced in
American resistance. Edmund Burke leveled his heavy batteries against
every measre of coercion and at last strove for a peace which, while
giving independence to America, would work for reconcilition rather
than estrangement. Charles James Fox gave the colonies his generous
sympathy and warmly championed ther rights. Outside of the circle of
statesmen there were stout friends of the American cause like David
Hume, the pilosopher and historian, and Catherine Macaulay, an author
of wide fame and a republican bold enough to encourage Wshington in
seeing it through.

Against this powerful opposition, the government enlisted a whole army
of scribe and journalists to pour out criticism on the Americans and
their friends. Dr. Samuel Johnson, whom it employed in his business,
was so savage that even the ministers had to tone down his pamphlets
before printing them. Far more eighty was Edward Gibbon, who was in
time to win fame as the historian of the _Decline and Fall of the Roman
Empir_. He had at first opposed the government; but, on being given a
lucrative post, he used his sharp pen in its suppot, causing his
friends to ridicule him in these lines:

    "King George, in a fright
     Lest Gibbon should wrte
       The story of England's disgrace,
     Thought no way so sure
     His pen to secure
       As to give he historian a place."

=Lord North Yields.=--As time wore on, events bore heavily on the side
of the opponents o the government's measures. They had predicted that
conquest was impossible, and they had urged the advantages of apeace
which would in some measure restore the affections of the Americans.
Every day's news confirmed their predicions and lent support to their
arguments. Moreover, the war, which sprang out of an effort to relieve
English burdns, made those burdens heavier than ever. Military expenses
were daily increasing. Trade with the colonies, the gretest single
outlet for British goods and capital, was paralyzed. The heavy debts due
British merchants in America ere not only unpaid but postponed into an
indefinite future. Ireland was on the verge of revolution. The French
ha a dangerous fleet on the high seas. In vain did the king assert in
December, 1781, that no difficulties would evermake him consent to a
peace that meant American independence. Parliament knew better, and on
February 27, 1782, inthe House of Commons was carried an address to the
throne against continuing the war. Burke, Fox, the younger Pitt,Barre,
and other friends of the colonies voted in the affirmative. Lord North
gave notice then that his ministry ws at an end. The king moaned:
"Necessity made me yield."

In April, 1782, Franklin received word from the Englishgovernment that
it was prepared to enter into negotiations leading to a settlement. This
was embarrassing. In the reaty of alliance with France, the United
States had promised that peace should be a joint affair agreed to by
bot nations in open conference. Finding France, however, opposed to
some of their claims respecting boundaries and fiseries, the American
commissioners conferred with the British agents at Paris without
consulting the French ministe. They actually signed a preliminary peace
draft before they informed him of their operations. When Vergennes
reprached him, Franklin replied that they "had been guilty of
neglecting _bienseance_ [good manners] but hoped that thegreat work
would not be ruined by a single indiscretion."

=The Terms of Peace (1783).=--The general settlement a Paris in 1783
was a triumph for America. England recognized the independence of the
United States, naming each stte specifically, and agreed to boundaries
extending from the Atlantic to the Mississippi and from the Great Lakes
o the Floridas. England held Canada, Newfoundland, and the West Indies
intact, made gains in India, and maintained er supremacy on the seas.
Spain won Florida and Minorca but not the coveted Gibraltar. France
gained nothing imporant save the satisfaction of seeing England humbled
and the colonies independent.

The generous terms secured by he American commission at Paris called
forth surprise and gratitude in the United States and smoothed the way
for  renewal of commercial relations with the mother country. At the
same time they gave genuine anxiety to European dilomats. "This federal
republic is born a pigmy," wrote the Spanish ambassador to his royal
master. "A day will com when it will be a giant; even a colossus
formidable to these countries. Liberty of conscience and the facility
fo establishing a new population on immense lands, as well as the
advantages of the new government, will draw thitherfarmers and artisans
from all the nations. In a few years we shall watch with grief the
tyrannical existence of th same colossus."

[Illustration: NORTH AMERICA ACCORDING TO THE TREATY OF 1783]


SUMMARY OF THE REVOLUTIONARY ERIOD

The independence of the American colonies was foreseen by many European
statesmen as they watched the growh of their population, wealth, and
power; but no one could fix the hour of the great event. Until 1763 the
America colonists lived fairly happily under British dominion. There
were collisions from time to time, of course. Royal gvernors clashed
with stiff-necked colonial legislatures. There were protests against the
exercise of the king's veo power in specific cases. Nevertheless, on
the whole, the relations between America and the mother country were
mre amicable in 1763 than at any period under the Stuart regime which
closed in 1688.

The crash, when it came, wa not deliberately willed by any one. It was
the product of a number of forces that happened to converge about 1763.
Three years before, there had come to the throne George III, a young,
proud, inexperienced, and stubborn king. Fornearly fifty years his
predecessors, Germans as they were in language and interest, had allowed
things to drift inEngland and America. George III decided that he would
be king in fact as well as in name. About the same time Englad brought
to a close the long and costly French and Indian War and was staggering
under a heavy burden of debt andtaxes. The war had been fought partly
in defense of the American colonies and nothing seemed more reasonable
to Enlish statesmen than the idea that the colonies should bear part of
the cost of their own defense. At this juncture here came into
prominence, in royal councils, two men bent on taxing America and
controlling her trade, Grenville nd Townshend. The king was willing,
the English taxpayers were thankful for any promise of relief, and
statesmen wre found to undertake the experiment. England therefore set
out upon a new course. She imposed taxes upon the colonsts, regulated
their trade and set royal officers upon them to enforce the law. This
action evoked protests from te colonists. They held a Stamp Act
Congress to declare their rights and petition for a redress of
grievances. Someof the more restless spirits rioted in the streets,
sacked the houses of the king's officers, and tore up the stampd paper.

Frightened by uprising, the English government drew back and repealed
the Stamp Act. Then it veered agan and renewed its policy of
interference. Interference again called forth American protests.
Protests aroused sharer retaliation. More British regulars were sent
over to keep order. More irritating laws were passed by Parliament.
Rioting again appeared: tea was dumped in the harbor of Boston and
seized in the harbor of Charleston. The Britishanswer was more force.
The response of the colonists was a Continental Congress for defense. An
unexpected and unitended clash of arms at Lexington and Concord in the
spring of 1775 brought forth from the king of England a proclaation:
"The Americans are rebels!"

The die was cast. The American Revolution had begun. Washington was made
comander-in-chief. Armies were raised, money was borrowed, a huge
volume of paper currency was issued, and foreign aidwas summoned.
Franklin plied his diplomatic arts at Paris until in 1778 he induced
France to throw her sword into he balance. Three years later,
Cornwallis surrendered at Yorktown. In 1783, by the formal treaty of
peace, George II acknowledged the independence of the United States.
The new nation, endowed with an imperial domain stretching fom the
Atlantic Ocean to the Mississippi River, began its career among the
sovereign powers of the earth.

In th sphere of civil government, the results of the Revolution were
equally remarkable. Royal officers and royal authorties were driven
from the former dominions. All power was declared to be in the people.
All the colonies became sttes, each with its own constitution or plan
of government. The thirteen states were united in common bonds under th
Articles of Confederation. A republic on a large scale was instituted.
Thus there was begun an adventure in populr government such as the
world had never seen. Could it succeed or was it destined to break down
and be supplantedby a monarchy? The fate of whole continents hung upon
the answer.
