PART III. THE UNION AND NATIONAL POLITICS




CHAPTER VII

THE FORMATION OF THE CONSTITUTION


THE PROMSE AND THE DIFFICULTIES OF AMERICA

The rise of a young republic composed of thirteen states, each governed
by oficials popularly elected under constitutions drafted by "the plain
people," was the most significant feature of theeighteenth century. The
majority of the patriots whose labors and sacrifices had made this
possible naturally lookd upon their work and pronounced it good. Those
Americans, however, who peered beneath the surface of things, saw tat
the Declaration of Independence, even if splendidly phrased, and paper
constitutions, drawn by finest enthusias "uninstructed by experience,"
could not alone make the republic great and prosperous or even free. All
around the they saw chaos in finance and in industry and perils for the
immediate future.

=The Weakness of the Articles ofConfederation.=--The government under
the Articles of Confederation had neither the strength nor the resources
necssary to cope with the problems of reconstruction left by the war.
The sole organ of government was a Congress compsed of from two to
seven members from each state chosen as the legislature might direct and
paid by the state. In etermining all questions, each state had one
vote--Delaware thus enjoying the same weight as Virginia. There was no
president to enforce the laws. Congress was given power to select a
committee of thirteen--one from each state--toact as an executive body
when it was not in session; but this device, on being tried out, proved
a failure. There as no system of national courts to which citizens and
states could appeal for the protection of their rights or thrugh which
they could compel obedience to law. The two great powers of government,
military and financial, were witheld. Congress, it is true, could
authorize expenditures but had to rely upon the states for the payment
of contriutions to meet its bills. It could also order the
establishment of an army, but it could only request the states tosupply
their respective quotas of soldiers. It could not lay taxes nor bring
any pressure to bear upon a single ciizen in the whole country. It
could act only through the medium of the state governments.

=Financial and Commercal Disorders.=--In the field of public finance,
the disorders were pronounced. The huge debt incurred during the wa was
still outstanding. Congress was unable to pay either the interest or the
principal. Public creditors were in espair, as the market value of
their bonds sank to twenty-five or even ten cents on the dollar. The
current bills f Congress were unpaid. As some one complained, there was
not enough money in the treasury to buy pen and ink with hich to record
the transactions of the shadow legislature. The currency was in utter
chaos. Millions of dollars innotes issued by Congress had become mere
trash worth a cent or two on the dollar. There was no other expression
ofcontempt so forceful as the popular saying: "not worth a
Continental." To make matters worse, several of the stateswere pouring
new streams of paper money from the press. Almost the only good money in
circulation consisted of Engish, French, and Spanish coins, and the
public was even defrauded by them because money changers were busy
clippin and filing away the metal. Foreign commerce was unsettled. The
entire British system of trade discrimination was trned against the
Americans, and Congress, having no power to regulate foreign commerce,
was unable to retaliate orto negotiate treaties which it could enforce.
Domestic commerce was impeded by the jealousies of the states, whicherected tariff barriers against their neighbors. The condition of the
currency made the exchange of money and goodsextremely difficult, and,
as if to increase the confusion, backward states enacted laws hindering
the prompt colletion of debts within their borders--an evil which
nothing but a national system of courts could cure.

=Congress n Disrepute.=--With treaties set at naught by the states, the
laws unenforced, the treasury empty, and the public cedit gone, the
Congress of the United States fell into utter disrepute. It called upon
the states to pay their quoas of money into the treasury, only to be
treated with contempt. Even its own members looked upon it as a solemn
ftility. Some of the ablest men refused to accept election to it, and
many who did take the doubtful honor failed toattend the sessions.
Again and again it was impossible to secure a quorum for the transaction
of business.

=Trobles of the State Governments.=--The state governments, free to
pursue their own course with no interference from wthout, had almost as
many difficulties as the Congress. They too were loaded with
revolutionary debts calling for eavy taxes upon an already restive
population. Oppressed by their financial burdens and discouraged by the
fall inprices which followed the return of peace, the farmers of
several states joined in a concerted effort and compelledtheir
legislatures to issue large sums of paper money. The currency fell in
value, but nevertheless it was forced n unwilling creditors to square
old accounts.

In every part of the country legislative action fluctuated violenty.
Laws were made one year only to be repealed the next and reenacted the
third year. Lands were sold by one legisature and the sales were
canceled by its successor. Uncertainty and distrust were the natural
consequences. Men ofsubstance longed for some power that would forbid
states to issue bills of credit, to make paper money legal tenderin
payment of debts, or to impair the obligation of contracts. Men heavily
in debt, on the other hand, urged even ore drastic action against
creditors.

So great did the discontent of the farmers in New Hampshire become in
178 that a mob surrounded the legislature, demanding a repeal of the
taxes and the issuance of paper money. It was wit difficulty that an
armed rebellion was avoided. In Massachusetts the malcontents, under the
leadership of Daniel hays, a captain in the Revolutionary army,
organized that same year open resistance to the government of the state.
Shays and his followers protested against the conduct of creditors in
foreclosing mortgages upon the debt-burdenedfarmers, against the
lawyers for increasing the costs of legal proceedings, against the
senate of the state the mebers of which were apportioned among the
towns on the basis of the amount of taxes paid, against heavy taxes, and
gainst the refusal of the legislature to issue paper money. They seized
the towns of Worcester and Springfield and roke up the courts of
justice. All through the western part of the state the revolt spread,
sending a shock of alam to every center and section of the young
republic. Only by the most vigorous action was Governor Bowdoin able toquell the uprising; and when that task was accomplished, the state
government did not dare to execute any of the prsoners because they had
so many sympathizers. Moreover, Bowdoin and several members of the
legislature who had bee most zealous in their attacks on the insurgents
were defeated at the ensuing election. The need of national assistnce
for state governments in times of domestic violence was everywhere
emphasized by men who were opposed to revoltionary acts.

=Alarm over Dangers to the Republic.=--Leading American citizens,
watching the drift of affairs, wre slowly driven to the conclusion that
the new ship of state so proudly launched a few years before was
careeninginto anarchy. "The facts of our peace and independence," wrote
a friend of Washington, "do not at present wear so pomising an
appearance as I had fondly painted in my mind. The prejudices,
jealousies, and turbulence of the peopleat times almost stagger my
confidence in our political establishments; and almost occasion me to
think that they wll show themselves unworthy of the noble prize for
which we have contended."

Washington himself was profoundly dscouraged. On hearing of Shays's
rebellion, he exclaimed: "What, gracious God, is man that there should
be such inonsistency and perfidiousness in his conduct! It is but the
other day that we were shedding our blood to obtain theconstitutions
under which we now live--constitutions of our own choice and making--and
now we are unsheathing our word to overturn them." The same year he
burst out in a lament over rumors of restoring royal government. "I am
tod that even respectable characters speak of a monarchical government
without horror. From thinking proceeds speakin. Hence to acting is
often but a single step. But how irresistible and tremendous! What a
triumph for our enemies o verify their predictions! What a triumph for
the advocates of despotism to find that we are incapable of governin
ourselves!"

=Congress Attempts Some Reforms.=--The Congress was not ind

ADVENTURE  I.  A SCANDAL IN BOHEMIA

I.


To Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman. I have seldo heard him mention her under any other name. In his eyes she eclipses and predominates the whole of her sex. It was ot that he felt any emotion akin to love for Irene Adler. All emotions, and that one particularly, were abhorrent tohis cold, precise but admirably balanced mind. He was, I take it, the most perfect reasoning and observing machine tat the world has seen, but as a lover he would have placed himself in a false position. He never spoke of the softerpassions, save with a gibe and a sneer. They were admirable things for the observer--excellent for drawing the veil rom men's motives and actions. But for the trained reasoner to admit such intrusions into his own delicate and finel adjusted temperament was to introduce a distracting factor which might throw a doubt upon all his mental results. Git in a sensitive instrument, or a crack in one of his own high-power lenses, would not be more disturbing than a stong emotion in a nature such as his. And yet there was but one woman to him, and that woman was the late Irene Adler of dubious and questionable memory.

I had seen little of Holmes lately. My marriage had drifted us away from eac other. My own complete happiness, and the home-centred interests which rise up around the man who first finds himsef master of his own establishment, were sufficient to absorb all my attention, while Holmes, who loathed every form f society with his whole Bohemian soul, remained in our lodgings in Baker Street, buried among his old books, and alernating from week to week between cocaine and ambition, the drowsiness of the drug, and the fierce energy of his ow keen nature. He was still, as ever, deeply attracted by the study of crime, and occupied his immense faculties and xtraordinary powers of observation in following out those clues, and clearing up those mysteries which had been abanoned as hopeless by the official police. From time to time I heard some vague account of his doings: of his summons o Odessa in the case of the Trepoff murder, of his clearing up of the singular tragedy of the Atkinson brothers at Tincomalee, and finally of the mission which he had accomplished so delicately and successfully for the reigning famiy of Holland. Beyond these signs of his activity, however, which I merely shared with all the readers of the daily pess, I knew little of my former friend and companion.

One night--it was on the twentieth of March, 1888--I was reurning from a journey to a patient (for I had now returned to civil practice), when my way led me through Baker Stret. As I passed the well-remembered door, which must always be associated in my mind with my wooing, and with the dar incidents of the Study in Scarlet, I was seized with a keen desire to see Holmes again, and to know how he was emplying his extraordinary powers. His rooms were brilliantly lit, and, even as I looked up, I saw his tall, spare figur pass twice in a dark silhouette against the blind. He was pacing the room swiftly, eagerly, with his head sunk uponhis chest and his hands clasped behind him. To me, who knew his every mood and habit, his attitude and manner told teir own story. He was at work again. He had risen out of his drug-created dreams and was hot upon the scent of some ew problem. I rang the bell and was shown up to the chamber which had formerly been in part my own.

His manner wa not effusive. It seldom was; but he was glad, I think, to see me. With hardly a word spoken, but with a kindly eye,he waved me to an armchair, threw across his case of cigars, and indicated a spirit case and a gasogene in the corne. Then he stood before the fire and looked me over in his singular introspective fashion.

"Wedlock suits you," heremarked. "I think, Watson, that you have put on seven and a half pounds since I saw you."

"Seven!" I answered.

"Indeed, I should have thought a little more. Just a trifle more, I fancy, Watson. And in practice again, I observe You did not tell me that you intended to go into harness."

"Then, how do you know?"

"I see it, I deduce it. Hw do I know that you have been getting yourself very wet lately, and that you have a most clumsy and careless servan girl?"

"My dear Holmes," said I, "this is too much. You would certainly have been burned, had you lived a few ceturies ago. It is true that I had a country walk on Thursday and came home in a dreadful mess, but as I have changedmy clothes I can't imagine how you deduce it. As to Mary Jane, she is incorrigible, and my wife has given her notice but there, again, I fail to see how you work it out."

He chuckled to himself and rubbed his long, nervous hands ogether.

"It is simplicity itself," said he; "my eyes tell me that on the inside of your left shoe, just where th firelight strikes it, the leather is scored by six almost parallel cuts. Obviously they have been caused by someonewho has very carelessly scraped round the edges of the sole in order to remove crusted mud from it. Hence, you see, y double deduction that you had been out in vile weather, and that you had a particularly malignant boot-slitting spcimen of the London slavey. As to your practice, if a gentleman walks into my rooms smelling of iodoform, with a blak mark of nitrate of silver upon his right forefinger, and a bulge on the right side of his top-hat to show where hehas secreted his stethoscope, I must be dull, indeed, if I do not pronounce him to be an active member of the medica profession."

I could not help laughing at the ease with which he explained his process of deduction. "When I hea you give your reasons," I remarked, "the thing always appears to me to be so ridiculously simple that I could easil do it myself, though at each successive instance of your reasoning I am baffled until you explain your process. Andyet I believe that my eyes are as good as yours."

"Quite so," he answered, lighting a cigarette, and throwing himelf down into an armchair. "You see, but you do not observe. The distinction is clear. For example, you have frequenly seen the steps which lead up from the hall to this room."

"Frequently."

"How often?"

"Well, some hundred of times."

"Then how many are there?"

"How many? I don't know."

"Quite so! You have not observed. And yet ou have seen. That is just my point. Now, I know that there are seventeen steps, because I have both seen and observd. By the way, since you are interested in these little problems, and since you are good enough to chronicle one or wo of my trifling experiences, you may be interested in this." He threw over a sheet of thick, pink-tinted notepaperwhich had been lying open upon the table. "It came by the last post," said he. "Read it aloud."

The note was undaed, and without either signature or address.

"There will call upon you to-night, at a quarter to eight o'clock," t said, "a gentleman who desires to consult you upon a matter of the very deepest moment. Your recent services to on of the royal houses of Europe have shown that you are one who may safely be trusted with matters which are of an imortance which can hardly be exaggerated. This account of you we have from all quarters received. Be in your chamber hen at that hour, and do not take it amiss if your visitor wear a mask."

"This is indeed a mystery," I remarked. What do you imagine that it means?"

"I have no data yet. It is a capital mistake to theorise before one has data.Insensibly one begins to twist facts to suit theories, instead of theories to suit facts. But the note itself. What o you deduce from it?"

I carefully examined the writing, and the paper upon which it was written.

"The man whowrote it was presumably well to do," I remarked, endeavouring to imitate my companion's processes. "Such paper couldnot be bought under half a crown a packet. It is peculiarly strong and stiff."

"Peculiar--that is the very word,"said Holmes. "It is not an English paper at all. Hold it up to the light."

I did so, and saw a large "E" with a sall "g," a "P," and a large "G" with a small "t" woven into the texture of the paper.

"What do you make of that?"asked Holmes.

"The name of the maker, no doubt; or his monogram, rather."

"Not at all. The 'G' with the small t' stands for 'Gesellschaft,' which is the German for 'Company.' It is a customary contraction like our 'Co.' 'P,' o course, stands for 'Papier.' Now for the 'Eg.' Let us glance at our Continental Gazetteer." He took down a heavy brwn volume from his shelves. "Eglow, Eglonitz--here we are, Egria. It is in a German-speaking country--in Bohemia, no far from Carlsbad. 'Remarkable as being the scene of the death of Wallenstein, and for its numerous glass-factoriesand paper-mills.' Ha, ha, my boy, what do you make of that?" His eyes sparkled, and he sent up a great blue triumphat cloud from his cigarette.

"The paper was made in Bohemia," I said.

"Precisely. And the man who wrote the not is a German. Do you note the peculiar construction of the sentence--'This account of you we have from all quarters eceived.' A Frenchman or Russian could not have written that. It is the German who is so uncourteous to his verbs. I only remains, therefore, to discover what is wanted by this German who writes upon Bohemian paper and prefers wearig a mask to showing his face. And here he comes, if I am not mistaken, to resolve all our doubts."

As he spoke thre was the sharp sound of horses' hoofs and grating wheels against the curb, followed by a sharp pull at the bell. Hlmes whistled.

"Not a bit, Doctor. Stay where you are. I am lost withoutmy Boswell. And this promises to be interesting. It would be a pity to miss it."

A slow and heavy step, which had been heard upon the stairs and in the passage, paused immediately outide the door. Then there was a loud and authoritative tap.

A man entered who could harly have been less than six feet six inches in height, with the chest and limbs of a Hercules. His dress was rich wit a richness which would, in England, be looked upon as akin to bad taste. Heavy bands of astrakhan were slashed acros the sleeves and fronts of his double-breasted coat, while the deep blue cloak which was thrown over his shoulders as lined with flame-coloured silk and secured at the neck with a brooch which consisted of a single flaming beryl. "And I."

For many years he had adopted a system of docketing all paragraphs concerning men and things, so that it ws difficult to name a subject or a person on which he could not at once furnish information. "Was there a secret marriage?"

"None."

"None."

"There is the writng."

"Stolen."

"My own seal."

"Bought."

II.


At three o'clock precisely I was at Baker Street, but Holmes had not yet returned. The landlady informed me tha he had left the house shortly after eight o'clock in the morning. I sat down beside the fire, however, with the intntion of awaiting him, however long he might be. I was already deeply interested in his inquiry, for, though it was urrounded by none of the grim and strange features which were associated with the two crimes which I have already reorded, still, the nature of the case and the exalted station of his client gave it a character of its own. Indeed, aart from the nature of the investigation which my friend had on hand, there was something in his masterly grasp of asituation, and his keen, incisive reasoning, which made it a pleasure to me to study his system of work, and to follw the quick, subtle methods by which he disentangled the most inextricable mysteries. So accustomed was I to his invriable success that the very possibility of his failing had ceased to enter into my head.

It was close upon four efore the door opened, and a drunken-looking groom, ill-kempt and side-whiskered, with an inflamed face and disreputble clothes, walked into the room. "This Godfrey Norton was evidently an important factor in the matter.He was a lawyer. That sounded ominous. What was the relation between them, and what the object of his repeated visit? "I shall be delighted"

"And when I raise my hand--so--you will throw into the room what  give you to throw, and will, at the same time, raise the cry of fire. You quite follow me?"

"It i nothing very formidable," he said, taking a long cigar-shaped roll from his pocket. "It is an ordinary plumber's smke-rocket, fitted with a cap at either end to make it self-lighting. He disappeared into his bedroom and returned i a few minutes in the character of an amiable and simple-minded Nonconformist clergyman. His broad black hat, his bagy trousers, his white tie, his sympathetic smile, and general look of peering and benevolent curiosity were such asMr. John Hare alone could have equalled. It was a quarter past six when we left Baker Street,and it still wanted ten minutes to the hour when we found ourselves in Serpentine Avenue. "But it hastwice been burgled."

"Pshaw! They did not know how to look."

"But how will you look?"

"I will not look."
"What then?"

"I will get her to show me."

"But she will refuse."

"She will not be able to. But I hear the rmble of wheels. It is her carriage. Now carry out my orders to the letter."

As he spoke the gleam of the sidelighs of a carriage came round the curve of the avenue. It was a smart little landau which rattled up to the door of Briny Lodge. "Is the poor gentleman much hurt?" she asked.

"No, no, there's life in him!" shouted another. "But he'll be gone before you can get him to hospital."

"He can't lie in the street. May we bring him in, marm?"
"Surely. Bring him into the sitting-room. There is a comfortable sofa. This way, please!"

Slowly and solemnly h was borne into Briony Lodge and laid out in the principal room, while I still observed the proceedings from my postby the window. Holmes had sat up upon the couch, and I saw him motion like a man who is in need of air. A maid ruhed across and threw open the window. "You did it very nicely, Doctor," he remarked. "Nothing could have ben better. It is all right."

"You have the photograph?"

"I know where it is."

"And how did you find out?"
"She showed me, as I told you she would."

"I do not wish to make a mystery," said he laughing. "The matter was perfectly simple. You, of course, saw that everyone in the street was an accomplice. Theywere all engaged for the evening."

"It was all-important. When a woman thinks tha her house is on fire, her instinct is at once to rush to the thing which she values most. In the case of the Darlington Substitution Scandal itwas of use to me, and also in the Arnsworth Castle business. A married woman grabs at her baby; an unmarried one reahes for her jewel-box. She was there in an instant, and I caught a glimpse of it as she half drew it out When I cried out that it was a false alarm, she replaced it, glanced at the rocket, rushed from the room, and I hav not seen her since. "And now?" I asked.

"Our quest is practically finished. I shall call ith the King to-morrow, and with you, if you care to come with us. We will be shown into the sitting-room to wait fo the lady, but it is probable that when she comes she may find neither us nor the photograph. It might be a satisfacion to his Majesty to regain it with his own hands."

"And when will you call?"

"At eight in the morning. She wll not be up, so that we shall have a clear field. Besides, we must be prompt, for this marriage may mean a completechange in her life and habits. I must wire to the King without delay."

We had reached Baker Street and had stoppe at the door. He was searching his pockets for the key when someone passing said:

"Good-night, Mister Sherlock Homes."

There were several people on the pavement at the time, but the greeting appeared to come from a slim youth n an ulster who had hurried by.

"I've heard that voice before," said Holmes, staring down the dimly lit street. "ow, I wonder who the deuce that could have been."

III.


I slept at Baker Street that night, and we were engagd upon our toast and coffee in the morning when the King of Bohemia rushed into the room.

"You have really got it" he cried, grasping Sherlock Holmes by either shoulder and looking eagerly into his face.

"Not yet."

"But youhave hopes?"

"I have hopes."

"Then, come. I am all impatience to be gone."

"We must have a cab."

"No, mybrougham is waiting."

"Then that will simplify matters." We descended and started off once more for Briony Lodge.

"Irene Adler is married," remarked Holmes.

"Married! When?"

"Yesterday."

"But to whom?"

"To an Englis lawyer named Norton."

"But she could not love him."

"I am in hopes that she does."

"And why in hopes?"

Because it would spare your Majesty all fear of future annoyance. If the lady loves her husband, she does not love yur Majesty. If she does not love your Majesty, there is no reason why she should interfere with your Majesty's plan.

"It is true. And yet--! Well! I wish she had been of my own station! What a queen she would have made!" He relaped into a moody silence, which was not broken until we drew up in Serpentine Avenue.

The door of Briony Lodge wasopen, and an elderly woman stood upon the steps. She watched us with a sardonic eye as we stepped from the brougham.

"Mr. Sherlock Holmes, I believe?" said she.

"I am Mr. Holmes," answered my companion, looking at her with a qustioning and rather startled gaze.

"Indeed! My mistress told me that you were likely to call. She left this mornig with her husband by the 5:15 train from Charing Cross for the Continent."

"What!" Sherlock Holmes staggered bac, white with chagrin and surprise. "Do you mean that she has left England?"

"Never to return."

"And the papers" asked the King hoarsely. "All is lost."

"We shall see." He pushed past the servant and rushed into the drawing-oom, followed by the King and myself. The furniture was scattered about in every direction, with dismantled shelves nd open drawers, as if the lady had hurriedly ransacked them before her flight. Holmes rushed at the bell-pull, toreback a small sliding shutter, and, plunging in his hand, pulled out a photograph and a letter. The photograph was ofIrene Adler herself in evening dress, the letter was superscribed to "Sherlock Holmes, Esq. To be left till called fr." My friend tore it open, and we all three read it together. It was dated at midnight of the preceding night and rn in this way:

"MY DEAR MR. SHERLOCK HOLMES,--You really did it very well. You took me in completely. Until afterthe alarm of fire, I had not a suspicion. But then, when I found how I had betrayed myself, I began to think. I had een warned against you months ago. I had been told that, if the King employed an agent, it would certainly be you. Ad your address had been given me. Yet, with all this, you made me reveal what you wanted to know. Even after I becam suspicious, I found it hard to think evil of such a dear, kind old clergyman. But, you know, I have been trained asan actress myself. Male costume is nothing new to me. I often take advantage of the freedom which it gives. I sent Jhn, the coachman, to watch you, ran upstairs, got into my walking clothes, as I call them, and came down just as youdeparted.

"Well, I followed you to your door, and so made sure that I was really an object of interest to the celbrated Mr. Sherlock Holmes. Then I, rather imprudently, wished you good-night, and started for the Temple to see my usband.

"We both thought the best resource was flight, when pursued by so formidable an antagonist; so you will fnd the nest empty when you call to-morrow. As to the photograph, your client may rest in peace. I love and am loved y a better man than he. The King may do what he will without hindrance from one whom he has cruelly wronged. I keep t only to safeguard myself, and to preserve a weapon which will always secure me from any steps which he might take n the future. I leave a photograph which he might care to possess; and I remain, dear Mr. Sherlock Holmes,


"Ver truly yours,              
"IRENE NORTON, nee ADLER."

"What a woman--oh, what a woman!" cried the King of Bohema, when we had all three read this epistle. "Did I not tell you how quick and resolute she was? Would she not have mde an admirable queen? Is it not a pity that she was not on my level?"

"From what I have seen of the lady, she sems, indeed, to be on a very different level to your Majesty," said Holmes coldly. "I am sorry that I have not been ale to bring your Majesty's business to a more successful conclusion."

"On the contrary, my dear sir," cried the Kng; "nothing could be more successful. I know that her word is inviolate. The photograph is now as safe as if it wer in the fire."

"I am glad to hear your Majesty say so."

"I am immensely indebted to you. Pray tell me in what ay I can reward you. This ring--" He slipped an emerald snake ring from his finger and held it out upon the palm of is hand.

"Your Majesty has something which I should value even more highly," said Holmes.

"You have but to nam it."

"This photograph!"

The King stared at him in amazement.

"Irene's photograph!" he cried. "Certainly, i you wish it."

"I thank your Majesty. Then there is no more to be done in the matter. I have the honour to wish yu a very good morning." He bowed, and, turning away without observing the hand which the King had stretched out to hm, he set off in my company for his chambers.

And that was how a great scandal threatened to affect the kingdom o Bohemia, and how the best plans of Mr. Sherlock Holmes were beaten by a woman's wit. He used to make merry over thecleverness of women, but I have not heard him do it of late. And when he speaks of Irene Adler, or when he refers toher photograph, it is always under the honourable title of the woman.

ADVENTURE  II.  THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE


 had called upon my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, one day in the autumn of last year and found him in deep conversatin with a very stout, florid-faced, elderly gentleman with fiery red hair. ADVENTURE  III.  A CAS OF IDENTITY


"My dear fellow," said Sherlock Holmes as we sat on either side of the fire in his lodgings at Bakr Street, "life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man could invent. We would not dare to conceie the things which are really mere commonplaces of existence. If we could fly out of that window hand in hand, hoverover this great city, gently remove the roofs, and peep in at the queer things which are going on, the strange coincdences, the plannings, the cross-purposes, the wonderful chains of events, working through generations, and leading o the most outre results, it would make all fiction with its conventionalities and foreseen conclusions most stale ad unprofitable."

"And yet I am not convinced of it," I answered. "The cases which come to light in the papers are as a rule, bald enough, and vulgar enough. We have in our police reports realism pushed to its extreme limits, and et the result is, it must be confessed, neither fascinating nor artistic."

"A certain selection and discretion mut be used in producing a realistic effect," remarked Holmes. "This is wanting in the police report, where more stres is laid, perhaps, upon the platitudes of the magistrate than upon the details, which to an observer contain the vitl essence of the whole matter. Take a inch of snuff, Doctor, and acknowledge that I have scored over you in your example."

He had risen from his chair and as standing between the parted blinds gazing down into the dull neutral-tinted London street. "If I tell her she will not believe me. You may remember the old Persian saying, 'There is danger for him who taket the tiger cub, and danger also for whoso snatches a delusion from a woman.' There is as much sense in Hafiz as in Hrace, and as much knowledge of the world."

ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLEY MYSTERY


We were seated at breakast one morning, my wife and I, when the maid brought in a telegram. It was from Sherlock Holmes and ran in this way

"Have you a couple of days to spare? Have just been wired for from the west of England in connection with Boscome Valley tragedy. Shall be glad if you will come with me. Air and scenery perfect. Leave Paddington by the 11:15."

"What do you say, dear?" said my wife, looking across at me. "Will you go?"

"I really don't know what to say. I ave a fairly long list at present."

"Oh, Anstruther would do your work for you. You have been looking a little pae lately. I think that the change would do you good, and you are always so interested in Mr. Sherlock Holmes' cases.

"I should be ungrateful if I were not, seeing what I gained through one of them," I answered. "But if I am to go I must pack at once, for I have only half an hour."

My experience of camp life in Afghanistan had at least had te effect of making me a prompt and ready traveller. My wants were few and simple, so that in less than the time statd I was in a cab with my valise, rattling away to Paddington Station. Sherlock Holmes was pacing up and down the plaform, his tall, gaunt figure made even gaunter and taller by his long grey travelling-cloak and close-fitting cloth ap.

"It is really very good of you to come, Watson," said he. "It makes a considerable difference to me, having smeone with me on whom I can thoroughly rely. Local aid is always either worthless or else biassed. If you will keep he two corner seats I shall get the tickets."

We had the carriage to ourselves save for an immense litter of papes which Holmes had brought with him. "Boscomb Valley is a country district not very far from Ross, in Herefordshire. The largest landed proprietor in that part i a Mr. John Turner, who made his money in Australia and returned some years ago to the old country. One of the farmswhich he held, that of Hatherley, was let to Mr. Charles McCarthy, who was also an ex-Australian. The men had known ach other in the colonies, so that it was not unnatural that when they came to settle down they should do so as neareach other as possible. Turner was apparently the richer man, so McCarthy became his tenant but still remained, it sems, upon terms of perfect equality, as they were frequently together. They appear to have avoided the soiety of the neighbouring English families and to have led retired lives, though both the McCarthys were fond of spor and were frequently seen at the race-meetings of the neighbourhood. "On June 3rd, that is, on Monday last, McCarthy left his house at Hatherley abou three in the afternoon and walked down to the Boscombe Pool, which is a small lake formed by the spreading out of te stream which runs down the Boscombe Valley. From that appointment he ever came back alive.

"From Hatherley Farmhouse to the Boscombe Pool is a quarter of a mile, and two people saw hm as he passed over this ground. Th Boscombe Pool is thickly wooded round, with just a fringe of grass and of reeds round the edge. "I could hardly imagine a more damning case," I remarked. "If ever circumstantial evidence pinted to a criminal it does so here."

"It may seem to point very straight to one thing, but if you shift your own point of view a little, you may findit pointing in an equally uncompromising manner to something entirely different. "Mr. James McCarthy, the only sonof the deceased, was then called and gave evidence as follows: 'I had been away from home for three days at Bristol,and had only just returned upon the morning of last Monday, the 3rd. Sherlock Holmes was transformed when he was hot upon such a scent asthis. Men who had only known the quiet thinker and logician of Baker Street would have failed to recognise him. Square, too, quie unusual boots! They come, they go, they come again--of course that was for the cloak. I think that I will go in an have a word with Moran, and perhaps write a little note. Having done that, we may drive back to our luncheon. You my walk to the cab, and I shall be with you presently."

It was about ten minutes before we regained our cab and drve back into Ross, Holmes still carrying with him the stone which he had picked up in the wood.

"This may interes you, Lestrade," he remarked, holding it out. "The murder was done with it."

"I see no marks."

"There are none"

"How do you know, then?"

"The grass was growing under it. It had only lain there a few days. There was no sin of a place whence it had been taken. It corresponds with the injuries. There is no sign of any other weapon."

"Is a tall man, left-handed, limps with the right leg, wears thick-soled shooting-boots and a gey cloak, smokes Indian cigars, uses a cigar-holder, and carries a blunt pen-knife in his pocket. There are several ther indications, but these may be enough to aid us in our search."

"No, finished."

"Bt the mystery?"

"It is solved."

"Who was the criminal, then?"

"The gentleman I describe."

"But who is he"

"Surely it would not be difficult to find out. This is not such a populous neighbourhood."

Lestrade shruggedhis shoulders. "I am a practical man," he said, "and I really cannot undertake to go about the country looking for aleft-handed gentleman with a game leg. I should become the laughing-stock of Scotland Yard."

Having left Lestrade at his rooms, we drove to our hotel, where we found lunch upon the table. Holmes was silentand buried in thought with a pained expression upon his face, as one who finds himself in a perplexing position.

Look here, Watson," he said when the cloth was cleared "just sit down in this chair and let me preach to you for a lttle. I don't know quite what to do, and I should value your advice. Light a cigar and let me expound."

"Well, now, in considering this case there are two points about young McCarthy's narrative which struck us boh instantly, although they impressed me in his favour and you against him. The 'Cooee!' was meant to attract the attention of whoever it was tha he had the appointment with. But 'Cooee' is a distinctly Australian cry, and one which is used between Australians.There is a strong presumption that the person whom McCarthy expected to meet him at Boscombe Pool was someone who ha been in Australia."

Sherlock Holmes took a folded paper from his pocket and flattene it out on the table. "This is a map of the Colony of Victoria," he said. "I wired to Bristol for it last night." Heput his hand over part of the map. "What do you read?"

"ARAT," I read.

"Certainly."

"And one who was at home inthe district, for the pool can only be approached by the farm or by the estate, where strangers could hardly wander.

"Quite so."

"Then comes our expedition of to-day. By an examination of the ground I gained the trifling detais which I gave to that imbecile Lestrade, as to the personality of the criminal."

"But how did you gain them?"
"You know my method. It is founded upon the observation of trifles."

The man who entered was a strange and impressive figure. is slow, limping step and bowed shoulders gave the appearance of decrepitude, and yet his hard, deep-lined, craggy fatures, and his enormous limbs showed that he was possessed of unusual strength of body and of character. "It's as well," said the old man; "it's a question whether I shall live to the Assizes, so i matters little to me, but I should wish to spare Alice the shock. And now I will make the thing clear to you; it ha been a long time in the acting, but will not take me long to tell.

"You didn't know this dead man, McCarthy. He as a devil incarnate. I tell you that. God keep you out of the clutches of such a man as he. His grip has been upon e these twenty years, and he has blasted my life. I'll tell you first how I came to be in his power.

"It was in te early '60's at the diggings. I was a young chap then, hot-blooded and reckless, ready to turn my hand at anything;I got among bad companions, took to drink, had no luck with my claim, took to the bush, and in a word became what yo would call over here a highway robber. Black Jack of Ballarat was the name I wentunder, and our party is still remembered in the colony as the Ballarat Gang.

"One day a gold convoy came down fro Ballarat to Melbourne, and we lay in wait for it and attacked it. There were six troopers and six of us, so it was  close thing, but we emptied four of their saddles at the first volley. Three of our boys were killed, however, befoe we got the swag. In a word, I trned over a new leaf and did my best to make up for the past. All was going well when McCarthy laid his grip upon me

"I had gone up to town about an investment, and I met him in Regent Street with hardly a coat to his back or a bot to his foot.

" 'Here we are, Jack,' says he, touching me on the arm; 'we'll be as good as a family to you. Thee's two of us, me and my son, and you can have the keeping of us. If you don't--it's a fine, law-abiding country is ngland, and there's always a policeman within hail.'

"Well, down they came to the west country, there was no shakng them off, and there they have lived rent free on my best land ever since. There was no rest for me, no peace, no orgetfulness; turn where I would, there was his cunning, grinning face at my elbow. It grew worse as Alice grew up, or he soon saw I was more afraid of her knowing my past than of the police. Whatever he wanted he must have, and whaever it was I gave him without question, land, money, houses, until at last he asked a thing which I could not give.He asked for Alice.

"His son, you see, had grown up, and so had my girl, and as I was known to be in weak health,it seemed a fine stroke to him that his lad should step into the whole property. But there I was firm. I would not hve his cursed stock mixed with mine; not that I had any dislike to the lad, but his blood was in him, and that was eough. I stood firm. McCarthy threatened. I braved him to do his worst. We were to meet at the pool midway between ou houses to talk it over.

"When I went down there I found him talking with his son, so I smoked a cigar and waitedbehind a tree until he should be alone. But as I listened to his talk all that was black and bitter in me seemed to ome uppermost. He was urging his son to marry my daughter with as little regard for what she might think as if she wre a slut from off the streets. Though clear of mind an fairly strong of limb, I knew that my own fate was sealed. But my memory and my girl! Both could be saved if I coul but silence that foul tongue. I did it, Mr. Holmes. I would do it again. Deeply as I have sinned, I have led a lifeof martyrdom to atone for it. But that my girl should be entangled in the same meshes which held me was more than I ould suffer. His cry brught back his son; but I had gained the cover of the wood, though I was forced to go back to fetch the cloak which Ihad dropped in my flight. That is the true story, gentlemen, of all that occurred."

"Well, it is not for me to juge you," said Holmes as the old man signed the statement which had been drawn out. "I pray that we may never be expoed to such a temptation."

"I pray not, sir. And what do you intend to do?"

"In view of your health, nothing. Yu are yourself aware that you will soon have to answer for your deed at a higher court than the Assizes. I will keepyour confession, and if McCarthy is condemned I shall be forced to use it. If not, it shall never be seen by mortal ye; and your secret, whether you be alive or dead, shall be safe with us."

"Farewell, then," said the old man solmnly. "Your own deathbeds, when they come, will be the easier for the thought of the peace which you have given to mne." Tottering and shaking in all his giant frame, he stumbled slowly from the room.

James Mcarthy was acquitted at the Assizes on the strength of a number of objections which had been drawn out by Holmes and ubmitted to the defending counsel. Old Turner lived for seven months after our interview, but he is now dead; and thre is every prospect that the son and daughter may come to live happily together in ignorance of the black cloud whih rests upon their past.

ADVENTURE  V.  THE FIVE ORANGE PIPS


When I glance over my notes and records of the herlock Holmes cases between the years '82 and '90, I am faced by so many which present strange and interesting featres that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave. Some, however, have already gained publiciy through the papers, and others have not offered a field for those peculiar qualities which my friend possessed in o high a degree, and which it is the object of these papers to illustrate. Some, too, have baffled his analytical skll, and would be, as narratives, beginnings without an ending, while others have been but partially cleared up, and ave their explanations founded rather upon conjecture and surmise than on that absolute logical proof which was so dar to him. There is, however, one of these last which was so remarkable in its details and so startling in its resuls that I am tempted to give some account of it in spite of the fact that there are points in connection with it whic never have been, and probably never will be, entirely cleared up.

The year '87 furnished us with a long series o cases of greater or less interest, of which I retain the records. Among my headings under this one twelve months I ind an account of the adventure of the Paradol Chamber, of the Amateur Mendicant Society, who held a luxurious club n the lower vault of a furniture warehouse, of the facts connected with the loss of the British barque Sophy Anderso, of the singular adventures of the Grice Patersons in the island of Uffa, and finally of the Camberwell poisoning cse. In the latter, as may be remembered, Sherlock Holmes was able, by winding up the dead man's watch, to prove thatit had been wound up two hours before, and that therefore the deceased had gone to bed within that time--a deductionwhich was of the greatest importance in clearing up the case. All these I may sketch out at some future date, but noe of them present such singular features as the strange train of circumstances which I have now taken up my pen to dscribe.

It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales had set in with exceptional violence. Al day the wind had screamed and the rain had beaten against the windows, so that even here in the heart of great, had-made London we were forced to raise our minds for the instant from the routine of life and to recognise the presene of those great elemental forces which shriek at mankind through the bars of his civilisation, like untamed beasts n a cage. As evening drew in, the storm grew higher and louder, and the wind cried and sobbed like a child in the chmney. Sherlock Holmes sat moodily at one side of the fireplace cross-indexing his records of crime, while I at the oher was deep in one of Clark Russell's fine sea-stories until the howl of the gale from without seemed to blend withthe text, and the splash of the rain to lengthen out into the long swash of the sea waves. My wife was on a visit toher mother's, and for a few days I was a dweller once more in my old quarters at Baker Street.

"Why," said I, glacing up at my companion, "that was surely the bell. Who could come to-night? Some friend of yours, perhaps?"

"Excpt yourself I have none," he answered. "I do not encourage visitors."

"A client, then?"

"If so, it is a seriou case. Nothing less would bring a man out on such a day and at such an hour. But I take it that it is more likely tobe some crony of the landlady's."

Sherlock Holmes was wrong in his conjecture, however, for there came a step in he passage and a tapping at the door. He stretched out his long arm to turn the lamp away from himself and towards te vacant chair upon which a newcomer must sit.

"Come in!" said he.

The man who entered was young, some two-andtwenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refinement and delicacy in his bearing. The sreaming umbrella which he held in his hand, and his long shining waterproof told of the fierce weather through whichhe had come. He looked about him anxiously in the glare of the lamp, and I could see that his face was pale and his yes heavy, like those of a man who is weighed down with some great anxiety.

"I owe you an apology," he said, raisng his golden pince-nez to his eyes. "I trust that I am not intruding. I fear that I have brought some traces of thestorm and rain into your snug chamber."

"Give me your coat and umbrella," said Holmes. "They may rest here on thehook and will be dry presently. You have come up from the south-west, I see."

"Yes, from Horsham."

"That clay nd chalk mixture which I see upon your toe caps is quite distinctive."

"I have come for advice."

"That is easiy got."

"And help."

"That is not always so easy."

"I have heard of you, Mr. Holmes. I heard from Major Prenergast how you saved him in the Tankerville Club scandal."

"Ah, of course. He was wrongfully accused of cheating t cards."

"He said that you could solve anything."

"He said too much."

"That you are never beaten."

"I hve been beaten four times--three times by men, and once by a woman."

"But what is that compared with the number o your successes?"

"It is true that I have been generally successful."

"Then you may be so with me."

"I beg hat you will draw your chair up to the fire and favour me with some details as to your case."

"It is no ordinary ne."

"None of those which come to me are. I am the last court of appeal."

"And yet I question, sir, whether, i all your experience, you have ever listened to a more mysterious and inexplicable chain of events than those which ave happened in my own family."

"You fill me with interest," said Holmes. "Pray give us the essential facts from he commencement, and I can afterwards question you as to those details which seem to me to be most important."

Th young man pulled his chair up and pushed his wet feet out towards the blaze.

"My name," said he, "is John Openshw, but my own affairs have, as far as I can understand, little to do with this awful business. It is a hereditary mater; so in order to give you an idea of the facts, I must go back to the commencement of the affair.

"You must knw that my grandfather had two sons--my uncle Elias and my father Joseph. My father had a small factory at Coventry, hich he enlarged at the time of the invention of bicycling. He was a patentee of the Openshaw unbreakable tire, and is business met with such success that he was able to sell it and to retire upon a handsome competence.

"My uncleElias emigrated to America when he was a young man and became a planter in Florida, where he was reported to have doe very well. At the time of the war he fought in Jackson's army, and afterwards under Hood, where he rose to be a coonel. When Lee laid down his arms my uncle returned to his plantation, where he remained for three or four years. Abut 1869 or 1870 he came back to Europe and took a small estate in Sussex, near Horsham. He had made a very considerale fortune in the States, and his reason for leaving them was his aversion to the negroes, and his dislike of the Reublican policy in extending the franchise to them. He was a singular man, fierce and quick-tempered, very foul-mouthd when he was angry, and of a most retiring disposition. During all the years that he lived at Horsham, I doubt if eer he set foot in the town. He had a garden and two or three fields round his house, and there he would take his execise, though very often for weeks on end he would never leave his room. He drank a great deal of brandy and smoked vry heavily, but he would see no society and did not want any friends, not even his own brother.

"He didn't mind m; in fact, he took a fancy to me, for at the time when he saw me first I was a youngster of twelve or so. This wouldbe in the year 1878, after he had been eight or nine years in England. He begged my father to let me live with him ad he was very kind to me in his way. When he was sober he used to be fond of playing backgammon and draughts with me and he would make me his representative both with the servants and with the tradespeople, so that by the time that  was sixteen I was quite master of the house. I kept all the keys and could go where I liked and do what I liked, solong as I did not disturb him in his privacy. There was one singular exception, however, for he had a single room, alumber-room up among the attics, which was invariably locked, and which he would never permit either me or anyone ele to enter. With a boy's curiosity I have peeped through the keyhole, but I was never able to see more than such a cllection of old trunks and bundles as would be expected in such a room.

"One day--it was in March, 1883--a letterwith a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel's plate. It was not a common thing for him to receiv letters, for his bills were all paid in ready money, and he had no friends of any sort. 'From India!' said he as hetook it up, 'Pondicherry postmark! What can this be?' Opening it hurriedly, out there jumped five little dried orang pips, which pattered down upon his plate. I began to laugh at this, but the laugh was struck from my lips at the siht of his face. His lip had fallen, his eyes were protruding, his skin the colour of putty, and he glared at the envlope which he still held in his trembling hand, 'K. K. K.!' he shrieked, and then, 'My God, my God, my sins have ovetaken me!'

" 'What is it, uncle?' I cried.

" 'Death,' said he, and rising from the table he retired to his roo, leaving me palpitating with horror. I took up the envelope and saw scrawled in red ink upon the inner flap, just aove the gum, the letter K three times repeated. There was nothing else save the five dried pips. What could be the rason of his overpowering terror? I left the breakfast-table, and as I ascended the stair I met him coming down with n old rusty key, which must have belonged to the attic, in one hand, and a small brass box, like a cashbox, in the oher.

" 'They may do what they like, but I'll checkmate them still,' said he with an oath. 'Tell Mary that I shallwant a fire in my room to-day, and send down to Fordham, the Horsham lawyer.'

"I did as he ordered, and when the awyer arrived I was asked to step up to the room. The fire was burning brightly, and in the grate there was a mass o black, fluffy ashes, as of burned paper, while the brass box stood open and empty beside it. As I glanced at the bo I noticed, with a start, that upon the lid was printed the treble K which I had read in the morning upon the enveloe.

" 'I wish you, John,' said my uncle, 'to witness my will. I leave my estate, with all its advantages and all is disadvantages, to my brother, your father, whence it will, no doubt, descend to you. If you can enjoy it in peace,well and good! If you find you cannot, take my advice, my boy, and leave it to your deadliest enemy. I am sorry to gve you such a two-edged thing, but I can't say what turn things are going to take. Kindly sign the paper where Mr. Frdham shows you.'

"I signed the paper as directed, and the lawyer took it away with him. The singular incident mae, as you may think, the deepest impression upon me, and I pondered over it and turned it every way in my mind withot being able to make anything of it. Yet I could not shake off the vague feeling of dread which it left behind, thouh the sensation grew less keen as the weeks passed and nothing happened to disturb the usual routine of our lives. Icould see a change in my uncle, however. He drank more than ever, and he was less inclined for any sort of society. ost of his time he would spend in his room, with the door locked upon the inside, but sometimes he would emerge in asort of drunken frenzy and would burst out of the house and tear about the garden with a revolver in his hand, screaing out that he was afraid of no man, and that he was not to be cooped up, like a sheep in a pen, by man or devil. Wen these hot fits were over, however, he would rush tumultuously in at the door and lock and bar it behind him, likea man who can brazen it out no longer against the terror which lies at the roots of his soul. At such times I have sen his face, even on a cold day, glisten with moisture, as though it were new raised from a basin.

"Well, to cometo an end of the matter, Mr. Holmes, and not to abuse your patience, there came a night when he made one of those drnken sallies from which he never came back. We found him, when we went to search for him, face downward in a little reen-scummed pool, which lay at the foot of the garden. There was no sign of any violence, and the water was but twofeet deep, so that the jury, having regard to his known eccentricity, brought in a verdict of 'suicide.' But I, who new how he winced from the very thought of death, had much ado to persuade myself that he had gone out of his way tomeet it. The matter passed, however, and my father entered into possession of the estate, and of some $14,000, whichlay to his credit at the bank."

"One moment," Holmes interposed, "your statement is, I foresee, one of the most rmarkable to which I have ever listened. Let me have the date of the reception by your uncle of the letter, and the dte of his supposed suicide."

"The letter arrived on March 10, 1883. His death was seven weeks later, upon the nigt of May 2nd."

"Thank you. Pray proceed."

"When my father took over the Horsham property, he, at my request, mde a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. We found the brass box there, although its cntents had been destroyed. On the inside of the cover was a paper label, with the initials of K. K. K. repeated uponit, and 'Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register' written beneath. These, we presume, indicated the nature of te papers which had been destroyed by Colonel Openshaw. "othing."

This strange, wild story seemed to have come to us from amid the madelements--blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale--and now to have been reabsorbed by them once more.

"The ideal reasoner," he remarked, "woud, when he had once been shown a single fact in all its bearings, deduce from it not only all the chain of events whch led up to it but also all the results which would follow from it. We have not yet grasped the result which the reason alone can attain to. Problems may be solved in the study which have baffled all those who have souht a solution by the aid of their senses. To carry the art, however, to its highest pitch, it is necessary that the easoner should be able to utilise all the facts which have come to his knowledge; and this in itself implies, as youwill readily see, a possession of all knowledge, which, even in these days of free education and encyclopaedias, is  somewhat rare accomplishment. " 'Ku Klux Klan. A name derived from the fanciful resemblance to the sound produced by cocking a ifle. This terrible secret society was formed by some ex-Confederate soldiers in the Southern states after the CivilWar, and it rapidly formed local branches in different parts of the country, notably in Tennessee, Louisiana, the Caolinas, Georgia, and Florida. Its power was used for political purposes, principally for the terrorising of the negr voters and the murdering and driving from the country of those who were opposed to its views. Its outrages were usully preceded by a warning sent to the marked man in some fantastic but generally recognised shape--a sprig of oak-leves in some parts, melon seeds or orange pips in others. On receiving this the victim might either openly abjure hisformer ways, or might fly from the country. If he braved the matter out, death would unfailingly come upon him, and sually in some strange and unforeseen manner. So perfect was the organisation of the society, and so systematic its ethods, that there is hardly a case upon record where any man succeeded in braving it with impunity, or in which anyof its outrages were traced home to the perpetrators. For some years the organisation flourished in spite of the effrts of the United States government and of the better classes of the community in the South. Eventually, in the year1869, the movement rather suddenly collapsed, although there have been sporadic outbreaks of the same sort since tha date.'

ADVENTURE  VI. THE MAN WITH THE TWISTED LIP


Isa Whitney, brother of the late Elias Whitney, D.D., Principal of the TheologicalCollege of St. George's, was much addicted to opium. The habit grew upon him, as I understand, from some foolish frek when he was at college; for having read De Quincey's description of his dreams and sensations, he had drenched histobacco with laudanum in an attempt to produce the same effects. He found, as so many more have done, that the practce is easier to attain than to get rid of, and for many years he continued to be a slave to the drug, an object of mngled horror and pity to his friends and relatives. I can see him now, with yellow, pasty face, drooping lids, and pn-point pupils, all huddled in a chair, the wreck and ruin of a noble man.

One night--it was in June, '89--there ame a ring to my bell, about the hour when a man gives his first yawn and glances at the clock. I sat up in my chair and my wife laid her needle-work down in her lap and made a little face of disappointment.

"A patient!" said she "You'll have to go out."

I groaned, for I was newly come back from a weary day.

We heard the door open, a fewhurried words, and then quick steps upon the linoleum. Our own door flew open, and a lady, clad in some dark-coloure stuff, with a black veil, entered the room.

"You will excuse my calling so late," she began, and then, suddenly osing her self-control, she ran forward, threw her arms about my wife's neck, and sobbed upon her shoulder. "Oh, I'min such trouble!" she cried; "I do so want a little help."

"Why," said my wife, pulling up her veil, "it is Kate hitney. How you startled me, Kate! I had not an idea who you were when you came in."

"I didn't know what to do, s I came straight to you." That was always the way. Folk who were in grief came to my wife like birds to a light-hous.

"It was very sweet of you to come. Now, you must have some wine and water, and sit here comfortably and tell usall about it. Or should you rather that I sent James off to bed?"

"Oh, no, no! I want the doctor's advice and hel, too. It's about Isa. He has not been home for two days. I am so frightened about him!"

It was not the first tim that she had spoken to us of her husband's trouble, to me as a doctor, to my wife as an old friend and school compaion. We soothed and comforted her by such words as we could find. Did she know where her husband was? Was it possibl that we could bring him back to her?

It seems that it was. She had the surest information that of late he had, wen the fit was on him, made use of an opium den in the farthest east of the City. Hitherto his orgies had always bee confined to one day, and he had come back, twitching and shattered, in the evening. But now the spell had been uponhim eight-and-forty hours, and he lay there, doubtless among the dregs of the docks, breathing in the poison or sleeing off the effects. There he was to be found, she was sure of it, at the Bar of Gold, in Upper Swandam Lane. But wht was she to do? How could she, a young and timid woman, make her way into such a place and pluck her husband out frm among the ruffians who surrounded him?

There was the case, and of course there was but one way out of it. MightI not escort her to this place? And then, as a second thought, why should she come at all? I was Isa Whitney's medicl adviser, and as such I had influence over him. I could manage it better if I were alone. I promised her on my wordthat I would send him home in a cab within two hours if he were indeed at the address which she had given me. And soin ten minutes I had left my armchair and cheery sitting-room behind me, and was speeding eastward in a hansom on a trange errand, as it seemed to me at the time, though the future only could show how strange it was to be.

But thre was no great difficulty in the first stage of my adventure. Upper Swandam Lane is a vile alley lurking behind thehigh wharves which line the north side of the river to the east of London Bridge. Between a slop-shop and a gin-shop approached by a steep flight of steps leading down to a black gap like the mouth of a cave, I found the den of whic I was in search. Ordering my cab to wait, I passed down the steps, worn hollow in the centre by the ceaseless treadof drunken feet; and by the light of a flickering oil-lamp above the door I found the latch and made my way into a lng, low room, thick and heavy with the brown opium smoke, and terraced with wooden berths, like the forecastle of anemigrant ship.

Through the gloom one could dimly catch a glimpse of bodies lying in strange fantastic poses, bowe shoulders, bent knees, heads thrown back, and chins pointing upward, with here and there a dark, lack-lustre eye tuned upon the newcomer. Out of the black shadows there glimmered little red circles of light, now bright, now faint, s the burning poison waxed or waned in the bowls of the metal pipes. The most lay silent, but some muttered to themslves, and others talked together in a strange, low, monotonous voice, their conversation coming in gushes, and then uddenly tailing off into silence, each mumbling out his own thoughts and paying little heed to the words of his neigbour. At the farther end was a small brazier of burning charcoal, beside which on a three-legged wooden stool there at a tall, thin old man, with his jaw resting upon his two fists, and his elbows upon his knees, staring into the fie.

As I entered, a sallow Malay attendant had hurried up with a pipe for me and a supply of the drug, beckoning m to an empty berth.

"Thank you. I have not come to stay," said I. "There is a friend of mine here, Mr. Isa Whitne, and I wish to speak with him."

There was a movement and an exclamation from my right, and peering through the goom, I saw Whitney, pale, haggard, and unkempt, staring out at me.

"Who is on duty?" asked Holmes.

"Inspector Bradstreet, sir."

"I called bout that beggarman, Boone--the one who was charged with being concerned in the disappearance of Mr. Neville St. Clar, of Lee."

"n the cells."

"Oh, he gives no trouble. But he is a dirty scoundrel."

"Yes, it i all we can do to make him wash his hands, and his face is as black as a tinker's. Well, when once his case has beensettled, he will have a regular prison bath; and I think, if you saw him, you would agree with me that he needed it.

"I should like to see him very much."

"Would you? That is easily done. Come this way. You can leave your bag.

"No, I think that I'll take it."

"Very good. Come this way, if you please." He led us down a passage, opened  barred door, passed down a winding stair, and brought us to a whitewashed corridor with a line of doors on each sid.

We both put our eyes o the grating. The prisoner lay with his face towards us, in a very deep sleep, breathing slowly and heavily. He was, as the inspector had said, extremely dirty, but the grime which covered his face could not concel its repulsive ugliness. A broad wheal from an old scar ran right across it from eye to chin, and by its contractio had turned up one side of the upper lip, so that three teeth were exposed in a perpetual snarl. Never in my life have I see such a sight. The man's face peeled off under the sponge like the bark from a tree. Gone was the coarse brown tint!Gone, too, was the horrid scar which had seamed it across, and the twisted lip which had given the repulsive sneer t the face! The prisoner urned with the reckless air of a man who abandons himself to his destiny. "Be it so," said he. "And pray what am I carged with?"
