"No crime, but a very great error has been committed," said Hlmes. "You would have done better to have trusted you wife."

"It was not the wife; it was the children," groaned he prisoner. "God help me, I would not have them ashamed of their father. My God! What an exposure! What can I do?"
Sherlock Holmes sat down beside him on the couch and patted him kindly on the shoulder.

"If you leave it to a curt of law to clear the matter up," said he, "of course you can hardly avoid publicity. On the other hand, if you covince the police authorities that there is no possible case against you, I do not know that there is any reason thatthe details should find their way into the papers. Inspector Bradstreet would, I am sure, make notes upon anything wich you might tell us and submit it to the proper authorities. The case would then never go into court at all."

"od bless you!" cried the prisoner passionately. "I would have endured imprisonment, ay, even execution, rather than ave left my miserable secret as a family blot to my children.

"You are the first who have ever heard my story. Myfather was a schoolmaster in Chesterfield, where I received an excellent education. I travelled in my youth, took tothe stage, and finally became a reporter on an evening paper in London. One day my editor wished to have a series ofarticles upon begging in the metropolis, and I volunteered to supply them. There was the point from which all my advntures started. It was only by trying begging as an amateur that I could get the facts upon which to base my article. When an actor I had, of course, learned all the secrets of making up, and had been famous in the green-room for myskill. I took advantage now of my attainments. I painted my face, and to make myself as pitiable as possible I made  good scar and fixed one side of my lip in a twist by the aid of a small slip of flesh-coloured plaster. Then with ared head of hair, and an appropriate dress, I took my station in the business part of the city, ostensibly as a matc-seller but really as a beggar. For seven hours I plied my trade, and when I returned home in the evening I found tomy surprise that I had received no less than 26s. 4d.

"I wrote my articles and thought little more of the matter ntil, some time later, I backed a bill for a friend and had a writ served upon me for $25. I was at my wit's end whee to get the money, but a sudden idea came to me. I begged a fortnight's grace from the creditor, asked for a holida from my employers, and spent the time in begging in the City under my disguise. In ten days I had the money and hadpaid the debt.

"Well, you can imagine how hard it was to settle down to arduous work at $2 a week when I knew tha I could earn as much in a day by smearing my face with a little paint, laying my cap on the ground, and sitting stil. It was a long fight between my pride and the money, but the dollars won at last, and I threw up reporting and satday after day in the corner which I had first chosen, inspiring pity by my ghastly face and filling my pockets with oppers. Only one man knew my secret. He was the keeper of a low den in which I used to lodge in Swandam Lane, where  could every morning emerge as a squalid beggar and in the evenings transform myself into a well-dressed man about twn. This fellow, a Lascar, was well paid by me for his rooms, so that I knew that my secret was safe in his possessin.

"Well, very soon I found that I was saving considerable sums of money. I do not mean that any beggar in the steets of London could earn $700 a year--which is less than my average takings--but I had exceptional advantages in mypower of making up, and also in a facility of repartee, which improved by practice and made me quite a recognised chracter in the City. All day a stream of pennies, varied by silver, poured in upon me, and it was a very bad day in wich I failed to take $2.

"As I grew richer I grew more ambitious, took a house in the country, and eventually maried, without anyone having a suspicion as to my real occupation. My dear wife knew that I had business in the City. he little knew what.

"Last Monday I had finished for the day and was dressing in my room above the opium den whenI looked out of my window and saw, to my horror and astonishment, that my wife was standing in the street, with her yes fixed full upon me. I gave a cry of surprise, threw up my arms to cover my face, and, rushing to my confidant, te Lascar, entreated him to prevent anyone from coming up to me. I heard her voice downstairs, but I knew that she cold not ascend. Swiftly I threw off my clothes, pulled on those of a beggar, and put on my pigments and wig. Even a wfe's eyes could not pierce so complete a disguise. But then it occurred to me that there might be a search in the rom, and that the clothes might betray me. I threw open the window, reopening by my violence a small cut which I had iflicted upon myself in the bedroom that morning. Then I seized my coat, which was weighted by the coppers which I ha just transferred to it from the leather bag in which I carried my takings. I hurled it out of the window, and it diappeared into the Thames. The other clothes would have followed, but at that moment there was a rush of constables u the stair, and a few minutes after I found, rather, I confess, to my relief, that instead of being identified as Mr Neville St. Clair, I was arrested as his murderer.

"I do not know that there is anything else for me to explain.I was determined to preserve my disguise as long as possible, and hence my preference for a dirty face. Knowing thatmy wife would be terribly anxious, I slipped off my ring and confided it to the Lascar at a moment when no constablewas watching me, together with a hurried scrawl, telling her that she had no cause to fear."

"That note only reaced her yesterday," said Holmes.

"Good God! What a week she must have spent!"

"The police have watched this Lasar," said Inspector Bradstreet, "and I can quite understand that he might find it difficult to post a letter unobsered. Probably he handed it to some sailor customer of his, who forgot all about it for some days."

"That was it," aid Holmes, nodding approvingly; "I have no doubt of it. But have you never been prosecuted for begging?"

"Many tmes; but what was a fine to me?"

"It must stop here, however," said Bradstreet. "If the police are to hush this ting up, there must be no more of Hugh Boone."

"I have sworn it by the most solemn oaths which a man can take."
"In that case I think that it is probable that no further steps may be taken. But if you are found again, then all mst come out. I am sure, Mr. Holmes, that we are very much indebted to you for having cleared the matter up. I wish Iknew how you reach your results."

"I reached this one," said my friend, "by sitting upon five pillows and consumig an ounce of shag. I think, Watson, that if we drive to Baker Street we shall just be in time for breakfast."

VI.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE BLUE CARBUNCLE


I had called upon my friend Sherlock Holmes upon the second morning afte Christmas, with the intention of wishing him the compliments of the season. He was lounging upon the sofa in a purpe dressing-gown, a pipe-rack within his reach upon the right, and a pile of crumpled morning papers, evidently newlystudied, near at hand. Beside the couch was a wooden chair, and on the angle of the back hung a very seedy and disreutable hard-felt hat, much the worse for wear, and cracked in several places. A lens and a forceps lying upon the set of the chair suggested that the hat had been suspended in this manner for the purpose of examination.

"You are ngaged," said I; "perhaps I interrupt you."

"Not at all. I am glad to have a friend with whom I can discuss my reults. The matter is a perfectly trivial one"--he jerked his thumb in the direction of the old hat--"but there are ponts in connection with it which are not entirely devoid of interest and even of instruction."

I seated myself in is armchair and warmed my hands before his crackling fire, for a sharp frost had set in, and the windows were thick ith the ice crystals. "I suppose," I remarked, "that, homely as it looks, this thing has some deadly story linked onto it--that it is the clue which will guide you in the solution of some mystery and the punishment of some crime."

"No, no. No crime," said Sherlock Holmes, laughing. "Only one of those whimsical little incidents which will happenwhen you have four million human beings all jostling each other within the space of a few square miles. Amid the acton and reaction of so dense a swarm of humanity, every possible combination of events may be expected to take place,and many a little problem will be presented which may be striking and bizarre without being criminal. We have alread had experience of such."

"So much so," I remarked, "that of the last six cases which I have added to my notes, tree have been entirely free of any legal crime."

"Precisely. You allude to my attempt to recover the Irene Adler apers, to the singular case of Miss Mary Sutherland, and to the adventure of the man with the twisted lip. Well, I hve no doubt that this small matter will fall into the same innocent category. You know Peterson, the commissionaire?

"Yes."

"It is to him that this trophy belongs."

"It is his hat."

"No, no, he found it. Its owner is unkown. I beg that you will look upon it not as a battered billycock but as an intellectual problem. And, first, as to ow it came here. It arrived upon Christmas morning, in company with a good fat goose, which is, I have no doubt, roating at this moment in front of Peterson's fire. The facts are these: about four o'clock on Christmas morning, Peteron, who, as you know, is a very honest fellow, was returning from some small jollification and was making his way hoeward down Tottenham Court Road. In front of him he saw, in the gaslight, a tallish man, walking with a slight staggr, and carrying a white goose slung over his shoulder. As he reached the corner of Goodge Street, a row broke out beween this stranger and a little knot of roughs. One of the latter knocked off the man's hat, on which he raised his tick to defend himself and, swinging it over his head, smashed the shop window behind him. Peterson had rushed forwad to protect the stranger from his assailants; but the man, shocked at having broken the window, and seeing an offical-looking person in uniform rushing towards him, dropped his goose, took to his heels, and vanished amid the labyrith of small streets which lie at the back of Tottenham Court Road. The roughs had also fled at the appearance of Petrson, so that he was left in possession of the field of battle, and also of the spoils of victory in the shape of ths battered hat and a most unimpeachable Christmas goose."

"Which surely he restored to their owner?"

"My dear ellow, there lies the problem. It is true that 'For Mrs. Henry Baker' was printed upon a small card which was tied t the bird's left leg, and it is also true that the initials 'H. B.' are legible upon the lining of this hat, but as here are some thousands of Bakers, and some hundreds of Henry Bakers in this city of ours, it is not easy to restorelost property to any one of them."

"What, then, did Peterson do?"

"He brought round both hat and goose to me o Christmas morning, knowing that even the smallest problems are of interest to me. The goose we retained until this orning, when there were signs that, in spite of the slight frost, it would be well that it should be eaten without unecessary delay. Its finder has carried it off, therefore, to fulfil the ultimate destiny of a goose, while I contine to retain the hat of the unknown gentleman who lost his Christmas dinner."

"Did he not advertise?"

"No."

Then, what clue could you have as to his identity?"

"Only as much as we can deduce."

"From his hat?"

"Preciely."

"But you are joking. What can you gather from this old battered felt?"

"Here is my lens. You know my metods. What can you gather yourself as to the individuality of the man who has worn this article?"

I took the tatteed object in my hands and turned it over rather ruefully. It was a very ordinary black hat of the usual round shape,hard and much the worse for wear. The lining had been of red silk, but was a good deal discoloured. There was no makr's name; but, as Holmes had remarked, the initials "H. B." were scrawled upon one side. It was pierced in the brim or a hat-securer, but the elastic was missing. For the rest, it was cracked, exceedingly dusty, and spotted in severl places, although there seemed to have been some attempt to hide the discoloured patches by smearing them with ink.

"I can see nothing," said I, handing it back to my friend.

He picked it up and gazed at it in the peculiar introspective fashio which was characteristic of him. This may account also for the obvious fact that his wife has eased to love him."

I this man could afford to buy so expensive a hat three years ago, and has had no hat since, then he has assuredly goe down in the world."

Sherlock Holmes laughed. "Here is the foresight," said he putting his finger upon the little disc and loop f the hat-securer. "They are never sold upon hats. Anyhow, h never got tallow-stains from a gas-jet. Are you satisfied?"

"Well, it is very ingenious," said I, laughing; "butsince, as you said just now, there has been no crime committed, and no harm done save the loss of a goose, all this eems to be rather a waste of energy."

Sherlock Holmes had opened his mouth to reply, when the door flew open, andPeterson, the commissionaire, rushed into the apartment with flushed cheeks and the face of a man who is dazed with stonishment.

"Hotel Cosmopolitan Jewel Robbery. John Horner, 26, plumbr, was brought up upon the charge of having upon the 22nd inst., abstracted from the jewel-case of the Countess of Mrcar the valuable gem known as the blue carbuncle. When the commissionaire had gone, Holms took up the stone and held it against the light. "It's a bonny thing," said he. "Just see how it glints and sparkls. Of course it is a nucleus and focus of crime. Every good stone is. They are the devil's pet baits. In the larger nd older jewels every facet may stand for a bloody deed. This stone is not yet twenty years old. It was found in thebanks of the Amoy River in southern China and is remarkable in having every characteristic of the carbuncle, save tht it is blue in shade instead of ruby red. In spite of its youth, it has already a sinister history. "I cannot tell."

"Well, then, do you imagine that this other one, Henry Baker, ha anything to do with the matter?"

That, however, I shall determine by a very simple test if we have an answer to our advertisement."

"Nothing."

"In that case I shall continue my professional round. But I shall come bak in the evening at the hour you have mentioned, for I should like to see the solution of so tangled a business."
"Very glad to see you. I dine at seven. There is a woodcock, I believe. By the way, in view of recent occurrences, prhaps I ought to ask Mrs. Hudson to examine its crop."

I had been delayed at a case, and it was a little after haf-past six when I found myself in Baker Street once more. He was a large man with rounded shoulders, a massive head, ad a broad, intelligent face, sloping down to a pointed beard of grizzled brown. "I had no doubt that the gang of roughs who assaulted me had carriedoff both my hat and the bird. I did not care to spend more money in a hopeless attempt at recovering them."

"Verynaturally. By the way, about the bird, we were compelled to eat it."

"To eat it!" Our visitor half rose from his hair in his excitement.

"Yes, it would have been of no use to anyone had we not done so. But I presume that this ther goose upon the sideboard, which is about the same weight and perfectly fresh, will answer your purpose equally ell?"

"There ae a few of us who frequent the Alpha Inn, near the Museum--we are to be found in the Museum itself during the day, yu understand. My pence were duly paid, and the rest is familia to you. I am much indebted to you, sir, for a Scotch bonnet is fitted neither to my years nor my gravity." Ryder pased his tongue over his parched lips. "I will tell you it just as it happened, sir," said he. "When Horner had been arested, it seemed to me that it would be best for me to get away with the stone at once, for I did not know at what oment the police might not take it into their heads to search me and my room. There was no place about the hotel whee it would be safe. I went out, as if on some commission, and I made for my sister's house. I knew that he would be true to me, for I knew one or two things about him; so I made up my ind to go right on to Kilburn, where he lived, and take him into my confidence. He would show me how to turn the stoe into money. But how to get to him in safety? I thought of the agonies I had gone through in coming from the hotel.I might at any moment be seized and searched, and there would be the stone in my waistcoat pocket. I was leaning aganst the wall at the time and looking at the geese which were waddling about round my feet, and suddenly an idea cameinto my head which showed me how I could beat the best detective that ever lived.

"My sister had told me some wees before that I might have the pick of her geese for a Christmas present, and I knew that she was always as good as er word. I would take my goose now, and in it I would carry my stone to Kilburn. There was a little shed in the yard and behind this I drove one of the birds--a fine big one, white, with a barred tail. I caught it, and prying its bil open, I thrust the stone down its throat as far as my finger could reach. The bird gave a gulp, and I felt the stoe pass along its gullet and down into its crop. " 'Watever were you doing with that bird, Jem?' says she.

" 'Where are they all, Maggie?' I cried

And now--and now I am myself a branded thief, without ever having toched the wealth for which I sold my character. God help me! God help me!" He burst into convulsive sobbing, with hisface buried in his hands.

Chance has put in our way a most singular and whimsical roblem, and its solution is its own reward. VIII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE SPECKLED BAND

On glancing over my notes of the seventy odd cases in which I have during the last eight years studied the methos of my friend Sherlock Holmes, I find many tragic, some comic, a large number merely strange, but none commonplace;for, working as he did rather for the love of his art than for the acquirement of wealth, he refused to associate hiself with any investigation which did not tend towards the unusual, and even the fantastic. Of all these varied case, however, I cannot recall any which presented more singular features than that which was associated with the well-kown Surrey family of the Roylotts of Stoke Moran. The events in question occurred in the early days of my associatio with Holmes, when we were sharing rooms as bachelors in Baker Street. It is possible that I might have placed them pon record before, but a promise of secrecy was made at the time, from which I have only been freed during the last onth by the untimely death of the lady to whom the pledge was given. It is perhaps as well that the facts should nowcome to light, for I have reasons to know that there are widespread rumours as to the death of Dr. Grimesby Roylott hich tend to make the matter even more terrible than the truth.

It was early in April in the year '83 that I wokeone morning to find Sherlock Holmes standing, fully dressed, by the side of my bed. He was a late riser, as a rule, nd as the clock on the mantelpiece showed me that it was only a quarter-past seven, I blinked up at him in some surpise, and perhaps just a little resentment, for I was myself regular in my habits.

"Very sorry to knock you up, Wason," said he, "but it's the common lot this morning. Mrs. Hudson has been knocked up, she retorted upon me, and I o you."

"What is it, then--a fire?"

"No; a client. It seems that a young lady has arrived in a considerable stae of excitement, who insists upon seeing me. She is waiting now in the sitting-room. Now, when young ladies wander aout the metropolis at this hour of the morning, and knock sleepy people up out of their beds, I presume that it is smething very pressing which they have to communicate. Should it prove to be an interesting case, you would, I am sur, wish to follow it from the outset. I thought, at any rate, that I should call you and give you the chance."

"Mydear fellow, I would not miss it for anything."

I had no keener pleasure than in following Holmes in his professinal investigations, and in admiring the rapid deductions, as swift as intuitions, and yet always founded on a logica basis with which he unravelled the problems which were submitted to him. I rapidly threw on my clothes and was read in a few minutes to accompany my friend down to the sitting-room. A lady dressed in black and heavily veiled, who hd been sitting in the window, rose as we entered.

"Good-morning, madam," said Holmes cheerily. "My name is Sherlok Holmes. This is my intimate friend and associate, Dr. Watson, before whom you can speak as freely as before myself Ha! I am glad to see that Mrs. Hudson has had the good sense to light the fire. Pray draw up to it, and I shall ordr you a cup of hot coffee, for I observe that you are shivering."

"It is not cold which makes me shiver," said th woman in a low voice, changing her seat as requested.

"What, then?"

"It is fear, Mr. Holmes. It is terror." Se raised her veil as she spoke, and we could see that she was indeed in a pitiable state of agitation, her face all rawn and grey, with restless frightened eyes, like those of some hunted animal. Her features and figure were those o a woman of thirty, but her hair was shot with premature grey, and her expression was weary and haggard. Sherlock Homes ran her over with one of his quick, all-comprehensive glances.

"You must not fear," said he soothingly, bendig forward and patting her forearm. "We shall soon set matters right, I have no doubt. You have come in by train thismorning, I see."

"You know me, then?"

"No, but I observe the second half of a return ticket in the palm of you left glove. You must have started early, and yet you had a good drive in a dog-cart, along heavy roads, before you eached the station."

The lady gave a violent start and stared in bewilderment at my companion.

"There is no mytery, my dear madam," said he, smiling. "The left arm of your jacket is spattered with mud in no less than seven plaes. The marks are perfectly fresh. There is no vehicle save a dog-cart which throws up mud in that way, and then onl when you sit on the left-hand side of the driver."

"Whatever your reasons may be, you are perfectly correct," sad she. "I started from home before six, reached Leatherhead at twenty past, and came in by the first train to Waterlo. Sir, I can stand this strain no longer; I shall go mad if it continues. I have no one to turn to--none, save onlyone, who cares for me, and he, poor fellow, can be of little aid. I have heard of you, Mr. Holmes; I have heard of yu from Mrs. Farintosh, whom you helped in the hour of her sore need. It was from her that I had your address. Oh, si, do you not think that you could help me, too, and at least throw a little light through the dense darkness which srrounds me? At present it is out of my power to reward you for your services, but in a month or six weeks I shall bemarried, with the control of my own income, and then at least you shall not find me ungrateful."

Holmes turned tohis desk and, unlocking it, drew out a small case-book, which he consulted.

"Farintosh," said he. "Ah yes, I recal the case; it was concerned with an opal tiara. I think it was before your time, Watson. I can only say, madam, tha I shall be happy to devote the same care to your case as I did to that of your friend. As to reward, my profession s its own reward; but you are at liberty to defray whatever expenses I may be put to, at the time which suits you bet. And now I beg that you will lay before us everything that may help us in forming an opinion upon the matter."

Alas!" replied our visitor, "the very horror of my situation lies in the fact that my fears are so vague, and my susicions depend so entirely upon small points, which might seem trivial to another, that even he to whom of all othersI have a right to look for help and advice looks upon all that I tell him about it as the fancies of a nervous woman He does not say so, but I can read it from his soothing answers and averted eyes. But I have heard, Mr. Holmes, tha you can see deeply into the manifold wickedness of the human heart. You may advise me how to walk amid the dangers hich encompass me."

"I am all attention, madam."

"My name is Helen Stoner, and I am living with my stepfather,who is the last survivor of one of the oldest Saxon families in England, the Roylotts of Stoke Moran, on the westernborder of Surrey."

Holmes nodded his head. "The name is familiar to me," said he.

"The family was at one time mong the richest in England, and the estates extended over the borders into Berkshire in the north, and Hampshire inthe west. In the last century, however, four successive heirs were of a dissolute and wasteful disposition, and the amily ruin was eventually completed by a gambler in the days of the Regency. Nothing was left save a few acres of grund, and the two-hundred-year-old house, which is itself crushed under a heavy mortgage. The last squire dragged outhis existence there, living the horrible life of an aristocratic pauper; but his only son, my stepfather, seeing tha he must adapt himself to the new conditions, obtained an advance from a relative, which enabled him to take a medicl degree and went out to Calcutta, where, by his professional skill and his force of character, he established a lare practice. In a fit of anger, however, caused by some robberies which had been perpetrated in the house, he beat hi native butler to death and narrowly escaped a capital sentence. As it was, he suffered a long term of imprisonment nd afterwards returned to England a morose and disappointed man.

"When Dr. Roylott was in India he married my moter, Mrs. Stoner, the young widow of Major-General Stoner, of the Bengal Artillery. My sister Julia and I were twins,and we were only two years old at the time of my mother's re-marriage. She had a considerable sum of money--not lessthan $1000 a year--and this she bequeathed to Dr. Roylott entirely while we resided with him, with a provision that  certain annual sum should be allowed to each of us in the event of our marriage. Shortly after our return to Englan my mother died--she was killed eight years ago in a railway accident near Crewe. IX.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE ENGINEER'STHUMB


Of all the problems which have been submitted to my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, for solution during the ears of our intimacy, there were only two which I was the means of introducing to his notice--that of Mr. Hatherley' thumb, and that of Colonel Warburton's madness. Of these the latter may have afforded a finer field for an acute an original observer, but the other was so strange in its inception and so dramatic in its details that it may be the ore worthy of being placed upon record, even if it gave my friend fewer openings for those deductive methods of reasning by which he achieved such remarkable results. The story has, I believe, been told more than once in the newspaprs, but, like all such narratives, its effect is much less striking when set forth en bloc in a single half-column o print than when the facts slowly evolve before your own eyes, and the mystery clears gradually away as each new disovery furnishes a step which leads on to the complete truth. At the time the circumstances made a deep impression upn me, and the lapse of two years has hardly served to weaken the effect.

It was in the summer of '89, not long afer my marriage, that the events occurred which I am now about to summarise. X.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE NOBLE BACHELOR


The Lord St. Simon marriage,and its curious termination, have long ceased to be a subject of interest in those exalted circles in which the unfotunate bridegroom moves. Fresh scandals have eclipsed it, and their more piquant details have drawn the gossips awayfrom this four-year-old drama. As I have reason to believe, however, that the full facts have never been revealed tothe general public, and as my friend Sherlock Holmes had a considerable share in clearing the matter up, I feel thatno memoir of him would be complete without some little sketch of this remarkable episode.

It was a few weeks befoe my own marriage, during the days when I was still sharing rooms with Holmes in Baker Street, that he came home fro an afternoon stroll to find a letter on the table waiting for him. I had remained indoors all day, for the weather ad taken a sudden turn to rain, with high autumnal winds, and the Jezail bullet which I had brought back in one of m limbs as a relic of my Afghan campaign throbbed with dull persistence. "Here is a very fashionable epistle," I remarked as heentered. "Your morning letters, if I remember right, were from a fish-monger and a tide-waiter."

"Yes, my correspndence has certainly the charm of variety," he answered, smiling, "and the humbler are usually the more interesting.This looks like one of those unwelcome social summonses which call upon a man either to be bored or to lie."

He boke the seal and glanced over the contents.

"ot social, then?"

"No, distinctly professional."

"One of the highest in England.

"That is well. The letter which I hold in my hand s from Lord St. Simon. I will read it to you, and in return you must turn over these papers and let me have whateverbears upon the matter. This is what he says:

" 'MY DEAR MR. SHERLOCK HOLMES:--Lord Backwater tells me that I may lace implicit reliance upon your judgment and discretion. " 'Lod Robert Walsingham de Vere St. Simon, second son of the Duke of Balmoral.' Hum! 'Arms: Azure, three caltrops in chif over a fess sable. Born in 1846.' He's forty-one years of age, which is mature for marriage. Was Under-Secretary fr the colonies in a late administration. The Duke, his father, was at one time Secretary for Foreign Affairs. They iherit Plantagenet blood by direct descent, and Tudor on the distaff side. Ha! Well, there is nothing very instructiv in all this. I think that I must turn to you Watson, for something more solid."

"

XI.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE BERYL CORONET

XII.  THE ADVENTURE OF THE COPPER BEECHES


"To the man who loves art for its own sake," remarked Sherlock Hlmes, tossing aside the advertisement sheet of the Daily Telegraph, "it is frequently in its least important and lowiest manifestations that the keenest pleasure is to be derived. It is pleasant to me to observe, Watson, that you hae so far grasped this truth that in these little records of our cases which you have been good enough to draw up, an, I am bound to say, occasionally to embellish, you have given prominence not so much to the many causes celebres an sensational trials in which I have figured but rather to those incidents which may have been trivial in themselves,but which have given room for those faculties of deduction and of logical synthesis which I have made my special proince."

"And yet," said I, smiling, "I cannot quite hold myself absolved from the charge of sensationalism which hs been urged against my records."

"You have erred, perhaps," he observed, taking up a glowing cinder with the tons and lighting with it the long cherry-wood pipe which was wont to replace his clay when he was in a disputatious raher than a meditative mood--"you have erred perhaps in attempting to put colour and life into each of your statement instead of confining yourself to the task of placing upon record that severe reasoning from cause to effect which i really the only notable feature about the thing."

"It seems to me that I have done you full justice in the matte," I remarked with some coldness, for I was repelled by the egotism which I had more than once observed to be a strog factor in my friend's singular character.

"No, it is not selfishness or conceit," said he, answering, as was hi wont, my thoughts rather than my words. "If I claim full justice for my art, it is because it is an impersonal thin--a thing beyond myself. Crime is common. Logic is rare. Therefore it is upon the logic rather than upon the crime tat you should dwell. You have degraded what should have been a course of lectures into a series of tales."

It wasa cold morning of the early spring, and we sat after breakfast on either side of a cheery fire in the old room at Baer Street. "Not I."

"It is alf-past ten now."

" 'Why do you think that I lock this door?'

" 'I a sure that I do not know.'

" 'It is to keep people out who have no business there. Do you see?' He was still smilng in the most amiable manner.

" 'I am sure if I had known--'

" 'Well, then, you know now. And if you ever putyour foot over that threshold again'--here in an instant the smile hardened into a grin of rage, and he glared down t me with the face of a demon--'I'll throw you to the mastiff.'

"I was so terrified that I do not know what I did I suppose that I must have rushed past him into my room. I remember nothing until I found myself lying on my bed trmbling all over. Then I thought of you, Mr. Holmes. I could not live there longer without some advice. I was frighteed of the house, of the man, of the woman, of the servants, even of the child. They were all horrible to me. If I cold only bring you down all would be well. Of course I might have fled from the house, but my curiosity was almost asstrong as my fears. My mind was soon made up. I would send you a wire. I put on my hat and cloak, went down to the ofice, which is about half a mile from the house, and then returned, feeling very much easier. A horrible doubt came nto my mind as I approached the door lest the dog might be loose, but I remembered that Toller had drunk himself int a state of insensibility that evening, and I knew that he was the only one in the household who had any influence wth the savage creature, or who would venture to set him free. I slipped in in safety and lay awake half the night inmy joy at the thought of seeing you. I had no difficulty in getting leave to come into Winchester this morning, but  must be back before three o'clock, for Mr. and Mrs. Rucastle are going on a visit, and will be away all the evening so that I must look after the child. Now I have told you all my adventures, Mr. Holmes, and I should be very glad i you could tell me what it all means, and, above all, what I should do."

Holmes and I had listened spellbound to his extraordinary story. My friend rose now and paced up and down the room, his hands in his pockets, and an expresson of the most profound gravity upon his face.

"Is Toller still drunk?" he asked.

"Yes. I heard his wife tell rs. Rucastle that she could do nothing with him."

"That is well. And the Rucastles go out to-night?"

"Yes."
"Is there a cellar with a good strong lock?"

"Yes, the wine-cellar."

"You seem to me to have acted all throughthis matter like a very brave and sensible girl, Miss Hunter. Do you think that you could perform one more feat? I sould not ask it of you if I did not think you a quite exceptional woman."

"I will try. What is it?"

"We shall e at the Copper Beeches by seven o'clock, my friend and I. The Rucastles will be gone by that time, and Toller will,we hope, be incapable. There only remains Mrs. Toller, who might give the alarm. If you could send her into the cellr on some errand, and then turn the key upon her, you would facilitate matters immensely."

"I will do it."

"Exellent! We shall then look thoroughly into the affair. Of course there is only one feasible explanation. You have ben brought there to personate someone, and the real person is imprisoned in this chamber. That is obvious. As to who his prisoner is, I have no doubt that it is the daughter, Miss Alice Rucastle, if I remember right, who was said to ave gone to America. You were chosen, doubtless, as resembling her in height, figure, and the colour of your hair. Hrs had been cut off, very possibly in some illness through which she has passed, and so, of course, yours had to be acrificed also. By a curious chance you came upon her tresses. The man in the road was undoubtedly some friend of hes--possibly her fiance--and no doubt, as you wore the girl's dress and were so like her, he was convinced from your aughter, whenever he saw you, and afterwards from your gesture, that Miss Rucastle was perfectly happy, and that sheno longer desired his attentions. The dog is let loose at night to prevent him from endeavouring to communicate withher. So much is fairly clear. The most serious point in the case is the disposition of the child."

"What on earthhas that to do with it?" I ejaculated.

"My dear Watson, you as a medical man are continually gaining light as to he tendencies of a child by the study of the parents. Don't you see that the converse is equally valid. I have frequntly gained my first real insight into the character of parents by studying their children. This child's dispositionis abnormally cruel, merely for cruelty's sake, and whether he derives this from his smiling father, as I should susect, or from his mother, it bodes evil for the poor girl who is in their power."

"I am sure that you are right, M. Holmes," cried our client. "A thousand things come back to me which make me certain that you have hit it. Oh, let s lose not an instant in bringing help to this poor creature."

"We must be circumspect, for we are dealing with avery cunning man. We can do nothing until seven o'clock. At that hour we shall be with you, and it will not be long efore we solve the mystery."

We were as good as our word, for it was just seven when we reached the Copper Beeche, having put up our trap at a wayside public-house. The group of trees, with their dark leaves shining like burnishe metal in the light of the setting sun, were sufficient to mark the house even had Miss Hunter not been standing smiing on the door-step.

"Have you managed it?" asked Holmes.

A loud thudding noise came from somewhere downstair. "That is Mrs. Toller in the cellar," said she. "Her husband lies snoring on the kitchen rug. Here are his keys, whch are the duplicates of Mr. Rucastle's."

"You have done well indeed!" cried Holmes with enthusiasm. "Now lead th way, and we shall soon see the end of this black business."

We passed up the stair, unlocked the door, followed n down a passage, and found ourselves in front of the barricade which Miss Hunter had described. Holmes cut the cordand removed the transverse bar. Then he tried the various keys in the lock, but without success. No sound came from ithin, and at the silence Holmes' face clouded over.

"I trust that we are not too late," said he. "I think, Miss unter, that we had better go in without you. Now, Watson, put your shoulder to it, and we shall see whether we canno make our way in."

It was an old rickety door and gave at once before our united strength. Together we rushed int the room. It was empty. There was no furniture save a little pallet bed, a small table, and a basketful of linen. Te skylight above was open, and the prisoner gone.

"There has been some villainy here," said Holmes; "this beauty as guessed Miss Hunter's intentions and has carried his victim off."

"But how?"

"Through the skylight. We shal soon see how he managed it." He swung himself up onto the roof. "Ah, yes," he cried, "here's the end of a long ligh ladder against the eaves. That is how he did it."

"But it is impossible," said Miss Hunter; "the ladder was not here when the Rucastles went away."

"He has come back and done it. I tell you that he is a clever and dangerous mn. I should not be very much surprised if this were he whose step I hear now upon the stair. I think, Watson, that i would be as well for you to have your pistol ready."

The words were hardly out of his mouth before a man appeare at the door of the room, a very fat and burly man, with a heavy stick in his hand. Miss Hunter screamed and shrunk gainst the wall at the sight of him, but Sherlock Holmes sprang forward and confronted him.

"You villain!" said h, "where's your daughter?"

The fat man cast his eyes round, and then up at the open skylight.

"It is for me toask you that," he shrieked, "you thieves! Spies and thieves! I have caught you, have I? You are in my power. I'll seve you!" He turned and clattered down the stairs as hard as he could go.

"He's gone for the dog!" cried Miss Huntr.

"I have my revolver," said I.

"Better close the front door," cried Holmes, and we all rushed down the stair together. We had hardly reached the hall when we heard the baying of a hound, and then a scream of agony, with a horible worrying sound which it was dreadful to listen to. An elderly man with a red face and shaking limbs came staggring out at a side door.

"My God!" he cried. "Someone has loosed the dog. It's not been fed for two days. Quick, uick, or it'll be too late!"

Holmes and I rushed out and round the angle of the house, with Toller hurrying behin us. There was the huge famished brute, its black muzzle buried in Rucastle's throat, while he writhed and screamed pon the ground. Running up, I blew its brains out, and it fell over with its keen white teeth still meeting in the geat creases of his neck. With much labour we separated them and carried him, living but horribly mangled, into the huse. We laid him upon the drawing-room sofa, and having dispatched the sobered Toller to bear the news to his wife,  did what I could to relieve his pain. We were all assembled round him when the door opened, and a tall, gaunt womanentered the room.

"Mrs. Toller!" cried Miss Hunter.

"Yes, miss. Mr. Rucastle let me out when he came back befoe he went up to you. Ah, miss, it is a pity you didn't let me know what you were planning, for I would have told youthat your pains were wasted."

"Ha!" said Holmes, looking keenly at her. "It is clear that Mrs. Toller knows more bout this matter than anyone else."

"Yes, sir, I do, and I am ready enough to tell what I know."

"Then, pray, it down, and let us hear it for there are several points on which I must confess that I am still in the dark."

"Iwill soon make it clear to you," said she; "and I'd have done so before now if I could ha' got out from the cellar. f there's police-court business over this, you'll remember that I was the one that stood your friend, and that I wasMiss Alice's friend too.

"She was never happy at home, Miss Alice wasn't, from the time that her father married aain. She was slighted like and had no say in anything, but it never really became bad for her until after she met Mr Fowler at a friend's house. As well as I could learn, Miss Alice had rights of her own by will, but she was so quie and patient, she was, that she never said a word about them but just left everything in Mr. Rucastle's hands. He knw he was safe with her; but when there was a chance of a husband coming forward, who would ask for all that the law ould give him, then her father thought it time to put a stop on it. He wanted her to sign a paper, so that whether se married or not, he could use her money. When she wouldn't do it, he kept on worrying her until she got brain-fever and for six weeks was at death's door. Then she got better at last, all worn to a shadow, and with her beautiful har cut off; but that didn't make no change in her young man, and he stuck to her as true as man could be."

"Ah," sid Holmes, "I think that what you have been good enough to tell us makes the matter fairly clear, and that I can dedce all that remains. Mr. Rucastle then, I presume, took to this system of imprisonment?"

"Yes, sir."

"And brouht Miss Hunter down from London in order to get rid of the disagreeable persistence of Mr. Fowler."

"That was it,sir."

"But Mr. Fowler being a persevering man, as a good seaman should be, blockaded the house, and having met yo succeeded by certain arguments, metallic or otherwise, in convincing you that your interests were the same as his."

"Mr. Fowler was a very kind-spoken, free-handed gentleman," said Mrs. Toller serenely.

"And in this way he manged that your good man should have no want of drink, and that a ladder should be ready at the moment when your maste had gone out."

"You have it, sir, just as it happened."

"I am sure we owe you an apology, Mrs. Toller," said olmes, "for you have certainly cleared up everything which puzzled us. And here comes the country surgeon and Mrs. Rcastle, so I think, Watson, that we had best escort Miss Hunter back to Winchester, as it seems to me that our locusstandi now is rather a questionable one."

And thus was solved the mystery of the sinister house with the copper beches in front of the door. Mr. Rucastle survived, but was always a broken man, kept alive solely through the care o his devoted wife. They still live with their old servants, who probably know so much of Rucastle's past life that h finds it difficult to part from them. Mr. Fowler and Miss Rucastle were married, by special license, in Southamptonthe day after their flight, and he is now the holder of a government appointment in the island of Mauritius. As to Mss Violet Hunter, my friend Holmes, rather to my disappointment, manifested no further interest in her when once shehad ceased to be the centre of one of his problems, and she is now the head of a private school at Walsall, where I elieve that she has met with considerable success.

PREFAC


As things now stand, the course of instruction in American history in
our public schools embraces three distict treatments of the subject.
Three separate books are used. First, there is the primary book, which
is usually a ery condensed narrative with emphasis on biographies and
anecdotes. Second, there is the advanced text for the seveth or eighth
grade, generally speaking, an expansion of the elementary book by the
addition of forty or fifty thouand words. Finally, there is the high
school manual. This, too, ordinarily follows the beaten path, giving
fuller ccounts of the same events and characters. To put it bluntly, we
do not assume that our children obtain permanent pssessions from their
study of history in the lower grades. If mathematicians followed the
same method, high schooltexts on algebra and geometry would include the
multiplication table and fractions.

There is, of course, a readyanswer to the criticism advanced above. It
is that teachers have learned from bitter experience how little historytheir pupils retain as they pass along the regular route. No teacher of
history will deny this. Still it is a standng challenge to existing
methods of historical instruction. If the study of history cannot be
made truly progressie like the study of mathematics, science, and
languages, then the historians assume a grave responsibility in addin
their subject to the already overloaded curriculum. If the successive
historical texts are only enlarged editionsof the first text--more
facts, more dates, more words--then history deserves most of the sharp
criticism which it s receiving from teachers of science, civics, and
economics.

In this condition of affairs we find our justificaton for offering a
new high school text in American history. Our first contribution is one
of omission. The time-hoored stories of exploration and the
biographies of heroes are left out. We frankly hold that, if pupils know
littl or nothing about Columbus, Cortes, Magellan, or Captain John
Smith by the time they reach the high school, it is ueless to tell the
same stories for perhaps the fourth time. It is worse than useless. It
is an offense against theteachers of those subjects that are
demonstrated to be progressive in character.

In the next place we have omittd all descriptions of battles. Our
reasons for this are simple. The strategy of a campaign or of a single
battle i a highly technical, and usually a highly controversial, matter
about which experts differ widely. In the field of ilitary and naval
operations most writers and teachers of history are mere novices. To
dispose of Gettysburg or th Wilderness in ten lines or ten pages is
equally absurd to the serious student of military affairs. Any one who
copares the ordinary textbook account of a single Civil War campaign
with the account given by Ropes, for instance, wll ask for no further
comment. No youth called upon to serve our country in arms would think
of turning to a high chool manual for information about the art of
warfare. The dramatic scene or episode, so useful in arousing the
inerest of the immature pupil, seems out of place in a book that
deliberately appeals to boys and girls on the very treshold of life's
serious responsibilities.

It is not upon negative features, however, that we rest our case. Itis
rather upon constructive features.

_First._ We have written a topical, not a narrative, history. We have
trid to set forth the important aspects, problems, and movements of
each period, bringing in the narrative rather by wy of illustration.

_Second._ We have emphasized those historical topics which help to
explain how our nation hascome to be what it is to-day.

_Third._ We have dwelt fully upon the social and economic aspects of our
history, specially in relation to the politics of each period.

_Fourth._ We have treated the causes and results of wars, te problems
of financing and sustaining armed forces, rather than military strategy.
These are the subjects which blong to a history for civilians. These
are matters which civilians can understand--matters which they must
understnd, if they are to play well their part in war and peace.

_Fifth._ By omitting the period of exploration, we havebeen able to
enlarge the treatment of our own time. We have given special attention
to the history of those curren questions which must form the subject
matter of sound instruction in citizenship.

_Sixth._ We have borne in min that America, with all her unique
characteristics, is a part of a general civilization. Accordingly we
have givendiplomacy, foreign affairs, world relations, and the
reciprocal influences of nations their appropriate place.

_eventh._ We have deliberately aimed at standards of maturity. The
study of a mere narrative calls mainly for the us of the memory. We
have aimed to stimulate habits of analysis, comparison, association,
reflection, and generalizaion--habits calculated to enlarge as well as
inform the mind. We have been at great pains to make our text clear,
imple, and direct; but we have earnestly sought to stretch the
intellects of our readers--to put them upon their metle. Most of them
will receive the last of their formal instruction in the high school.
The world will soon expectmaturity from them. Their achievements will
depend upon the possession of other powers than memory alone. The
effetiveness of their citizenship in our republic will be measured by
the excellence of their judgment as well as the fllness of their
information.

     C.A.B.
     M.R.B.

     NEW YORK CITY,
     February 8, 1921.
