HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATS




PART I. THE COLONIAL PERIOD




CHAPTER I

THE GREAT MIGRATION TO AMERICA


The tide of migratin that set in toward the shores of North America
during the early years of the seventeenth century was but one phas in
the restless and eternal movement of mankind upon the surface of the
earth. The ancient Greeks flung out theircolonies in every direction,
westward as far as Gaul, across the Mediterranean, and eastward into
Asia Minor, perhps to the very confines of India. The Romans, supported
by their armies and their government, spread their dominionbeyond the
narrow lands of Italy until it stretched from the heather of Scotland to
the sands of Arabia. The Teutoic tribes, from their home beyond the
Danube and the Rhine, poured into the empire of the Caesars and made the
begnnings of modern Europe. Of this great sweep of races and empires
the settlement of America was merely a part. And t was, moreover, only
one aspect of the expansion which finally carried the peoples, the
institutions, and the trae of Europe to the very ends of the earth.

In one vital point, it must be noted, American colonization differed
rom that of the ancients. The Greeks usually carried with them
affection for the government they left behind and sared fire from the
altar of the parent city; but thousands of the immigrants who came to
America disliked the stateand disowned the church of the mother
country. They established compacts of government for themselves and set
up atars of their own. They sought not only new soil to till but also
political and religious liberty for themselves an their children.


THE AGENCIES OF AMERICAN COLONIZATION

It was no light matter for the English to cross threethousand miles of
water and found homes in the American wilderness at the opening of the
seventeenth century. Ship, tools, and supplies called for huge outlays
of money. Stores had to be furnished in quantities sufficient to sustin
the life of the settlers until they could gather harvests of their own.
Artisans and laborers of skill and indutry had to be induced to risk
the hazards of the new world. Soldiers were required for defense and
mariners for th exploration of inland waters. Leaders of good judgment,
adept in managing men, had to be discovered. Altogether suh an
enterprise demanded capital larger than the ordinary merchant or
gentleman could amass and involved risks mor imminent than he dared to
assume. Though in later days, after initial tests had been made, wealthy
proprietors wee able to establish colonies on their own account, it was
the corporation that furnished the capital and leadershipin the
beginning.

=The Trading Company.=--English pioneers in exploration found an
instrument for colonization n companies of merchant adventurers, which
had long been employed in carrying on commerce with foreign countries.
uch a corporation was composed of many persons of different ranks of
society--noblemen, merchants, and gentlemen--wo banded together for a
particular undertaking, each contributing a sum of money and sharing in
the profits of theventure. It was organized under royal authority; it
received its charter, its grant of land, and its trading privilges from
the king and carried on its operations under his supervision and
control. The charter named all the persos originally included in the
corporation and gave them certain powers in the management of its
affairs, including he right to admit new members. The company was in
fact a little government set up by the king. When the members of he
corporation remained in England, as in the case of the Virginia Company,
they operated through agents sent to te colony. When they came over the
seas themselves and settled in America, as in the case of Massachusetts,
they beame the direct government of the country they possessed. The
stockholders in that instance became the voters and th governor, the
chief magistrate.

[Illustration: JOHN WINTHROP, GOVERNOR OF THE MASSACHUSETTS BAY
COMPANY]

For of the thirteen colonies in America owed their origins to the
trading corporation. It was the London Company, creted by King James I,
in 1606, that laid during the following year the foundations of Virginia
at Jamestown. It wasunder the auspices of their West India Company,
chartered in 1621, that the Dutch planted the settlements of the Ne
Netherland in the valley of the Hudson. The founders of Massachusetts
were Puritan leaders and men of affairs who King Charles I incorporated
in 1629 under the title: "The governor and company of the Massachusetts
Bay in New Enland." In this case the law did but incorporate a group
drawn together by religious ties. "We must be knit togetheras one man,"
wrote John Winthrop, the first Puritan governor in America. Far to the
south, on the banks of the Delware River, a Swedish commercial company
in 1638 made the beginnings of a settlement, christened New Sweden; it
wa destined to pass under the rule of the Dutch, and finally under the
rule of William Penn as the proprietary colonyof Delaware.

In a certain sense, Georgia may be included among the "company
colonies." It was, however, originaly conceived by the moving spirit,
James Oglethorpe, as an asylum for poor men, especially those imprisoned
for deb. To realize this humane purpose, he secured from King George
II, in 1732, a royal charter uniting several gentleme, including
himself, into "one body politic and corporate," known as the "Trustees
for establishing the colony of eorgia in America." In the structure of
their organization and their methods of government, the trustees did not
dffer materially from the regular companies created for trade and
colonization. Though their purposes were benevolen, their transactions
had to be under the forms of law and according to the rules of business.

=The Religious Conregation.=--A second agency which figured largely in
the settlement of America was the religious brotherhood, or
cngregation, of men and women brought together in the bonds of a common
religious faith. By one of the strange fortues of history, this
institution, founded in the early days of Christianity, proved to be a
potent force in the oriin and growth of self-government in a land far
away from Galilee. "And the multitude of them that believed were of ne
heart and of one soul," we are told in the Acts describing the Church at
Jerusalem. "We are knit together as a ody in a most sacred covenant of
the Lord ... by virtue of which we hold ourselves strictly tied to all
care of eah other's good and of the whole," wrote John Robinson, a
leader among the Pilgrims who founded their tiny colony ofPlymouth in
1620. The Mayflower Compact, so famous in American history, was but a
written and signed agreement, inorporating the spirit of obedience to
the common good, which served as a guide to self-government until
Plymouth ws annexed to Massachusetts in 1691.

[Illustration: THE ORIGINAL GRANTS]

Three other colonies, all of which retined their identity until the eve
of the American Revolution, likewise sprang directly from the
congregations of te faithful: Rhode Island, Connecticut, and New
Hampshire, mainly offshoots from Massachusetts. They were founded by
small bodies of men and women, "united in solemn covenants with the
Lord," who planted their settlements in the widerness. Not until many a
year after Roger Williams and Anne Hutchinson conducted their followers
to the Narraganstt country was Rhode Island granted a charter of
incorporation (1663) by the crown. Not until long after the congreation
of Thomas Hooker from Newtown blazed the way into the Connecticut River
Valley did the king of England give onnecticut a charter of its own
(1662) and a place among the colonies. Half a century elapsed before the
towns lai out beyond the Merrimac River by emigrants from Massachusetts
were formed into the royal province of New Hampshirein 1679.

Even when Connecticut was chartered, the parchment and sealing wax of
the royal lawyers did but confirmrights and habits of self-government
and obedience to law previously established by the congregations. The
towns o Hartford, Windsor, and Wethersfield had long lived happily
under their "Fundamental Orders" drawn up by themselvesin 1639; so had
the settlers dwelt peacefully at New Haven under their "Fundamental
Articles" drafted in the same ear. The pioneers on the Connecticut
shore had no difficulty in agreeing that "the Scriptures do hold forth a
perfct rule for the direction and government of all men."

=The Proprietor.=--A third and very important colonial ageny was the
proprietor, or proprietary. As the name, associated with the word
"property," implies, the proprietor wa a person to whom the king
granted property in lands in North America to have, hold, use, and enjoy
for his own beefit and profit, with the right to hand the estate down
to his heirs in perpetual succession. The proprietor was a ich and
powerful person, prepared to furnish or secure the capital, collect the
ships, supply the stores, and asseble the settlers necessary to found
and sustain a plantation beyond the seas. Sometimes the proprietor
worked alon. Sometimes two or more were associated like partners in the
common undertaking.

Five colonies, Maryland, Pennsyvania, New Jersey, and the Carolinas,
owe their formal origins, though not always their first settlements, nor
in ost cases their prosperity, to the proprietary system. Maryland,
established in 1634 under a Catholic nobleman, Lor Baltimore, and
blessed with religious toleration by the act of 1649, flourished under
the mild rule of proprietor until it became a state in the American
union. New Jersey, beginning its career under two proprietors, Berkeley
ad Carteret, in 1664, passed under the direct government of the crown
in 1702. Pennsylvania was, in a very large meaure, the product of the
generous spirit and tireless labors of its first proprietor, the leader
of the Friends, Wiliam Penn, to whom it was granted in 1681 and in
whose family it remained until 1776. The two Carolinas were firstorganized as one colony in 1663 under the government and patronage of
eight proprietors, including Lord Clarendon; ut after more than half a
century both became royal provinces governed by the king.

[Illustration: WILLIAM PENN,PROPRIETOR OF PENNSYLVANIA]


THE COLONIAL PEOPLES

=The English.=--In leadership and origin the thirteen colones, except
New York and Delaware, were English. During the early days of all, save
these two, the main, if not thesole, current of immigration was from
England. The colonists came from every walk of life. They were men,
women, ad children of "all sorts and conditions." The major portion
were yeomen, or small land owners, farm laborers, and atisans. With
them were merchants and gentlemen who brought their stocks of goods or
their fortunes to the New Worl. Scholars came from Oxford and
Cambridge to preach the gospel or to teach. Now and then the son of an
English nobeman left his baronial hall behind and cast his lot with
America. The people represented every religious faith--memers of the
Established Church of England; Puritans who had labored to reform that
church; Separatists, Baptists, ad Friends, who had left it altogether;
and Catholics, who clung to the religion of their fathers.

New England wa almost purely English. During the years between 1629 and
1640, the period of arbitrary Stuart government, about twnty thousand
Puritans emigrated to America, settling in the colonies of the far
North. Although minor additions wee made from time to time, the greater
portion of the New England people sprang from this original stock.
Virginia,too, for a long time drew nearly all her immigrants from
England alone. Not until the eve of the Revolution did othr
nationalities, mainly the Scotch-Irish and Germans, rival the English in
numbers.

The populations of later Enlish colonies--the Carolinas, New York,
Pennsylvania, and Georgia--while receiving a steady stream of
immigration rom England, were constantly augmented by wanderers from
the older settlements. New York was invaded by Puritans frm New England
in such numbers as to cause the Anglican clergymen there to lament that
"free thinking spreads almos as fast as the Church." North Carolina was
first settled toward the northern border by immigrants from Virginia.
ome of the North Carolinians, particularly the Quakers, came all the
way from New England, tarrying in Virginia onl long enough to learn how
little they were wanted in that Anglican colony.

=The Scotch-Irish.=--Next to the Englsh in numbers and influence were
the Scotch-Irish, Presbyterians in belief, English in tongue. Both
religious and conomic reasons sent them across the sea. Their Scotch
ancestors, in the days of Cromwell, had settled in the northof Ireland
whence the native Irish had been driven by the conqueror's sword. There
the Scotch nourished for many yars enjoying in peace their own form of
religion and growing prosperous in the manufacture of fine linen and
woole cloth. Then the blow fell. Toward the end of the seventeenth
century their religious worship was put under the banand the export of
their cloth was forbidden by the English Parliament. Within two decades
twenty thousand Scotch-Iish left Ulster alone, for America; and all
during the eighteenth century the migration continued to be heavy.
Altough no exact record was kept, it is reckoned that the Scotch-Irish
and the Scotch who came directly from Scotland,composed one-sixth of
the entire American population on the eve of the Revolution.

[Illustration: SETTLEMENTS OFGERMAN AND SCOTCH-IRISH
IMMIGRANTS]

These newcomers in America made their homes chiefly in New Jersey,
Pennsylvnia, Maryland, Virginia, and the Carolinas. Coming late upon
the scene, they found much of the land immediately upo the seaboard
already taken up. For this reason most of them became frontier people
settling the interior and uplad regions. There they cleared the land,
laid out their small farms, and worked as "sturdy yeomen on the soil,"
hary, industrious, and independent in spirit, sharing neither the
luxuries of the rich planters nor the easy life of te leisurely
merchants. To their agriculture they added woolen and linen
manufactures, which, flourishing in the suple fingers of their tireless
women, made heavy inroads upon the trade of the English merchants in
the colonies. O their labors a poet has sung:

        "O, willing hands to toil;
    Strong natures tuned to the harvest-song ad bound to the kindly soil;
    Bold pioneers for the wilderness, defenders in the field."

=The Germans.=--Thirdamong the colonists in order of numerical
importance were the Germans. From the very beginning, they appeared in
clonial records. A number of the artisans and carpenters in the first
Jamestown colony were of German descent. PeterMinuit, the famous
governor of New Motherland, was a German from Wesel on the Rhine, and
Jacob Leisler, leader of  popular uprising against the provincial
administration of New York, was a German from Frankfort-on-Main. The
wholsale migration of Germans began with the founding of Pennsylvania.
Penn was diligent in searching for thrifty farmes to cultivate his
lands and he made a special effort to attract peasants from the Rhine
country. A great associaton, known as the Frankfort Company, bought
more than twenty thousand acres from him and in 1684 established a
centr at Germantown for the distribution of German immigrants. In old
New York, Rhinebeck-on-the-Hudson became a simila center for
distribution. All the way from Maine to Georgia inducements were offered
to the German farmers and in early every colony were to be found, in
time, German settlements. In fact the migration became so large that
Germa princes were frightened at the loss of so many subjects and
England was alarmed by the influx of foreigners into hr overseas
dominions. Yet nothing could stop the movement. By the end of the
colonial period, the number of German had risen to more than two
hundred thousand.

The majority of them were Protestants from the Rhine region, and Suth
Germany. Wars, religious controversies, oppression, and poverty drove
them forth to America. Though most of thm were farmers, there were also
among them skilled artisans who contributed to the rapid growth of
industries in Pnnsylvania. Their iron, glass, paper, and woolen mills,
dotted here and there among the thickly settled regions, aded to the
wealth and independence of the province.

[Illustration: _From an old print_

A GLIMPSE OF OLD GERMANOWN]

Unlike the Scotch-Irish, the Germans did not speak the language of the
original colonists or mingle freely ith them. They kept to themselves,
built their own schools, founded their own newspapers, and published
their own ooks. Their clannish habits often irritated their neighbors
and led to occasional agitations against "foreigners." owever, no
serious collisions seem to have occurred; and in the days of the
Revolution, German soldiers from Pennslvania fought in the patriot
armies side by side with soldiers from the English and Scotch-Irish
sections.

=Othr Nationalities.=--Though the English, the Scotch-Irish, and the
Germans made up the bulk of the colonial populatio, there were other
racial strains as well, varying in numerical importance but contributing
their share to colonia life.

From France came the Huguenots fleeing from the decree of the king which
inflicted terrible penalties upo Protestants.

From "Old Ireland" came thousands of native Irish, Celtic in race and
Catholic in religion. Like teir Scotch-Irish neighbors to the north,
they revered neither the government nor the church of England imposed
upo them by the sword. How many came we do not know, but shipping
records of the colonial period show that boatload afer boatload left
the southern and eastern shores of Ireland for the New World.
Undoubtedly thousands of their passngers were Irish of the native
stock. This surmise is well sustained by the constant appearance of
Celtic names inthe records of various colonies.

[Illustration:_From an old print_

OLD DUTCH FORT AND ENGLISH CHURCH NEAR ALBAY]

The Jews, then as ever engaged in their age-long battle for religious
and economic toleration, found in the Aerican colonies, not complete
liberty, but certainly more freedom than they enjoyed in England,
France, Spain, or ortugal. The English law did not actually recognize
their right to live in any of the dominions, but owing to the esy-going
habits of the Americans they were allowed to filter into the seaboard
towns. The treatment they received here varied. On one occasion the
mayor and council of New York forbade them to sell by retail and on
another prohiited the exercise of their religious worship. Newport,
Philadelphia, and Charleston were more hospitable, and therelarge
Jewish colonies, consisting principally of merchants and their families,
flourished in spite of nominal prohbitions of the law.

Though the small Swedish colony in Delaware was quickly submerged
beneath the tide of Englis migration, the Dutch in New York continued
to hold their own for more than a hundred years after the English
conqest in 1664. At the end of the colonial period over one-half of the
170,000 inhabitants of the province were descenants of the original
Dutch--still distinct enough to give a decided cast to the life and
manners of New York. Manyof them clung as tenaciously to their mother
tongue as they did to their capacious farmhouses or their Dutch ovens;
but they were slowly losing their identity as the English pressed in
beside them to farm and trade.

The meltingpot had begun its historic mission.


THE PROCESS OF COLONIZATION

Considered from one side, colonization, whatver the motives of the
emigrants, was an economic matter. It involved the use of capital to pay
for their passage,to sustain them on the voyage, and to start them on
the way of production. Under this stern economic necessity, Purtans,
Scotch-Irish, Germans, and all were alike laid.

=Immigrants Who Paid Their Own Way.=--Many of the immigrans to America
in colonial days were capitalists themselves, in a small or a large way,
and paid their own passage. hat proportion of the colonists were able
to finance their voyage across the sea is a matter of pure conjecture.
Udoubtedly a very considerable number could do so, for we can trace the
family fortunes of many early settlers. Henr Cabot Lodge is authority
for the statement that "the settlers of New England were drawn from the
country gentleme, small farmers, and yeomanry of the mother
country.... Many of the emigrants were men of wealth, as the old listsshow, and all of them, with few exceptions, were men of property and
good standing. They did not belong to the clases from which emigration
is usually supplied, for they all had a stake in the country they left
behind." Though itwould be interesting to know how accurate this
statement is or how applicable to the other colonies, no study has a
yet been made to gratify that interest. For the present it is an
unsolved problem just how many of the colonists ere able to bear the
cost of their own transfer to the New World.

=Indentured Servants.=--That at least tens of housands of immigrants
were unable to pay for their passage is established beyond the shadow of
a doubt by the shiping records that have come down to us. The great
barrier in the way of the poor who wanted to go to America was th cost
of the sea voyage. To overcome this difficulty a plan was worked out
whereby shipowners and other persons ofmeans furnished the passage
money to immigrants in return for their promise, or bond, to work for a
term of years o repay the sum advanced. This system was called
indentured servitude.

It is probable that the number of bond sevants exceeded the original
twenty thousand Puritans, the yeomen, the Virginia gentlemen, and the
Huguenots combind. All the way down the coast from Massachusetts to
Georgia were to be found in the fields, kitchens, and workshops men,
women, and children serving out terms of bondage generally ranging from
five to seven years. In the proprietry colonies the proportion of bond
servants was very high. The Baltimores, Penns, Carterets, and other
promoters axiously sought for workers of every nationality to till
their fields, for land without labor was worth no more thanland in the
moon. Hence the gates of the proprietary colonies were flung wide open.
Every inducement was offered t immigrants in the form of cheap land,
and special efforts were made to increase the population by importing
servats. In Pennsylvania, it was not uncommon to find a master with
fifty bond servants on his estate. It has been estimted that two-thirds
of all the immigrants into Pennsylvania between the opening of the
eighteenth century and the utbreak of the Revolution were in bondage.
In the other Middle colonies the number was doubtless not so large; butit formed a considerable part of the population.

The story of this traffic in white servants is one of the most sriking
things in the history of labor. Bondmen differed from the serfs of the
feudal age in that they were not boud to the soil but to the master.
They likewise differed from the negro slaves in that their servitude had
a time lmit. Still they were subject to many special disabilities. It
was, for instance, a common practice to impose on the penalties far
heavier than were imposed upon freemen for the same offense. A free
citizen of Pennsylvania who indlged in horse racing and gambling was
let off with a fine; a white servant guilty of the same unlawful conduct
waswhipped at the post and fined as well.

The ordinary life of the white servant was also severely restricted. A
bodman could not marry without his master's consent; nor engage in
trade; nor refuse work assigned to him. For an attmpt to escape or
indeed for any infraction of the law, the term of service was extended.
The condition of white bodmen in Virginia, according to Lodge, "was
little better than that of slaves. Loose indentures and harsh laws put
hem at the mercy of their masters." It would not be unfair to add that
such was their lot in all other colonies. Thir fate depended upon the
temper of their masters.

Cruel as was the system in many ways, it gave thousands of peple in the
Old World a chance to reach the New--an opportunity to wrestle with fate
for freedom and a home of thei own. When their weary years of servitude
were over, if they survived, they might obtain land of their own or
sette as free mechanics in the towns. For many a bondman the gamble
proved to be a losing venture because he found himslf unable to rise
out of the state of poverty and dependence into which his servitude
carried him. For thousands, n the contrary, bondage proved to be a real
avenue to freedom and prosperity. Some of the best citizens of Americahave the blood of indentured servants in their veins.

=The Transported--Involuntary Servitude.=--In their anxietyto secure
settlers, the companies and proprietors having colonies in America
either resorted to or connived at thepractice of kidnapping men, women,
and children from the streets of English cities. In 1680 it was
officially estiated that "ten thousand persons were spirited away" to
America. Many of the victims of the practice were young chilren, for
the traffic in them was highly profitable. Orphans and dependents were
sometimes disposed of in America b relatives unwilling to support them.
In a single year, 1627, about fifteen hundred children were shipped to
Virgiia.

In this gruesome business there lurked many tragedies, and very few
romances. Parents were separated from thir children and husbands from
their wives. Hundreds of skilled artisans--carpenters, smiths, and
weavers--utterly isappeared as if swallowed up by death. A few thus
dragged off to the New World to be sold into servitude for a ter of
five or seven years later became prosperous and returned home with
fortunes. In one case a young man who was frcibly carried over the sea
lived to make his way back to England and establish his claim to a
peerage.

Akin tothe kidnapped, at least in economic position, were convicts
deported to the colonies for life in lieu of fines and mprisonment. The
Americans protested vigorously but ineffectually against this practice.
Indeed, they exaggerated ts evils, for many of the "criminals" were
only mild offenders against unduly harsh and cruel laws. A peasant
caugt shooting a rabbit on a lord's estate or a luckless servant girl
who purloined a pocket handkerchief was branded a a criminal along with
sturdy thieves and incorrigible rascals. Other transported offenders
were "political criminls"; that is, persons who criticized or opposed
the government. This class included now Irish who revolted againstBritish rule in Ireland; now Cavaliers who championed the king against
the Puritan revolutionists; Puritans, in tur, dispatched after the
monarchy was restored; and Scotch and English subjects in general who
joined in political urisings against the king.

=The African Slaves.=--Rivaling in numbers, in the course of time, the
indentured servnts and whites carried to America against their will
were the African negroes brought to America and sold into slavry. When
this form of bondage was first introduced into Virginia in 1619, it was
looked upon as a temporary necessty to be discarded with the increase
of the white population. Moreover it does not appear that those planters
who irst bought negroes at the auction block intended to establish a
system of permanent bondage. Only by a slow proces did chattel slavery
take firm root and become recognized as the leading source of the labor
supply. In 1650, thiry years after the introduction of slavery, there
were only three hundred Africans in Virginia.

The great increas in later years was due in no small measure to the
inordinate zeal for profits that seized slave traders both in Ol and in
New England. Finding it relatively easy to secure negroes in Africa,
they crowded the Southern ports with heir vessels. The English Royal
African Company sent to America annually between 1713 and 1743 from five
to ten thusand slaves. The ship owners of New England were not far
behind their English brethren in pushing this extraordinay traffic.

As the proportion of the negroes to the free white population steadily
rose, and as whole sections wee overrun with slaves and slave traders,
the Southern colonies grew alarmed. In 1710, Virginia sought to curtail
te importation by placing a duty of $5 on each slave. This effort was
futile, for the royal governor promptly vetoedit. From time to time
similar bills were passed, only to meet with royal disapproval. South
Carolina, in 1760, abslutely prohibited importation; but the measure
was killed by the British crown. As late as 1772, Virginia, not dauned
by a century of rebuffs, sent to George III a petition in this vein:
"The importation of slaves into the colonis from the coast of Africa
hath long been considered as a trade of great inhumanity and under its
present encouragment, we have too much reason to fear, will endanger
the very existence of Your Majesty's American dominions.... Deply
impressed with these sentiments, we most humbly beseech Your Majesty to
remove all those restraints on Your Maesty's governors of this colony
which inhibit their assenting to such laws as might check so very
pernicious a comerce."

All such protests were without avail. The negro population grew by leaps
and bounds, until on the eve of he Revolution it amounted to more than
half a million. In five states--Maryland, Virginia, the two Carolinas,
and eorgia--the slaves nearly equalled or actually exceeded the whites
in number. In South Carolina they formed almost wo-thirds of the
population. Even in the Middle colonies of Delaware and Pennsylvania
about one-fifth of the inhabtants were from Africa. To the North, the
proportion of slaves steadily diminished although chattel servitude was
n the same legal footing as in the South. In New York approximately one
in six and in New England one in fifty werenegroes, including a few
freedmen.

The climate, the soil, the commerce, and the industry of the North were
all nfavorable to the growth of a servile population. Still, slavery,
though sectional, was a part of the national systm of economy. Northern
ships carried slaves to the Southern colonies and the produce of the
plantations to Europe."If the Northern states will consult their
interest, they will not oppose the increase in slaves which will
increae the commodities of which they will become the carriers," said
John Rutledge, of South Carolina, in the conventionwhich framed the
Constitution of the United States. "What enriches a part enriches the
whole and the states are th best judges of their particular interest,"
responded Oliver Ellsworth, the distinguished spokesman of Connecticut.

CHAPTER II

COLONIAL AGRICULTURE, INDUSTRY, AND COMMERCE

THE LAND AND THE WESTWARD MOVEMET


=The Significance of Land Tenure.=--The way in which land may be
acquired, held, divided among heirs, and boght and sold exercises a
deep influence on the life and culture of a people. The feudal and
aristocratic societiesof Europe were founded on a system of landlordism
which was characterized by two distinct features. In the first plce,
the land was nearly all held in great estates, each owned by a single
proprietor. In the second place, every etate was kept intact under the
law of primogeniture, which at the death of a lord transferred all his
landed propety to his eldest son. This prevented the subdivision of
estates and the growth of a large body of small farmers or reeholders
owning their own land. It made a form of tenantry or servitude
inevitable for the mass of those who labred on the land. It also
enabled the landlords to maintain themselves in power as a governing
class and kept the tnants and laborers subject to their economic and
political control. If land tenure was so significant in Europe, itwas
equally important in the development of America, where practically all
the first immigrants were forced by cirumstances to derive their
livelihood from the soil.

=Experiments in Common Tillage.=--In the New World, with itsbroad
extent of land awaiting the white man's plow, it was impossible to
introduce in its entirety and over the whle area the system of lords
and tenants that existed across the sea. So it happened that almost
every kind of expeiment in land tenure, from communism to feudalism,
was tried. In the early days of the Jamestown colony, the land, hough
owned by the London Company, was tilled in common by the settlers. No
man had a separate plot of his own. Th motto of the community was:
"Labor and share alike." All were supposed to work in the fields and
receive an equalshare of the produce. At Plymouth, the Pilgrims
attempted a similar experiment, laying out the fields in common and
distributing the joint produce of their labor with rough equality among
the workers.

In both colonies the commuistic experiments were failures. Angry at the
lazy men in Jamestown who idled their time away and yet expected reguar
meals, Captain John Smith issued a manifesto: "Everyone that gathereth
not every day as much as I do, the next ay shall be set beyond the
river and forever banished from the fort and live there or starve." Even
this terrible hreat did not bring a change in production. Not until
each man was given a plot of his own to till, not until each athered
the fruits of his own labor, did the colony prosper. In Plymouth, where
the communal experiment lasted forfive years, the results were similar
to those in Virginia, and the system was given up for one of separate
fields n which every person could "set corn for his own particular."
Some other New England towns, refusing to profit by te experience of
their Plymouth neighbor, also made excursions into common ownership and
labor, only to abandon theidea and go in for individual ownership of
the land. "By degrees it was seen that even the Lord's people could notcarry the complicated communist legislation into perfect and wholesome
practice."

=Feudal Elements in the Colonis--Quit Rents, Manors, and
Plantations.=--At the other end of the scale were the feudal elements of
land tenure fond in the proprietary colonies, in the seaboard regions
of the South, and to some extent in New York. The proprieto was in fact
a powerful feudal lord, owning land granted to him by royal charter. He
could retain any part of it fr his personal use or dispose of it all in
large or small lots. While he generally kept for himself an estate of
bronial proportions, it was impossible for him to manage directly any
considerable part of the land in his dominion.Consequently he either
sold it in parcels for lump sums or granted it to individuals on
condition that they make t him an annual payment in money, known as
"quit rent." In Maryland, the proprietor sometimes collected as high as
9000 (equal to about $500,000 to-day) in a single year from this
source. In Pennsylvania, the quit rents brought a andsome annual
tribute into the exchequer of the Penn family. In the royal provinces,
the king of England claimed ll revenues collected in this form from the
land, a sum amounting to $19,000 at the time of the Revolution. The qui
rent,--"really a feudal payment from freeholders,"--was thus a material
source of income for the crown as well asfor the proprietors. Wherever
it was laid, however, it proved to be a burden, a source of constant
irritation; andit became a formidable item in the long list of
grievances which led to the American Revolution.

Something stillmore like the feudal system of the Old World appeared in
the numerous manors or the huge landed estates granted by he crown, the
companies, or the proprietors. In the colony of Maryland alone there
were sixty manors of three thouand acres each, owned by wealthy men and
tilled by tenants holding small plots under certain restrictions of
tenur. In New York also there were many manors of wide extent, most of
which originated in the days of the Dutch West Inia Company, when
extensive concessions were made to patroons to induce them to bring over
settlers. The Van Rensseaer, the Van Cortlandt, and the Livingston
manors were so large and populous that each was entitled to send a
reprsentative to the provincial legislature. The tenants on the New
York manors were in somewhat the same position as srfs on old European
estates. They were bound to pay the owner a rent in money and kind; they
ground their grain athis mill; and they were subject to his judicial
power because he held court and meted out justice, in some instance
extending to capital punishment.

The manors of New York or Maryland were, however, of slight consequence
as copared with the vast plantations of the Southern seaboard--huge
estates, far wider in expanse than many a European brony and tilled by
slaves more servile than any feudal tenants. It must not be forgotten
that this system of land enure became the dominant feature of a large
section and gave a decided bent to the economic and political life ofAmerica.

[Illustration: SOUTHERN PLANTATION MANSION]

=The Small Freehold.=--In the upland regions of the South however, and
throughout most of the North, the drift was against all forms of
servitude and tenantry and in the drection of the freehold; that is,
the small farm owned outright and tilled by the possessor and his
family. This ws favored by natural circumstances and the spirit of the
immigrants. For one thing, the abundance of land and the sarcity of
labor made it impossible for the companies, the proprietors, or the
crown to develop over the whole contnent a network of vast estates. In
many sections, particularly in New England, the climate, the stony soil,
the hils, and the narrow valleys conspired to keep the farms within a
moderate compass. For another thing, the English, Sotch-Irish, and
German peasants, even if they had been tenants in the Old World, did not
propose to accept permanet dependency of any kind in the New. If they
could not get freeholds, they would not settle at all; thus they force
proprietors and companies to bid for their enterprise by selling land in
small lots. So it happened that the freeold of modest proportions
became the cherished unit of American farmers. The people who tilled the
farms were draw from every quarter of western Europe; but the freehold
system gave a uniform cast to their economic and social lif in America.

[Illustration: _From an old print_

A NEW ENGLAND FARMHOUSE]

=Social Effects of Land Tenure.=--and tenure and the process of western
settlement thus developed two distinct types of people engaged in the
same prsuit--agriculture. They had a common tie in that they both
cultivated the soil and possessed the local interest an independence
which arise from that occupation. Their methods and their culture,
however, differed widely.

The outhern planter, on his broad acres tilled by slaves, resembled the
English landlord on his estates more than he di the colonial farmer who
labored with his own hands in the fields and forests. He sold his rice
and tobacco in lare amounts directly to English factors, who took his
entire crop in exchange for goods and cash. His fine clothes,
ilverware, china, and cutlery he bought in English markets. Loving the
ripe old culture of the mother country, he oten sent his sons to Oxford
or Cambridge for their education. In short, he depended very largely for
his prosperit and his enjoyment of life upon close relations with the
Old World. He did not even need market towns in which to by native
goods, for they were made on his own plantation by his own artisans who
were usually gifted slaves.

Th economic condition of the small farmer was totally different. His
crops were not big enough to warrant direct connction with English
factors or the personal maintenance of a corps of artisans. He needed
local markets, and they srang up to meet the need. Smiths, hatters,
weavers, wagon-makers, and potters at neighboring towns supplied him
wih the rough products of their native skill. The finer goods, bought
by the rich planter in England, the small farme ordinarily could not
buy. His wants were restricted to staples like tea and sugar, and
between him and the Europen market stood the merchant. His community
was therefore more self-sufficient than the seaboard line of great
planations. It was more isolated, more provincial, more independent,
more American. The planter faced the Old East. Thefarmer faced the New
West.

=The Westward Movement.=--Yeoman and planter nevertheless were alike in
one respect.Their land hunger was never appeased. Each had the eye of
an expert for new and fertile soil; and so, north and souh, as soon as
a foothold was secured on the Atlantic coast, the current of migration
set in westward, creeping thrugh forests, across rivers, and over
mountains. Many of the later immigrants, in their search for cheap
lands, wer compelled to go to the border; but in a large part the path
breakers to the West were native Americans of the secod and third
generations. Explorers, fired by curiosity and the lure of the
mysterious unknown, and hunters, fur trders, and squatters, following
their own sweet wills, blazed the trail, opening paths and sending back
stories of he new regions they traversed. Then came the regular
settlers with lawful titles to the lands they had purchased, smetimes
singly and sometimes in companies.

In Massachusetts, the westward movement is recorded in the founding o
Springfield in 1636 and Great Barrington in 1725. By the opening of the
eighteenth century the pioneers of Connecicut had pushed north and west
until their outpost towns adjoined the Hudson Valley settlements. In New
York, the nland movement was directed by the Hudson River to Albany,
and from that old Dutch center it radiated in every diretion,
particularly westward through the Mohawk Valley. New Jersey was early
filled to its borders, the beginnings f the present city of New
Brunswick being made in 1681 and those of Trenton in 1685. In
Pennsylvania, as in New Yok, the waterways determined the main lines of
advance. Pioneers, pushing up through the valley of the Schuylkill,
pread over the fertile lands of Berks and Lancaster counties, laying
out Reading in 1748. Another current of migraton was directed by the
Susquehanna, and, in 1726, the first farmhouse was built on the bank
where Harrisburg was lter founded. Along the southern tier of counties
a thin line of settlements stretched westward to Pittsburgh, reachng
the upper waters of the Ohio while the colony was still under the Penn
family.

In the South the westward marh was equally swift. The seaboard was
quickly occupied by large planters and their slaves engaged in the
cultivatin of tobacco and rice. The Piedmont Plateau, lying back from
the coast all the way from Maryland to Georgia, was fe by two streams
of migration, one westward from the sea and the other southward from the
other colonies--Germans fom Pennsylvania and Scotch-Irish furnishing
the main supply. "By 1770, tide-water Virginia was full to overflowingand the 'back country' of the Blue Ridge and the Shenandoah was fully
occupied. Even the mountain valleys ... were laimed by sturdy pioneers.
Before the Declaration of Independence, the oncoming tide of
home-seekers had reached te crest of the Alleghanies."

[Illustration: DISTRIBUTION OF POPULATION, 1790]

Beyond the mountains pioneers ha already ventured, harbingers of an
invasion that was about to break in upon Kentucky and Tennessee. As
early as 169 that mighty Nimrod, Daniel Boone, curious to hunt
buffaloes, of which he had heard weird reports, passed throughthe
Cumberland Gap and brought back news of a wonderful country awaiting the
plow. A hint was sufficient. Singly, n pairs, and in groups, settlers
followed the trail he had blazed. A great land corporation, the
Transylvania Compny, emulating the merchant adventurers of earlier
times, secured a huge grant of territory and sought profits in qut
rents from lands sold to farmers. By the outbreak of the Revolution
there were several hundred people in the Kenucky region. Like the older
colonists, they did not relish quit rents, and their opposition wrecked
the Transylvana Company. They even carried their protests into the
Continental Congress in 1776, for by that time they were our "mbryo
fourteenth colony."


INDUSTRIAL AND COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT

Though the labor of the colonists was mainl spent in farming, there was
a steady growth in industrial and commercial pursuits. Most of the
staple industries f to-day, not omitting iron and textiles, have their
beginnings in colonial times. Manufacturing and trade soon gav rise to
towns which enjoyed an importance all out of proportion to their
numbers. The great centers of commerce ad finance on the seaboard
originated in the days when the king of England was "lord of these
dominions."

[Illusration: DOMESTIC INDUSTRY: DIPPING TALLOW CANDLES]

=Textile Manufacture as a Domestic Industry.=--Colonial women,in
addition to sharing every hardship of pioneering, often the heavy labor
of the open field, developed in the couse of time a national industry
which was almost exclusively their own. Wool and flax were raised in
abundance in te North and South. "Every farm house," says Coman, the
economic historian, "was a workshop where the women spun andwove the
serges, kerseys, and linsey-woolseys which served for the common wear."
By the close of the seventeenth cntury, New England manufactured cloth
in sufficient quantities to export it to the Southern colonies and to
the Wet Indies. As the industry developed, mills were erected for the
more difficult process of dyeing, weaving, and fullng, but carding and
spinning continued to be done in the home. The Dutch of New Netherland,
the Swedes of Delaware and the Scotch-Irish of the interior "were not
one whit behind their Yankee neighbors."

The importance of this nterprise to British economic life can hardly be
overestimated. For many a century the English had employed their fne
woolen cloth as the chief staple in a lucrative foreign trade, and the
government had come to look upon it as a object of special interest and
protection. When the colonies were established, both merchants and
statesmen naturlly expected to maintain a monopoly of increasing value;
but before long the Americans, instead of buying cloth, esecially of
the coarser varieties, were making it to sell. In the place of
customers, here were rivals. In the plac of helpless reliance upon
English markets, here was the germ of economic independence.

If British merchants hadnot discovered it in the ordinary course of
trade, observant officers in the provinces would have conveyed the news
to them. Even in the early years of the eighteenth century the royal
governor of New York wrote of the industriousAmericans to his home
government: "The consequence will be that if they can clothe themselves
once, not only comfotably, but handsomely too, without the help of
England, they who already are not very fond of submitting to governmnt
will soon think of putting in execution designs they have long harboured
in their breasts. This will not seem srange when you consider what sort
of people this country is inhabited by."

=The Iron Industry.=--Almost equally idespread was the art of iron
working--one of the earliest and most picturesque of colonial
industries. Lynn, Masschusetts, had a forge and skilled artisans within
fifteen years after the founding of Boston. The smelting of iron egan
at New London and New Haven about 1658; in Litchfield county,
Connecticut, a few years later; at Great Barrinton, Massachusetts, in
1731; and near by at Lenox some thirty years after that. New Jersey had
iron works at Shrewbury within ten years after the founding of the
colony in 1665. Iron forges appeared in the valleys of the Delawareand
the Susquehanna early in the following century, and iron masters then
laid the foundations of fortunes in a reion destined to become one of
the great iron centers of the world. Virginia began iron working in the
year that sa the introduction of slavery. Although the industry soon
lapsed, it was renewed and flourished in the eighteenth cetury.
Governor Spotswood was called the "Tubal Cain" of the Old Dominion
because he placed the industry on a firm oundation. Indeed it seems
that every colony, except Georgia, had its iron foundry. Nails, wire,
metallic ware, chins, anchors, bar and pig iron were made in large
quantities; and Great Britain, by an act in 1750, encouraged thecolonists to export rough iron to the British Islands.

=Shipbuilding.=--Of all the specialized industries in the olonies,
shipbuilding was the most important. The abundance of fir for masts, oak
for timbers and boards, pitch fo tar and turpentine, and hemp for rope
made the way of the shipbuilder easy. Early in the seventeenth century a
shp was built at New Amsterdam, and by the middle of that century
shipyards were scattered along the New England coas at Newburyport,
Salem, New Bedford, Newport, Providence, New London, and New Haven.
Yards at Albany and Poughkeepie in New York built ships for the trade
of that colony with England and the Indies. Wilmington and Philadelphia
son entered the race and outdistanced New York, though unable to equal
the pace set by New England. While Maryland, irginia, and South
Carolina also built ships, Southern interest was mainly confined to the
lucrative business of poducing ship materials: fir, cedar, hemp, and
tar.

=Fishing.=--The greatest single economic resource of New Englnd outside
of agriculture was the fisheries. This industry, started by hardy
sailors from Europe, long before the anding of the Pilgrims, flourished
under the indomitable seamanship of the Puritans, who labored with the
net and he harpoon in almost every quarter of the Atlantic. "Look,"
exclaimed Edmund Burke, in the House of Commons, "at th manner in
which the people of New England have of late carried on the whale
fishery. Whilst we follow them among he tumbling mountains of ice and
behold them penetrating into the deepest frozen recesses of Hudson's Bay
and Davi's Straits, while we are looking for them beneath the arctic
circle, we hear that they have pierced into the opposie region of polar
cold, that they are at the antipodes and engaged under the frozen
serpent of the south.... Nor i the equinoctial heat more discouraging
to them than the accumulated winter of both poles. We know that, whilst
soe of them draw the line and strike the harpoon on the coast of
Africa, others run the longitude and pursue their giantic game along
the coast of Brazil. No sea but what is vexed by their fisheries. No
climate that is not witness o their toils. Neither the perseverance of
Holland nor the activity of France nor the dexterous and firm sagacity
f English enterprise ever carried this most perilous mode of hard
industry to the extent to which it has been pushe by this recent
people."

The influence of the business was widespread. A large and lucrative
European trade wasbuilt upon it. The better quality of the fish caught
for food was sold in the markets of Spain, Portugal, and Italy or
exchanged for salt, lemons, and raisins for the American market. The
lower grades of fish were carried to the est Indies for slave
consumption, and in part traded for sugar and molasses, which furnished
the raw materials forthe thriving rum industry of New England. These
activities, in turn, stimulated shipbuilding, steadily enlarging th
demand for fishing and merchant craft of every kind and thus keeping the
shipwrights, calkers, rope makers, and oher artisans of the seaport
towns rushed with work. They also increased trade with the mother
country for, out of he cash collected in the fish markets of Europe and
the West Indies, the colonists paid for English manufactures. S an
ever-widening circle of American enterprise centered around this single
industry, the nursery of seamanship an the maritime spirit.

=Oceanic Commerce and American Merchants.=--All through the eighteenth
century, the commere of the American colonies spread in every direction
until it rivaled in the number of people employed, the capitalengaged,
and the profits gleaned, the commerce of European nations. A modern
historian has said: "The enterprisingmerchants of New England developed
a network of trade routes that covered well-nigh half the world." This
commerce destined to be of such significance in the conflict with the
mother country, presented, broadly speaking, two aspets.

On the one side, it involved the export of raw materials and
agricultural produce. The Southern colonies prouced for shipping,
tobacco, rice, tar, pitch, and pine; the Middle colonies, grain, flour,
furs, lumber, and salt ork; New England, fish, flour, rum, furs, shoes,
and small articles of manufacture. The variety of products was in act
astounding. A sarcastic writer, while sneering at the idea of an
American union, once remarked of colonial trae: "What sort of dish will
you make? New England will throw in fish and onions. The middle states,
flax-seed and four. Maryland and Virginia will add tobacco. North
Carolina, pitch, tar, and turpentine. South Carolina, rice and idigo,
and Georgia will sprinkle the whole composition with sawdust. Such an
absurd jumble will you make if you attmpt to form a union among such
discordant materials as the thirteen British provinces."

On the other side, Amerian commerce involved the import trade,
consisting principally of English and continental manufactures, tea, and
"Idia goods." Sugar and molasses, brought from the West Indies,
supplied the flourishing distilleries of Massachusett, Rhode Island,
and Connecticut. The carriage of slaves from Africa to the Southern
colonies engaged hundreds of Nw England's sailors and thousands of
pounds of her capital.

The disposition of imported goods in the colonies, tough in part
controlled by English factors located in America, employed also a large
and important body of America merchants like the Willings and Morrises
of Philadelphia; the Amorys, Hancocks, and Faneuils of Boston; and the
Lvingstons and Lows of New York. In their zeal and enterprise, they
were worthy rivals of their English competitors,so celebrated for
world-wide commercial operations. Though fully aware of the advantages
they enjoyed in British mrkets and under the protection of the British
navy, the American merchants were high-spirited and mettlesome, readyto
contend with royal officers in order to shield American interests
against outside interference.

[Illustratio: THE DUTCH WEST INDIA WAREHOUSE IN NEW AMSTERDAM
(NEW YORK CITY)]

Measured against the immense business of moden times, colonial commerce
seems perhaps trivial. That, however, is not the test of its
significance. It must be cnsidered in relation to the growth of English
colonial trade in its entirety--a relation which can be shown by a fe
startling figures. The whole export trade of England, including that to
the colonies, was, in 1704, $6,509,000. O the eve of the American
Revolution, namely, in 1772, English exports to the American colonies
alone amounted to $,024,000; in other words, almost as much as the
whole foreign business of England two generations before. At the fist
date, colonial trade was but one-twelfth of the English export business;
at the second date, it was considerabl more than one-third. In 1704,
Pennsylvania bought in English markets goods to the value of $11,459; in
1772 the prchases of the same colony amounted to $507,909. In short,
Pennsylvania imports increased fifty times within sixty-ight years,
amounting in 1772 to almost the entire export trade of England to the
colonies at the opening of the cntury. The American colonies were
indeed a great source of wealth to English merchants.

=Intercolonial Commerce.--Although the bad roads of colonial times made
overland transportation difficult and costly, the many rivers and
arbors along the coast favored a lively water-borne trade among the
colonies. The Connecticut, Hudson, Delaware, an Susquehanna rivers in
the North and the many smaller rivers in the South made it possible for
goods to be broughtfrom, and carried to, the interior regions in little
sailing vessels with comparative ease. Sloops laden with manufctures,
domestic and foreign, collected at some city like Providence, New York,
or Philadelphia, skirted the coast, visited small ports, and sailed up
the navigable rivers to trade with local merchants who had for exchange
the rw materials which they had gathered in from neighboring farms.
Larger ships carried the grain, live stock, cloth, ad hardware of New
England to the Southern colonies, where they were traded for tobacco,
leather, tar, and ship timer. From the harbors along the Connecticut
shores there were frequent sailings down through Long Island Sound to
Mryland, Virginia, and the distant Carolinas.

=Growth of Towns.=--In connection with this thriving trade and indusry
there grew up along the coast a number of prosperous commercial centers
which were soon reckoned among the firs commercial towns of the whole
British empire, comparing favorably in numbers and wealth with such
ports as Liverpol and Bristol. The statistical records of that time are
mainly guesses; but we know that Philadelphia stood first n size among
these towns. Serving as the port of entry for Pennsylvania, Delaware,
and western Jersey, it had draw within its borders, just before the
Revolution, about 25,000 inhabitants. Boston was second in rank, with
somewha more than 20,000 people. New York, the "commercial capital of
Connecticut and old East Jersey," was slightly smallr than Boston, but
growing at a steady rate. The fourth town in size was Charleston, South
Carolina, with about 10000 inhabitants. Newport in Rhode Island, a
center of rum manufacture and shipping, stood fifth, with a populationof about 7000. Baltimore and Norfolk were counted as "considerable
towns." In the interior, Hartford in Connecticut Lancaster and York in
Pennsylvania, and Albany in New York, with growing populations and
increasing trade, gave pophecy of an urban America away from the
seaboard. The other towns were straggling villages. Williamsburg,
Virgini, for example, had about two hundred houses, in which dwelt a
dozen families of the gentry and a few score of trademen. Inland county
seats often consisted of nothing more than a log courthouse, a prison,
and one wretched inn to ouse judges, lawyers, and litigants during the
sessions of the court.

The leading towns exercised an influence o colonial opinion all out of
proportion to their population. They were the centers of wealth, for one
thing; of th press and political activity, for another. Merchants and
artisans could readily take concerted action on public qustions arising
from their commercial operations. The towns were also centers for news,
gossip, religious controvery, and political discussion. In the market
places the farmers from the countryside learned of British policies andlaws, and so, mingling with the townsmen, were drawn into the main
currents of opinion which set in toward colonialnationalism and
independence.

Chapter III

SOCIAL AND POLITICAL PROGRESS


Colonial life, crowded as it was wih hard and unremitting toil, left
scant leisure for the cultivation of the arts and sciences. There was
little mony in private purses or public treasuries to be dedicated to
schools, libraries, and museums. Few there were with tie to read long
and widely, and fewer still who could devote their lives to things that
delight the eye and the min. And yet, poor and meager as the
intellectual life of the colonists may seem by way of comparison, heroic
effortswere made in every community to lift the people above the plane
of mere existence. After the first clearings were oened in the forests
those efforts were redoubled, and with lengthening years told upon the
thought and spirit of te land. The appearance, during the struggle with
England, of an extraordinary group of leaders familiar with histor,
political philosophy, and the arts of war, government, and diplomacy
itself bore eloquent testimony to the high uality of the American
intellect. No one, not even the most critical, can run through the
writings of distinguishe Americans scattered from Massachusetts to
Georgia--the Adamses, Ellsworth, the Morrises, the Livingstons,
Hamilto, Franklin, Washington, Madison, Marshall, Henry, the Randolphs,
and the Pinckneys--without coming to the conclusio that there was
something in American colonial life which fostered minds of depth and
power. Women surmounted evengreater difficulties than the men in the
process of self-education, and their keen interest in public issues is
evdent in many a record like the _Letters_ of Mrs. John Adams to her
husband during the Revolution; the writings of Ms. Mercy Otis Warren,
the sister of James Otis, who measured her pen with the British
propagandists; and the patrit newspapers founded and managed by women.


THE LEADERSHIP OF THE CHURCHES

In the intellectual life of Americ, the churches assumed a role of high
importance. There were abundant reasons for this. In many of the
colonies--Mryland, Pennsylvania, and New England--the religious impulse
had been one of the impelling motives in stimulating imigration. In all
the colonies, the clergy, at least in the beginning, formed the only
class with any leisure to dvote to matters of the spirit. They preached
on Sundays and taught school on week days. They led in the discussion f
local problems and in the formation of political opinion, so much of
which was concerned with the relation betwen church and state. They
wrote books and pamphlets. They filled most of the chairs in the
colleges; under clericalguidance, intellectual and spiritual, the
Americans received their formal education. In several of the provinces
te Anglican Church was established by law. In New England the Puritans
were supreme, notwithstanding the efforts of he crown to overbear their
authority. In the Middle colonies, particularly, the multiplication of
sects made the dminance of any single denomination impossible; and in
all of them there was a growing diversity of faith, which proised in
time a separation of church and state and freedom of opinion.

=The Church of England.=--Virginia was thestronghold of the English
system of church and state. The Anglican faith and worship were
prescribed by law, sustaned by taxes imposed on all, and favored by the
governor, the provincial councilors, and the richest planters. "The
Established Church," says Lodge, "was one of the appendages of the
Virginia aristocracy. They controlled the vestres and the ministers,
and the parish church stood not infrequently on the estate of the
planter who built and manaed it." As in England, Catholics and
Protestant Dissenters were at first laid under heavy disabilities. Only
slowl and on sufferance were they admitted to the province; but when
once they were even covertly tolerated, they presse steadily in, until,
by the Revolution, they outnumbered the adherents of the established
order.

The Church wasalso sanctioned by law and supported by taxes in the
Carolinas after 1704, and in Georgia after that colony passed irectly
under the crown in 1754--this in spite of the fact that the majority of
the inhabitants were Dissenters. Aainst the protests of the Catholics
it was likewise established in Maryland. In New York, too,
notwithstanding theresistance of the Dutch, the Established Church was
fostered by the provincial officials, and the Anglicans, embracng about
one-fifteenth of the population, exerted an influence all out of
proportion to their numbers.

Many facors helped to enhance the power of the English Church in the
colonies. It was supported by the British government ad the official
class sent out to the provinces. Its bishops and archbishops in England
were appointed by the king,and its faith and service were set forth by
acts of Parliament. Having its seat of power in the English monarchy, i
could hold its clergy and missionaries loyal to the crown and so
counteract to some extent the independent spiritthat was growing up in
America. The Church, always a strong bulwark of the state, therefore had
a political role t play here as in England. Able bishops and far-seeing
leaders firmly grasped this fact about the middle of the eigheenth
century and redoubled their efforts to augment the influence of the
Church in provincial affairs. Unhappily or their plans they failed to
calculate in advance the effect of their methods upon dissenting
Protestants, who stll cherished memories of bitter religious conflicts
in the mother country.

=Puritanism in New England.=--If the stablished faith made for imperial
unity, the same could not be said of Puritanism. The Plymouth Pilgrims
had castoff all allegiance to the Anglican Church and established a
separate and independent congregation before they came o America. The
Puritans, essaying at first the task of reformers within the Church,
soon after their arrival in Masachusetts, likewise flung off their yoke
of union with the Anglicans. In each town a separate congregation was
oranized, the male members choosing the pastor, the teachers, and the
other officers. They also composed the voters i the town meeting, where
secular matters were determined. The union of church and government was
thus complete, an uniformity of faith and life prescribed by law and
enforced by civil authorities; but this worked for local autonoy
instead of imperial unity.

The clergy became a powerful class, dominant through their learning and
their fearul denunciations of the faithless. They wrote the books for
the people to read--the famous Cotton Mather having thre hundred and
eighty-three books and pamphlets to his credit. In cooperation with the
civil officers they enforceda strict observance of the Puritan
Sabbath--a day of rest that began at six o'clock on Saturday evening and
lasteduntil sunset on Sunday. All work, all trading, all amusement, and
all worldly conversation were absolutely prohibitd during those hours.
A thoughtless maid servant who for some earthly reason smiled in church
was in danger of beig banished as a vagabond. Robert Pike, a devout
Puritan, thinking the sun had gone to rest, ventured forth on horseack
one Sunday evening and was luckless enough to have a ray of light strike
him through a rift in the clouds. Thenext day he was brought into court
and fined for "his ungodly conduct." With persons accused of witchcraft
the Purtans were still more ruthless. When a mania of persecution swept
over Massachusetts in 1692, eighteen people were hnged, one was pressed
to death, many suffered imprisonment, and two died in jail.

Just about this time, however,there came a break in the uniformity of
Puritan rule. The crown and church in England had long looked upon it
withdisfavor, and in 1684 King Charles II annulled the old charter of
the Massachusetts Bay Company. A new document issed seven years later
wrested from the Puritans of the colony the right to elect their own
governor and reserved th power of appointment to the king. It also
abolished the rule limiting the suffrage to church members, substituting
for it a simple property qualification. Thus a royal governor and an
official family, certain to be Episcopalian i faith and monarchist in
sympathies, were forced upon Massachusetts; and members of all religious
denominations, i they had the required amount of property, were
permitted to take part in elections. By this act in the name of the
crown, the Puritan monopoly was broken down in Massachusetts, and that
province was brought into line with Connectcut, Rhode Island, and New
Hampshire, where property, not religious faith, was the test for the
suffrage.

=Growh of Religious Toleration.=--Though neither the Anglicans of
Virginia nor the Puritans of Massachusetts believed intoleration for
other denominations, that principle was strictly applied in Rhode
Island. There, under the leadershp of Roger Williams, liberty in
matters of conscience was established in the beginning. Maryland, by
granting in 149 freedom to those who professed to believe in Jesus
Christ, opened its gates to all Christians; and Pennsylvania,true to
the tenets of the Friends, gave freedom of conscience to those "who
confess and acknowledge the one Almighy and Eternal God to be the
creator, upholder, and ruler of the World." By one circumstance or
another, the Middlecolonies were thus early characterized by diversity
rather than uniformity of opinion. Dutch Protestants, Huguenots
Quakers, Baptists, Presbyterians, New Lights, Moravians, Lutherans,
Catholics, and other denominations became toostrongly intrenched and
too widely scattered to permit any one of them to rule, if it had
desired to do so. There ere communities and indeed whole sections where
one or another church prevailed, but in no colony was a legislature
steadily controlled by a single group. Toleration encouraged diversity,
and diversity, in turn, worked for greatertoleration.

The government and faith of the dissenting denominations conspired with
economic and political tendecies to draw America away from the English
state. Presbyterians, Quakers, Baptists, and Puritans had no hierarchy
f bishops and archbishops to bind them to the seat of power in London.
Neither did they look to that metropolis forguidance in interpreting
articles of faith. Local self-government in matters ecclesiastical
helped to train them fr local self-government in matters political. The
spirit of independence which led Dissenters to revolt in the Old orld,
nourished as it was amid favorable circumstances in the New World, made
them all the more zealous in the defnse of every right against
authority imposed from without.


SCHOOLS AND COLLEGES

=Religion and Local Schools=--One of the first cares of each Protestant
denomination was the education of the children in the faith. In this
ork the Bible became the center of interest. The English version was
indeed the one book of the people. Farmers, shpkeepers, and artisans,
whose life had once been bounded by the daily routine of labor, found in
the Scriptures no only an inspiration to religious conduct, but also a
book of romance, travel, and history. "Legend and annal," say John
Richard Green, "war-song and psalm, state-roll and biography, the mighty
voices of prophets, the parables ofEvangelists, stories of mission
journeys, of perils by sea and among the heathen, philosophic arguments,
apocalyptc visions, all were flung broadcast over minds unoccupied for
the most part by any rival learning.... As a mere litrary monument, the
English version of the Bible remains the noblest example of the English
tongue." It was the Kin James version just from the press that the
Pilgrims brought across the sea with them.

For the authority of the stablished Church was substituted the
authority of the Scriptures. The Puritans devised a catechism based upon
ther interpretation of the Bible, and, very soon after their arrival in
America, they ordered all parents and masters f servants to be diligent
in seeing that their children and wards were taught to read religious
works and give ansers to the religious questions. Massachusetts was
scarcely twenty years old before education of this character wasdeclared to be compulsory, and provision was made for public schools
where those not taught at home could receive istruction in reading and
writing.
