Outside of New England the idea of compulsory education was not regarded
with the same favor; but the whole land was nevertheless dotted with
little schools kept by "dames, itinerant teacers, or local parsons."
Whether we turn to the life of Franklin in the North or Washington in
the South, we read o tiny schoolhouses, where boys, and sometimes
girls, were taught to read and write. Where there were no schools,
fthers and mothers of the better kind gave their children the rudiments
of learning. Though illiteracy was widesprea, there is evidence to show
that the diffusion of knowledge among the masses was making steady
progress all throug the eighteenth century.

=Religion and Higher Learning.=--Religious motives entered into the
establishment of coleges as well as local schools. Harvard, founded in
1636, and Yale, opened in 1718, were intended primarily to trai
"learned and godly ministers" for the Puritan churches of New England.
To the far North, Dartmouth, chartered in 769, was designed first as a
mission to the Indians and then as a college for the sons of New England
farmers prepring to preach, teach, or practice law. The College of New
Jersey, organized in 1746 and removed to Princeton eleve years later,
was sustained by the Presbyterians. Two colleges looked to the
Established Church as their source ofinspiration and support: William
and Mary, founded in Virginia in 1693, and King's College, now Columbia
Universit, chartered by King George II in 1754, on an appeal from the
New York Anglicans, alarmed at the growth of religiousdissent and the
"republican tendencies" of the age. Two colleges revealed a drift away
from sectarianism. Brown, etablished in Rhode Island in 1764, and the
Philadelphia Academy, forerunner of the University of Pennsylvania,
orgnized by Benjamin Franklin, reflected the spirit of toleration by
giving representation on the board of trustees toseveral religious
sects. It was Franklin's idea that his college should prepare young men
to serve in public offic as leaders of the people and ornaments to
their country.

=Self-education in America.=--Important as were these nstitutions of
learning, higher education was by no means confined within their walls.
Many well-to-do families set their sons to Oxford or Cambridge in
England. Private tutoring in the home was common. In still more families
thre were intelligent children who grew up in the great colonial school
of adversity and who trained themselves until in every contest of mind
and wit, they could vie with the sons of Harvard or William and Mary or
any other colleg. Such, for example, was Benjamin Franklin, whose
charming autobiography, in addition to being an American classic,is a
fine record of self-education. His formal training in the classroom was
limited to a few years at a local schol in Boston; but his
self-education continued throughout his life. He early manifested a zeal
for reading, and deoured, he tells us, his father's dry library on
theology, Bunyan's works, Defoe's writings, Plutarch's _Lives_, Loce's
_On the Human Understanding_, and innumerable volumes dealing with
secular subjects. His literary style, perhas the best of his time,
Franklin acquired by the diligent and repeated analysis of the
_Spectator_. In a life crowed with labors, he found time to read widely
in natural science and to win single-handed recognition at the hands o
European savants for his discoveries in electricity. By his own efforts
he "attained an acquaintance" with Latin,Italian, French, and Spanish,
thus unconsciously preparing himself for the day when he was to speak
for all Americ at the court of the king of France.

Lesser lights than Franklin, educated by the same process, were found
all oer colonial America. From this fruitful source of native ability,
self-educated, the American cause drew great stregth in the trials of
the Revolution.


THE COLONIAL PRESS

=The Rise of the Newspaper.=--The evolution of Amercan democracy into a
government by public opinion, enlightened by the open discussion of
political questions, was n no small measure aided by a free press. That
too, like education, was a matter of slow growth. A printing press ws
brought to Massachusetts in 1639, but it was put in charge of an
official censor and limited to the publication f religious works. Forty
years elapsed before the first newspaper appeared, bearing the curious
title, _Public Occrrences Both Foreign and Domestic_, and it had not
been running very long before the government of Massachusetts supressed
it for discussing a political question.

Publishing, indeed, seemed to be a precarious business; but in 104
there came a second venture in journalism, _The Boston News-Letter_,
which proved to be a more lasting enterprie because it refrained from
criticizing the authorities. Still the public interest languished. When
Franklin's broher, James, began to issue his _New England Courant_
about 1720, his friends sought to dissuade him, saying that on
newspaper was enough for America. Nevertheless he continued it; and his
confidence in the future was rewarded. Innearly every colony a gazette
or chronicle appeared within the next thirty years or more. Benjamin
Franklin was abe to record in 1771 that America had twenty-five
newspapers. Boston led with five. Philadelphia had three: two in Eglish
and one in German.

=Censorship and Restraints on the Press.=--The idea of printing,
unlicensed by the govrnment and uncontrolled by the church, was,
however, slow in taking form. The founders of the American colonies had
never known what it was to have the free and open publication of books,
pamphlets, broadsides, and newspapers. Whe the art of printing was
first discovered, the control of publishing was vested in clerical
authorities. After theestablishment of the State Church in England in
the reign of Elizabeth, censorship of the press became a part of roal
prerogative. Printing was restricted to Oxford, Cambridge, and London;
and no one could publish anything withou previous approval of the
official censor. When the Puritans were in power, the popular party,
with a zeal which rvaled that of the crown, sought, in turn, to silence
royalist and clerical writers by a vigorous censorship. After he
restoration of the monarchy, control of the press was once more placed
in royal hands, where it remained until 695, when Parliament, by
failing to renew the licensing act, did away entirely with the official

censorship. By hat time political parties were so powerful and so
active and printing presses were so numerous that official revie of all
published matter became a sheer impossibility.

In America, likewise, some troublesome questions arose inconnection
with freedom of the press. The Puritans of Massachusetts were no less
anxious than King Charles or the rchbishop of London to shut out from
the prying eyes of the people all literature "not mete for them to
read"; andso they established a system of official licensing for
presses, which lasted until 1755. In the other colonies wher there was
more diversity of opinion and publishers could set up in business with
impunity, they were neverthelessconstantly liable to arrest for
printing anything displeasing to the colonial governments. In 1721 the
editor of te _Mercury_ in Philadelphia was called before the
proprietary council and ordered to apologize for a political artile,
and for a later offense of a similar character he was thrown into jail.
A still more famous case was that of Pter Zenger, a New York publisher,
who was arrested in 1735 for criticising the administration. Lawyers who
venture to defend the unlucky editor were deprived of their licenses to
practice, and it became necessary to bring an attoney all the way from
Philadelphia. By this time the tension of feeling was high, and the
approbation of the publicwas forthcoming when the lawyer for the
defense exclaimed to the jury that the very cause of liberty itself, not
tat of the poor printer, was on trial! The verdict for Zenger, when it
finally came, was the signal for an outburst f popular rejoicing.
Already the people of King George's province knew how precious a thing
is the freedom of the ress.

Thanks to the schools, few and scattered as they were, and to the
vigilance of parents, a very large portin, perhaps nearly one-half, of
the colonists could read. Through the newspapers, pamphlets, and
almanacs that stremed from the types, the people could follow the
course of public events and grasp the significance of political
aruments. An American opinion was in the process of making--an
independent opinion nourished by the press and enriche by discussions
around the fireside and at the taverns. When the day of resistance to
British rule came, governmen by opinion was at hand. For every person
who could hear the voice of Patrick Henry and Samuel Adams, there were athousand who could see their appeals on the printed page. Men who had
spelled out their letters while poring over Fanklin's _Poor Richard's
Almanac_ lived to read Thomas Paine's thrilling call to arms.


THE EVOLUTION IN POLITIAL INSTITUTIONS

Two very distinct lines of development appeared in colonial politics.
The one, exalting royal rihts and aristocratic privileges, was the
drift toward provincial government through royal officers appointed in
Enland. The other, leading toward democracy and self-government, was
the growth in the power of the popular legislatie assembly. Each
movement gave impetus to the other, with increasing force during the
passing years, until at lastthe final collision between the two ideals
of government came in the war of independence.

=The Royal Provinces.=-Of the thirteen English colonies eight were
royal provinces in 1776, with governors appointed by the king. Virgini
passed under the direct rule of the crown in 1624, when the charter of
the London Company was annulled. The Massahusetts Bay corporation lost
its charter in 1684, and the new instrument granted seven years later
stripped the coonists of the right to choose their chief executive. In
the early decades of the eighteenth century both the Carolias were
given the provincial instead of the proprietary form. New Hampshire,
severed from Massachusetts in 1679, ad Georgia, surrendered by the
trustees in 1752, went into the hands of the crown. New York,
transferred to the Duk of York on its capture from the Dutch in 1664,
became a province when he took the title of James II in 1685. New
ersey, after remaining for nearly forty years under proprietors, was
brought directly under the king in 1702. Marylnd, Pennsylvania, and
Delaware, although they retained their proprietary character until the
Revolution, were in sme respects like the royal colonies, for their
governors were as independent of popular choice as were the appointes
of King George. Only two colonies, Rhode Island and Connecticut,
retained full self-government on the eve of theRevolution. They alone
had governors and legislatures entirely of their own choosing.

The chief officer of the ryal province was the governor, who enjoyed
high and important powers which he naturally sought to augment at everyturn. He enforced the laws and, usually with the consent of a council,
appointed the civil and military officers. H granted pardons and
reprieves; he was head of the highest court; he was commander-in-chief
of the militia; he leved troops for defense and enforced martial law in
time of invasion, war, and rebellion. In all the provinces, excep
Massachusetts, he named the councilors who composed the upper house of
the legislature and was likely to choose tose who favored his claims.
He summoned, adjourned, and dissolved the popular assembly, or the lower
house; he lai before it the projects of law desired by the crown; and
he vetoed measures which he thought objectionable. Here wee in America
all the elements of royal prerogative against which Hampden had
protested and Cromwell had battled inEngland.

[Illustration: THE ROYAL GOVERNOR'S PALACE AT NEW BERNE]

The colonial governors were generally surrouded by a body of
office-seekers and hunters for land grants. Some of them were noblemen
of broken estates who had ome to America to improve their fortunes. The
pretensions of this circle grated on colonial nerves, and privilegesgranted to them, often at the expense of colonists, did much to deepen
popular antipathy to the British government.Favors extended to
adherents of the Established Church displeased Dissenters. The
reappearance of this formidable nion of church and state, from which
they had fled, stirred anew the ancient wrath against that combination.

=Th Colonial Assembly.=--Coincident with the drift toward
administration through royal governors was the second and oposite
tendency, namely, a steady growth in the practice of self-government.
The voters of England had long been acustomed to share in taxation and
law-making through representatives in Parliament, and the idea was early
introducd in America. Virginia was only twelve years old (1619) when
its first representative assembly appeared. As the tows of
Massachusetts multiplied and it became impossible for all the members of
the corporation to meet at one place the representative idea was
adopted, in 1633. The river towns of Connecticut formed a representative
system undertheir "Fundamental Orders" of 1639, and the entire colony
was given a royal charter in 1662. Generosity, as well aspractical
considerations, induced such proprietors as Lord Baltimore and William
Penn to invite their colonists toshare in the government as soon as any
considerable settlements were made. Thus by one process or another every
on of the colonies secured a popular assembly.

It is true that in the provision for popular elections, the suffragewas
finally restricted to property owners or taxpayers, with a leaning
toward the freehold qualification. In Virgiia, the rural voter had to
be a freeholder owning at least fifty acres of land, if there was no
house on it, or twnty-five acres with a house twenty-five feet square.
In Massachusetts, the voter for member of the assembly under te charter
of 1691 had to be a freeholder of an estate worth forty shillings a year
at least or of other property t the value of forty pounds sterling. In
Pennsylvania, the suffrage was granted to freeholders owning fifty acres
o more of land well seated, twelve acres cleared, and to other persons
worth at least fifty pounds in lawful money.
Restrictions like these undoubtedly excluded from the suffrage a very
considerable number of men, particularly th mechanics and artisans of
the towns, who were by no means content with their position.
Nevertheless, it was relatvely easy for any man to acquire a small
freehold, so cheap and abundant was land; and in fact a large proportion
f the colonists were land owners. Thus the assemblies, in spite of the
limited suffrage, acquired a democratic tone

The popular character of the assemblies increased as they became engaged
in battles with the royal and proprietry governors. When called upon by
the executive to make provision for the support of the administration,
the legisature took advantage of the opportunity to make terms in the
interest of the taxpayers. It made annual, not permanet, grants of
money to pay official salaries and then insisted upon electing a
treasurer to dole it out. Thus the clonists learned some of the
mysteries of public finance, as well as the management of rapacious
officials. The legslature also used its power over money grants to
force the governor to sign bills which he would otherwise have veted.

=Contests between Legislatures and Governors.=--As may be imagined, many
and bitter were the contests betwee the royal and proprietary governors
and the colonial assemblies. Franklin relates an amusing story of how
the Pensylvania assembly held in one hand a bill for the executive to
sign and, in the other hand, the money to pay his saary. Then, with sly
humor, Franklin adds: "Do not, my courteous reader, take pet at our
proprietary constitution fr these our bargain and sale proceedings in
legislation. It is a happy country where justice and what was your ownbefore can be had for ready money. It is another addition to the value
of money and of course another spur to indusry. Every land is not so
blessed."

It must not be thought, however, that every governor got off as easily
as Frnklin's tale implies. On the contrary, the legislatures, like
Caesar, fed upon meat that made them great and steadiy encroached upon
executive prerogatives as they tried out and found their strength. If
we may believe contemporar laments, the power of the crown in America
was diminishing when it was struck down altogether. In New York, the
fiends of the governor complained in 1747 that "the inhabitants of
plantations are generally educated in republican rinciples; upon
republican principles all is conducted. Little more than a shadow of
royal authority remains in th Northern colonies." "Here," echoed the
governor of South Carolina, the following year, "levelling principles
previl; the frame of the civil government is unhinged; a governor, if
he would be idolized, must betray his trust; the eople have got their
whole administration in their hands; the election of the members of the
assembly is by ballot not civil posts only, but all ecclesiastical
preferments, are in the disposal or election of the people."

Thoug baffled by the "levelling principles" of the colonial assemblies,
the governors did not give up the case as hopeles. Instead they evolved
a system of policy and action which they thought could bring the
obstinate provincials to erms. That system, traceable in their letters
to the government in London, consisted of three parts: (1) the royalofficers in the colonies were to be made independent of the legislatures
by taxes imposed by acts of Parliament; (2 a British standing army was
to be maintained in America; (3) the remaining colonial charters were to
be revoked ad government by direct royal authority was to be enlarged.

Such a system seemed plausible enough to King George II and to many
ministers of the crown in London. With governors, courts, and an army
independent of the colonists, hey imagined it would be easy to carry
out both royal orders and acts of Parliament. This reasoning seemed both
prctical and logical. Nor was it founded on theory, for it came fresh
from the governors themselves. It was wanting i one respect only. It
failed to take account of the fact that the American people were growing
strong in the practce of self-government and could dispense with the
tutelage of the British ministry, no matter how excellent it migh be or
how benevolent its intentions.

CHAPTER IV

THE DEVELOPMENT OF COLONIAL NATIONALISM


It s one of the well-known facts of history that a people loosely
united by domestic ties of a political and economic ature, even a
people torn by domestic strife, may be welded into a solid and compact
body by an attack from a foregn power. The imperative call to common
defense, the habit of sharing common burdens, the fusing force of common
srvice--these things, induced by the necessity of resisting outside
interference, act as an amalgam drawing togetherall elements, except,
perhaps, the most discordant. The presence of the enemy allays the most
virulent of quarrels temporarily at least. "Politics," runs an old
saying, "stops at the water's edge."

This ancient political princple, so well understood in diplomatic
circles, applied nearly as well to the original thirteen American
colonies a to the countries of Europe. The necessity for common
defense, if not equally great, was certainly always pressing.Though it
has long been the practice to speak of the early settlements as founded
in "a wilderness," this was not ctually the case. From the earliest
days of Jamestown on through the years, the American people were
confronted bydangers from without. All about their tiny settlements
were Indians, growing more and more hostile as the frontier dvanced and
as sharp conflicts over land aroused angry passions. To the south and
west was the power of Spain, humliated, it is true, by the disaster to
the Armada, but still presenting an imposing front to the British
empire. T the north and west were the French, ambitious, energetic,
imperial in temper, and prepared to contest on land and ater the
advance of British dominion in America.


RELATIONS WITH THE INDIANS AND THE FRENCH

=Indian Affairs.--It is difficult to make general statements about the
relations of the colonists to the Indians. The problem was pesented in
different shape in different sections of America. It was not handled
according to any coherent or unifom plan by the British government,
which alone could speak for all the provinces at the same time. Neither
did the roprietors and the governors who succeeded one another, in an
irregular train, have the consistent policy or the maured experience
necessary for dealing wisely with Indian matters. As the difficulties
arose mainly on the frontier, where the restless and pushing pioneers
were making their way with gun and ax, nearly everything that happened
ws the result of chance rather than of calculation. A personal quarrel
between traders and an Indian, a jug of whisk, a keg of gunpowder, the
exchange of guns for furs, personal treachery, or a flash of bad temper
often set in moton destructive forces of the most terrible character.

On one side of the ledger may be set innumerable generous rcords--of
Squanto and Samoset teaching the Pilgrims the ways of the wilds; of
Roger Williams buying his lands fromthe friendly natives; or of William
Penn treating with them on his arrival in America. On the other side of
the leger must be recorded many a cruel and bloody conflict as the
frontier rolled westward with deadly precision. The Peuots on the
Connecticut border, sensing their doom, fell upon the tiny settlements
with awful fury in 1637 only tomeet with equally terrible punishment. A
generation later, King Philip, son of Massasoit, the friend of the
Pilgris, called his tribesmen to a war of extermination which brought
the strength of all New England to the field and ened in his own
destruction. In New York, the relations with the Indians, especially
with the Algonquins and the Mohwks, were marked by periodic and
desperate wars. Virginia and her Southern neighbors suffered as did New
England. n 1622 Opecacano, a brother of Powhatan, the friend of the
Jamestown settlers, launched a general massacre; and in 644 he
attempted a war of extermination. In 1675 the whole frontier was ablaze.
Nathaniel Bacon vainly attempted t stir the colonial governor to put up
an adequate defense and, failing in that plea, himself headed a revolt
and asuccessful expedition against the Indians. As the Virginia
outposts advanced into the Kentucky country, the strife ith the natives
was transferred to that "dark and bloody ground"; while to the
southeast, a desperate struggle wit the Tuscaroras called forth the
combined forces of the two Carolinas and Virginia.

[Illustration: _From an old rint._

VIRGINIANS DEFENDING THEMSELVES AGAINST THE INDIANS]

From such horrors New Jersey and Delaware were savd on account of their
geographical location. Pennsylvania, consistently following a policy of
conciliation, was liewise spared until her western vanguard came into
full conflict with the allied French and Indians. Georgia, by cleer
negotiations and treaties of alliance, managed to keep on fair terms
with her belligerent Cherokees and Creeks.But neither diplomacy nor
generosity could stay the inevitable conflict as the frontier advanced,
especially afterthe French soldiers enlisted the Indians in their
imperial enterprises. It was then that desultory fighting became eneral
warfare.

[Illustration: ENGLISH, FRENCH, AND SPANISH POSSESSIONS IN AMERICA,
1750]

=Early Relations wth the French.=--During the first decades of French
exploration and settlement in the St. Lawrence country, the Engish
colonies, engrossed with their own problems, gave little or no thought
to their distant neighbors. Quebec, fouded in 1608, and Montreal, in
1642, were too far away, too small in population, and too slight in
strength to be mch of a menace to Boston, Hartford, or New York. It was
the statesmen in France and England, rather than the colonits in
America, who first grasped the significance of the slowly converging
empires in North America. It was the amition of Louis XIV of France,
rather than the labors of Jesuit missionaries and French rangers, that
sounded the frst note of colonial alarm.

Evidence of this lies in the fact that three conflicts between the
English and the Fench occurred before their advancing frontiers met on
the Pennsylvania border. King William's War (1689-1697), Quee Anne's
War (1701-1713), and King George's War (1744-1748) owed their origins
and their endings mainly to the intrgues and rivalries of European
powers, although they all involved the American colonies in struggles
with the Frenh and their savage allies.

=The Clash in the Ohio Valley.=--The second of these wars had hardly
closed, however,before the English colonists themselves began to be
seriously alarmed about the rapidly expanding French dominion i the
West. Marquette and Joliet, who opened the Lake region, and La Salle,
who in 1682 had gone down the Mississipi to the Gulf, had been followed
by the builders of forts. In 1718, the French founded New Orleans, thus
taking posession of the gateway to the Mississippi as well as the St.
Lawrence. A few years later they built Fort Niagara; i 1731 they
occupied Crown Point; in 1749 they formally announced their dominion
over all the territory drained by he Ohio River. Having asserted this
lofty claim, they set out to make it good by constructing in the years
1752-174 Fort Le Boeuf near Lake Erie, Fort Venango on the upper
waters of the Allegheny, and Fort Duquesne at the junctio of the
streams forming the Ohio. Though they were warned by George Washington,
in the name of the governor of Virinia, to keep out of territory "so
notoriously known to be property of the crown of Great Britain," the
French shoed no signs of relinquishing their pretensions.

[Illustration: _From an old print_

BRADDOCK'S RETREAT]

=TheFinal Phase--the French and Indian War.=--Thus it happened that the
shot which opened the Seven Years' War, known i America as the French
and Indian War, was fired in the wilds of Pennsylvania. There began the
conflict that sprea to Europe and even Asia and finally involved
England and Prussia, on the one side, and France, Austria, Spain, and
minor powers on the other. On American soil, the defeat of Braddock in
1755 and Wolfe's exploit in capturing Quebe four years later were the
dramatic features. On the continent of Europe, England subsidized
Prussian arms to holdFrance at bay. In India, on the banks of the
Ganges, as on the banks of the St. Lawrence, British arms were
triumpant. Well could the historian write: "Conquests equaling in
rapidity and far surpassing in magnitude those of Corte and Pizarro had
been achieved in the East." Well could the merchants of London declare
that under the administraton of William Pitt, the imperial genius of
this world-wide conflict, commerce had been "united with and made to
flurish by war."

From the point of view of the British empire, the results of the war
were momentous. By the peaceof 1763, Canada and the territory east of
the Mississippi, except New Orleans, passed under the British flag. The
emainder of the Louisiana territory was transferred to Spain and French
imperial ambitions on the American continen were laid to rest. In
exchange for Havana, which the British had seized during the war, Spain
ceded to King Georg the colony of Florida. Not without warrant did
Macaulay write in after years that Pitt "was the first Englishman o his
time; and he had made England the first country in the world."


THE EFFECTS OF WARFARE ON THE COLONIES

he various wars with the French and the Indians, trivial in detail as
they seem to-day, had a profound influence oncolonial life and on the
destiny of America. Circumstances beyond the control of popular
assemblies, jealous of thir individual powers, compelled cooperation
among them, grudging and stingy no doubt, but still cooperation. The
Aerican people, more eager to be busy in their fields or at their
trades, were simply forced to raise and support aries, to learn the
arts of warfare, and to practice, if in a small theater, the science of
statecraft. These forces all cumulative, drove the colonists, so
tenaciously provincial in their habits, in the direction of nationalism.

=The New England Confederation.=--It was in their efforts to deal with
the problems presented by the Indian and Frnch menace that the
Americans took the first steps toward union. Though there were many
common ties among the setters of New England, it required a deadly
fear of the Indians to produce in 1643 the New England Confederation,
comosed of Massachusetts, Plymouth, Connecticut, and New Haven. The
colonies so united were bound together in "a firm nd perpetual league
of friendship and amity for offense and defense, mutual service and
succor, upon all just occaions." They made provision for distributing
the burdens of wars among the members and provided for a congress of
cmmissioners from each colony to determine upon common policies. For
some twenty years the Confederation was active nd it continued to hold
meetings until after the extinction of the Indian peril on the immediate
border.

Virgina, no less than Massachusetts, was aware of the importance of
intercolonial cooperation. In the middle of the seveneenth century, the
Old Dominion began treaties of commerce and amity with New York and the
colonies of New England In 1684 delegates from Virginia met at Albany
with the agents of New York and Massachusetts to discuss problems of
mutual defense. A few years later the Old Dominion cooperated loyally
with the Carolinas in defending their border against Indian forays.

=The Albany Plan of Union.=--An attempt at a general colonial union was
made in 1754. Onthe suggestion of the Lords of Trade in England, a
conference was held at Albany to consider Indian relations, to dvise
measures of defense against the French, and to enter into "articles of
union and confederation for the genera defense of his Majesty's
subjects and interests in North America as well in time of peace as of
war." New Hampshie, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, New York,
Pennsylvania, and Maryland were represented. After a long dicussion, a
plan of union, drafted mainly, it seems, by Benjamin Franklin, was
adopted and sent to the colonies andthe crown for approval. The
colonies, jealous of their individual rights, refused to accept the
scheme and the kin disapproved it for the reason, Franklin said, that
it had "too much weight in the democratic part of the constituton."
Though the Albany union failed, the document is still worthy of study
because it forecast many of the perplexng problems that were not solved
until thirty-three years afterward, when another convention of which
also Frankli was a member drafted the Constitution of the United
States.

[Illustration: BENJAMIN FRANKLIN]

=The Military ducation of the Colonists.=--The same wars that showed
the provincials the meaning of union likewise instructed the in the art
of defending their institutions. Particularly was this true of the last
French and Indian conflict, whch stretched all the way from Maine to
the Carolinas and made heavy calls upon them all for troops. The answer,
itis admitted, was far from satisfactory to the British government and
the conduct of the militiamen was far from proessional; but thousands
of Americans got a taste, a strong taste, of actual fighting in the
field. Men like GeorgeWashington and Daniel Morgan learned lessons that
were not forgotten in after years. They saw what American militiaen
could do under favorable circumstances and they watched British regulars
operating on American soil. "This whol transaction," shrewdly remarked
Franklin of Braddock's campaign, "gave us Americans the first suspicion
that our xalted ideas of the prowess of British regular troops had not
been well founded." It was no mere accident that the irginia colonel
who drew his sword under the elm at Cambridge and took command of the
army of the Revolution was te brave officer who had "spurned the
whistle of bullets" at the memorable battle in western Pennsylvania.

=Finanial Burdens and Commercial Disorder.=--While the provincials were
learning lessons in warfare they were also payingthe bills. All the
conflicts were costly in treasure as in blood. King Philip's war left
New England weak and almot bankrupt. The French and Indian struggle was
especially expensive. The twenty-five thousand men put in the field y
the colonies were sustained only by huge outlays of money. Paper
currency streamed from the press and debts wereaccumulated. Commerce
was driven from its usual channels and prices were enhanced. When the
end came, both Englandand America were staggering under heavy
liabilities, and to make matters worse there was a fall of prices
accompaned by a commercial depression which extended over a period of
ten years. It was in the midst of this crisis that mesures of taxation
had to be devised to pay the cost of the war, precipitating the quarrel
which led to American inependence.

=The Expulsion of French Power from North America.=--The effects of the
defeat administered to France as time proved, were difficult to
estimate. Some British statesmen regarded it as a happy circumstance
that the clonists, already restive under their administration, had no
foreign power at hand to aid them in case they struck fr independence.
American leaders, on the other hand, now that the soldiers of King Louis
were driven from the contnent, thought that they had no other country
to fear if they cast off British sovereignty. At all events, France,
hough defeated, was not out of the sphere of American influence; for,
as events proved, it was the fortunate Frenchalliance negotiated by
Franklin that assured the triumph of American arms in the War of the
Revolution.


COLONAL RELATIONS WITH THE BRITISH GOVERNMENT

It was neither the Indian wars nor the French wars that finally broughtforth American nationality. That was the product of the long strife
with the mother country which culminated in unin for the war of
independence. The forces that created this nation did not operate in the
colonies alone. The charcter of the English sovereigns, the course of
events in English domestic politics, and English measures of controlover the colonies--executive, legislative, and judicial--must all be
taken into account.

=The Last of the Stuart.=--The struggles between Charles I (1625-49)
and the parliamentary party and the turmoil of the Puritan regime
(149-60) so engrossed the attention of Englishmen at home that they had
little time to think of colonial policies or o interfere with colonial
affairs. The restoration of the monarchy in 1660, accompanied by
internal peace and the ncreasing power of the mercantile classes in the
House of Commons, changed all that. In the reign of Charles II
(160-85), himself an easy-going person, the policy of regulating trade
by act of Parliament was developed into a closly knit system and
powerful agencies to supervise the colonies were created. At the same
time a system of strictercontrol over the dominions was ushered in by
the annulment of the old charter of Massachusetts which conferred so
uch self-government on the Puritans.

Charles' successor, James II, a man of sterner stuff and jealous of his
autority in the colonies as well as at home, continued the policy thus
inaugurated and enlarged upon it. If he could hve kept his throne, he
would have bent the Americans under a harsh rule or brought on in his
dominions a revolutio like that which he precipitated at home in 1688.
He determined to unite the Northern colonies and introduce a more
efficient administration based on the pattern of the royal provinces. He
made a martinet, Sir Edmund Andros, goveror of all New England, New
York, and New Jersey. The charter of Massachusetts, annulled in the last
days of his brther's reign, he continued to ignore, and that of
Connecticut would have been seized if it had not been spirited awy and
hidden, according to tradition, in a hollow oak.

For several months, Andros gave the Northern colonies a tste of
ill-tempered despotism. He wrung quit rents from land owners not
accustomed to feudal dues; he abrogated tiles to land where, in his
opinion, they were unlawful; he forced the Episcopal service upon the
Old South Church i Boston; and he denied the writ of _habeas corpus_ to
a preacher who denounced taxation without representation. In he middle
of his arbitrary course, however, his hand was stayed. The news came
that King James had been dethroned y his angry subjects, and the people
of Boston, kindling a fire on Beacon Hill, summoned the countryside to
dispos of Andros. The response was prompt and hearty. The hated
governor was arrested, imprisoned, and sent back across te sea under
guard.

The overthrow of James, followed by the accession of William and Mary
and by assured parliamntary supremacy, had an immediate effect in the
colonies. The new order was greeted with thanksgiving. Massachusett was
given another charter which, though not so liberal as the first,
restored the spirit if not the entire letterof self-government. In the
other colonies where Andros had been operating, the old course of
affairs was resumed.
=The Indifference of the First Two Georges.=--On the death in 1714 of
Queen Anne, the successor of King William, he throne passed to a
Hanoverian prince who, though grateful for English honors and revenues,
was more interested n Hanover than in England. George I and George II,
whose combined reigns extended from 1714 to 1760, never even leaned to
speak the English language, at least without an accent. The necessity of
taking thought about colonial affars bored both of them so that the
stoutest defender of popular privileges in Boston or Charleston had no
ground tocomplain of the exercise of personal prerogatives by the king.
Moreover, during a large part of this period, the diection of affairs
was in the hands of an astute leader, Sir Robert Walpole, who betrayed
his somewhat cynical viewof politics by adopting as his motto: "Let
sleeping dogs lie." He revealed his appreciation of popular sentiment
b exclaiming: "I will not be the minister to enforce taxes at the
expense of blood." Such kings and such ministers wre not likely to
arouse the slumbering resistance of the thirteen colonies across the
sea.

=Control of the Crow over the Colonies.=--While no English ruler from
James II to George III ventured to interfere with colonial matter
personally, constant control over the colonies was exercised by royal
officers acting under the authority of the rown. Systematic supervision
began in 1660, when there was created by royal order a committee of the
king's counci to meet on Mondays and Thursdays of each week to consider
petitions, memorials, and addresses respecting the planttions. In 1696
a regular board was established, known as the "Lords of Trade and
Plantations," which continued, unil the American Revolution, to
scrutinize closely colonial business. The chief duties of the board were
to examineacts of colonial legislatures, to recommend measures to those
assemblies for adoption, and to hear memorials and peitions from the
colonies relative to their affairs.

The methods employed by this board were varied. All laws pased by
American legislatures came before it for review as a matter of routine.
If it found an act unsatisfactory, i recommended to the king the
exercise of his veto power, known as the royal disallowance. Any person
who believed is personal or property rights injured by a colonial law
could be heard by the board in person or by attorney; in sch cases it
was the practice to hear at the same time the agent of the colony so
involved. The royal veto power ovr colonial legislation was not,
therefore, a formal affair, but was constantly employed on the
suggestion of a higly efficient agency of the crown. All this was in
addition to the powers exercised by the governors in the royal
povinces.

=Judicial Control.=--Supplementing this administrative control over the
colonies was a constant superviion by the English courts of law. The
king, by virtue of his inherent authority, claimed and exercised high
appellte powers over all judicial tribunals in the empire. The right
of appeal from local courts, expressly set forth in ome charters, was,
on the eve of the Revolution, maintained in every colony. Any subject in
England or America, wh, in the regular legal course, was aggrieved by
any act of a colonial legislature or any decision of a colonial cout,
had the right, subject to certain regulations, to carry his case to the
king in council, forcing his opponent t follow him across the sea. In
the exercise of appellate power, the king in council acting as a court
could, and fequently did, declare acts of colonial legislatures duly
enacted and approved, null and void, on the ground that thy were
contrary to English law.

=Imperial Control in Operation.=--Day after day, week after week, year
after yer, the machinery for political and judicial control over
colonial affairs was in operation. At one time the Britishgovernors in
the colonies were ordered not to approve any colonial law imposing a
duty on European goods imported n English vessels. Again, when North
Carolina laid a tax on peddlers, the council objected to it as
"restrictive uon the trade and dispersion of English manufactures
throughout the continent." At other times, Indian trade was reglated in
the interests of the whole empire or grants of lands by a colonial
legislature were set aside. Virginia ws forbidden to close her ports to
North Carolina lest there should be retaliation.

In short, foreign and intercoonial trade were subjected to a control
higher than that of the colony, foreshadowing a day when the
Constitution f the United States was to commit to Congress the power to
regulate interstate and foreign commerce and commerce wih the Indians.
A superior judicial power, towering above that of the colonies, as the
Supreme Court at Washington ow towers above the states, kept the
colonial legislatures within the metes and bounds of established law. In
the housands of appeals, memorials, petitions, and complaints, and the
rulings and decisions upon them, were written th real history of
British imperial control over the American colonies.

So great was the business before the Lordsof Trade that the colonies
had to keep skilled agents in London to protect their interests. As
common grievances aainst the operation of this machinery of control
arose, there appeared in each colony a considerable body of men, wth
the merchants in the lead, who chafed at the restraints imposed on their
enterprise. Only a powerful blow was neded to weld these bodies into a
common mass nourishing the spirit of colonial nationalism. When to the
repeated mnor irritations were added general and sweeping measures of
Parliament applying to every colony, the rebound came i the Revolution.

=Parliamentary Control over Colonial Affairs.=--As soon as Parliament
gained in power at the exense of the king, it reached out to bring the
American colonies under its sway as well. Between the execution of
Carles I and the accession of George III, there was enacted an immense
body of legislation regulating the shipping, rade, and manufactures of
America. All of it, based on the "mercantile" theory then prevalent in
all countries of urope, was designed to control the overseas
plantations in such a way as to foster the commercial and business
intrests of the mother country, where merchants and men of finance had
got the upper hand. According to this theory, te colonies of the
British empire should be confined to agriculture and the production of
raw materials, and forcedto buy their manufactured goods of England.

_The Navigation Acts._--In the first rank among these measures of
Brtish colonial policy must be placed the navigation laws framed for
the purpose of building up the British merchant arine and navy--arms so
essential in defending the colonies against the Spanish, Dutch, and
French. The beginning f this type of legislation was made in 1651 and
it was worked out into a system early in the reign of Charles II
(660-85).

The Navigation Acts, in effect, gave a monopoly of colonial commerce to
British ships. No trade could b carried on between Great Britain and
her dominions save in vessels built and manned by British subjects. No
Europan goods could be brought to America save in the ships of the
country that produced them or in English ships. Theselaws, which were
almost fatal to Dutch shipping in America, fell with severity upon the
colonists, compelling themto pay higher freight rates. The adverse
effect, however, was short-lived, for the measures stimulated
shipbuildin in the colonies, where the abundance of raw materials gave
the master builders of America an advantage over those f the mother
country. Thus the colonists in the end profited from the restrictive
policy written into the Navigatin Acts.

_The Acts against Manufactures._--The second group of laws was
deliberately aimed to prevent colonial inustries from competing too
sharply with those of England. Among the earliest of these measures may
be counted the oolen Act of 1699, forbidding the exportation of woolen
goods from the colonies and even the woolen trade between twns and
colonies. When Parliament learned, as the result of an inquiry, that New
England and New York were making housands of hats a year and sending
large numbers annually to the Southern colonies and to Ireland, Spain,
and Porugal, it enacted in 1732 a law declaring that "no hats or felts,
dyed or undyed, finished or unfinished" should be put upon any vessel
or laden upon any horse or cart with intent to export to any place
whatever." The effect of ths measure upon the hat industry was almost
ruinous. A few years later a similar blow was given to the iron
industr. By an act of 1750, pig and bar iron from the colonies were
given free entry to England to encourage the productio of the raw
material; but at the same time the law provided that "no mill or other
engine for slitting or rolling f iron, no plating forge to work with a
tilt hammer, and no furnace for making steel" should be built in the
colones. As for those already built, they were declared public
nuisances and ordered closed. Thus three important economc interests of
the colonists, the woolen, hat, and iron industries, were laid under the
ban.

_The Trade Laws._-The third group of restrictive measures passed by the
British Parliament related to the sale of colonial produce. A act of
1663 required the colonies to export certain articles to Great Britain
or to her dominions alone; while suar, tobacco, and ginger consigned to
the continent of Europe had to pass through a British port paying custom
dutis and through a British merchant's hands paying the usual
commission. At first tobacco was the only one of the "enuerated
articles" which seriously concerned the American colonies, the rest
coming mainly from the British West Indes. In the course of time,
however, other commodities were added to the list of enumerated
articles, until by 1764it embraced rice, naval stores, copper, furs,
hides, iron, lumber, and pearl ashes. This was not all. The colonieswere compelled to bring their European purchases back through English
ports, paying duties to the government and comissions to merchants
again.

_The Molasses Act._--Not content with laws enacted in the interest of
English mercants and manufacturers, Parliament sought to protect the
British West Indies against competition from their French nd Dutch
neighbors. New England merchants had long carried on a lucrative trade
with the French islands in the Wes Indies and Dutch Guiana, where sugar
and molasses could be obtained in large quantities at low prices. Acting
on he protests of English planters in the Barbadoes and Jamaica,
Parliament, in 1733, passed the famous Molasses Act iposing duties on
sugar and molasses imported into the colonies from foreign
countries--rates which would have destoyed the American trade with the
French and Dutch if the law had been enforced. The duties, however, were
not collcted. The molasses and sugar trade with the foreigners went on
merrily, smuggling taking the place of lawful traffi.

=Effect of the Laws in America.=--As compared with the strict monopoly
of her colonial trade which Spain consitently sought to maintain, the
policy of England was both moderate and liberal. Furthermore, the
restrictive laws ere supplemented by many measures intended to be
favorable to colonial prosperity. The Navigation Acts, for example
redounded to the advantage of American shipbuilders and the producers
of hemp, tar, lumber, and ship stores in geeral. Favors in British
ports were granted to colonial producers as against foreign competitors
and in some instanes bounties were paid by England to encourage
colonial enterprise. Taken all in all, there is much justification in
the argument advanced by some modern scholars to the effect that the
colonists gained more than they lost by Britih trade and industrial
legislation. Certainly after the establishment of independence, when
free from these old retrictions, the Americans found themselves
handicapped by being treated as foreigners rather than favored traders
ad the recipients of bounties in English markets.

Be that as it may, it appears that the colonists felt little irrtation
against the mother country on account of the trade and navigation laws
enacted previous to the close of theFrench and Indian war. Relatively
few were engaged in the hat and iron industries as compared with those
in farmin and planting, so that England's policy of restricting America
to agriculture did not conflict with the interests o the majority of
the inhabitants. The woolen industry was largely in the hands of women
and carried on in connectin with their domestic duties, so that it was
not the sole support of any considerable number of people.

As a mater of fact, moreover, the restrictive laws, especially those
relating to trade, were not rigidly enforced. Cargoes f tobacco were
boldly sent to continental ports without even so much as a bow to the
English government, to which uties should have been paid. Sugar and
molasses from the French and Dutch colonies were shipped into New
England i spite of the law. Royal officers sometimes protested against
smuggling and sometimes connived at it; but at no tim did they succeed
in stopping it. Taken all in all, very little was heard of "the galling
restraints of trade" untl after the French war, when the British
government suddenly entered upon a new course.


SUMMARY OF THE COLONIA PERIOD

In the period between the landing of the English at Jamestown, Virginia,
in 1607, and the close of the Fench and Indian war in 1763--a period of
a century and a half--a new nation was being prepared on this continent
t take its place among the powers of the earth. It was an epoch of
migration. Western Europe contributed emigrants o many races and
nationalities. The English led the way. Next to them in numerical
importance were the Scotch-Irishand the Germans. Into the melting pot
were also cast Dutch, Swedes, French, Jews, Welsh, and Irish. Thousands
of ngroes were brought from Africa to till Southern fields or labor as
domestic servants in the North.

Why did they ome? The reasons are various. Some of them, the Pilgrims
and Puritans of New England, the French Huguenots, Scotch-rish and
Irish, and the Catholics of Maryland, fled from intolerant governments
that denied them the right to worsip God according to the dictates of
their consciences. Thousands came to escape the bondage of poverty in
the Old orld and to find free homes in America. Thousands, like the
negroes from Africa, were dragged here against their wil. The lure of
adventure appealed to the restless and the lure of profits to the
enterprising merchants.

How di they come? In some cases religious brotherhoods banded together
and borrowed or furnished the funds necessary to py the way. In other
cases great trading companies were organized to found colonies. Again it
was the wealthy propretor, like Lord Baltimore or William Penn, who
undertook to plant settlements. Many immigrants were able to pay ther
own way across the sea. Others bound themselves out for a term of years
in exchange for the cost of the passage.Negroes were brought on account
of the profits derived from their sale as slaves.

Whatever the motive for their oming, however, they managed to get
across the sea. The immigrants set to work with a will. They cut down
forests,built houses, and laid out fields. They founded churches,
schools, and colleges. They set up forges and workshops. hey spun and
wove. They fashioned ships and sailed the seas. They bartered and
traded. Here and there on favorableharbors they established centers of
commerce--Boston, Providence, New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and
Charlesto. As soon as a firm foothold was secured on the shore line
they pressed westward until, by the close of the colonia period, they
were already on the crest of the Alleghanies.

Though they were widely scattered along a thousand mles of seacoast,
the colonists were united in spirit by many common ties. The major
portion of them were Protestans. The language, the law, and the
literature of England furnished the basis of national unity. Most of the
coloniss were engaged in the same hard task; that of conquering a
wilderness. To ties of kinship and language were added tes created by
necessity. They had to unite in defense; first, against the Indians and
later against the French. Thy were all subjects of the same
sovereign--the king of England. The English Parliament made laws for
them and the nglish government supervised their local affairs, their
trade, and their manufactures. Common forces assailed them.Common
grievances vexed them. Common hopes inspired them.

Many of the things which tended to unite them likewisetended to throw
them into opposition to the British Crown and Parliament. Most of them
were freeholders; that is, armers who owned their own land and tilled
it with their own hands. A free soil nourished the spirit of freedom.
Te majority of them were Dissenters, critics, not friends, of the
Church of England, that stanch defender of the Briish monarchy. Each
colony in time developed its own legislature elected by the voters; it
grew accustomed to makin laws and laying taxes for itself. Here was a
people learning self-reliance and self-government. The attempts to
srengthen the Church of England in America and the transformation of
colonies into royal provinces only fanned the sirit of independence
which they were designed to quench.

Nevertheless, the Americans owed much of their prosperiy to the
assistance of the government that irritated them. It was the protection
of the British navy that prevente Holland, Spain, and France from
wiping out their settlements. Though their manufacture and trade were
controlled n the interests of the mother country, they also enjoyed
great advantages in her markets. Free trade existed nowher upon the
earth; but the broad empire of Britain was open to American ships and
merchandise. It could be said, wit good reason, that the disadvantages
which the colonists suffered through British regulation of their
industry andtrade were more than offset by the privileges they enjoyed.
Still that is somewhat beside the point, for mere econoic advantage is
not necessarily the determining factor in the fate of peoples. A
thousand circumstances had helpedto develop on this continent a nation,
to inspire it with a passion for independence, and to prepare it for a
destny greater than that of a prosperous dominion of the British
empire. The economists, who tried to prove by logic unssailable that
America would be richer under the British flag, could not change the
spirit of Patrick Henry, Samue Adams, Benjamin Franklin, or George
Washington.
