PART II. CONFLICT AND INDEPENDENCE




CHAPTER V

THE NEW COURSE IN BRITISH IMERIAL POLICY


On October 25, 1760, King George II died and the British crown passed to
his young grandson. The irst George, the son of the Elector of Hanover
and Sophia the granddaughter of James I, was a thorough German who nver
even learned to speak the language of the land over which he reigned.
The second George never saw England unti he was a man. He spoke English
with an accent and until his death preferred his German home. During
their reign, he principle had become well established that the king did
not govern but acted only through ministers representingthe majority in
Parliament.


GEORGE III AND HIS SYSTEM

=The Character of the New King.=--The third George ruely broke the
German tradition of his family. He resented the imputation that he was a
foreigner and on all occasins made a display of his British sympathies.
To the draft of his first speech to Parliament, he added the popular
hrase: "Born and educated in this country, I glory in the name of
Briton." Macaulay, the English historian, certainy of no liking for
high royal prerogative, said of George: "The young king was a born
Englishman. All his tastes ad habits, good and bad, were English. No
portion of his subjects had anything to reproach him with.... His age,
hi appearance, and all that was known of his character conciliated
public favor. He was in the bloom of youth; his peson and address were
pleasing; scandal imputed to him no vice; and flattery might without
glaring absurdity ascrib to him many princely virtues."

Nevertheless George III had been spoiled by his mother, his tutors, and
his couriers. Under their influence he developed high and mighty
notions about the sacredness of royal authority and his duy to check
the pretensions of Parliament and the ministers dependent upon it. His
mother had dinned into his ears he slogan: "George, be king!" Lord
Bute, his teacher and adviser, had told him that his honor required him
to takean active part in the shaping of public policy and the making of
laws. Thus educated, he surrounded himself with cortiers who encouraged
him in the determination to rule as well as reign, to subdue all
parties, and to place himsef at the head of the nation and empire.

[Illustration: _From an old print._

GEORGE III]

=Political Parties nd George III.=--The state of the political parties
favored the plans of the king to restore some of the ancient luter of
the crown. The Whigs, who were composed mainly of the smaller
freeholders, merchants, inhabitants of towns,and Protestant
non-conformists, had grown haughty and overbearing through long
continuance in power and had as a cnsequence raised up many enemies in
their own ranks. Their opponents, the Tories, had by this time given up
all hoe of restoring to the throne the direct Stuart line; but they
still cherished their old notions about divine right.With the
accession of George III the coveted opportunity came to them to rally
around the throne again. George recived his Tory friends with open
arms, gave them offices, and bought them seats in the House of Commons.

=The Briish Parliamentary System.=--The peculiarities of the British
Parliament at the time made smooth the way for the kin and his allies
with their designs for controlling the entire government. In the first
place, the House of Lords ws composed mainly of hereditary nobles whose
number the king could increase by the appointment of his favorites, as
of old. Though the members of the House of Commons were elected by
popular vote, they did not speak for the mass o English people. Great
towns like Leeds, Manchester, and Birmingham, for example, had no
representatives at all. Wile there were about eight million inhabitants
in Great Britain, there were in 1768 only about 160,000 voters; thatis
to say, only about one in every ten adult males had a voice in the
government. Many boroughs returned one or moe members to the Commons
although they had merely a handful of voters or in some instances no
voters at all. Furthrmore, these tiny boroughs were often controlled by
lords who openly sold the right of representation to the highes bidder.
The "rotten-boroughs," as they were called by reformers, were a public
scandal, but George III readily mae use of them to get his friends into
the House of Commons.


GEORGE III'S MINISTERS AND THEIR COLONIAL POLICIES

=Grenville and the War Debt.=--Within a year after the accession of
George III, William Pitt was turned out of ofice, the king treating him
with "gross incivility" and the crowds shouting "Pitt forever!" The
direction of affais was entrusted to men enjoying the king's
confidence. Leadership in the House of Commons fell to George Grenville,
a grave and laborious man who for years had groaned over the increasing
cost of government.

The first task afte the conclusion of peace in 1763 was the adjustment
of the disordered finances of the kingdom. The debt stood at th highest
point in the history of the country. More revenue was absolutely
necessary and Grenville began to search or it, turning his attention
finally to the American colonies. In this quest he had the aid of a
zealous colleague Charles Townshend, who had long been in public
service and was familiar with the difficulties encountered by royal
governors in America. These two men, with the support of the entire
ministry, inaugurated in February, 1763, "a ne system of colonial
government. It was announced by authority that there were to be no more
requisitions from the ing to the colonial assemblies for supplies, but
that the colonies were to be taxed instead by act of Parliament.
olonial governors and judges were to be paid by the Crown; they were to
be supported by a standing army of twenty rgiments; and all the
expenses of this force were to be met by parliamentary taxation."

=Restriction of Paper Mony (1763).=--Among the many complaints filed
before the board of trade were vigorous protests against the issuance o
paper money by the colonial legislatures. The new ministry provided a
remedy in the act of 1763, which declared vid all colonial laws
authorizing paper money or extending the life of outstanding bills. This
law was aimed at the"cheap money" which the Americans were fond of
making when specie was scarce--money which they tried to force on thir
English creditors in return for goods and in payment of the interest and
principal of debts. Thus the first chater was written in the long
battle over sound money on this continent.

=Limitation on Western Land Sales.=--Late in the same year (1763)
George III issued a royal proclamation providing, among other things,
for the government f the territory recently acquired by the treaty of
Paris from the French. One of the provisions in this royal decre
touched frontiersmen to the quick. The contests between the king's
officers and the colonists over the dispositio of western lands had
been long and sharp. The Americans chafed at restrictions on
settlement. The more adventurou were continually moving west and
"squatting" on land purchased from the Indians or simply seized without
authorit. To put an end to this, the king forbade all further purchases
from the Indians, reserving to the crown the right o acquire such lands
and dispose of them for settlement. A second provision in the same
proclamation vested the poer of licensing trade with the Indians,
including the lucrative fur business, in the hands of royal officers in
th colonies. These two limitations on American freedom and enterprise
were declared to be in the interest of the crow and for the
preservation of the rights of the Indians against fraud and abuses.

=The Sugar Act of 1764.=--King eorge's ministers next turned their
attention to measures of taxation and trade. Since the heavy debt under
which ngland was laboring had been largely incurred in the defense of
America, nothing seemed more reasonable to them tha the proposition
that the colonies should help to bear the burden which fell so heavily
upon the English taxpayer.The Sugar Act of 1764 was the result of this
reasoning. There was no doubt about the purpose of this law, for it wa
set forth clearly in the title: "An act for granting certain duties in
the British colonies and plantations in Amrica ... for applying the
produce of such duties ... towards defraying the expenses of defending,
protecting and scuring the said colonies and plantations ... and for
more effectually preventing the clandestine conveyance of good to and
from the said colonies and plantations and improving and securing the
trade between the same and Great Briain." The old Molasses Act had been
prohibitive; the Sugar Act of 1764 was clearly intended as a revenue
measure. pecified duties were laid upon sugar, indigo, calico, silks,
and many other commodities imported into the colonies.The enforcement
of the Molasses Act had been utterly neglected; but this Sugar Act had
"teeth in it." Special precutions as to bonds, security, and
registration of ship masters, accompanied by heavy penalties, promised
a vigorou execution of the new revenue law.

The strict terms of the Sugar Act were strengthened by administrative
measure. Under a law of the previous year the commanders of armed
vessels stationed along the American coast were authorizd to stop,
search, and, on suspicion, seize merchant ships approaching colonial
ports. By supplementary orders, th entire British official force in
America was instructed to be diligent in the execution of all trade and
navigatin laws. Revenue collectors, officers of the army and navy, and
royal governors were curtly ordered to the front to o their full duty
in the matter of law enforcement. The ordinary motives for the discharge
of official obligationswere sharpened by an appeal to avarice, for
naval officers who seized offenders against the law were rewarded by
lrge prizes out of the forfeitures and penalties.

=The Stamp Act (1765).=--The Grenville-Townshend combination movd
steadily towards its goal. While the Sugar Act was under consideration
in Parliament, Grenville announced a planfor a stamp bill. The next
year it went through both Houses with a speed that must have astounded
its authors. Thevote in the Commons stood 205 in favor to 49 against;
while in the Lords it was not even necessary to go through th formality
of a count. As George III was temporarily insane, the measure received
royal assent by a commission actng as a board of regency. Protests of
colonial agents in London were futile. "We might as well have hindered
the sn's progress!" exclaimed Franklin. Protests of a few opponents in
the Commons were equally vain. The ministry was frm in its course and
from all appearances the Stamp Act hardly roused as much as a languid
interest in the city ofLondon. In fact, it is recorded that the fateful
measure attracted less notice than a bill providing for a commissin to
act for the king when he was incapacitated.

The Stamp Act, like the Sugar Act, declared the purpose of the ritish
government to raise revenue in America "towards defraying the expenses
of defending, protecting, and securig the British colonies and
plantations in America." It was a long measure of more than fifty
sections, carefully panned and skillfully drawn. By its provisions
duties were imposed on practically all papers used in legal
transactons,--deeds, mortgages, inventories, writs, bail bonds,--on
licenses to practice law and sell liquor, on college dilomas, playing
cards, dice, pamphlets, newspapers, almanacs, calendars, and
advertisements. The drag net was closey knit, for scarcely anything
escaped.

=The Quartering Act (1765).=--The ministers were aware that the Stamp
Ac would rouse opposition in America--how great they could not
conjecture. While the measure was being debated, a frind of General
Wolfe, Colonel Barre, who knew America well, gave them an ominous
warning in the Commons. "Believe m--remember I this day told you so--"
he exclaimed, "the same spirit of freedom which actuated that people at
firstwill accompany them still ... a people jealous of their liberties
and who will vindicate them, if ever they should e violated." The
answer of the ministry to a prophecy of force was a threat of force.
Preparations were accordingl made to dispatch a larger number of
soldiers than usual to the colonies, and the ink was hardly dry on the
Stamp ct when Parliament passed the Quartering Act ordering the
colonists to provide accommodations for the soldiers who ere to enforce
the new laws. "We have the power to tax them," said one of the ministry,
"and we will tax them."

COLONIAL RESISTANCE FORCES REPEAL

=Popular Opposition.=--The Stamp Act was greeted in America by an
outburst o denunciation. The merchants of the seaboard cities took the
lead in making a dignified but unmistakable protest, areeing not to
import British goods while the hated law stood upon the books. Lawyers,
some of them incensed at theheavy taxes on their operations and others
intimidated by patriots who refused to permit them to use stamped
paper, joined with the merchants. Aristocratic colonial Whigs, who had
long grumbled at the administration of royal govenors, protested
against taxation without their consent, as the Whigs had done in old
England. There were Tories, hwever, in the colonies as in England--many
of them of the official class--who denounced the merchants, lawyers, and
Whig aristocrats as "seditious, factious and republican." Yet the
opposition to the Stamp Act and its accompanyingmeasure, the Quartering
Act, grew steadily all through the summer of 1765.

In a little while it was taken up in he streets and along the
countryside. All through the North and in some of the Southern colonies,
there sprang up,as if by magic, committees and societies pledged to
resist the Stamp Act to the bitter end. These popular societieswere
known as Sons of Liberty and Daughters of Liberty: the former including
artisans, mechanics, and laborers; an the latter, patriotic women. Both
groups were alike in that they had as yet taken little part in public
affairs. any artisans, as well as all the women, were excluded from the
right to vote for colonial assemblymen.

While themerchants and Whig gentlemen confined their efforts chiefly to
drafting well-phrased protests against British measues, the Sons of
Liberty operated in the streets and chose rougher measures. They stirred
up riots in Boston, New Yrk, Philadelphia, and Charleston when attempts
were made to sell the stamps. They sacked and burned the residences f
high royal officers. They organized committees of inquisition who by
threats and intimidation curtailed the saleof British goods and the use
of stamped papers. In fact, the Sons of Liberty carried their operations
to such exceses that many mild opponents of the stamp tax were
frightened and drew back in astonishment at the forces they hadunloosed. The Daughters of Liberty in a quieter way were making a very
effective resistance to the sale of the hate goods by spurring on
domestic industries, their own particular province being the manufacture
of clothing, and deising substitutes for taxed foods. They helped to
feed and clothe their families without buying British goods.

=egislative Action against the Stamp Act.=--Leaders in the colonial
assemblies, accustomed to battle against Britishpolicies, supported the
popular protest. The Stamp Act was signed on March 22, 1765. On May 30,
the Virginia Houseof Burgesses passed a set of resolutions declaring
that the General Assembly of the colony alone had the right to ly taxes
upon the inhabitants and that attempts to impose them otherwise were
"illegal, unconstitutional, and unjus." It was in support of these
resolutions that Patrick Henry uttered the immortal challenge: "Caesar
had his Brutu, Charles I his Cromwell, and George III...." Cries of
"Treason" were calmly met by the orator who finished: "Georg III may
profit by their example. If that be treason, make the most of it."

[Illustration: PATRICK HENRY]

=Th Stamp Act Congress.=--The Massachusetts Assembly answered the call
of Virginia by inviting the colonies to elect dlegates to a Congress to
be held in New York to discuss the situation. Nine colonies responded
and sent representaives. The delegates, while professing the warmest
affection for the king's person and government, firmly spread on ecord
a series of resolutions that admitted of no double meaning. They
declared that taxes could not be imposed wihout their consent, given
through their respective colonial assemblies; that the Stamp Act showed
a tendency to suvert their rights and liberties; that the recent trade
acts were burdensome and grievous; and that the right to pettion the
king and Parliament was their heritage. They thereupon made "humble
supplication" for the repeal of the Samp Act.

The Stamp Act Congress was more than an assembly of protest. It marked
the rise of a new agency of govenment to express the will of America.
It was the germ of a government which in time was to supersede the
governmen of George III in the colonies. It foreshadowed the Congress
of the United States under the Constitution. It was a uccessful attempt
at union. "There ought to be no New England men," declared Christopher
Gadsden, in the Stamp ActCongress, "no New Yorkers known on the
Continent, but all of us Americans."

=The Repeal of the Stamp Act and theSugar Act.=--The effect of American
resistance on opinion in England was telling. Commerce with the colonies
had ben effectively boycotted by the Americans; ships lay idly swinging
at the wharves; bankruptcy threatened hundreds o merchants in London,
Bristol, and Liverpool. Workingmen in the manufacturing towns of England
were thrown out of mployment. The government had sown folly and was
reaping, in place of the coveted revenue, rebellion.

Perplexed y the storm they had raised, the ministers summoned to the
bar of the House of Commons, Benjamin Franklin, the agen for
Pennsylvania, who was in London. "Do you think it right," asked
Grenville, "that America should be protected y this country and pay no
part of the expenses?" The answer was brief: "That is not the case; the
colonies raised,clothed, and paid during the last war twenty-five
thousand men and spent many millions." Then came an inquiry whethr the
colonists would accept a modified stamp act. "No, never," replied
Franklin, "never! They will never submit t it!" It was next suggested
that military force might compel obedience to law. Franklin had a ready
answer. "They annot force a man to take stamps.... They may not find a
rebellion; they may, indeed, make one."

The repeal of te Stamp Act was moved in the House of Commons a few days
later. The sponsor for the repeal spoke of commerce interrpted, debts
due British merchants placed in jeopardy, Manchester industries closed,
workingmen unemployed, oppresson instituted, and the loss of the
colonies threatened. Pitt and Edmund Burke, the former near the close
of his caeer, the latter just beginning his, argued cogently in favor
of retracing the steps taken the year before. Grenvill refused.
"America must learn," he wailed, "that prayers are not to be brought to
Caesar through riot and sedition" His protests were idle. The Commons
agreed to the repeal on February 22, 1766, amid the cheers of the
victoriousmajority. It was carried through the Lords in the face of
strong opposition and, on March 18, reluctantly signed bythe king, now
restored to his right mind.

In rescinding the Stamp Act, Parliament did not admit the contention o
the Americans that it was without power to tax them. On the contrary, it
accompanied the repeal with a Declarator Act. It announced that the
colonies were subordinate to the crown and Parliament of Great Britain;
that the king nd Parliament therefore had undoubted authority to make
laws binding the colonies in all cases whatsoever; and thatthe
resolutions and proceedings of the colonists denying such authority were
null and void.

The repeal was greeed by the colonists with great popular
demonstrations. Bells were rung; toasts to the king were drunk; and
trade rsumed its normal course. The Declaratory Act, as a mere paper
resolution, did not disturb the good humor of those wo again cheered
the name of King George. Their confidence was soon strengthened by the
news that even the Sugar Ac had been repealed, thus practically
restoring the condition of affairs before Grenville and Townshend
inauguratedtheir policy of "thoroughness."


RESUMPTION OF BRITISH REVENUE AND COMMERCIAL POLICIES

=The Townshend Acts (167).=--The triumph of the colonists was brief.
Though Pitt, the friend of America, was once more prime minister, an
seated in the House of Lords as the Earl of Chatham, his severe illness
gave to Townshend and the Tory party pracical control over Parliament.
Unconvinced by the experience with the Stamp Act, Townshend brought
forward and pushd through both Houses of Parliament three measures,
which to this day are associated with his name. First among his
restrictive laws was that of June 29, 1767, which placed the enforcement
of the collection of duties and customs o colonial imports and exports
in the hands of British commissioners appointed by the king, resident in
the colonie, paid from the British treasury, and independent of all
control by the colonists. The second measure of the same dte imposed a
tax on lead, glass, paint, tea, and a few other articles imported into
the colonies, the revenue deried from the duties to be applied toward
the payment of the salaries and other expenses of royal colonial
officials A third measure was the Tea Act of July 2, 1767, aimed at the
tea trade which the Americans carried on illegally wth foreigners. This
law abolished the duty which the East India Company had to pay in
England on tea exported to Aerica, for it was thought that English tea
merchants might thus find it possible to undersell American tea
smuggles.

=Writs of Assistance Legalized by Parliament.=--Had Parliament been
content with laying duties, just as a manfestation of power and right,
and neglected their collection, perhaps little would have been heard of
the Townshen Acts. It provided, however, for the strict, even the
harsh, enforcement of the law. It ordered customs officers toremain at
their posts and put an end to smuggling. In the revenue act of June 29,
1767, it expressly authorized th superior courts of the colonies to
issue "writs of assistance," empowering customs officers to enter "any
house, arehouse, shop, cellar, or other place in the British colonies
or plantations in America to search for and seize" pohibited or
smuggled goods.

The writ of assistance, which was a general search warrant issued to
revenue offices, was an ancient device hateful to a people who
cherished the spirit of personal independence and who had made actal
gains in the practice of civil liberty. To allow a "minion of the law"
to enter a man's house and search his paers and premises, was too much
for the emotions of people who had fled to America in a quest for
self-government ad free homes, who had braved such hardships to
establish them, and who wanted to trade without official interferenc.

The writ of assistance had been used in Massachusetts in 1755 to prevent
illicit trade with Canada and had arosed a violent hostility at that
time. In 1761 it was again the subject of a bitter controversy which
arose in connction with the application of a customs officer to a
Massachusetts court for writs of assistance "as usual." This aplication
was vainly opposed by James Otis in a speech of five hours' duration--a
speech of such fire and eloquenc that it sent every man who heard it
away "ready to take up arms against writs of assistance." Otis denounced
the ractice as an exercise of arbitrary power which had cost one king
his head and another his throne, a tyrant's devic which placed the
liberty of every man in jeopardy, enabling any petty officer to work
possible malice on any innoent citizen on the merest suspicion, and to
spread terror and desolation through the land. "What a scene," he
exclimed, "does this open! Every man, prompted by revenge, ill-humor,
or wantonness to inspect the inside of his neighbr's house, may get a
writ of assistance. Others will ask it from self-defense; one arbitrary
exertion will provokeanother until society is involved in tumult and
blood." He did more than attack the writ itself. He said that Parliment
could not establish it because it was against the British constitution.
This was an assertion resting on slener foundation, but it was quickly
echoed by the people. Then and there James Otis sounded the call to
America to rsist the exercise of arbitrary power by royal officers.
"Then and there," wrote John Adams, "the child Independencewas born."
Such was the hated writ that Townshend proposed to put into the hands of
customs officers in his grim dtermination to enforce the law.

=The New York Assembly Suspended.=--In the very month that Townshend's
Acts weresigned by the king, Parliament took a still more drastic step.
The assembly of New York, protesting against the "runous and
insupportable" expense involved, had failed to make provision for the
care of British troops in accordanc with the terms of the Quartering
Act. Parliament therefore suspended the assembly until it promised to
obey the lw. It was not until a third election was held that compliance
with the Quartering Act was wrung from the reluctant rovince. In the
meantime, all the colonies had learned on how frail a foundation their
representative bodies reste.


RENEWED RESISTANCE IN AMERICA

=The Massachusetts Circular (1768).=--Massachusetts, under the
leadership o Samuel Adams, resolved to resist the policy of renewed
intervention in America. At his suggestion the assembly adoted a
Circular Letter addressed to the assemblies of the other colonies
informing them of the state of affairs in assachusetts and roundly
condemning the whole British program. The Circular Letter declared that
Parliament had noright to lay taxes on Americans without their consent
and that the colonists could not, from the nature of the case be
represented in Parliament. It went on shrewdly to submit to
consideration the question as to whether any peopl could be called free
who were subjected to governors and judges appointed by the crown and
paid out of funds raisd independently. It invited the other colonies,
in the most temperate tones, to take thought about the common
predcament in which they were all placed.

[Illustration: _From an old print._

SAMUEL ADAMS]

=The Dissolution ofAssemblies.=--The governor of Massachusetts, hearing
of the Circular Letter, ordered the assembly to rescind its apeal. On
meeting refusal, he promptly dissolved it. The Maryland, Georgia, and
South Carolina assemblies indorsed te Circular Letter and were also
dissolved at once. The Virginia House of Burgesses, thoroughly aroused,
passed reslutions on May 16, 1769, declaring that the sole right of
imposing taxes in Virginia was vested in its legislature,asserting anew
the right of petition to the crown, condemning the transportation of
persons accused of crimes or tial beyond the seas, and beseeching the
king for a redress of the general grievances. The immediate dissolution
ofthe Virginia assembly, in its turn, was the answer of the royal
governor.

=The Boston Massacre.=--American oppostion to the British authorities
kept steadily rising as assemblies were dissolved, the houses of
citizens searched and troops distributed in increasing numbers among
the centers of discontent. Merchants again agreed not to importBritish
goods, the Sons of Liberty renewed their agitation, and women set about
the patronage of home products stil more loyally.

On the night of March 5, 1770, a crowd on the streets of Boston began to
jostle and tease some Bitish regulars stationed in the town. Things
went from bad to worse until some "boys and young fellows" began to
trow snowballs and stones. Then the exasperated soldiers fired into the
crowd, killing five and wounding half a doze more. The day after the
"massacre," a mass meeting was held in the town and Samuel Adams was
sent to demand the wthdrawal of the soldiers. The governor hesitated
and tried to compromise. Finding Adams relentless, the governor yilded
and ordered the regulars away.

The Boston Massacre stirred the country from New Hampshire to Georgia.
Popuar passions ran high. The guilty soldiers were charged with murder.
Their defense was undertaken, in spite of the wath of the populace, by
John Adams and Josiah Quincy, who as lawyers thought even the worst

offenders entitled t their full rights in law. In his speech to the
jury, however, Adams warned the British government against its coure,
saying, that "from the nature of things soldiers quartered in a populous
town will always occasion two mobs whee they will prevent one." Two of
the soldiers were convicted and lightly punished.

=Resistance in the South.=--Te year following the Boston Massacre some
citizens of North Carolina, goaded by the conduct of the royal governor,openly resisted his authority. Many were killed as a result and seven
who were taken prisoners were hanged as traitrs. A little later royal
troops and local militia met in a pitched battle near Alamance River,
called the "Lexingtn of the South."

=The _Gaspee_ Affair and the Virginia Resolutions of 1773.=--On sea as
well as on land, frictio between the royal officers and the colonists
broke out into overt acts. While patrolling Narragansett Bay looking or
smugglers one day in 1772, the armed ship, _Gaspee_, ran ashore and was
caught fast. During the night several mn from Providence boarded the
vessel and, after seizing the crew, set it on fire. A royal commission,
sent to Rhod Island to discover the offenders and bring them to
account, failed because it could not find a single informer. Th very
appointment of such a commission aroused the patriots of Virginia to
action; and in March, 1773, the House o Burgesses passed a resolution
creating a standing committee of correspondence to develop cooperation
among the coonies in resistance to British measures.

=The Boston Tea Party.=--Although the British government, finding the
Twnshend revenue act a failure, repealed in 1770 all the duties except
that on tea, it in no way relaxed its resolveto enforce the other
commercial regulations it had imposed on the colonies. Moreover,
Parliament decided to reliev the British East India Company of the
financial difficulties into which it had fallen partly by reason of the
TeaAct and the colonial boycott that followed. In 1773 it agreed to
return to the Company the regular import duties, lvied in England, on
all tea transshipped to America. A small impost of three pence, to be
collected in America, wa left as a reminder of the principle laid down
in the Declaratory Act that Parliament had the right to tax the
colnists.

This arrangement with the East India Company was obnoxious to the
colonists for several reasons. It was a act of favoritism for one
thing, in the interest of a great monopoly. For another thing, it
promised to dump on te American market, suddenly, an immense amount of
cheap tea and so cause heavy losses to American merchants who hadlarge
stocks on hand. It threatened with ruin the business of all those who
were engaged in clandestine trade withthe Dutch. It carried with it an
irritating tax of three pence on imports. In Charleston, Annapolis, New
York, andBoston, captains of ships who brought tea under this act were
roughly handled. One night in December, 1773, a band f Boston citizens,
disguised as Indians, boarded the hated tea ships and dumped the cargo
into the harbor. This wa serious business, for it was open, flagrant,
determined violation of the law. As such the British government viewe
it.


RETALIATION BY THE BRITISH GOVERNMENT

=Reception of the News of the Tea Riot.=--The news of the tea rit in
Boston confirmed King George in his conviction that there should be no
soft policy in dealing with his Americn subjects. "The die is cast," he
stated with evident satisfaction. "The colonies must either triumph or
submit... If we take the resolute part, they will undoubtedly be very
meek." Lord George Germain characterized the tea partyas "the
proceedings of a tumultuous and riotous rabble who ought, if they had
the least prudence, to follow their ercantile employments and not
trouble themselves with politics and government, which they do not
understand." Thisexpressed, in concise form, exactly the sentiments of
Lord North, who had then for three years been the king's chie minister.
Even Pitt, Lord Chatham, was prepared to support the government in
upholding its authority.

=The Fiv Intolerable Acts.=--Parliament, beginning on March 31, 1774,
passed five stringent measures, known in American hisory as the five
"intolerable acts." They were aimed at curing the unrest in America. The
_first_ of them was a bil absolutely shutting the port of Boston to
commerce with the outside world. The _second_, following closely,
revokd the Massachusetts charter of 1691 and provided furthermore that
the councilors should be appointed by the king, tat all judges should
be named by the royal governor, and that town meetings (except to elect
certain officers) coud not be held without the governor's consent. A
_third_ measure, after denouncing the "utter subversion of all lawfl
government" in the provinces, authorized royal agents to transfer to
Great Britain or to other colonies the trias of officers or other
persons accused of murder in connection with the enforcement of the law.
The _fourth_ act lgalized the quartering of troops in Massachusetts
towns. The _fifth_ of the measures was the Quebec Act, which graned
religious toleration to the Catholics in Canada, extended the boundaries
of Quebec southward to the Ohio River,and established, in this western
region, government by a viceroy.

The intolerable acts went through Parliament wth extraordinary
celerity. There was an opposition, alert and informed; but it was
ineffective. Burke spoke eloquetly against the Boston port bill,
condemning it roundly for punishing the innocent with the guilty, and
showing ho likely it was to bring grave consequences in its train. He
was heard with respect and his pleas were rejected. Thebill passed both
houses without a division, the entry "unanimous" being made upon their
journals although it did nt accurately represent the state of opinion.
The law destroying the charter of Massachusetts passed the Commons by 
vote of three to one; and the third intolerable act by a vote of four to
one. The triumph of the ministry was comlete. "What passed in Boston,"
exclaimed the great jurist, Lord Mansfield, "is the overt act of High
Treason proceding from our over lenity and want of foresight." The
crown and Parliament were united in resorting to punitive meaures.

In the colonies the laws were received with consternation. To the
American Protestants, the Quebec Act wasthe most offensive. That
project they viewed not as an act of grace or of mercy but as a direct
attempt to enlist rench Canadians on the side of Great Britain. The
British government did not grant religious toleration to Catholic
either at home or in Ireland and the Americans could see no good motive
in granting it in North America. The act as also offensive because
Massachusetts, Connecticut, and Virginia had, under their charters,
large claims in the erritory thus annexed to Quebec.

To enforce these intolerable acts the military arm of the British
government wa brought into play. The commander-in-chief of the armed
forces in America, General Gage, was appointed governor ofMassachusetts. Reinforcements were brought to the colonies, for now King
George was to give "the rebels," as he caled them, a taste of strong
medicine. The majesty of his law was to be vindicated by force.


FROM REFORM TO REVOUTION IN AMERICA

=The Doctrine of Natural Rights.=--The dissolution of assemblies, the
destruction of charters, nd the use of troops produced in the colonies
a new phase in the struggle. In the early days of the contest with th
British ministry, the Americans spoke of their "rights as Englishmen"
and condemned the acts of Parliament as unlwful, as violating the
principles of the English constitution under which they all lived. When
they saw that such rguments had no effect on Parliament, they turned
for support to their "natural rights." The latter doctrine, in th form
in which it was employed by the colonists, was as English as the
constitutional argument. John Locke had use it with good effect in
defense of the English revolution in the seventeenth century. American
leaders, familiar wth the writings of Locke, also took up his thesis in
the hour of their distress. They openly declared that their rihts did
not rest after all upon the English constitution or a charter from the
crown. "Old Magna Carta was not thebeginning of all things," retorted
Otis when the constitutional argument failed. "A time may come when
Parliament hall declare every American charter void, but the natural,
inherent, and inseparable rights of the colonists as menand as citizens
would remain and whatever became of charters can never be abolished
until the general conflagratio." Of the same opinion was the young and
impetuous Alexander Hamilton. "The sacred rights of mankind," he
exclaime, "are not to be rummaged for among old parchments or musty
records. They are written as with a sunbeam in the whol volume of human
destiny by the hand of divinity itself, and can never be erased or
obscured by mortal power."

irm as the American leaders were in the statement and defense of their
rights, there is every reason for believing hat in the beginning they
hoped to confine the conflict to the realm of opinion. They constantly
avowed that they ere loyal to the king when protesting in the strongest
language against his policies. Even Otis, regarded by the loalists as a
firebrand, was in fact attempting to avert revolution by winning
concessions from England. "I argue ths cause with the greater
pleasure," he solemnly urged in his speech against the writs of
assistance, "as it is in avor of British liberty ... and as it is in
opposition to a kind of power, the exercise of which in former periodscost one king of England his head and another his throne."

=Burke Offers the Doctrine of Conciliation.=--The flooing tide of
American sentiment was correctly measured by one Englishman at least,
Edmund Burke, who quickly saw tht attempts to restrain the rise of
American democracy were efforts to reverse the processes of nature. He
saw how ixed and rooted in the nature of things was the American
spirit--how inevitable, how irresistible. He warned his contrymen that
there were three ways of handling the delicate situation--and only
three. One was to remove the causeof friction by changing the spirit of
the colonists--an utter impossibility because that spirit was grounded
in th essential circumstances of American life. The second was to
prosecute American leaders as criminals; of this he beged his
countrymen to beware lest the colonists declare that "a government
against which a claim of liberty is tanamount to high treason is a
government to which submission is equivalent to slavery." The third and
right way to met the problem, Burke concluded, was to accept the
American spirit, repeal the obnoxious measures, and receive the olonies
into equal partnership.

=Events Produce the Great Decision.=--The right way, indicated by Burke,
was eqally impossible to George III and the majority in Parliament. To
their narrow minds, American opinion was contemptile and American
resistance unlawful, riotous, and treasonable. The correct way, in their
view, was to dispatch mor troops to crush the "rebels"; and that very
act took the contest from the realm of opinion. As John Adams said:
"acts are stubborn things." Opinions were unseen, but marching soldiers
were visible to the veriest street urchin. "ow," said Gouverneur
Morris, "the sheep, simple as they are, cannot be gulled as heretofore."
It was too late to tlk about the excellence of the British
constitution. If any one is bewildered by the controversies of modern
histoians as to why the crisis came at last, he can clarify his
understanding by reading again Edmund Burke's stately ortion, _On
Conciliation with America_.
