PART III. THE UNION AND NATIONAL POLITICS




CHAPTER VII

THE FORMTION OF THE CONSTITUTION


THE PROMISE AND THE DIFFICULTIES OF AMERICA

The rise of a young republic composed o thirteen states, each governed
by officials popularly elected under constitutions drafted by "the plain
people," as the most significant feature of the eighteenth century. The
majority of the patriots whose labors and sacrificeshad made this
possible naturally looked upon their work and pronounced it good. Those
Americans, however, who peerd beneath the surface of things, saw that
the Declaration of Independence, even if splendidly phrased, and paper
cnstitutions, drawn by finest enthusiasm "uninstructed by experience,"
could not alone make the republic great and posperous or even free. All
around them they saw chaos in finance and in industry and perils for the
immediate futue.

=The Weakness of the Articles of Confederation.=--The government under
the Articles of Confederation had neiter the strength nor the resources
necessary to cope with the problems of reconstruction left by the war.
The sole rgan of government was a Congress composed of from two to
seven members from each state chosen as the legislature mght direct and
paid by the state. In determining all questions, each state had one
vote--Delaware thus enjoying th same weight as Virginia. There was no
president to enforce the laws. Congress was given power to select a
committe of thirteen--one from each state--to act as an executive body
when it was not in session; but this device, on beig tried out, proved
a failure. There was no system of national courts to which citizens and
states could appeal fo the protection of their rights or through which
they could compel obedience to law. The two great powers of governent,
military and financial, were withheld. Congress, it is true, could
authorize expenditures but had to rely upo the states for the payment
of contributions to meet its bills. It could also order the
establishment of an army, ut it could only request the states to supply
their respective quotas of soldiers. It could not lay taxes nor bring
any pressure to bear upon a single citizen in the whole country. It
could act only through the medium of the stategovernments.

=Financial and Commercial Disorders.=--In the field of public finance,
the disorders were pronounce. The huge debt incurred during the war was
still outstanding. Congress was unable to pay either the interest or th
principal. Public creditors were in despair, as the market value of
their bonds sank to twenty-five or even ten cnts on the dollar. The
current bills of Congress were unpaid. As some one complained, there was
not enough money i the treasury to buy pen and ink with which to record
the transactions of the shadow legislature. The currency was n utter
chaos. Millions of dollars in notes issued by Congress had become mere
trash worth a cent or two on the dolar. There was no other expression
of contempt so forceful as the popular saying: "not worth a
Continental." To mae matters worse, several of the states were pouring
new streams of paper money from the press. Almost the only goodmoney in
circulation consisted of English, French, and Spanish coins, and the
public was even defrauded by them beause money changers were busy
clipping and filing away the metal. Foreign commerce was unsettled. The
entire Britih system of trade discrimination was turned against the
Americans, and Congress, having no power to regulate foreig commerce,
was unable to retaliate or to negotiate treaties which it could enforce.
Domestic commerce was impeded y the jealousies of the states, which
erected tariff barriers against their neighbors. The condition of the
curreny made the exchange of money and goods extremely difficult, and,
as if to increase the confusion, backward states eacted laws hindering
the prompt collection of debts within their borders--an evil which
nothing but a national sysem of courts could cure.

=Congress in Disrepute.=--With treaties set at naught by the states, the
laws unenforce, the treasury empty, and the public credit gone, the
Congress of the United States fell into utter disrepute. It clled upon
the states to pay their quotas of money into the treasury, only to be
treated with contempt. Even its ow members looked upon it as a solemn
futility. Some of the ablest men refused to accept election to it, and
many wh did take the doubtful honor failed to attend the sessions.
Again and again it was impossible to secure a quorum fo the transaction
of business.

=Troubles of the State Governments.=--The state governments, free to
pursue theirown course with no interference from without, had almost as
many difficulties as the Congress. They too were loadedwith
revolutionary debts calling for heavy taxes upon an already restive
population. Oppressed by their financial urdens and discouraged by the
fall in prices which followed the return of peace, the farmers of
several states joied in a concerted effort and compelled their
legislatures to issue large sums of paper money. The currency fell invalue, but nevertheless it was forced on unwilling creditors to square
old accounts.

In every part of the countr legislative action fluctuated violently.
Laws were made one year only to be repealed the next and reenacted the
tird year. Lands were sold by one legislature and the sales were
canceled by its successor. Uncertainty and distrustwere the natural
consequences. Men of substance longed for some power that would forbid
states to issue bills of cedit, to make paper money legal tender in
payment of debts, or to impair the obligation of contracts. Men heavily
n debt, on the other hand, urged even more drastic action against
creditors.

So great did the discontent of the armers in New Hampshire become in
1786 that a mob surrounded the legislature, demanding a repeal of the
taxes and he issuance of paper money. It was with difficulty that an
armed rebellion was avoided. In Massachusetts the malconents, under the
leadership of Daniel Shays, a captain in the Revolutionary army,
organized that same year open resstance to the government of the state.
Shays and his followers protested against the conduct of creditors in
forecosing mortgages upon the debt-burdened farmers, against the
lawyers for increasing the costs of legal proceedings, gainst the
senate of the state the members of which were apportioned among the
towns on the basis of the amount oftaxes paid, against heavy taxes, and
against the refusal of the legislature to issue paper money. They seized
the owns of Worcester and Springfield and broke up the courts of
justice. All through the western part of the state therevolt spread,
sending a shock of alarm to every center and section of the young
republic. Only by the most vigoros action was Governor Bowdoin able to
quell the uprising; and when that task was accomplished, the state
governmen did not dare to execute any of the prisoners because they had
so many sympathizers. Moreover, Bowdoin and several embers of the
legislature who had been most zealous in their attacks on the insurgents
were defeated at the ensuin election. The need of national assistance
for state governments in times of domestic violence was everywhere
emphsized by men who were opposed to revolutionary acts.

=Alarm over Dangers to the Republic.=--Leading American citiens,
watching the drift of affairs, were slowly driven to the conclusion that
the new ship of state so proudly lauched a few years before was
careening into anarchy. "The facts of our peace and independence," wrote
a friend of Wshington, "do not at present wear so promising an
appearance as I had fondly painted in my mind. The prejudices,
jalousies, and turbulence of the people at times almost stagger my
confidence in our political establishments; and amost occasion me to
think that they will show themselves unworthy of the noble prize for
which we have contended."

Washington himself was profoundly discouraged. On hearing of Shays's
rebellion, he exclaimed: "What, gracious Go, is man that there should
be such inconsistency and perfidiousness in his conduct! It is but the
other day that w were shedding our blood to obtain the constitutions
under which we now live--constitutions of our own choice and mking--and
now we are unsheathing our sword to overturn them." The same year he
burst out in a lament over rumors o restoring royal government. "I am
told that even respectable characters speak of a monarchical government
withouthorror. From thinking proceeds speaking. Hence to acting is
often but a single step. But how irresistible and tremedous! What a
triumph for our enemies to verify their predictions! What a triumph for
the advocates of despotism tofind that we are incapable of governing
ourselves!"

ADVENTURE  I.  A SCANDAL IN BOHEMIA

I.


To Sherlock Holme she is always the woman. I have seldom heard him mention her under any other name. In his eyes she eclipses and preominates the whole of her sex. It was not that he felt any emotion akin to love for Irene Adler. All emotions, and tat one particularly, were abhorrent to his cold, precise but admirably balanced mind. He was, I take it, the most pefect reasoning and observing machine that the world has seen, but as a lover he would have placed himself in a falseposition. He never spoke of the softer passions, save with a gibe and a sneer. They were admirable things for the oberver--excellent for drawing the veil from men's motives and actions. But for the trained reasoner to admit such intusions into his own delicate and finely adjusted temperament was to introduce a distracting factor which might throwa doubt upon all his mental results. Grit in a sensitive instrument, or a crack in one of his own high-power lenses,would not be more disturbing than a strong emotion in a nature such as his. And yet there was but one woman to him, nd that woman was the late Irene Adler, of dubious and questionable memory.

I had seen little of Holmes lately. M marriage had drifted us away from each other. My own complete happiness, and the home-centred interests which rise p around the man who first finds himself master of his own establishment, were sufficient to absorb all my attention while Holmes, who loathed every form of society with his whole Bohemian soul, remained in our lodgings in Baker Stret, buried among his old books, and alternating from week to week between cocaine and ambition, the drowsiness of th drug, and the fierce energy of his own keen nature. He was still, as ever, deeply attracted by the study of crime, nd occupied his immense faculties and extraordinary powers of observation in following out those clues, and clearingup those mysteries which had been abandoned as hopeless by the official police. From time to time I heard some vagueaccount of his doings: of his summons to Odessa in the case of the Trepoff murder, of his clearing up of the singula tragedy of the Atkinson brothers at Trincomalee, and finally of the mission which he had accomplished so delicatelyand successfully for the reigning family of Holland. Beyond these signs of his activity, however, which I merely shaed with all the readers of the daily press, I knew little of my former friend and companion.

One night--it was onthe twentieth of March, 1888--I was returning from a journey to a patient (for I had now returned to civil practice) when my way led me through Baker Street. As I passed the well-remembered door, which must always be associated in m mind with my wooing, and with the dark incidents of the Study in Scarlet, I was seized with a keen desire to see Homes again, and to know how he was employing his extraordinary powers. His rooms were brilliantly lit, and, even as Ilooked up, I saw his tall, spare figure pass twice in a dark silhouette against the blind. He was pacing the room swftly, eagerly, with his head sunk upon his chest and his hands clasped behind him. To me, who knew his every mood an habit, his attitude and manner told their own story. He was at work again. He had risen out of his drug-created drems and was hot upon the scent of some new problem. I rang the bell and was shown up to the chamber which had formerl been in part my own.

His manner was not effusive. It seldom was; but he was glad, I think, to see me. With hardl a word spoken, but with a kindly eye, he waved me to an armchair, threw across his case of cigars, and indicated a pirit case and a gasogene in the corner. Then he stood before the fire and looked me over in his singular introspectve fashion.

"Wedlock suits you," he remarked. "I think, Watson, that you have put on seven and a half pounds sinc I saw you."

"Seven!" I answered.

"Indeed, I should have thought a little more. Just a trifle more, I fancy, Wtson. And in practice again, I observe. You did not tell me that you intended to go into harness."

"Then, how do ou know?"

"I see it, I deduce it. How do I know that you have been getting yourself very wet lately, and that youhave a most clumsy and careless servant girl?"

"My dear Holmes," said I, "this is too much. You would certainly hve been burned, had you lived a few centuries ago. It is true that I had a country walk on Thursday and came home ina dreadful mess, but as I have changed my clothes I can't imagine how you deduce it. As to Mary Jane, she is incorriible, and my wife has given her notice, but there, again, I fail to see how you work it out."

He chuckled to himslf and rubbed his long, nervous hands together.

"It is simplicity itself," said he; "my eyes tell me that on the nside of your left shoe, just where the firelight strikes it, the leather is scored by six almost parallel cuts. Obvously they have been caused by someone who has very carelessly scraped round the edges of the sole in order to remov crusted mud from it. Hence, you see, my double deduction that you had been out in vile weather, and that you had a articularly malignant boot-slitting specimen of the London slavey. As to your practice, if a gentleman walks into myrooms smelling of iodoform, with a black mark of nitrate of silver upon his right forefinger, and a bulge on the rigt side of his top-hat to show where he has secreted his stethoscope, I must be dull, indeed, if I do not pronounce hm to be an active member of the medical profession."

I could not help laughing at the ease with which he explaine his process of deduction. "When I hear you give your reasons," I remarked, "the thing always appears to me to be soridiculously simple that I could easily do it myself, though at each successive instance of your reasoning I am baffed until you explain your process. And yet I believe that my eyes are as good as yours."

"Quite so," he answered,lighting a cigarette, and throwing himself down into an armchair. "You see, but you do not observe. The distinction s clear. For example, you have frequently seen the steps which lead up from the hall to this room."

"Frequently."

"How often?"

"Well, some hundreds of times."

"Then how many are there?"

"How many? I don't know."

"Qute so! You have not observed. And yet you have seen. That is just my point. Now, I know that there are seventeen stes, because I have both seen and observed. By the way, since you are interested in these little problems, and since yu are good enough to chronicle one or two of my trifling experiences, you may be interested in this." He threw over  sheet of thick, pink-tinted notepaper which had been lying open upon the table. "It came by the last post," said he "Read it aloud."

The note was undated, and without either signature or address.

"There will call upon you to-ight, at a quarter to eight o'clock," it said, "a gentleman who desires to consult you upon a matter of the very deeest moment. Your recent services to one of the royal houses of Europe have shown that you are one who may safely be rusted with matters which are of an importance which can hardly be exaggerated. This account of you we have from allquarters received. Be in your chamber then at that hour, and do not take it amiss if your visitor wear a mask."

"his is indeed a mystery," I remarked. "What do you imagine that it means?"

"I have no data yet. It is a capital mstake to theorise before one has data. Insensibly one begins to twist facts to suit theories, instead of theories tosuit facts. But the note itself. What do you deduce from it?"

I carefully examined the writing, and the paper upo which it was written.

"The man who wrote it was presumably well to do," I remarked, endeavouring to imitate my cmpanion's processes. "Such paper could not be bought under half a crown a packet. It is peculiarly strong and stiff.

"Peculiar--that is the very word," said Holmes. "It is not an English paper at all. Hold it up to the light."
I did so, and saw a large "E" with a small "g," a "P," and a large "G" with a small "t" woven into the texture of th paper.

"What do you make of that?" asked Holmes.

"The name of the maker, no doubt; or his monogram, rather."
"Not at all. The 'G' with the small 't' stands for 'Gesellschaft,' which is the German for 'Company.' It is a custmary contraction like our 'Co.' 'P,' of course, stands for 'Papier.' Now for the 'Eg.' Let us glance at our Continenal Gazetteer." He took down a heavy brown volume from his shelves. "Eglow, Eglonitz--here we are, Egria. It is in a erman-speaking country--in Bohemia, not far from Carlsbad. 'Remarkable as being the scene of the death of Wallenstei, and for its numerous glass-factories and paper-mills.' Ha, ha, my boy, what do you make of that?" His eyes sparkle, and he sent up a great blue triumphant cloud from his cigarette.

"The paper was made in Bohemia," I said.

"Pecisely. And the man who wrote the note is a German. Do you note the peculiar construction of the sentence--'This acount of you we have from all quarters received.' A Frenchman or Russian could not have written that. It is the Germa who is so uncourteous to his verbs. It only remains, therefore, to discover what is wanted by this German who write upon Bohemian paper and prefers wearing a mask to showing his face. And here he comes, if I am not mistaken, to reslve all our doubts."

As he spoke there was the sharp sound of horses' hoofs and grating wheels against the curb, ollowed by a sharp pull at the bell. Holmes whistled.

"A pair, by the sound," said he. "Yes," he continued, glancng out of the window. "A nice little brougham and a pair of beauties. A hundred and fifty guineas apiece. There's moey in this case, Watson, if there is nothing else."

"I think that I had better go, Holmes."

"Not a bit, Doctor Stay where you are. I am lost without my Boswell. And this promises to be interesting. It would be a pity to miss i."

"But your client--"

"Never mind him. I may want your help, and so may he. Here he comes. Sit down in that amchair, Doctor, and give us your best attention."

A slow and heavy step, which had been heard upon the stairs andin the passage, paused immediately outside the door. Then there was a loud and authoritative tap.

"Come in!" saidHolmes.

A man entered who could hardly have been less than six feet six inches in height, with the chest and limb of a Hercules. His dress was rich with a richness which would, in England, be looked upon as akin to bad taste. Heay bands of astrakhan were slashed across the sleeves and fronts of his double-breasted coat, while the deep blue clok which was thrown over his shoulders was lined with flame-coloured silk and secured at the neck with a brooch whichconsisted of a single flaming beryl. Boots which extended halfway up his calves, and which were trimmed at the tops ith rich brown fur, completed the impression of barbaric opulence which was suggested by his whole appearance. He caried a broad-brimmed hat in his hand, while he wore across the upper part of his face, extending down past the cheekones, a black vizard mask, which he had apparently adjusted that very moment, for his hand was still raised to it ashe entered. From the lower part of the face he appeared to be a man of strong character, with a thick, hanging lip, nd a long, straight chin suggestive of resolution pushed to the length of obstinacy.

"You had my note?" he asked ith a deep harsh voice and a strongly marked German accent. "I told you that I would call." He looked from one to th other of us, as if uncertain which to address.

"Pray take a seat," said Holmes. "This is my friend and colleague Dr. Watson, who is occasionally good enough to help me in my cases. Whom have I the honour to address?"

"You mayaddress me as the Count Von Kramm, a Bohemian nobleman. I understand that this gentleman, your friend, is a man of hnour and discretion, whom I may trust with a matter of the most extreme importance. If not, I should much prefer to ommunicate with you alone."

I rose to go, but Holmes caught me by the wrist and pushed me back into my chair. "Itis both, or none," said he. "You may say before this gentleman anything which you may say to me."

The Count shruged his broad shoulders. "Then I must begin," said he, "by binding you both to absolute secrecy for two years; at theend of that time the matter will be of no importance. At present it is not too much to say that it is of such weightit may have an influence upon European history."

"I promise," said Holmes.

"And I."

"You will excuse this msk," continued our strange visitor. "The august person who employs me wishes his agent to be unknown to you, and I my confess at once that the title by which I have just called myself is not exactly my own."

"None."

"M own seal."

"Bought."

We have tried and failed."

I am about to be married."

II.


At three o'clock precisely I was at Baker Street, but Holmes had not yetreturned. The landlady informed me that he had left the house shortly after eight o'clock in the morning. III.

Even after I became suspicious, I found it hard to think evil of such a dear, kind old clergyman But, you know, I have been trained as an actress myself. Male costume is nothing new to me. I often take advantage f the freedom which it gives. I sent John, the coachman, to watch you, ran upstairs, got into my walking clothes, asI call them, and came down just as you departed.

"Well, I followed you to your door, and so made sure that I was eally an object of interest to the celebrated Mr. Sherlock Holmes. Then I, rather imprudently, wished you good-night and started for the Temple to see my husband.

"We both thought the best resource was flight, when pursued by so ormidable an antagonist; so you will find the nest empty when you call to-morrow. As to the photograph, your client ay rest in peace. I love and am loved by a better man than he. The King may do what he will without hindrance from oe whom he has cruelly wronged. I keep it only to safeguard myself, and to preserve a weapon which will always secureme from any steps which he might take in the future. I leave a photograph which he might care to possess; and I reman, dear Mr. Sherlock Holmes,


"Very truly yours,              
"IRENE NORTON, nee ADLER."

"What a woman--oh,what a woman!" cried the King of Bohemia, when we had all three read this epistle. "Did I not tell you how quick andresolute she was? Would she not have made an admirable queen? Is it not a pity that she was not on my level?"

"Frm what I have seen of the lady, she seems, indeed, to be on a very different level to your Majesty," said Holmes colly. "I am sorry that I have not been able to bring your Majesty's business to a more successful conclusion."

"On he contrary, my dear sir," cried the King; "nothing could be more successful. I know that her word is inviolate. Thephotograph is now as safe as if it were in the fire."

"I am glad to hear your Majesty say so."

"I am immenselyindebted to you. Pray tell me in what way I can reward you. This ring--" He slipped an emerald snake ring from his fnger and held it out upon the palm of his hand.

"Your Majesty has something which I should value even more highly" said Holmes.

"You have but to name it."

"This photograph!"

The King stared at him in amazement.

"Irenes photograph!" he cried. "Certainly, if you wish it."

"I thank your Majesty. Then there is no more to be done in he matter. I have the honour to wish you a very good morning." He bowed, and, turning away without observing the han which the King had stretched out to him, he set off in my company for his chambers.

And that was how a great scadal threatened to affect the kingdom of Bohemia, and how the best plans of Mr. Sherlock Holmes were beaten by a woma's wit. He used to make merry over the cleverness of women, but I have not heard him do it of late. And when he speas of Irene Adler, or when he refers to her photograph, it is always under the honourable title of the woman.

ADVETURE  II.  THE RED-HEADED LEAGUE

ADVENTURE  III.  A CASE OF IDENTITY


"My dear fellow," said Sherlock Holmes as we sat on either ide of the fire in his lodgings at Baker Street, "life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man cold invent. We would not dare to conceive the things which are really mere commonplaces of existence. If we could flyout of that window hand in hand, hover over this great city, gently remove the roofs, and peep in at the queer thing which are going on, the strange coincidences, the plannings, the cross-purposes, the wonderful chains of events, woking through generations, and leading to the most outre results, it would make all fiction with its conventionalitie and foreseen conclusions most stale and unprofitable."

"And yet I am not convinced of it," I answered. "The case which come to light in the papers are, as a rule, bald enough, and vulgar enough. We have in our police reports reaism pushed to its extreme limits, and yet the result is, it must be confessed, neither fascinating nor artistic."
"A certain selection and discretion must be used in producing a realistic effect," remarked Holmes. "This is wantingin the police report, where more stress is laid, perhaps, upon the platitudes of the magistrate than upon the detail, which to an observer contain the vital essence of the whole matter. Depend upon it, there is nothing so unnatural s the commonplace."

I smiled and shook my head. "I can quite understand your thinking so." I said. "Of course, inyour position of unofficial adviser and helper to everybody who is absolutely puzzled, throughout three continents, ou are brought in contact with all that is strange and bizarre. But here"--I picked up the morning paper from the grund--"let us put it to a practical test. Here is the first heading upon which I come. 'A husband's cruelty to his wie.' There is half a column of print, but I know without reading it that it is all perfectly familiar to me. There is of course, the other woman, the drink, the push, the blow, the bruise, the sympathetic sister or landlady. The crudst of writers could invent nothing more crude."

"Indeed, your example is an unfortunate one for your argument," sid Holmes, taking the paper and glancing his eye down it. "This is the Dundas separation case, and, as it happens, Iwas engaged in clearing up some small points in connection with it. The husband was a teetotaler, there was no otherwoman, and the conduct complained of was that he had drifted into the habit of winding up every meal by taking out hs false teeth and hurling them at his wife, which, you will allow, is not an action likely to occur to the imaginatin of the average story-teller. Take a pinch of snuff, Doctor, and acknowledge that I have scored over you in your exmple."

He held out his snuffbox of old gold, with a great amethyst in the centre of the lid. Its splendour was insuch contrast to his homely ways and simple life that I could not help commenting upon it.

"Some ten or twelve, but none which presen any feature of interest. They are important, you understand, without being interesting. Indeed, I have found that i is usually in unimportant matters that there is a field for the observation, and for the quick analysis of cause an effect which gives the charm to an investigation. The larger crimes are apt to be the simpler, for the bigger the cime the more obvious, as a rule, is the motive. He had risen from his chair and was standing between the parted blinds gazing down into the dull neutral-tinte London street. When a woman has been seriously wronged by a ma she no longer oscillates, and the usual symptom is a broken bell wire. Here we may take it that there is a love mater, but that the maiden is not so much angry as perplexed, or grieved. But here she comes in person to resolve our dubts."

"o?"

"Well, you know father didn't like anything of the sort. He wouldn't have any visitors if he could help it, ad he used to say that a woman should be happy in her own family circle. But then, as I used to say to mother, a woma wants her own circle to begin with, and I had not got mine yet."

ADVENTURE IV. THE BOSCOMBE VALLY MYSTERY


We were seated at breakfast one morning, my wife and I, when the maid brought in a telegram. It was fom Sherlock Holmes and ran in this way:

"Have you a couple of days to spare? Have just been wired for from the wet of England in connection with Boscombe Valley tragedy. Shall be glad if you will come with me. Air and scenery perect. Leave Paddington by the 11:15."

"What do you say, dear?" said my wife, looking across at me. "Will you go?"
"I really don't know what to say. I have a fairly long list at present."

"Oh, Anstruther would do your work foryou. You have been looking a little pale lately. I think that the change would do you good, and you are always so inerested in Mr. Sherlock Holmes' cases."

"I should be ungrateful if I were not, seeing what I gained through one o them," I answered. "But if I am to go, I must pack at once, for I have only half an hour."

My experience of camplife in Afghanistan had at least had the effect of making me a prompt and ready traveller. My wants were few and simle, so that in less than the time stated I was in a cab with my valise, rattling away to Paddington Station. Sherloc Holmes was pacing up and down the platform, his tall, gaunt figure made even gaunter and taller by his long grey trvelling-cloak and close-fitting cloth cap.

"It is really very good of you to come, Watson," said he. "It makes a onsiderable difference to me, having someone with me on whom I can thoroughly rely. Local aid is always either worthess or else biassed. If you will keep the two corner seats I shall get the tickets."

We had the carriage to ourseves save for an immense litter of papers which Holmes had brought with him. Among these he rummaged and read, with itervals of note-taking and of meditation, until we were past Reading. Then he suddenly rolled them all into a gigantc ball and tossed them up onto the rack.

"Have you heard anything of the case?" he asked.

"Not a word. I have ot seen a paper for some days."

"The London press has not had very full accounts. I have just been looking throug all the recent papers in order to master the particulars. It seems, from what I gather, to be one of those simple cses which are so extremely difficult."

"That sounds a little paradoxical."

"But it is profoundly true. Singulaity is almost invariably a clue. The more featureless and commonplace a crime is, the more difficult it is to bring t home. In this case, however, they have established a very serious case against the son of the murdered man."

"I is a murder, then?"

"Well, it is conjectured to be so. I shall take nothing for granted until I have the opportuity of looking personally into it. I will explain the state of things to you, as far as I have been able to understad it, in a very few words.

"Boscombe Valley is a country district not very far from Ross, in Herefordshire. The lrgest landed proprietor in that part is a Mr. John Turner, who made his money in Australia and returned some years ao to the old country. One of the farms which he held, that of Hatherley, was let to Mr. Charles McCarthy, who was alo an ex-Australian. The men had known each other in the colonies, so that it was not unnatural that when they came t settle down they should do so as near each other as possible. Turner was apparently the richer man, so McCarthy becme his tenant but still remained, it seems, upon terms of perfect equality, as they were frequently together. McCarty had one son, a lad of eighteen, and Turner had an only daughter of the same age, but neither of them had wives livng. They appear to have avoided the society of the neighbouring English families and to have led retired lives, thouh both the McCarthys were fond of sport and were frequently seen at the race-meetings of the neighbourhood. McCarthykept two servants--a man and a girl. Turner had a considerable household, some half-dozen at the least. That is as mch as I have been able to gather about the families. Now for the facts.

"On June 3rd, that is, on Monday last, Mcarthy left his house at Hatherley about three in the afternoon and walked down to the Boscombe Pool, which is a smal lake formed by the spreading out of the stream which runs down the Boscombe Valley. He had been out with his servin-man in the morning at Ross, and he had told the man that he must hurry, as he had an appointment of importance to kep at three. From that appointment he never came back alive.

"From Hatherley Farmhouse to the Boscombe Pool is a uarter of a mile, and two people saw him as he passed over this ground. One was an old woman, whose name is not mentoned, and the other was William Crowder, a game-keeper in the employ of Mr. Turner. Both these witnesses depose thatMr. McCarthy was walking alone. The game-keeper adds that within a few minutes of his seeing Mr. McCarthy pass he ha seen his son, Mr. James McCarthy, going the same way with a gun under his arm. To the best of his belief, the fathe was actually in sight at the time, and the son was following him. He thought no more of the matter until he heard i the evening of the tragedy that had occurred.

"The two McCarthys were seen after the time when William Crowder, he game-keeper, lost sight of them. The Boscombe Pool is thickly wooded round, with just a fringe of grass and of reds round the edge. A girl of fourteen, Patience Moran, who is the daughter of the lodge-keeper of the Boscombe Valle estate, was in one of the woods picking flowers. She states that while she was there she saw, at the border of the ood and close by the lake, Mr. McCarthy and his son, and that they appeared to be having a violent quarrel. She hear Mr. McCarthy the elder using very strong language to his son, and she saw the latter raise up his hand as if to strke his father. She was so frightened by their violence that she ran away and told her mother when she reached home tat she had left the two McCarthys quarrelling near Boscombe Pool, and that she was afraid that they were going to fiht. She had hardly said the words when young Mr. McCarthy came running up to the lodge to say that he had found his ather dead in the wood, and to ask for the help of the lodge-keeper. "Look here, Watson," he said when the cloth was cleared "just sit down in thischair and let me preach to you for a little. I don't know quite what to do, and I should value your advice. Light a igar and let me expound."

"Pray do so."

"Well, now, in considering this case there are two points about young cCarthy's narrative which struck us both instantly, although they impressed me in his favour and you against him. On was the fact that his father should, according to his account, cry 'Cooee!' before seeing him. The other was his sigular dying reference to a rat. He mumbled several words, you understand, but that was all that caught the son's ear Now from this double point our research must commence, and we will begin it by presuming that what the lad says is bsolutely true."

"What of this 'Cooee!' then?"

"Well, obviously it could not have been meant for the son. The on, as far as he knew, was in Bristol. It was mere chance that he was within earshot. The 'Cooee!' was meant to attrct the attention of whoever it was that he had the appointment with. But 'Cooee' is a distinctly Australian cry, andone which is used between Australians. There is a strong presumption that the person whom McCarthy expected to meet im at Boscombe Pool was someone who had been in Australia."

"What of the rat, then?"

Sherlock Holmes took a foded paper from his pocket and flattened it out on the table. "This is a map of the Colony of Victoria," he said. "I ired to Bristol for it last night." He put his hand over part of the map. "What do you read?"

"ARAT," I read.

And now?" He raised his hand.

"BALLARAT."

"Quite so. That was the word the man uttered, and of which his son oly caught the last two syllables. He was trying to utter the name of his murderer. So and so, of Ballarat."

"It i wonderful!" I exclaimed.

"It is obvious. And now, you see, I had narrowed the field down considerably. The possesion of a grey garment was a third point which, granting the son's statement to be correct, was a certainty. We havecome now out of mere vagueness to the definite conception of an Australian from Ballarat with a grey cloak."

"Cerainly."

"And one who was at home in the district, for the pool can only be approached by the farm or by the estat, where strangers could hardly wander."

"Quite so."

"Then comes our expedition of to-day. By an examination ofthe ground I gained the trifling details which I gave to that imbecile Lestrade, as to the personality of the criminl."

"But how did you gain them?"

"You know my method. It is founded upon the observation of trifles."

"His eight I know that you might roughly judge from the length of his stride. His boots, too, might be told from their trces."

"Yes, they were peculiar boots."

"But his lameness?"

"The impression of his right foot was always les distinct than his left. He put less weight upon it. Why? Because he limped--he was lame."

"But his left-handednes."

"You were yourself struck by the nature of the injury as recorded by the surgeon at the inquest. The blow wasstruck from immediately behind, and yet was upon the left side. Now, how can that be unless it were by a left-handedman? He had stood behind that tree during the interview between the father and son. He had even smoked there. I foun the ash of a cigar, which my special knowledge of tobacco ashes enables me to pronounce as an Indian cigar. I have,as you know, devoted some attention to this, and written a little monograph on the ashes of 140 different varieties f pipe, cigar, and cigarette tobacco. Having found the ash, I then looked round and discovered the stump among the mss where he had tossed it. It was an Indian cigar, of the variety which are rolled in Rotterdam."

"And the cigar-older?"

"I could see that the end had not been in his mouth. Therefore he used a holder. The tip had been cut off not bitten off, but the cut was not a clean one, so I deduced a blunt pen-knife."

"Holmes," I said, "you have drwn a net round this man from which he cannot escape, and you have saved an innocent human life as truly as if you ha cut the cord which was hanging him. I see the direction in which all this points. The culprit is--"

"Mr. John Tuner," cried the hotel waiter, opening the door of our sitting-room, and ushering in a visitor.

The man who entere was a strange and impressive figure. His slow, limping step and bowed shoulders gave the appearance of decrepitude,and yet his hard, deep-lined, craggy features, and his enormous limbs showed that he was possessed of unusual strengh of body and of character. His tangled beard, grizzled hair, and outstanding, drooping eyebrows combined to give anair of dignity and power to his appearance, but his face was of an ashen white, while his lips and the corners of hi nostrils were tinged with a shade of blue. It was clear to me at a glance that he was in the grip of some deadly an chronic disease.

"Pray sit down on the sofa," said Holmes gently. "You had my note?"

"Yes, the lodge-keeper bought it up. You said that you wished to see me here to avoid scandal."

"I thought people would talk if I went tothe Hall."

"And why did you wish to see me?" He looked across at my companion with despair in his weary eyes, as hough his question was already answered.

"Yes," said Holmes, answering the look rather than the words. "It is so.I know all about McCarthy."

The old man sank his face in his hands. "God help me!" he cried. "But I would not hav let the young man come to harm. I give you my word that I would have spoken out if it went against him at the Assizs."

"I am glad to hear you say so," said Holmes gravely.

"I would have spoken now had it not been for my dear irl. It would break her heart--it will break her heart when she hears that I am arrested."

"It may not come to tht," said Holmes.

"What?"

"I am no official agent. I understand that it was your daughter who required my presece here, and I am acting in her interests. Young McCarthy must be got off, however."

"I am a dying man," said oldTurner. "I have had diabetes for years. My doctor says it is a question whether I shall live a month. Yet I would raher die under my own roof than in a gaol."

Holmes rose and sat down at the table with his pen in his hand and a bndle of paper before him. "Just tell us the truth," he said. "I shall jot down the facts. You will sign it, and Watsn here can witness it. Then I could produce your confession at the last extremity to save young McCarthy. I promise ou that I shall not use it unless it is absolutely needed."

"It's as well," said the old man; "it's a question whther I shall live to the Assizes, so it matters little to me, but I should wish to spare Alice the shock. And now I ill make the thing clear to you; it has been a long time in the acting, but will not take me long to tell.

"You ddn't know this dead man, McCarthy. He was a devil incarnate. I tell you that. God keep you out of the clutches of suh a man as he. His grip has been upon me these twenty years, and he has blasted my life. I'll tell you first how I cme to be in his power.

"It was in the early '60's at the diggings. I was a young chap then, hot-blooded and recklss, ready to turn my hand at anything; I got among bad companions, took to drink, had no luck with my claim, took tothe bush, and in a word became what you would call over here a highway robber. There were six of us, and we had a wid, free life of it, sticking up a station from time to time, or stopping the wagons on the road to the diggings. Blak Jack of Ballarat was the name I went under, and our party is still remembered in the colony as the Ballarat Gang.
"One day a gold convoy came down from Ballarat to Melbourne, and we lay in wait for it and attacked it. There weresix troopers and six of us, so it was a close thing, but we emptied four of their saddles at the first volley. Threeof our boys were killed, however, before we got the swag. I put my pistol to the head of the wagon-driver, who was tis very man McCarthy. I wish to the Lord that I had shot him then, but I spared him, though I saw his wicked little yes fixed on my face, as though to remember every feature. We got away with the gold, became wealthy men, and made or way over to England without being suspected. There I parted from my old pals and determined to settle down to a quet and respectable life. I bought this estate, which chanced to be in the market, and I set myself to do a little god with my money, to make up for the way in which I had earned it. I married, too, and though my wife died young she eft me my dear little Alice. Even when she was just a baby her wee hand seemed to lead me down the right path as noting else had ever done. In a word, I turned over a new leaf and did my best to make up for the past. All was going wll when McCarthy laid his grip upon me.

"I had gone up to town about an investment, and I met him in Regent Stree with hardly a coat to his back or a boot to his foot.

" 'Here we are, Jack,' says he, touching me on the arm; 'w'll be as good as a family to you. There's two of us, me and my son, and you can have the keeping of us. If you don'--it's a fine, law-abiding country is England, and there's always a policeman within hail.'

"Well, down they cameto the west country, there was no shaking them off, and there they have lived rent free on my best land ever since. here was no rest for me, no peace, no forgetfulness; turn where I would, there was his cunning, grinning face at my lbow. It grew worse as Alice grew up, for he soon saw I was more afraid of her knowing my past than of the police. Watever he wanted he must have, and whatever it was I gave him without question, land, money, houses, until at last h asked a thing which I could not give. He asked for Alice.

"His son, you see, had grown up, and so had my girl, ad as I was known to be in weak health, it seemed a fine stroke to him that his lad should step into the whole propery. But there I was firm. I would not have his cursed stock mixed with mine; not that I had any dislike to the lad, bt his blood was in him, and that was enough. I stood firm. McCarthy threatened. I braved him to do his worst. We wer to meet at the pool midway between our houses to talk it over.

"When I went down there I found him talking with is son, so I smoked a cigar and waited behind a tree until he should be alone. But as I listened to his talk all tha was black and bitter in me seemed to come uppermost. He was urging his son to marry my daughter with as little regad for what she might think as if she were a slut from off the streets. It drove me mad to think that I and all that  held most dear should be in the power of such a man as this. Could I not snap the bond? I was already a dying and adesperate man. Though clear of mind and fairly strong of limb, I knew that my own fate was sealed. But my memory andmy girl! Both could be saved if I could but silence that foul tongue. I did it, Mr. Holmes. I would do it again. Deely as I have sinned, I have led a life of martyrdom to atone for it. But that my girl should be entangled in the sam meshes which held me was more than I could suffer. I struck him down with no more compunction than if he had been sme foul and venomous beast. His cry brought back his son; but I had gained the cover of the wood, though I was force to go back to fetch the cloak which I had dropped in my flight. That is the true story, gentlemen, of all that occured."

"Well, it is not for me to judge you," said Holmes as the old man signed the statement which had been drawnout. "I pray that we may never be exposed to such a temptation."

"I pray not, sir. And what do you intend to do?"

"In view of your health, nothing. You are yourself aware that you will soon have to answer for your deed at a higer court than the Assizes. I will keep your confession, and if McCarthy is condemned I shall be forced to use it. Ifnot, it shall never be seen by mortal eye; and your secret, whether you be alive or dead, shall be safe with us."
"Farewell, then," said the old man solemnly. "Your own deathbeds, when they come, will be the easier for the thoughtof the peace which you have given to mine." Tottering and shaking in all his giant frame, he stumbled slowly from th room.

"God help us!" said Holmes after a long silence. "Why does fate play such tricks with poor, helpless worms I never hear of such a case as this that I do not think of Baxter's words, and say, 'There, but for the grace of Go, goes Sherlock Holmes.' "

James McCarthy was acquitted at the Assizes on the strength of a number of objections hich had been drawn out by Holmes and submitted to the defending counsel. Old Turner lived for seven months after ou interview, but he is now dead; and there is every prospect that the son and daughter may come to live happily togeter in ignorance of the black cloud which rests upon their past.

ADVENTURE  V.  THE FIVE ORANGE PIPS


When I gance over my notes and records of the Sherlock Holmes cases between the years '82 and '90, I am faced by so many whih present strange and interesting features that it is no easy matter to know which to choose and which to leave. Som, however, have already gained publicity through the papers, and others have not offered a field for those peculiar ualities which my friend possessed in so high a degree, and which it is the object of these papers to illustrate. Soe, too, have baffled his analytical skill, and would be, as narratives, beginnings without an ending, while others hve been but partially cleared up, and have their explanations founded rather upon conjecture and surmise than on tha absolute logical proof which was so dear to him. There is, however, one of these last which was so remarkable in it details and so startling in its results that I am tempted to give some account of it in spite of the fact that ther are points in connection with it which never have been, and probably never will be, entirely cleared up.

The yea '87 furnished us with a long series of cases of greater or less interest, of which I retain the records. Among my hadings under this one twelve months I find an account of the adventure of the Paradol Chamber, of the Amateur Mendicnt Society, who held a luxurious club in the lower vault of a furniture warehouse, of the facts connected with the lss of the British barque Sophy Anderson, of the singular adventures of the Grice Patersons in the island of Uffa, an finally of the Camberwell poisoning case. In the latter, as may be remembered, Sherlock Holmes was able, by windingup the dead man's watch, to prove that it had been wound up two hours before, and that therefore the deceased had goe to bed within that time--a deduction which was of the greatest importance in clearing up the case. All these I maysketch out at some future date, but none of them present such singular features as the strange train of circumstance which I have now taken up my pen to describe.

It was in the latter days of September, and the equinoctial gales ad set in with exceptional violence. All day the wind had screamed and the rain had beaten against the windows, so tat even here in the heart of great, hand-made London we were forced to raise our minds for the instant from the routne of life and to recognise the presence of those great elemental forces which shriek at mankind through the bars ofhis civilisation, like untamed beasts in a cage. As evening drew in, the storm grew higher and louder, and the wind ried and sobbed like a child in the chimney. Sherlock Holmes sat moodily at one side of the fireplace cross-indexinghis records of crime, while I at the other was deep in one of Clark Russell's fine sea-stories until the howl of thegale from without seemed to blend with the text, and the splash of the rain to lengthen out into the long swash of te sea waves. My wife was on a visit to her mother's, and for a few days I was a dweller once more in my old quartersat Baker Street.

"Why," said I, glancing up at my companion, "that was surely the bell. Who could come to-night? ome friend of yours, perhaps?"

"Except yourself I have none," he answered. "I do not encourage visitors."

"A cient, then?"

"If so, it is a serious case. Nothing less would bring a man out on such a day and at such an hour. ut I take it that it is more likely to be some crony of the landlady's."

Sherlock Holmes was wrong in his conjectre, however, for there came a step in the passage and a tapping at the door. He stretched out his long arm to turn te lamp away from himself and towards the vacant chair upon which a newcomer must sit.

"Come in!" said he.

The an who entered was young, some two-and-twenty at the outside, well-groomed and trimly clad, with something of refineent and delicacy in his bearing. The streaming umbrella which he held in his hand, and his long shining waterproof tld of the fierce weather through which he had come. He looked about him anxiously in the glare of the lamp, and I cold see that his face was pale and his eyes heavy, like those of a man who is weighed down with some great anxiety.

"I owe you an apology," he said, raising his golden pince-nez to his eyes. "I trust that I am not intruding. I fearthat I have brought some traces of the storm and rain into your snug chamber."

"Give me your coat and umbrella," aid Holmes. "They may rest here on the hook and will be dry presently. You have come up from the south-west, I see."

"Yes, from Horsham."

"That clay and chalk mixture which I see upon your toe caps is quite distinctive."

"I ave come for advice."

"That is easily got."

"And help."

"That is not always so easy."

"I have heard of yu, Mr. Holmes. I heard from Major Prendergast how you saved him in the Tankerville Club scandal."

"Ah, of course.He was wrongfully accused of cheating at cards."

"He said that you could solve anything."

"He said too much."
"That you are never beaten."

"I have been beaten four times--three times by men, and once by a woman."

"But hat is that compared with the number of your successes?"

"It is true that I have been generally successful."

"hen you may be so with me."

"I beg that you will draw your chair up to the fire and favour me with some details a to your case."

"It is no ordinary one."

"None of those which come to me are. I am the last court of appeal."
"And yet I question, sir, whether, in all your experience, you have ever listened to a more mysterious and inexpliable chain of events than those which have happened in my own family."

"You fill me with interest," said Holmes. Pray give us the essential facts from the commencement, and I can afterwards question you as to those details which eem to me to be most important."

The young man pulled his chair up and pushed his wet feet out towards the blaze.

"My name," said he, "is John Openshaw, but my own affairs have, as far as I can understand, little to do with thi awful business. It is a hereditary matter; so in order to give you an idea of the facts, I must go back to the commncement of the affair.

"You must know that my grandfather had two sons--my uncle Elias and my father Joseph. My fther had a small factory at Coventry, which he enlarged at the time of the invention of bicycling. He was a patenteeof the Openshaw unbreakable tire, and his business met with such success that he was able to sell it and to retire uon a handsome competence.

"My uncle Elias emigrated to America when he was a young man and became a planter in Flrida, where he was reported to have done very well. At the time of the war he fought in Jackson's army, and afterwars under Hood, where he rose to be a colonel. When Lee laid down his arms my uncle returned to his plantation, where e remained for three or four years. About 1869 or 1870 he came back to Europe and took a small estate in Sussex, nea Horsham. He had made a very considerable fortune in the States, and his reason for leaving them was his aversion tothe negroes, and his dislike of the Republican policy in extending the franchise to them. He was a singular man, fiece and quick-tempered, very foul-mouthed when he was angry, and of a most retiring disposition. During all the yearsthat he lived at Horsham, I doubt if ever he set foot in the town. He had a garden and two or three fields round hishouse, and there he would take his exercise, though very often for weeks on end he would never leave his room. He drnk a great deal of brandy and smoked very heavily, but he would see no society and did not want any friends, not eve his own brother.

"He didn't mind me; in fact, he took a fancy to me, for at the time when he saw me first I was  youngster of twelve or so. This would be in the year 1878, after he had been eight or nine years in England. He beged my father to let me live with him and he was very kind to me in his way. When he was sober he used to be fond of laying backgammon and draughts with me, and he would make me his representative both with the servants and with the radespeople, so that by the time that I was sixteen I was quite master of the house. I kept all the keys and could g where I liked and do what I liked, so long as I did not disturb him in his privacy. There was one singular exceptio, however, for he had a single room, a lumber-room up among the attics, which was invariably locked, and which he wold never permit either me or anyone else to enter. With a boy's curiosity I have peeped through the keyhole, but I ws never able to see more than such a collection of old trunks and bundles as would be expected in such a room.

"Oe day--it was in March, 1883--a letter with a foreign stamp lay upon the table in front of the colonel's plate. It ws not a common thing for him to receive letters, for his bills were all paid in ready money, and he had no friends o any sort. 'From India!' said he as he took it up, 'Pondicherry postmark! What can this be?' Opening it hurriedly, ot there jumped five little dried orange pips, which pattered down upon his plate. I began to laugh at this, but the augh was struck from my lips at the sight of his face. His lip had fallen, his eyes were protruding, his skin the coour of putty, and he glared at the envelope which he still held in his trembling hand, 'K. K. K.!' he shrieked, and hen, 'My God, my God, my sins have overtaken me!'

" 'What is it, uncle?' I cried.

" 'Death,' said he, and risig from the table he retired to his room, leaving me palpitating with horror. I took up the envelope and saw scrawledin red ink upon the inner flap, just above the gum, the letter K three times repeated. There was nothing else save te five dried pips. What could be the reason of his overpowering terror? I left the breakfast-table, and as I ascende the stair I met him coming down with an old rusty key, which must have belonged to the attic, in one hand, and a smll brass box, like a cashbox, in the other.

" 'They may do what they like, but I'll checkmate them still,' said h with an oath. 'Tell Mary that I shall want a fire in my room to-day, and send down to Fordham, the Horsham lawyer.'

"I did as he ordered, and when the lawyer arrived I was asked to step up to the room. The fire was burning brighty, and in the grate there was a mass of black, fluffy ashes, as of burned paper, while the brass box stood open and mpty beside it. As I glanced at the box I noticed, with a start, that upon the lid was printed the treble K which I ad read in the morning upon the envelope.

" 'I wish you, John,' said my uncle, 'to witness my will. I leave my esate, with all its advantages and all its disadvantages, to my brother, your father, whence it will, no doubt, descen to you. If you can enjoy it in peace, well and good! If you find you cannot, take my advice, my boy, and leave it t your deadliest enemy. I am sorry to give you such a two-edged thing, but I can't say what turn things are going to ake. Kindly sign the paper where Mr. Fordham shows you.'

"I signed the paper as directed, and the lawyer took it way with him. The singular incident made, as you may think, the deepest impression upon me, and I pondered over it ad turned it every way in my mind without being able to make anything of it. Yet I could not shake off the vague feelng of dread which it left behind, though the sensation grew less keen as the weeks passed and nothing happened to diturb the usual routine of our lives. I could see a change in my uncle, however. He drank more than ever, and he was ess inclined for any sort of society. Most of his time he would spend in his room, with the door locked upon the insde, but sometimes he would emerge in a sort of drunken frenzy and would burst out of the house and tear about the gaden with a revolver in his hand, screaming out that he was afraid of no man, and that he was not to be cooped up, lie a sheep in a pen, by man or devil. When these hot fits were over, however, he would rush tumultuously in at the dor and lock and bar it behind him, like a man who can brazen it out no longer against the terror which lies at the rots of his soul. At such times I have seen his face, even on a cold day, glisten with moisture, as though it were newraised from a basin.

"Well, to come to an end of the matter, Mr. Holmes, and not to abuse your patience, there cae a night when he made one of those drunken sallies from which he never came back. We found him, when we went to seach for him, face downward in a little green-scummed pool, which lay at the foot of the garden. There was no sign of ny violence, and the water was but two feet deep, so that the jury, having regard to his known eccentricity, broughtin a verdict of 'suicide.' But I, who knew how he winced from the very thought of death, had much ado to persuade myelf that he had gone out of his way to meet it. The matter passed, however, and my father entered into possession ofthe estate, and of some $14,000, which lay to his credit at the bank."

"One moment," Holmes interposed, "your staement is, I foresee, one of the most remarkable to which I have ever listened. Let me have the date of the receptionby your uncle of the letter, and the date of his supposed suicide."

"The letter arrived on March 10, 1883. His deth was seven weeks later, upon the night of May 2nd."

"Thank you. Pray proceed."

"When my father took over theHorsham property, he, at my request, made a careful examination of the attic, which had been always locked up. We fond the brass box there, although its contents had been destroyed. On the inside of the cover was a paper label, withthe initials of K. K. K. repeated upon it, and 'Letters, memoranda, receipts, and a register' written beneath. These we presume, indicated the nature of the papers which had been destroyed by Colonel Openshaw. For the rest, there wa nothing of much importance in the attic save a great many scattered papers and note-books bearing upon my uncle's lfe in America. Some of them were of the war time and showed that he had done his duty well and had borne the repute f a brave soldier. Others were of a date during the reconstruction of the Southern states, and were mostly concernedwith politics, for he had evidently taken a strong part in opposing the carpet-bag politicians who had been sent dow from the North.

"Well, it was the beginning of '84 when my father came to live at Horsham, and all went as well s possible with us until the January of '85. On the fourth day after the new year I heard my father give a sharp cryof surprise as we sat together at the breakfast-table. There he was, sitting with a newly opened envelope in one han and five dried orange pips in the outstretched palm of the other one. He had always laughed at what he called my cok-and-bull story about the colonel, but he looked very scared and puzzled now that the same thing had come upon himslf.

" 'Why, what on earth does this mean, John?' he stammered.

"My heart had turned to lead. 'It is K. K. K.,'said I.

"He looked inside the envelope. 'So it is,' he cried. 'Here are the very letters. But what is this writte above them?'

" 'Put the papers on the sundial,' I read, peeping over his shoulder.

" 'What papers? What sundil?' he asked.

" 'The sundial in the garden. There is no other,' said I; 'but the papers must be those that are detroyed.'

" 'Pooh!' said he, gripping hard at his courage. 'We are in a civilised land here, and we can't have tomoolery of this kind. Where does the thing come from?'

" 'From Dundee,' I answered, glancing at the postmark.

"'Some preposterous practical joke,' said he. 'What have I to do with sundials and papers? I shall take no notice of uch nonsense.'

" 'I should certainly speak to the police,' I said.

" 'And be laughed at for my pains. Nothing f the sort.'

" 'Then let me do so?'

" 'No, I forbid you. I won't have a fuss made about such nonsense.'

"Itwas in vain to argue with him, for he was a very obstinate man. I went about, however, with a heart which was full o forebodings.

"On the third day after the coming of the letter my father went from home to visit an old friend ofhis, Major Freebody, who is in command of one of the forts upon Portsdown Hill. I was glad that he should go, for itseemed to me that he was farther from danger when he was away from home. In that, however, I was in error. Upon the econd day of his absence I received a telegram from the major, imploring me to come at once. My father had fallen ovr one of the deep chalk-pits which abound in the neighbourhood, and was lying senseless, with a shattered skull. I hrried to him, but he passed away without having ever recovered his consciousness. He had, as it appears, been returnng from Fareham in the twilight, and as the country was unknown to him, and the chalk-pit unfenced, the jury had no esitation in bringing in a verdict of 'death from accidental causes.' Carefully as I examined every fact connected wth his death, I was unable to find anything which could suggest the idea of murder. There were no signs of violence,no footmarks, no robbery, no record of strangers having been seen upon the roads. And yet I need not tell you that m mind was far from at ease, and that I was well-nigh certain that some foul plot had been woven round him.

"In ths sinister way I came into my inheritance. You will ask me why I did not dispose of it? I answer, because I was wellconvinced that our troubles were in some way dependent upon an incident in my uncle's life, and that the danger woul be as pressing in one house as in another.

"It was in January, '85, that my poor father met his end, and two yeas and eight months have elapsed since then. During that time I have lived happily at Horsham, and I had begun to hop that this curse had passed away from the family, and that it had ended with the last generation. I had begun to tak comfort too soon, however; yesterday morning the blow fell in the very shape in which it had come upon my father."
The young man took from his waistcoat a crumpled envelope, and turning to the table he shook out upon it five litte dried orange pips.

"This is the envelope," he continued. "The postmark is London--eastern division. Within are he very words which were upon my father's last message: 'K. K. K.'; and then 'Put the papers on the sundial.' "

"hat have you done?" asked Holmes.

"Nothing."

"Nothing?"

"To tell the truth"--he sank his face into his thin white hands--"I have felt helpless. I have felt like one of those poor rabbits when the snake is writhing towards i. I seem to be in the grasp of some resistless, inexorable evil, which no foresight and no precautions can guard aganst."

"I have seen the police."

"Ah!"

"But they listened to my story with a smile. I a convinced that the inspector has formed the opinion that the letters are all practical jokes, and that the deaths o my relations were really accidents, as the jury stated, and were not to be connected with the warnings."

Holmes hook his clenched hands in the air. "Incredible imbecility!" he cried.

"No. His orders were to stay in the huse."

Again Holmes raved in the air.

"I have some remembrance," said he, "that on the day when my ucle burned the papers I observed that the small, unburned margins which lay amid the ashes were of this particular clour. Beyond the menton of pips, I do not see that it helps us much. I think myself that it is a page from some private diary. The writin is undoubtedly my uncle's."

Holmes moved the lamp, and we both bent over the sheet of paper, which showed by itsragged edge that it had indeed been torn from a book. It was headed, "March, 1869," and beneath were the following eigmatical notices:

"4th. Hudson came. Same old platform.

"7th. Set the pips on McCauley, Paramore, and

       John Swain, of St. Augustine.

"9th. McCauley cleared.

"10th. John Swain cleared.

"12th. Visited Paramore All well."

You must also put in a note to say tht all the other papers were burned by your uncle, and that this is the only one which remains. You must assert that n such words as will carry conviction with them. Having done this, you must at once put the box out upon the sundial as directed. Do you understand?"

"Do not think of revenge, or anything of the sort, at present. Ithink that we may gain that by means of the law; but we have our web to weave, while theirs is already woven. The fist consideration is to remove the pressing danger which threatens you. The second is to clear up the mystery and to unish the guilty parties."

"It is not yet nine. The streets will be crowde, so I trust that you may be in safety. And yet you cannot guard yourself too closely."

"I am armed."

"That iswell. To-morrow I shall set to work upon your case."

He shook hands with us and took his leave. utside the wind still screamed and the rain splashed and pattered against the windows. This strange, wild story seemd to have come to us from amid the mad elements--blown in upon us like a sheet of sea-weed in a gale--and now to hav been reabsorbed by them once more.

Sherlock Holmes sat for some time in silence, with his head sunk forward and is eyes bent upon the red glow of the fire. Then he lit his pipe, and leaning back in his chair he watched the blue moke-rings as they chased each other up to the ceiling.

"Then what are they? Who is this K. K. K., and why does he pursue this unhappy family?"

Sherlock Holmes closed his eyes and placed his elbows upon the arms of his chair, with his finger-tips together. The ideal reasoner," he remarked, "would, when he had once been shown a single fact in all its bearings, deduce fromit not only all the chain of events which led up to it but also all the results which would follow from it. As Cuvie could correctly describe a whole animal by the contemplation of a single bone, so the observer who has thoroughly uderstood one link in a series of incidents should be able to accurately state all the other ones, both before and afer. We have not yet grasped the results which the reason alone can attain to. Problems may be solved in the study whch have baffled all those who have sought a solution by the aid of their senses. To carry the art, however, to its hghest pitch, it is necessary that the reasoner should be able to utilise all the facts which have come to his knowlege; and this in itself implies, as you will readily see, a possession of all knowledge, which, even in these days offree education and encyclopaedias, is a somewhat rare accomplishment. It is not so impossible, however, that a man sould possess all knowledge which is likely to be useful to him in his work, and this I have endeavoured in my case t do. If I remember rightly, you on one occasion, in the early days of our friendship, defined my limits in a very prcise fashion."

"Yes," I answered, laughing. "It was a singular document. Philosophy, astronomy, and politics weremarked at zero, I remember. Botany variable, geology profound as regards the mud-stains from any region within fiftymiles of town, chemistry eccentric, anatomy unsystematic, sensational literature and crime records unique, violin-plyer, boxer, swordsman, lawyer, and self-poisoner by cocaine and tobacco. Those, I think, were the main points of my nalysis."

Holmes grinned at the last item. "Well," he said, "I say now, as I said then, that a man should keep hi little brain-attic stocked with all the furniture that he is likely to use, and the rest he can put away in the lumer-room of his library, where he can get it if he wants it. Now, for such a case as the one which has been submittedto us to-night, we need certainly to muster all our resources. Kindly hand me down the letter K of the American Encylopaedia which stands upon the shelf beside you. Thank you. Now let us consider the situation and see what may be deuced from it. In the first place, we may start with a strong presumption that Colonel Openshaw had some very strong eason for leaving America. Men at his time of life do not change all their habits and exchange willingly the charmin climate of Florida for the lonely life of an English provincial town. His extreme love of solitude in England suggets the idea that he was in fear of someone or something, so we may assume as a working hypothesis that it was fear o someone or something which drove him from America. As to what it was he feared, we can only deduce that by considerng the formidable letters which were received by himself and his successors. Did you remark the postmarks of those ltters?"

"The first was from Pondicherry, the second from Dundee, and the third from London."

"From East London What do you deduce from that?"

"They are all seaports. That the writer was on board of a ship."

"Excellent. W have already a clue. There can be no doubt that the probability--the strong probability--is that the writer was on oard of a ship. And now let us consider another point. In the case of Pondicherry, seven weeks elapsed between the treat and its fulfilment, in Dundee it was only some three or four days. Does that suggest anything?"

"A greater dstance to travel."

"But the letter had also a greater distance to come."

"Then I do not see the point."

"Thre is at least a presumption that the vessel in which the man or men are is a sailing-ship. It looks as if they alwas send their singular warning or token before them when starting upon their mission. You see how quickly the deed folowed the sign when it came from Dundee. If they had come from Pondicherry in a steamer they would have arrived almot as soon as their letter. But, as a matter of fact, seven weeks elapsed. I think that those seven weeks representedthe difference between the mail-boat which brought the letter and the sailing vessel which brought the writer."

"t is possible."

"More than that. It is probable. And now you see the deadly urgency of this new case, and why I uged young Openshaw to caution. The blow has always fallen at the end of the time which it would take the senders to ravel the distance. But this one comes from London, and therefore we cannot count upon delay."

"Good God!" I crie. "What can it mean, this relentless persecution?"

"The papers which Openshaw carried are obviously of vital impotance to the person or persons in the sailing-ship. I think that it is quite clear that there must be more than one f them. A single man could not have carried out two deaths in such a way as to deceive a coroner's jury. There must ave been several in it, and they must have been men of resource and determination. Their papers they mean to have, b the holder of them who it may. In this way you see K. K. K. ceases to be the initials of an individual and becomes he badge of a society."

"But of what society?"

"Have you never--" said Sherlock Holmes, bending forward and siking his voice--"have you never heard of the Ku Klux Klan?"

"I never have."

Holmes turned over the leaves of te book upon his knee. "Here it is," said he presently:

" 'Ku Klux Klan. A name derived from the fanciful resemblace to the sound produced by cocking a rifle. This terrible secret society was formed by some ex-Confederate soldiersin the Southern states after the Civil War, and it rapidly formed local branches in different parts of the country, otably in Tennessee, Louisiana, the Carolinas, Georgia, and Florida. Its power was used for political purposes, prinipally for the terrorising of the negro voters and the murdering and driving from the country of those who were oppoed to its views. Its outrages were usually preceded by a warning sent to the marked man in some fantastic but generaly recognised shape--a sprig of oak-leaves in some parts, melon seeds or orange pips in others. On receiving this th victim might either openly abjure his former ways, or might fly from the country. If he braved the matter out, deat would unfailingly come upon him, and usually in some strange and unforeseen manner. So perfect was the organisationof the society, and so systematic its methods, that there is hardly a case upon record where any man succeeded in brving it with impunity, or in which any of its outrages were traced home to the perpetrators. For some years the orgaisation flourished in spite of the efforts of the United States government and of the better classes of the communit in the South. Eventually, in the year 1869, the movement rather suddenly collapsed, although there have been sporadc outbreaks of the same sort since that date.'

"You will observe," said Holmes, laying down the volume, "that thesudden breaking up of the society was coincident with the disappearance of Openshaw from America with their papers. t may well have been cause and effect. It is no wonder that he and his family have some of the more implacable spiris upon their track. You can understand that this register and diary may implicate some of the first men in the South and that there may be many who will not sleep easy at night until it is recovered."

"Then the page we have seen-"

"Is such as we might expect. It ran, if I remember right, 'sent the pips to A, B, and C'--that is, sent the socety's warning to them. Then there are successive entries that A and B cleared, or left the country, and finally thatC was visited, with, I fear, a sinister result for C. Well, I think, Doctor, that we may let some light into this dak place, and I believe that the only chance young Openshaw has in the meantime is to do what I have told him. There s nothing more to be said or to be done to-night, so hand me over my violin and let us try to forget for half an hou the miserable weather and the still more miserable ways of our fellow men."

It had cleared in the morning, and te sun was shining with a subdued brightness through the dim veil which hangs over the great city. Sherlock Holmes wa already at breakfast when I came down.

"You will excuse me for not waiting for you," said he; "I have, I foresee a very busy day before me in looking into this case of young Openshaw's."

"What steps will you take?" I asked.

"It will very much depend upon the results of my first inquiries. I may have to go down to Horsham, after all."

You will not go there first?"

"No, I shall commence with the City. Just ring the bell and the maid will bring up our coffee."

As I waited, I lifted the unopened newspaper from the table and glanced my eye over it. It rested upn a heading which sent a chill to my heart.

"My eye cught the name of Openshaw, and the heading 'Tragedy Near Waterloo Bridge.' Here is the account:

" 'Between nine ad ten last night Police-Constable Cook, of the H Division, on duty near Waterloo Bridge, heard a cry for help and a plash in the water. The night, however, was extremely dark and stormy, so that, in spite of the help of several passrs-by, it was quite impossible to effect a rescue.
