HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES




PART I. THE COLONIAL PERIOD




CHAPTER I

THE GREAT MIGRATON TO AMERICA


The tide of migration that set in toward the shores of North America
during the early years of te seventeenth century was but one phase in
the restless and eternal movement of mankind upon the surface of the
eath. The ancient Greeks flung out their colonies in every direction,
westward as far as Gaul, across the Mediterranen, and eastward into
Asia Minor, perhaps to the very confines of India. The Romans, supported
by their armies and heir government, spread their dominion beyond the
narrow lands of Italy until it stretched from the heather of Scotand to
the sands of Arabia. The Teutonic tribes, from their home beyond the
Danube and the Rhine, poured into the mpire of the Caesars and made the
beginnings of modern Europe. Of this great sweep of races and empires
the settleent of America was merely a part. And it was, moreover, only
one aspect of the expansion which finally carried the eoples, the
institutions, and the trade of Europe to the very ends of the earth.

In one vital point, it must be oted, American colonization differed
from that of the ancients. The Greeks usually carried with them
affection forthe government they left behind and sacred fire from the
altar of the parent city; but thousands of the immigrants ho came to
America disliked the state and disowned the church of the mother
country. They established compacts of overnment for themselves and set
up altars of their own. They sought not only new soil to till but also
political nd religious liberty for themselves and their children.


THE AGENCIES OF AMERICAN COLONIZATION

It was no ligh matter for the English to cross three thousand miles of
water and found homes in the American wilderness at the opning of the
seventeenth century. Ships, tools, and supplies called for huge outlays
of money. Stores had to be furished in quantities sufficient to sustain
the life of the settlers until they could gather harvests of their own.
rtisans and laborers of skill and industry had to be induced to risk
the hazards of the new world. Soldiers were reuired for defense and
mariners for the exploration of inland waters. Leaders of good judgment,
adept in managing mn, had to be discovered. Altogether such an
enterprise demanded capital larger than the ordinary merchant or
gentlman could amass and involved risks more imminent than he dared to
assume. Though in later days, after initial testshad been made, wealthy
proprietors were able to establish colonies on their own account, it was
the corporation tht furnished the capital and leadership in the
beginning.

=The Trading Company.=--English pioneers in explorationfound an
instrument for colonization in companies of merchant adventurers, which
had long been employed in carryin on commerce with foreign countries.
Such a corporation was composed of many persons of different ranks of
society-noblemen, merchants, and gentlemen--who banded together for a
particular undertaking, each contributing a sum of mney and sharing in
the profits of the venture. It was organized under royal authority; it
received its charter, it grant of land, and its trading privileges from
the king and carried on its operations under his supervision and
cntrol. The charter named all the persons originally included in the
corporation and gave them certain powers in themanagement of its
affairs, including the right to admit new members. The company was in
fact a little government st up by the king. When the members of the
corporation remained in England, as in the case of the Virginia Company,they operated through agents sent to the colony. When they came over the
seas themselves and settled in America, asin the case of Massachusetts,
they became the direct government of the country they possessed. The
stockholders inthat instance became the voters and the governor, the
chief magistrate.

[Illustration: JOHN WINTHROP, GOVERNOR O THE MASSACHUSETTS BAY
COMPANY]

Four of the thirteen colonies in America owed their origins to the
trading corpration. It was the London Company, created by King James I,
in 1606, that laid during the following year the foundaions of Virginia
at Jamestown. It was under the auspices of their West India Company,
chartered in 1621, that the utch planted the settlements of the New
Netherland in the valley of the Hudson. The founders of Massachusetts
werePuritan leaders and men of affairs whom King Charles I incorporated
in 1629 under the title: "The governor and compny of the Massachusetts
Bay in New England." In this case the law did but incorporate a group
drawn together by reigious ties. "We must be knit together as one man,"
wrote John Winthrop, the first Puritan governor in America. Farto the
south, on the banks of the Delaware River, a Swedish commercial company
in 1638 made the beginnings of a setlement, christened New Sweden; it
was destined to pass under the rule of the Dutch, and finally under the
rule ofWilliam Penn as the proprietary colony of Delaware.

In a certain sense, Georgia may be included among the "compan
colonies." It was, however, originally conceived by the moving spirit,
James Oglethorpe, as an asylum for poor me, especially those imprisoned
for debt. To realize this humane purpose, he secured from King George
II, in 1732, aroyal charter uniting several gentlemen, including
himself, into "one body politic and corporate," known as the "Trstees
for establishing the colony of Georgia in America." In the structure of
their organization and their methodsof government, the trustees did not
differ materially from the regular companies created for trade and
colonizatio. Though their purposes were benevolent, their transactions
had to be under the forms of law and according to the rles of business.

=The Religious Congregation.=--A second agency which figured largely in
the settlement of Ameria was the religious brotherhood, or
congregation, of men and women brought together in the bonds of a common
religous faith. By one of the strange fortunes of history, this
institution, founded in the early days of Christianity, roved to be a
potent force in the origin and growth of self-government in a land far
away from Galilee. "And the mltitude of them that believed were of one
heart and of one soul," we are told in the Acts describing the Church atJerusalem. "We are knit together as a body in a most sacred covenant of
the Lord ... by virtue of which we hold ourelves strictly tied to all
care of each other's good and of the whole," wrote John Robinson, a
leader among the Pigrims who founded their tiny colony of Plymouth in
1620. The Mayflower Compact, so famous in American history, was ut a
written and signed agreement, incorporating the spirit of obedience to
the common good, which served as a guie to self-government until
Plymouth was annexed to Massachusetts in 1691.

[Illustration: THE ORIGINAL GRANTS]
Three other colonies, all of which retained their identity until the eve
of the American Revolution, likewise spran directly from the
congregations of the faithful: Rhode Island, Connecticut, and New
Hampshire, mainly offshoots fom Massachusetts. They were founded by
small bodies of men and women, "united in solemn covenants with the
Lord," ho planted their settlements in the wilderness. Not until many a
year after Roger Williams and Anne Hutchinson condcted their followers
to the Narragansett country was Rhode Island granted a charter of
incorporation (1663) by thecrown. Not until long after the congregation
of Thomas Hooker from Newtown blazed the way into the Connecticut Rive
Valley did the king of England give Connecticut a charter of its own
(1662) and a place among the colonies. Half  century elapsed before the
towns laid out beyond the Merrimac River by emigrants from Massachusetts
were formed ito the royal province of New Hampshire in 1679.

Even when Connecticut was chartered, the parchment and sealing wa of
the royal lawyers did but confirm rights and habits of self-government
and obedience to law previously establihed by the congregations. The
towns of Hartford, Windsor, and Wethersfield had long lived happily
under their "Funamental Orders" drawn up by themselves in 1639; so had
the settlers dwelt peacefully at New Haven under their "Fundmental
Articles" drafted in the same year. The pioneers on the Connecticut
shore had no difficulty in agreeing tha "the Scriptures do hold forth a
perfect rule for the direction and government of all men."

=The Proprietor.=--Athird and very important colonial agency was the
proprietor, or proprietary. As the name, associated with the word"property," implies, the proprietor was a person to whom the king
granted property in lands in North America to hav, hold, use, and enjoy
for his own benefit and profit, with the right to hand the estate down
to his heirs in perptual succession. The proprietor was a rich and
powerful person, prepared to furnish or secure the capital, collect he
ships, supply the stores, and assemble the settlers necessary to found
and sustain a plantation beyond the seas Sometimes the proprietor
worked alone. Sometimes two or more were associated like partners in the
common undertakng.

Five colonies, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and the Carolinas,
owe their formal origins, though not aways their first settlements, nor
in most cases their prosperity, to the proprietary system. Maryland,
establishedin 1634 under a Catholic nobleman, Lord Baltimore, and
blessed with religious toleration by the act of 1649, flourihed under
the mild rule of proprietors until it became a state in the American
union. New Jersey, beginning its caeer under two proprietors, Berkeley
and Carteret, in 1664, passed under the direct government of the crown
in 1702 Pennsylvania was, in a very large measure, the product of the
generous spirit and tireless labors of its first prorietor, the leader
of the Friends, William Penn, to whom it was granted in 1681 and in
whose family it remained unil 1776. The two Carolinas were first
organized as one colony in 1663 under the government and patronage of
eight roprietors, including Lord Clarendon; but after more than half a
century both became royal provinces governed by th king.

[Illustration: WILLIAM PENN, PROPRIETOR OF PENNSYLVANIA]


THE COLONIAL PEOPLES

=The English.=--In ladership and origin the thirteen colonies, except
New York and Delaware, were English. During the early days of all save
these two, the main, if not the sole, current of immigration was from
England. The colonists came from everywalk of life. They were men,
women, and children of "all sorts and conditions." The major portion
were yeomen, or mall land owners, farm laborers, and artisans. With
them were merchants and gentlemen who brought their stocks of gods or
their fortunes to the New World. Scholars came from Oxford and
Cambridge to preach the gospel or to teach. ow and then the son of an
English nobleman left his baronial hall behind and cast his lot with
America. The peoplerepresented every religious faith--members of the
Established Church of England; Puritans who had labored to reformthat
church; Separatists, Baptists, and Friends, who had left it altogether;
and Catholics, who clung to the religon of their fathers.

New England was almost purely English. During the years between 1629 and
1640, the period o arbitrary Stuart government, about twenty thousand
Puritans emigrated to America, settling in the colonies of the ar
North. Although minor additions were made from time to time, the greater
portion of the New England people sprag from this original stock.
Virginia, too, for a long time drew nearly all her immigrants from
England alone. Not ntil the eve of the Revolution did other
nationalities, mainly the Scotch-Irish and Germans, rival the English in
umbers.

The populations of later English colonies--the Carolinas, New York,
Pennsylvania, and Georgia--while reciving a steady stream of
immigration from England, were constantly augmented by wanderers from
the older settlemens. New York was invaded by Puritans from New England
in such numbers as to cause the Anglican clergymen there to laent that
"free thinking spreads almost as fast as the Church." North Carolina was
first settled toward the norther border by immigrants from Virginia.
Some of the North Carolinians, particularly the Quakers, came all the
way fro New England, tarrying in Virginia only long enough to learn how
little they were wanted in that Anglican colony.

=The Scotch-Irish.=--Next to the English in numbers and influence were
the Scotch-Irish, Presbyterians in belief, nglish in tongue. Both
religious and economic reasons sent them across the sea. Their Scotch
ancestors, in the day of Cromwell, had settled in the north of Ireland
whence the native Irish had been driven by the conqueror's sword.There
the Scotch nourished for many years enjoying in peace their own form of
religion and growing prosperous in te manufacture of fine linen and
woolen cloth. Then the blow fell. Toward the end of the seventeenth
century their eligious worship was put under the ban and the export of
their cloth was forbidden by the English Parliament. Withi two decades
twenty thousand Scotch-Irish left Ulster alone, for America; and all
during the eighteenth century th migration continued to be heavy.
Although no exact record was kept, it is reckoned that the Scotch-Irish
and the cotch who came directly from Scotland, composed one-sixth of
the entire American population on the eve of the Revoltion.

[Illustration: SETTLEMENTS OF GERMAN AND SCOTCH-IRISH
IMMIGRANTS]

These newcomers in America made theirhomes chiefly in New Jersey,
Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, and the Carolinas. Coming late upon
the scene, theyfound much of the land immediately upon the seaboard
already taken up. For this reason most of them became frontierpeople
settling the interior and upland regions. There they cleared the land,
laid out their small farms, and workd as "sturdy yeomen on the soil,"
hardy, industrious, and independent in spirit, sharing neither the
luxuries of te rich planters nor the easy life of the leisurely
merchants. To their agriculture they added woolen and linen
manfactures, which, flourishing in the supple fingers of their tireless
women, made heavy inroads upon the trade of th English merchants in
the colonies. Of their labors a poet has sung:

        "O, willing hands to toil;
    Strng natures tuned to the harvest-song and bound to the kindly soil;
    Bold pioneers for the wilderness, defenders n the field."

=The Germans.=--Third among the colonists in order of numerical
importance were the Germans. From he very beginning, they appeared in
colonial records. A number of the artisans and carpenters in the first
Jameston colony were of German descent. Peter Minuit, the famous
governor of New Motherland, was a German from Wesel on th Rhine, and
Jacob Leisler, leader of a popular uprising against the provincial
administration of New York, was a Grman from Frankfort-on-Main. The
wholesale migration of Germans began with the founding of Pennsylvania.
Penn was iligent in searching for thrifty farmers to cultivate his
lands and he made a special effort to attract peasants frm the Rhine
country. A great association, known as the Frankfort Company, bought
more than twenty thousand acres fom him and in 1684 established a
center at Germantown for the distribution of German immigrants. In old
New York, hinebeck-on-the-Hudson became a similar center for
distribution. All the way from Maine to Georgia inducements wereoffered
to the German farmers and in nearly every colony were to be found, in
time, German settlements. In fact th migration became so large that
German princes were frightened at the loss of so many subjects and
England was alamed by the influx of foreigners into her overseas
dominions. Yet nothing could stop the movement. By the end of the
colonial period, the number of Germans had risen to more than two
hundred thousand.

The majority of them were Potestants from the Rhine region, and South
Germany. Wars, religious controversies, oppression, and poverty drove
tem forth to America. Though most of them were farmers, there were also
among them skilled artisans who contributed o the rapid growth of
industries in Pennsylvania. Their iron, glass, paper, and woolen mills,
dotted here and ther among the thickly settled regions, added to the
wealth and independence of the province.

[Illustration: _From a old print_

A GLIMPSE OF OLD GERMANTOWN]

Unlike the Scotch-Irish, the Germans did not speak the language of th
original colonists or mingle freely with them. They kept to themselves,
built their own schools, founded their ow newspapers, and published
their own books. Their clannish habits often irritated their neighbors
and led to occasonal agitations against "foreigners." However, no
serious collisions seem to have occurred; and in the days of theRevolution, German soldiers from Pennsylvania fought in the patriot
armies side by side with soldiers from the Englsh and Scotch-Irish
sections.

=Other Nationalities.=--Though the English, the Scotch-Irish, and the
Germans mad up the bulk of the colonial population, there were other
racial strains as well, varying in numerical importance bt contributing
their share to colonial life.

From France came the Huguenots fleeing from the decree of the king hich
inflicted terrible penalties upon Protestants.

From "Old Ireland" came thousands of native Irish, Celtic inrace and
Catholic in religion. Like their Scotch-Irish neighbors to the north,
they revered neither the governmentnor the church of England imposed
upon them by the sword. How many came we do not know, but shipping
records of th colonial period show that boatload after boatload left
the southern and eastern shores of Ireland for the New Worl.
Undoubtedly thousands of their passengers were Irish of the native
stock. This surmise is well sustained by the onstant appearance of
Celtic names in the records of various colonies.

[Illustration:_From an old print_

OLD UTCH FORT AND ENGLISH CHURCH NEAR ALBANY]

The Jews, then as ever engaged in their age-long battle for religious
nd economic toleration, found in the American colonies, not complete
liberty, but certainly more freedom than they njoyed in England,
France, Spain, or Portugal. The English law did not actually recognize
their right to live in ay of the dominions, but owing to the easy-going
habits of the Americans they were allowed to filter into the seaboad
towns. The treatment they received there varied. On one occasion the
mayor and council of New York forbade them o sell by retail and on
another prohibited the exercise of their religious worship. Newport,
Philadelphia, and Chaleston were more hospitable, and there large
Jewish colonies, consisting principally of merchants and their familie,
flourished in spite of nominal prohibitions of the law.

Though the small Swedish colony in Delaware was quickl submerged
beneath the tide of English migration, the Dutch in New York continued
to hold their own for more than  hundred years after the English
conquest in 1664. At the end of the colonial period over one-half of the
170,000 nhabitants of the province were descendants of the original
Dutch--still distinct enough to give a decided cast to he life and
manners of New York. Many of them clung as tenaciously to their mother
tongue as they did to their capcious farmhouses or their Dutch ovens;
but they were slowly losing their identity as the English pressed in
besidethem to farm and trade.

The melting pot had begun its historic mission.


THE PROCESS OF COLONIZATION

Consiered from one side, colonization, whatever the motives of the
emigrants, was an economic matter. It involved the us of capital to pay
for their passage, to sustain them on the voyage, and to start them on
the way of production. Uder this stern economic necessity, Puritans,
Scotch-Irish, Germans, and all were alike laid.

=Immigrants Who Pai Their Own Way.=--Many of the immigrants to America
in colonial days were capitalists themselves, in a small or a lrge way,
and paid their own passage. What proportion of the colonists were able
to finance their voyage across thesea is a matter of pure conjecture.
Undoubtedly a very considerable number could do so, for we can trace the
famil fortunes of many early settlers. Henry Cabot Lodge is authority
for the statement that "the settlers of New Englan were drawn from the
country gentlemen, small farmers, and yeomanry of the mother
country.... Many of the emigrant were men of wealth, as the old lists
show, and all of them, with few exceptions, were men of property and
good stnding. They did not belong to the classes from which emigration
is usually supplied, for they all had a stake in th country they left
behind." Though it would be interesting to know how accurate this
statement is or how applicabl to the other colonies, no study has as
yet been made to gratify that interest. For the present it is an
unsolved roblem just how many of the colonists were able to bear the
cost of their own transfer to the New World.

=Indentred Servants.=--That at least tens of thousands of immigrants
were unable to pay for their passage is established byond the shadow of
a doubt by the shipping records that have come down to us. The great
barrier in the way of the oor who wanted to go to America was the cost
of the sea voyage. To overcome this difficulty a plan was worked out
hereby shipowners and other persons of means furnished the passage
money to immigrants in return for their promise,or bond, to work for a
term of years to repay the sum advanced. This system was called
indentured servitude.

Itis probable that the number of bond servants exceeded the original
twenty thousand Puritans, the yeomen, the Virgina gentlemen, and the
Huguenots combined. All the way down the coast from Massachusetts to
Georgia were to be foundin the fields, kitchens, and workshops, men,
women, and children serving out terms of bondage generally ranging fro
five to seven years. In the proprietary colonies the proportion of bond
servants was very high. The Baltimores, Pnns, Carterets, and other
promoters anxiously sought for workers of every nationality to till
their fields, for lad without labor was worth no more than land in the
moon. Hence the gates of the proprietary colonies were flung wid open.
Every inducement was offered to immigrants in the form of cheap land,
and special efforts were made to incrase the population by importing
servants. In Pennsylvania, it was not uncommon to find a master with
fifty bond sevants on his estate. It has been estimated that two-thirds
of all the immigrants into Pennsylvania between the openng of the
eighteenth century and the outbreak of the Revolution were in bondage.
In the other Middle colonies the umber was doubtless not so large; but
it formed a considerable part of the population.

The story of this trafficin white servants is one of the most striking
things in the history of labor. Bondmen differed from the serfs of th
feudal age in that they were not bound to the soil but to the master.
They likewise differed from the negro slave in that their servitude had
a time limit. Still they were subject to many special disabilities. It
was, for instace, a common practice to impose on them penalties far
heavier than were imposed upon freemen for the same offense.  free
citizen of Pennsylvania who indulged in horse racing and gambling was
let off with a fine; a white servant gilty of the same unlawful conduct
was whipped at the post and fined as well.

The ordinary life of the white servnt was also severely restricted. A
bondman could not marry without his master's consent; nor engage in
trade; nor efuse work assigned to him. For an attempt to escape or
indeed for any infraction of the law, the term of service ws extended.
The condition of white bondmen in Virginia, according to Lodge, "was
little better than that of slaves Loose indentures and harsh laws put
them at the mercy of their masters." It would not be unfair to add that
such as their lot in all other colonies. Their fate depended upon the
temper of their masters.

Cruel as was the syste in many ways, it gave thousands of people in the
Old World a chance to reach the New--an opportunity to wrestle wih fate
for freedom and a home of their own. When their weary years of servitude
were over, if they survived, they ight obtain land of their own or
settle as free mechanics in the towns. For many a bondman the gamble
proved to bea losing venture because he found himself unable to rise
out of the state of poverty and dependence into which his ervitude
carried him. For thousands, on the contrary, bondage proved to be a real
avenue to freedom and prosperity Some of the best citizens of America
have the blood of indentured servants in their veins.

=The Transported--Inoluntary Servitude.=--In their anxiety to secure
settlers, the companies and proprietors having colonies in America
either resorted to or connived at the practice of kidnapping men, women,
and children from the streets of English ities. In 1680 it was
officially estimated that "ten thousand persons were spirited away" to
America. Many of the ictims of the practice were young children, for
the traffic in them was highly profitable. Orphans and dependents wre
sometimes disposed of in America by relatives unwilling to support them.
In a single year, 1627, about fifteen undred children were shipped to
Virginia.

In this gruesome business there lurked many tragedies, and very few
rmances. Parents were separated from their children and husbands from
their wives. Hundreds of skilled artisans--carenters, smiths, and
weavers--utterly disappeared as if swallowed up by death. A few thus
dragged off to the New Wold to be sold into servitude for a term of
five or seven years later became prosperous and returned home with
fortnes. In one case a young man who was forcibly carried over the sea
lived to make his way back to England and establsh his claim to a
peerage.

Akin to the kidnapped, at least in economic position, were convicts
deported to the olonies for life in lieu of fines and imprisonment. The
Americans protested vigorously but ineffectually against ths practice.
Indeed, they exaggerated its evils, for many of the "criminals" were
only mild offenders against undul harsh and cruel laws. A peasant
caught shooting a rabbit on a lord's estate or a luckless servant girl
who purloied a pocket handkerchief was branded as a criminal along with
sturdy thieves and incorrigible rascals. Other transprted offenders
were "political criminals"; that is, persons who criticized or opposed
the government. This class icluded now Irish who revolted against
British rule in Ireland; now Cavaliers who championed the king against
the Pritan revolutionists; Puritans, in turn, dispatched after the
monarchy was restored; and Scotch and English subject in general who
joined in political uprisings against the king.

=The African Slaves.=--Rivaling in numbers, in te course of time, the
indentured servants and whites carried to America against their will
were the African negroe brought to America and sold into slavery. When
this form of bondage was first introduced into Virginia in 1619, itwas
looked upon as a temporary necessity to be discarded with the increase
of the white population. Moreover it dos not appear that those planters
who first bought negroes at the auction block intended to establish a
system of prmanent bondage. Only by a slow process did chattel slavery
take firm root and become recognized as the leading souce of the labor
supply. In 1650, thirty years after the introduction of slavery, there
were only three hundred Afrcans in Virginia.

The great increase in later years was due in no small measure to the
inordinate zeal for profis that seized slave traders both in Old and in
New England. Finding it relatively easy to secure negroes in Africa,
they crowded the Southern ports with their vessels. The English Royal
African Company sent to America annually beteen 1713 and 1743 from five
to ten thousand slaves. The ship owners of New England were not far
behind their Englih brethren in pushing this extraordinary traffic.

As the proportion of the negroes to the free white population seadily
rose, and as whole sections were overrun with slaves and slave traders,
the Southern colonies grew alarmed.In 1710, Virginia sought to curtail
the importation by placing a duty of $5 on each slave. This effort was
futile,for the royal governor promptly vetoed it. From time to time
similar bills were passed, only to meet with royal dispproval. South
Carolina, in 1760, absolutely prohibited importation; but the measure
was killed by the British cron. As late as 1772, Virginia, not daunted
by a century of rebuffs, sent to George III a petition in this vein:
"Th importation of slaves into the colonies from the coast of Africa
hath long been considered as a trade of great inhmanity and under its
present encouragement, we have too much reason to fear, will endanger
the very existence of Yur Majesty's American dominions.... Deeply
impressed with these sentiments, we most humbly beseech Your Majesty toremove all those restraints on Your Majesty's governors of this colony
which inhibit their assenting to such laws a might check so very
pernicious a commerce."

All such protests were without avail. The negro population grew by eaps
and bounds, until on the eve of the Revolution it amounted to more than
half a million. In five states--Marylnd, Virginia, the two Carolinas,
and Georgia--the slaves nearly equalled or actually exceeded the whites
in number In South Carolina they formed almost two-thirds of the
population. Even in the Middle colonies of Delaware and Pensylvania
about one-fifth of the inhabitants were from Africa. To the North, the
proportion of slaves steadily dimiished although chattel servitude was
on the same legal footing as in the South. In New York approximately one
in sx and in New England one in fifty were negroes, including a few
freedmen.

The climate, the soil, the commerce, ad the industry of the North were
all unfavorable to the growth of a servile population. Still, slavery,
though secional, was a part of the national system of economy. Northern
ships carried slaves to the Southern colonies and theproduce of the
plantations to Europe. "If the Northern states will consult their
interest, they will not oppose th increase in slaves which will
increase the commodities of which they will become the carriers," said
John Rutledg, of South Carolina, in the convention which framed the
Constitution of the United States. "What enriches a part eniches the
whole and the states are the best judges of their particular interest,"
responded Oliver Ellsworth, the istinguished spokesman of Connecticut.

CHAPTER II

COLONIAL AGRICULTURE, INDUSTRY, AND COMMECE

THE LAND AND THE WESTWARD MOVEMENT


=The Significance of Land Tenure.=--The way in which land may be
acqured, held, divided among heirs, and bought and sold exercises a
deep influence on the life and culture of a people.The feudal and
aristocratic societies of Europe were founded on a system of landlordism
which was characterized bytwo distinct features. In the first place,
the land was nearly all held in great estates, each owned by a single
poprietor. In the second place, every estate was kept intact under the
law of primogeniture, which at the death of alord transferred all his
landed property to his eldest son. This prevented the subdivision of
estates and the growh of a large body of small farmers or freeholders
owning their own land. It made a form of tenantry or servitude
ievitable for the mass of those who labored on the land. It also
enabled the landlords to maintain themselves in powr as a governing
class and kept the tenants and laborers subject to their economic and
political control. If land enure was so significant in Europe, it was
equally important in the development of America, where practically all
he first immigrants were forced by circumstances to derive their
livelihood from the soil.

=Experiments in Commo Tillage.=--In the New World, with its broad
extent of land awaiting the white man's plow, it was impossible to
inroduce in its entirety and over the whole area the system of lords
and tenants that existed across the sea. So it hppened that almost
every kind of experiment in land tenure, from communism to feudalism,
was tried. In the early dys of the Jamestown colony, the land, though
owned by the London Company, was tilled in common by the settlers. Noman had a separate plot of his own. The motto of the community was:
"Labor and share alike." All were supposed to wrk in the fields and
receive an equal share of the produce. At Plymouth, the Pilgrims
attempted a similar experimet, laying out the fields in common and
distributing the joint produce of their labor with rough equality among
theworkers.

In both colonies the communistic experiments were failures. Angry at the
lazy men in Jamestown who idle their time away and yet expected regular
meals, Captain John Smith issued a manifesto: "Everyone that gathereth
nt every day as much as I do, the next day shall be set beyond the
river and forever banished from the fort and livethere or starve." Even
this terrible threat did not bring a change in production. Not until
each man was given a pot of his own to till, not until each gathered
the fruits of his own labor, did the colony prosper. In Plymouth, whre
the communal experiment lasted for five years, the results were similar
to those in Virginia, and the system wa given up for one of separate
fields in which every person could "set corn for his own particular."
Some other NewEngland towns, refusing to profit by the experience of
their Plymouth neighbor, also made excursions into common owership and
labor, only to abandon the idea and go in for individual ownership of
the land. "By degrees it was seenthat even the Lord's people could not
carry the complicated communist legislation into perfect and wholesome
practce."

=Feudal Elements in the Colonies--Quit Rents, Manors, and
Plantations.=--At the other end of the scale werethe feudal elements of
land tenure found in the proprietary colonies, in the seaboard regions
of the South, and tosome extent in New York. The proprietor was in fact
a powerful feudal lord, owning land granted to him by royal chater. He
could retain any part of it for his personal use or dispose of it all in
large or small lots. While he genrally kept for himself an estate of
baronial proportions, it was impossible for him to manage directly any
consideable part of the land in his dominion. Consequently he either
sold it in parcels for lump sums or granted it to indviduals on
condition that they make to him an annual payment in money, known as
"quit rent." In Maryland, the propietor sometimes collected as high as
$9000 (equal to about $500,000 to-day) in a single year from this
source. In ennsylvania, the quit rents brought a handsome annual
tribute into the exchequer of the Penn family. In the royal povinces,
the king of England claimed all revenues collected in this form from the
land, a sum amounting to $19,000at the time of the Revolution. The quit
rent,--"really a feudal payment from freeholders,"--was thus a material
sorce of income for the crown as well as for the proprietors. Wherever
it was laid, however, it proved to be a burden a source of constant
irritation; and it became a formidable item in the long list of
grievances which led to the merican Revolution.

Something still more like the feudal system of the Old World appeared in
the numerous manorsor the huge landed estates granted by the crown, the
companies, or the proprietors. In the colony of Maryland alonethere
were sixty manors of three thousand acres each, owned by wealthy men and
tilled by tenants holding small plos under certain restrictions of
tenure. In New York also there were many manors of wide extent, most of
which orignated in the days of the Dutch West India Company, when
extensive concessions were made to patroons to induce them o bring over
settlers. The Van Rensselaer, the Van Cortlandt, and the Livingston
manors were so large and populousthat each was entitled to send a
representative to the provincial legislature. The tenants on the New
York manors ere in somewhat the same position as serfs on old European
estates. They were bound to pay the owner a rent in mone and kind; they
ground their grain at his mill; and they were subject to his judicial
power because he held court nd meted out justice, in some instances
extending to capital punishment.

The manors of New York or Maryland were however, of slight consequence
as compared with the vast plantations of the Southern seaboard--huge
estates, far ider in expanse than many a European barony and tilled by
slaves more servile than any feudal tenants. It must not e forgotten
that this system of land tenure became the dominant feature of a large
section and gave a decided bentto the economic and political life of
America.

[Illustration: SOUTHERN PLANTATION MANSION]

=The Small Freehol.=--In the upland regions of the South, however, and
throughout most of the North, the drift was against all forms f
servitude and tenantry and in the direction of the freehold; that is,
the small farm owned outright and tilled b the possessor and his
family. This was favored by natural circumstances and the spirit of the
immigrants. For onething, the abundance of land and the scarcity of
labor made it impossible for the companies, the proprietors, or th
crown to develop over the whole continent a network of vast estates. In
many sections, particularly in New Englan, the climate, the stony soil,
the hills, and the narrow valleys conspired to keep the farms within a
moderate comass. For another thing, the English, Scotch-Irish, and
German peasants, even if they had been tenants in the Old Wold, did not
propose to accept permanent dependency of any kind in the New. If they
could not get freeholds, they wuld not settle at all; thus they forced
proprietors and companies to bid for their enterprise by selling land in
sall lots. So it happened that the freehold of modest proportions
became the cherished unit of American farmers. Thepeople who tilled the
farms were drawn from every quarter of western Europe; but the freehold
system gave a unifor cast to their economic and social life in America.

[Illustration: _From an old print_

A NEW ENGLAND FARMHOUSE

=Social Effects of Land Tenure.=--Land tenure and the process of western
settlement thus developed two distincttypes of people engaged in the
same pursuit--agriculture. They had a common tie in that they both
cultivated the sil and possessed the local interest and independence
which arise from that occupation. Their methods and their cultre,
however, differed widely.

The Southern planter, on his broad acres tilled by slaves, resembled the
English andlord on his estates more than he did the colonial farmer who
labored with his own hands in the fields and forest. He sold his rice
and tobacco in large amounts directly to English factors, who took his
entire crop in exchange or goods and cash. His fine clothes,
silverware, china, and cutlery he bought in English markets. Loving the
ripe ld culture of the mother country, he often sent his sons to Oxford
or Cambridge for their education. In short, he dpended very largely for
his prosperity and his enjoyment of life upon close relations with the
Old World. He did nt even need market towns in which to buy native
goods, for they were made on his own plantation by his own artisanswho
were usually gifted slaves.

The economic condition of the small farmer was totally different. His
crops wer not big enough to warrant direct connection with English
factors or the personal maintenance of a corps of artisan. He needed
local markets, and they sprang up to meet the need. Smiths, hatters,
weavers, wagon-makers, and potter at neighboring towns supplied him
with the rough products of their native skill. The finer goods, bought
by the rch planter in England, the small farmer ordinarily could not
buy. His wants were restricted to staples like tea andsugar, and
between him and the European market stood the merchant. His community
was therefore more self-sufficien than the seaboard line of great
plantations. It was more isolated, more provincial, more independent,
more Americn. The planter faced the Old East. The farmer faced the New
West.

=The Westward Movement.=--Yeoman and planter nvertheless were alike in
one respect. Their land hunger was never appeased. Each had the eye of
an expert for new nd fertile soil; and so, north and south, as soon as
a foothold was secured on the Atlantic coast, the current of mgration
set in westward, creeping through forests, across rivers, and over
mountains. Many of the later immigrants in their search for cheap
lands, were compelled to go to the border; but in a large part the path
breakers to theWest were native Americans of the second and third
generations. Explorers, fired by curiosity and the lure of the
ysterious unknown, and hunters, fur traders, and squatters, following
their own sweet wills, blazed the trail, openng paths and sending back
stories of the new regions they traversed. Then came the regular
settlers with lawful tiles to the lands they had purchased, sometimes
singly and sometimes in companies.

In Massachusetts, the westwardmovement is recorded in the founding of
Springfield in 1636 and Great Barrington in 1725. By the opening of the
eihteenth century the pioneers of Connecticut had pushed north and west
until their outpost towns adjoined the HudsonValley settlements. In New
York, the inland movement was directed by the Hudson River to Albany,
and from that oldDutch center it radiated in every direction,
particularly westward through the Mohawk Valley. New Jersey was earlyfilled to its borders, the beginnings of the present city of New
Brunswick being made in 1681 and those of Trenton n 1685. In
Pennsylvania, as in New York, the waterways determined the main lines of
advance. Pioneers, pushing up hrough the valley of the Schuylkill,
spread over the fertile lands of Berks and Lancaster counties, laying
out Reaing in 1748. Another current of migration was directed by the
Susquehanna, and, in 1726, the first farmhouse was bult on the bank
where Harrisburg was later founded. Along the southern tier of counties
a thin line of settlements tretched westward to Pittsburgh, reaching
the upper waters of the Ohio while the colony was still under the Penn
fmily.

In the South the westward march was equally swift. The seaboard was
quickly occupied by large planters andtheir slaves engaged in the
cultivation of tobacco and rice. The Piedmont Plateau, lying back from
the coast all te way from Maryland to Georgia, was fed by two streams
of migration, one westward from the sea and the other southwrd from the
other colonies--Germans from Pennsylvania and Scotch-Irish furnishing
the main supply. "By 1770, tide-ater Virginia was full to overflowing
and the 'back country' of the Blue Ridge and the Shenandoah was fully
occupid. Even the mountain valleys ... were claimed by sturdy pioneers.
Before the Declaration of Independence, the oncomng tide of
home-seekers had reached the crest of the Alleghanies."

[Illustration: DISTRIBUTION OF POPULATION, 170]

Beyond the mountains pioneers had already ventured, harbingers of an
invasion that was about to break in uponKentucky and Tennessee. As
early as 1769 that mighty Nimrod, Daniel Boone, curious to hunt
buffaloes, of which he ad heard weird reports, passed through the
Cumberland Gap and brought back news of a wonderful country awaiting the
plow. A hint was sufficient. Singly, in pairs, and in groups, settlers
followed the trail he had blazed. A great lnd corporation, the
Transylvania Company, emulating the merchant adventurers of earlier
times, secured a huge gran of territory and sought profits in quit
rents from lands sold to farmers. By the outbreak of the Revolution
therewere several hundred people in the Kentucky region. Like the older
colonists, they did not relish quit rents, and teir opposition wrecked
the Transylvania Company. They even carried their protests into the
Continental Congress in1776, for by that time they were our "embryo
fourteenth colony."


INDUSTRIAL AND COMMERCIAL DEVELOPMENT

Thouh the labor of the colonists was mainly spent in farming, there was
a steady growth in industrial and commercial pusuits. Most of the
staple industries of to-day, not omitting iron and textiles, have their
beginnings in colonial imes. Manufacturing and trade soon gave rise to
towns which enjoyed an importance all out of proportion to their
nmbers. The great centers of commerce and finance on the seaboard
originated in the days when the king of England wa "lord of these
dominions."

[Illustration: DOMESTIC INDUSTRY: DIPPING TALLOW CANDLES]

=Textile Manufacture asa Domestic Industry.=--Colonial women, in
addition to sharing every hardship of pioneering, often the heavy labor
f the open field, developed in the course of time a national industry
which was almost exclusively their own. Wool nd flax were raised in
abundance in the North and South. "Every farm house," says Coman, the
economic historian, "as a workshop where the women spun and wove the
serges, kerseys, and linsey-woolseys which served for the common wer."
By the close of the seventeenth century, New England manufactured cloth
in sufficient quantities to export it o the Southern colonies and to
the West Indies. As the industry developed, mills were erected for the
more difficut process of dyeing, weaving, and fulling, but carding and
spinning continued to be done in the home. The Dutch of ew Netherland,
the Swedes of Delaware, and the Scotch-Irish of the interior "were not
one whit behind their Yankeeneighbors."

The importance of this enterprise to British economic life can hardly be
overestimated. For many a cntury the English had employed their fine
woolen cloth as the chief staple in a lucrative foreign trade, and the
gvernment had come to look upon it as an object of special interest and
protection. When the colonies were establishd, both merchants and
statesmen naturally expected to maintain a monopoly of increasing value;
but before long theAmericans, instead of buying cloth, especially of
the coarser varieties, were making it to sell. In the place of
cstomers, here were rivals. In the place of helpless reliance upon
English markets, here was the germ of economic inependence.

If British merchants had not discovered it in the ordinary course of
trade, observant officers in theprovinces would have conveyed the news
to them. Even in the early years of the eighteenth century the royal
governr of New York wrote of the industrious Americans to his home
government: "The consequence will be that if they can lothe themselves
once, not only comfortably, but handsomely too, without the help of
England, they who already arenot very fond of submitting to government
will soon think of putting in execution designs they have long harbouredin their breasts. This will not seem strange when you consider what sort
of people this country is inhabited by."

=The Iron Industry.=--Almost equally widespread was the art of iron
working--one of the earliest and most picturesue of colonial
industries. Lynn, Massachusetts, had a forge and skilled artisans within
fifteen years after the fonding of Boston. The smelting of iron began
at New London and New Haven about 1658; in Litchfield county,
Connectiut, a few years later; at Great Barrington, Massachusetts, in
1731; and near by at Lenox some thirty years after tht. New Jersey had
iron works at Shrewsbury within ten years after the founding of the
colony in 1665. Iron forges ppeared in the valleys of the Delaware and
the Susquehanna early in the following century, and iron masters then
lid the foundations of fortunes in a region destined to become one of
the great iron centers of the world. Virginia egan iron working in the
year that saw the introduction of slavery. Although the industry soon
lapsed, it was reneed and flourished in the eighteenth century.
Governor Spotswood was called the "Tubal Cain" of the Old Dominion
beause he placed the industry on a firm foundation. Indeed it seems
that every colony, except Georgia, had its iron fundry. Nails, wire,
metallic ware, chains, anchors, bar and pig iron were made in large
quantities; and Great Britin, by an act in 1750, encouraged the
colonists to export rough iron to the British Islands.

=Shipbuilding.=--Ofall the specialized industries in the colonies,
shipbuilding was the most important. The abundance of fir for masts oak
for timbers and boards, pitch for tar and turpentine, and hemp for rope
made the way of the shipbuilder easy.Early in the seventeenth century a
ship was built at New Amsterdam, and by the middle of that century
shipyards wee scattered along the New England coast at Newburyport,
Salem, New Bedford, Newport, Providence, New London, and Ne Haven.
Yards at Albany and Poughkeepsie in New York built ships for the trade
of that colony with England and theIndies. Wilmington and Philadelphia
soon entered the race and outdistanced New York, though unable to equal
the pae set by New England. While Maryland, Virginia, and South
Carolina also built ships, Southern interest was mainly cnfined to the
lucrative business of producing ship materials: fir, cedar, hemp, and
tar.

=Fishing.=--The greatet single economic resource of New England outside
of agriculture was the fisheries. This industry, started by hardy
sailors from Europe, long before the landing of the Pilgrims, flourished
under the indomitable seamanship of the Pritans, who labored with the
net and the harpoon in almost every quarter of the Atlantic. "Look,"
exclaimed EdmundBurke, in the House of Commons, "at the manner in
which the people of New England have of late carried on the whale
fishery. Whilst we follow them among the tumbling mountains of ice and
behold them penetrating into the deepest frzen recesses of Hudson's Bay
and Davis's Straits, while we are looking for them beneath the arctic
circle, we hearthat they have pierced into the opposite region of polar
cold, that they are at the antipodes and engaged under thefrozen
serpent of the south.... Nor is the equinoctial heat more discouraging
to them than the accumulated winter f both poles. We know that, whilst
some of them draw the line and strike the harpoon on the coast of
Africa, other run the longitude and pursue their gigantic game along
the coast of Brazil. No sea but what is vexed by their fishries. No
climate that is not witness to their toils. Neither the perseverance of
Holland nor the activity of Franc nor the dexterous and firm sagacity
of English enterprise ever carried this most perilous mode of hard
industry t the extent to which it has been pushed by this recent
people."

The influence of the business was widespread. A arge and lucrative
European trade was built upon it. The better quality of the fish caught
for food was sold in th markets of Spain, Portugal, and Italy, or
exchanged for salt, lemons, and raisins for the American market. The
loer grades of fish were carried to the West Indies for slave
consumption, and in part traded for sugar and molasses,which furnished
the raw materials for the thriving rum industry of New England. These
activities, in turn, stimulaed shipbuilding, steadily enlarging the
demand for fishing and merchant craft of every kind and thus keeping the
sipwrights, calkers, rope makers, and other artisans of the seaport
towns rushed with work. They also increased trad with the mother
country for, out of the cash collected in the fish markets of Europe and
the West Indies, the colnists paid for English manufactures. So an
ever-widening circle of American enterprise centered around this singleindustry, the nursery of seamanship and the maritime spirit.

=Oceanic Commerce and American Merchants.=--All throgh the eighteenth
century, the commerce of the American colonies spread in every direction
until it rivaled in thenumber of people employed, the capital engaged,
and the profits gleaned, the commerce of European nations. A modern
historian has said: "The enterprising merchants of New England developed
a network of trade routes that covered wel-nigh half the world." This
commerce, destined to be of such significance in the conflict with the
mother country presented, broadly speaking, two aspects.

On the one side, it involved the export of raw materials and
agricultral produce. The Southern colonies produced for shipping,
tobacco, rice, tar, pitch, and pine; the Middle colonies,grain, flour,
furs, lumber, and salt pork; New England, fish, flour, rum, furs, shoes,
and small articles of manufcture. The variety of products was in fact
astounding. A sarcastic writer, while sneering at the idea of an
Americn union, once remarked of colonial trade: "What sort of dish will
you make? New England will throw in fish and onios. The middle states,
flax-seed and flour. Maryland and Virginia will add tobacco. North
Carolina, pitch, tar, andturpentine. South Carolina, rice and indigo,
and Georgia will sprinkle the whole composition with sawdust. Such anabsurd jumble will you make if you attempt to form a union among such
discordant materials as the thirteen British rovinces."

On the other side, American commerce involved the import trade,
consisting principally of English andcontinental manufactures, tea, and
"India goods." Sugar and molasses, brought from the West Indies,
supplied the fourishing distilleries of Massachusetts, Rhode Island,
and Connecticut. The carriage of slaves from Africa to the Suthern
colonies engaged hundreds of New England's sailors and thousands of
pounds of her capital.

The dispositin of imported goods in the colonies, though in part
controlled by English factors located in America, employed alsoa large
and important body of American merchants like the Willings and Morrises
of Philadelphia; the Amorys, Hancoks, and Faneuils of Boston; and the
Livingstons and Lows of New York. In their zeal and enterprise, they
were worty rivals of their English competitors, so celebrated for
world-wide commercial operations. Though fully aware of th advantages
they enjoyed in British markets and under the protection of the British
navy, the American merchants wre high-spirited and mettlesome, ready to
contend with royal officers in order to shield American interests
agains outside interference.

(NEW YORK CITY)]

Measurd against the immense business of modern times, colonial commerce
seems perhaps trivial. That, however, is not the est of its
significance. It must be considered in relation to the growth of English
colonial trade in its entirety-a relation which can be shown by a few
startling figures. The whole export trade of England, including that to
th colonies, was, in 1704, $6,509,000. On the eve of the American
Revolution, namely, in 1772, English exports to theAmerican colonies
alone amounted to $6,024,000; in other words, almost as much as the
whole foreign business of Enland two generations before. At the first
date, colonial trade was but one-twelfth of the English export business;at the second date, it was considerably more than one-third. In 1704,
Pennsylvania bought in English markets goods o the value of $11,459; in
1772 the purchases of the same colony amounted to $507,909. In short,
Pennsylvania impots increased fifty times within sixty-eight years,
amounting in 1772 to almost the entire export trade of England t the
colonies at the opening of the century. The American colonies were
indeed a great source of wealth to Englishmerchants.

=Intercolonial Commerce.=--Although the bad roads of colonial times made
overland transportation diffcult and costly, the many rivers and
harbors along the coast favored a lively water-borne trade among the
colonies The Connecticut, Hudson, Delaware, and Susquehanna rivers in
the North and the many smaller rivers in the South mae it possible for
goods to be brought from, and carried to, the interior regions in little
sailing vessels with coparative ease. Sloops laden with manufactures,
domestic and foreign, collected at some city like Providence, New Yok,
or Philadelphia, skirted the coasts, visited small ports, and sailed up
the navigable rivers to trade with loca merchants who had for exchange
the raw materials which they had gathered in from neighboring farms.
Larger ships arried the grain, live stock, cloth, and hardware of New
England to the Southern colonies, where they were traded fr tobacco,
leather, tar, and ship timber. From the harbors along the Connecticut
shores there were frequent sailins down through Long Island Sound to
Maryland, Virginia, and the distant Carolinas.

=Growth of Towns.=--In connecion with this thriving trade and industry
there grew up along the coast a number of prosperous commercial centers
hich were soon reckoned among the first commercial towns of the whole
British empire, comparing favorably in number and wealth with such
ports as Liverpool and Bristol. The statistical records of that time are
mainly guesses; butwe know that Philadelphia stood first in size among
